THE GARDEN OF HEALTH, Conteyning the sundry rare and hidden vertues and properties of all kindes of Simples and Plants, together with the maner how they are to be vsed and applyed in medicine for the health of mans body, against diuers diseases and infirmities most common amongst men. Gathered by the long experience and industrie of WILLIAM LANGHAM, Practicioner in Phisicke. IN this booke are conteined very many strange effects and operations of all sorts of simples, gathered by the long experience and trauaile of the Authour, so that for variety of things therein handled, it may be compared with any that are written of the like argument. All which simples with their vses are easily knowen, being plainely described in this booke, and are gotten without any great cost or labour, the most of them being such as growe in most places, and are common amongst vs. But for thy better direction, thou shalt vnderstand (good Reader) that all the simples (except Oke, which being omitted in the right place, is set in the ende of the booke) are set downe in order of the Alphabet, so that thou mayest without any difficultie finde them by the titles of the pages: and to euery simple is annexed a briefe Table of the effects thereof. There are moreouer two generall Tables: the one at the beginning of the booke, conteining all the simples in order, with numbers directing to the seuerall places where they are to bee found: the other at the ende setting downe the names of the diseases and other operations, hauing those simples which afford any remedy for the same, added vnto them in order so plainely, as thou canst not erre therein. Pag. Alecost, Costmary, or Maudlinwort Pag. Alehoofe, Ground Iuy, Gilrumbith ground, or Tudnoore. Pag. The Garden of Health, conteyning a description of all sortes of Simples, with their seuerall vertues and properties. Acatia, ACatia stoppeth the Laske, and the termes, and setteth the loose matrix in the naturall place being drunke with red wine. It is good to be laid to serpigo or wilde fire, all inflamations and hot tumours, wheales, and hote blisters of the mouth, and with eye medicines to heale inflamations, blastings and swellings of the eyes being applied. It maketh the haire blacke being often washed with the water wherein it hath beene soked: The leaues and tender crops of Acatia doe settle and strengthen members that are out of ioynt, if they be bathed in a hot bath, or stewe made with the broth thereof. Being ground with vineger, it abateth the pusshes of the lepry. In plasters it helpeth swellings, and humours in the eyes wonderfully, drinke it for the flixe, seethe it in the water of decoction of Pomegranates, or in vineger, and drink it to kill wormes. Vse it in a pessary to stop the flowers, to stop fluxes, vse subfumigatio~s thereof, or els drink it. It helpeth the holy fire, apostumes and woundes of the eyes, it stoppeth the termes, it healeth creeping sores, the falling of the matrix, it stayeth vomiting, and strengtheneth the stomake, and ceaseth paine. Haire to be blacke Holy fire Inflamations Ioynts out Lepry Matrix loose Mouth blisters Pusshes Reines running Seede distilling Stomacke weake Swellings Tetters Vomiting Wheales Wildfire Wormes Acorus, or Gladen. DRinke halfe a spoonefull of the pouder of the Roote with white wine, and vse it as much in thy pottage to heale the elfe cake and hardnesse of the side. Stamp the roote and streine it with some Rew and Mints in Ale, and make possets therewith, and drinke the ale of them to expell vrine. The broth of the roote procureth vrine, is good for the paines of the side, liuer and brest, the gnawing of the guts, drawings together or burstings, and for womens griefes as Iris is, it wasteth away the milte, and helpeth the strangurie, the bitings of serpents. Drinke a scruple of the roote against all inward bruises with foure ounces of honied wine. The broth is good against the swellings of the stones, and all hardnesse and gathering of humours being sodden in wine and laide to. The roote punned with a little Verdigreice, a little of the roote of great Centorie and a little hony, draweth foorth all kindes of thornes, splints, and broken bones. The roote mixt with vineger and applied, doeth consume and waste colde tumours and swellings. The iuice rubbed on the place, driueth away and killeth the stinking wormes, and mothes called Cimici. Halfe a dram of the seede taken with vineger wasteth and cureth the hardnesse of the milce. For the griefes of the liuer and milte, bruise one pound of Acorus, and steepe it three dayes in vineger, then seethe it to the one halfe, then streine it, and put hony to it, and seethe it againe till the vineger be consumed, and take of this Oximel dayly in the morning with the decoction of Acorus. If any beare Acorus about them, they shall not haue the bloody flixe, nor the crampe. Seethe Acorus in water vse for the plurisie, the griefes of the chest or brest, and of the liuer or milte, the strangurie and painefull making of Stampe the roote and seethe it in water to the third part, and drinke thereof three dayes, it doeth wonderfully bring forth the vrine, and healeth the strangurie. Note that the same roote or herbe is not to be vsed in Agues. Calamus Aromaticus, or the roote of Asarabacca may supply the want of it. For the stitch in the side drinke pouder of it with a draught of Malmesie. Toothache apply a piece of the roote to the tooth that aketh. For venom or poyson drunke, stampe Gladen that groweth on hie grounde and Dragons, and drinke it with wine. To dry vp wounds and to heale them vp with cleane flesh, although the bone be bare, apply powder of the roote with hony. For the dropsie in the belly feete, and to kill wormes, stampe a good quantity of the root and streine it in white wine and drinke it. Fluxe to stop, seethe bramble berries in water of the decoction thereof and vse it, but if thou haue an ache, bathe in the decoction of it, or wipe thee ouer with cloth weeted therein. Iaundies, bath in the decoction of Gladen and Ciclamen, or stampe them and drinke them with water and couer thee to sweate. Flowers to cause, make a pessary of the roote, and anoynt it with oyle de Bay or common oyle, and cast thereon powder of Wallwort, and put it in all night till it prouoke it to bleede. Prickes and bones to drawe out, stampe the roote and apply it. Boyle it in water or ale, and streine it with hony, and boyle it againe, and scum it, and drinke it warme in the mornings two houres before meate to purge watrish humours, and for the dropsie. The conserue thereof made with the pappe of the rootes, two or three times so much hony or rather sugar, comforteth the stomacke, and nourisheth and looseth tough flegme downewardes marueilously, and is good for the sickenesse of the braine, and sinewes, and all diseases comming of flegme, and openeth the naturall course and the termes. Stampe the roote of Gladen, and drinke it with stale Ale, and the iuice of Fumiterie morning and euen fifteene dayes, and vse this ointment therewith, stampe snayles, and Red dock rootes, and boyle them with Barrowes greace, and put thereto brimstone and Mercurie ana, and anoynt any skab therewith, and bee whole though it be of seuen yeeres continuance. To bring downe the flowers seethe Gladen rootes in strong vineger or wine and receiue vp the fume thereof into the matrix closely, &c. it neuer faileth, and therefore beware that you be not with childe. Face euill coloured distill the rootes of Acorus, and of Turnips in a limbeck, and drinke thereof fiue ounces before meate fifteene dayes. Stingings of serpents, apply powder of the vpper partes with wine. To dissolue impostumes vnder the eare, boyle the rootes and stampe them with salt, and apply them. Belly bound, drinke the iuice with the yolke of an egge hote as may bee suffered. Milt griefes, drinke it with wine, sight to cleare put in the iuice. Belly bounde Blood fluxe Bones to drawe out Braine griefes Breast griefes Eare impostume Eyes darke Elfe cake Face euill coloured Flegme Flowers to cause Fluxe Guts gnawing Humors watrish to purge Iaundies Liuer griefes Milte hard Mothes to kill Plurisie Poyson drunke Prickes to drawe out Serpents biting Sides hard Skabbes Stich Stomake to comfort Stones swelling Strangurie Teeth ache Termes to open Tumors to waste Vrine to expell ADders tongue, stampe it with Swines grease, and apply it to all swellings, inflamations, ringwormes, and shingles, and to heale all woundes and cuts with speede. It is singular good to heale wounds both inward and outward, and for all burstings Seeth it in water, and drinke it against all hot feuers, inflamations of the liuer, and all inward and outward heates. Stampe it with swines grease, and vse it to all burning and spreading sores, hote swellings and impostumes, and the holy fire. Apply it to a wound either greene or drie to heale it speedely, drinke the decoction of it to heale al inward wounds and al other griefes. Apply it to the newe ruptures of children, and binde it hard with a trusse. Seeth it with Sallet oyle while it is greene, and so it helpeth both swellings and sores, wounds, &c. Being wrapt in Virgins waxe, and put into the left eare of a horse, it causeth him to fall as if he were dead, but being taken out, he riseth againe. Feuers hote Holy fire Horse Hote griefes Infla~mations Liuer hote Ring wormes Shingles Sicknesse generall Sores AGnus castus is a singular good remedy for all such as would liue chaste: for it withstandeth all filthie desire to lechery, it drieth vp the seede of generation, whether it be taken in powder or decoction, or that the leaues be strawed in the bed to sleepe vpon, and therefore is called chaste, cleane, or pure. The seede drunke dissolueth all windinesse in the stomacke, intralles, bowels, and matrix, and all other partes of the body, and openeth and cureth all hardnesse and stopping of the liuer and milte, and is good in the beginnings of dropsies, one ounce being drunke with wine. Taken by itselfe, or with Peneroiall, it prouoketh termes, and so it doeth, put in as a pessarie. Some mixe it with oyles and ointments that are made to heate, mollifie, and heale the hard and stiffe members that are waxen dead, sleepie, benommed or wearied, it cureth also the clifts and chops of the fundiment and great gut being laide to with water. It healeth all venemous bitings being applied, or the seede thereof drunke. It helpeth hardnesse, stoppings, apostumations, and vlcers of the matrix, if women sit in the decoction or broth thereof. The leaues with butter doe dissolue the swellings of the coddes being applied. branch or rod thereof caried in the hand, defendeth the bearer from chafing and wearinesse. With vineger and oyle, it is good for the frensie and letargie. The leaues sodden in wine and honie, heale the vlcers and sores of the mouth and gummes. For satyriasis or standing of the yarde, eate the seedes thereof, or seethe it in wine, and plaster it to the reines and secret partes. Agnus castus sodden in vineger with Fenell, is good against the dropsie. Sodden in salt water with Sage and Smallage, and the hinder part of the head washed therewith, helpeth the letargie. Being either drunke or caried about one, it taketh away luste. plaister thereof applied, helpeth the head ache that commeth of euill humors. Bitings venemous Chastitie to cause Cods swollen Dropsie Frensie Fundament chapt Head ache Letargie Liuer stopt Lust to abate Matrix sores Members benommed Milke to increase Milte stopte Mouth sores Stomake windie Termes to prouoke Wearines to preserue fro~ Yard standing Alecost, Costmary, or Maudlinwort. ALecost, Costmary, or Maudlinwort, either alone or with Persnipseedes boyled in wine and drunke, cureth the gripings and torments of the belly or guts, and the flixe. The conserue of the leaues made with sugar, doth warme and drie the braine, and open the stopping thereof, and helpeth reumes distillations taken in quantitie of a beane. Sage and other hearbes, especially in sallads and sawses (for the which it is excellent) it yeldeth a proper sent or taste: Alecost and Maudlin be of equall vertues, they comfort the stomake. The iuice drunke killeth wormes both small and great: it is good for the cold mother, it strengtheneth ye stomake, whether it be drunke or applied, and stayeth vomiting. The herbe strawed or burned driueth away serpents, and is good against their poysons. Being sodden in wine and drunke, it is good for them that haue drunke Opium, or other venemous things, and for biting of serpents, especially one dramme of ye powder of the roote thereof taken in wine, with the like waight of the seedes of wilde Persnips. It hath the nature of Feuerfue in all things, and it is good for women to sit in the decoction thereof to prouoke sweate, and to drawe downe the termes, and auoide the paine that commeth by retention of them. The same stamped and applied taketh away hardnesse and swelling in any place. The flowers of Maudlinwort sodden and drunke, killeth great wormes in the belly, causeth sweate, and openeth the obstructions of the liuer, milte, kidneis and bladder. The hearbe sodden in water is good for the hardnesse and swelling of the belly matrix. The flowers sodden in lee, and the head washed therewith, taketh away the skurfe and skab thereof, and killeth lice: the flowres laide among clothes, defendeth them from mothes. Stampe the hearbe with Melilote, and apply it but once to cuts of veines to heale them: eate the powder thereof with honie for the griefes of the mouth. It healeth the greefes of the breast lungs, it breaketh impostumes, draweth euil humors from the head, and is good for the stomake. Vse it to drawe euill humors from the eyes, and for the griefes of the breast, lungs, stomake, and reines. Milt stopt Mother colde Mothes Mouth griefes Obstructions Poyson Serpents Skab skurfe Stom. griefs STampe thereof, and put it into the eares to take away their noise and sounding, and deafenesse. For paine in the soles of the feete, pricke the leaues and binde them thereto to haue present remedy. The iuice put into the nose doth purge the head. For dalling and giddinesse in the head, dip silke or wooll in the iuice thereof with vineger, and apply it. For all paine in the head, stampe the leaues with the white of an egge, and apply it. Seethe it in wine and drinke it to expell poyson, vrine, termes, and the Iaundies, and to open all obstructions of the liuer milte: the water thereof doeth the like. The leaues sodden in wine or water gargarised, helpeth the exulcerations and griefes of the iawes and mouth, and wash the secrete partes of women, and all skabs therewith. The iuice thereof is very good to cleanse fistulaes and such like, toothache. Boile it with ginger in wine and hold thereof in thy mouth. Eyes web, stampe the hearbe, flowers, and rootes of Dasie one handfull, Alehoofe somewhat more, and streine it with Ale or Beere, and then drinke thereof. Emerods, stampe Dasie rootes, Persley, Alehoofe with fresh grease, put thereto a little Turpentine, apply it. The iuice of Alehoofe and of put into the nose purgeth rhewme exceedingly, and taketh away the tooth ache. Seethe the iuice of it with honie to helpe any thing that couereth the sight. Mixe the iuice with honie and oyle of Roses, and anoint the temples therewith and foreehead for the head ache, or mixe the iuice of it with a third part of oyle, and put it blood warme into thy eares, to helpe the head ache, or stampe it with the white of an Eg, and apply it all night to thy forehead. Mouth griefes, take honie one spoonefull, vineger two spoonefull, water three spoonefulls, seethe them, and put thereto some iuice of Ground Iuie, and powder of Myrrhe, and wash therewith. Teeth ache grieuous, anoint them with the iuice and poure thereof into the eare Wash a handfull of Alehoofe and drie it, then stampe it streine it with one spoonefull of thicke creame, and anoint therewith burnings, skaldings, inflammations, and all hote griefes. Meigrim, anoint the forehead and nostrels with the iuice vineger and oyle, or stampe the leaues with the white of an egge, apply it. Burne white Coprose and dissolue it in the iuice, and put three drops into the deafe eare morning and euening dayly. Seethe it with Swines grease, and anoint all aches therewith. Tetters or Ringwormes, mixe the iuice of Ground Iuie with vineger and Alom, and anoint therewith and be whole. Frensie and want of sleepe, stampe Ground Iuie and seethe it in water, and stampe it with Lettuse and vineger, and apply it to thy head and thou shalt sleepe. Head ache, put the iuice of Alehoofe into the nose and be whole. Eares deafe, dissolue burnt Coprose in the iuice thereof, and put three drops thereof into your eare at morne euen dayly. Eares dull, distill the iuice with wine and vse it. Hand dried vp or withered, anoint it against the fire with oyle of Senuie seedes, or of Colewort seedes, and boyle Danewort and Alehoofe a long time in wine, and foment therewith blood warme a long time, and then apply the hearbes. Fluxes general, boyle Alehoofe Cheruile in water, wash thy feete therewith, if it mend thee not, thou shalt dye. Emerods Eyes spots Eyes webbe Feete soles paine Fistilae Frensie Fluxes generall Hand withered Nose stinking Poyson to expell Rewme Ringwormes Sight Sleepe wanting Termes to come downe Tetters ALkakengie, red Nightshad, or Winterchery, the leaues are colde as Morell, and as good for all such griefes as Morrell serueth for, as Morrell it selfe outwardly, but not to bee eaten. The fruite openeth the stopping of the liuer and kidneis, cleanseth the bladder, and prouoketh vrine. And therfore very good against the Iaundies, the ache of the reines and bladder, and prouoketh vrine, and helpeth the sharpnesse of the vrine, and is good for the grauell and stone. The iuice of it and of Morrell is pressed out, and when it is dried, it is kept in the shadowe for all purposes aforesaid. The iuice of the berries dried in the shadow, is good for ye dropsie, the stone, stopping of ye vrine. ALlder is good against impostumes and swellings in the throte, and kernels, or almonds vnder the tongue euell as well as the shales or greene pilles of Walnuts, it dieth blacke colour. The leaues be much vsed against hot swellings, vlcers, and all inward inflamations. The same are good to bee put into the shooes of them that are surbated and wearie, to mitigate the heate and paine. The greene leaues with their dewe in the mornings, are good to be strawed in chambers to voyde fleas, the chamber being first swept. The barke with olde iron put into water, maketh blacke as inke. The wood neuer rotteth in water nor in moyst ground, but rather turneth into stone. The iuice of the barke is good for a burning. The iuice of blacke Allder which is yellowe, being steeped in wine or beere and drunke, causeth to vomit vehemently, cleanseth the stomake. boyled in vineger and holden in the mouth, swageth tooth ache, and cureth skurfe and fretting sores being applied. The leaues cause kine to giue good store of milke, if they eate them, for they are good fodder. Blacke to colour Burnings Colouring Feete sore Fleaes Impostumes Inflamation Kernels Milke to cause Mouth sores Skurfe Sores Stomake clensing Surbated Swellings Throte swolne Vomit to cause Wearinesse Alysander. ALysander the seedes drunke alone, or with honied water prouoke termes, dissolueth winde and griping in the body, it warmeth the members that are taken with shaking, and is good for the strangurie. The roote breaketh and expelleth the stone, prouoketh vrine, and is good for the paine in the reines, and ache in the sides. The seedes is of like vertue with the seedes of garden Persley, and in all things more conuenient and better then common Persley. Alysander drieth sores without any griefe, and maketh ripe such as be hard. The seedes prouoke termes and vrine, and are good against stopping of the breast, and shortnesse of breath, stampe Alysander, and apply it to stop blood. For the chollike, drinke powder of the seedes of Alysander, Persley, and Fennell. To prouoke vrine, heate Alysander on a tyle stone, and apply it to the priuie partes, and so it voydeth the paine. ALlgood, or wilde Mercurie, taken in meates or brothes, doth soften the belly, and prouoketh to the stoole: the greene hearbe stampt and applied, healeth olde sores and greene wounds, and killeth and bringeth foorth wormes ingendred in the same. The iuice of the roote with vineger killeth skabbes, and taketh away the filthie spots of the skinne. The same is good against venemous bitings: for wormes in the eares and spots in the eyes, put in the iuice. Face deformed, seethe the roote in water, and wash therewith, but beware it come not neere the eyes. To heale a kanker, stampe Mercury, and apply it: wartes to kill, rub them with the iuice of it. Eies brused, apply the iuice with the white of an egge. Wilde tetters, frie it with oyle Oliue and hard Sope, and anoint therewith. Bruses Eares wormes Eyes brused Face deformed Head skalde Kanker Skabs Skin cleansing Sores Spots Tetter Venime Wartes Wormes Woundes Alleluya, Clauer Sorrell, or Sorrell de Boies. IT is good for sicke and feeble stomakes, for it drieth and doeth strengthen the stomake, and causeth appetite. It is good for stinking sores, mouthes being washed therewith. It is good for them to eate of it that haue the bursting of the guts. The distilled water thereof quencheth thirst, comforteth the heart and liuer, and is good for all hote diseases inflammations. With Alom it is good for all woundes, fistilaes, and sores of the mouth: it is good for all the hote griefes that the Pomegranate is good for, and the iuice is good to bee put into all cooling ointments. Boyle it with the flowers, and by it selfe in honied water or wine, and drinke it to swage the hote burning and fretting of the bowels, or seethe it in water, and take it with a glister for the same purpose. The flowers or leaues sodden in oyle and applied, doth ripen hote apostumes and swellings, and other tumors, and breaketh them, sometime doth dissolue them cleane. thy head with the decoction thereof, and apply the hearbe vnto thy forehead for the swimming and giddinesse or turning thereof. The seedes and leaues sodden in wine and drunke, helpeth the diseases of the sides, the falling sicknesse, the dropsie, the strangurie, both in men women, and purgeth the humors menstruall. Three dragmes thereof drunke with wine, doeth helpe all venemous bitings, and will not suffer any venom to come within the body, and so it helpeth both tertians and quartaines. graines or seede be drunke: it healeth woundes and kankers, it with the red flowers or may bee vsed for Fenigreeke. The leaues taken with Oximell, is good against venemous bitings, and so is the decoction thereof with the roote being also washt withall. Drinke three leaues of it against ye fit of the Feuer tertian, and foure leaues against the Feuer quartaine with wine. The leaues and rootes are mixt with Treacles, Mithridates, Preseruatiues made against poyson, the plague. Being rosted in a Docke or Worte leafe, it fretteth away dead flesh of woundes, (See Sorrell, See Aniseedes. Bowels burning Dropsie Falling sicknesse Fistilae Flesh dead Guttes burst Heart to comfort Head giddie Inflammation Kanker Mouth sores Quarteine ALmonds taken before meate, stop the belly, nourish but litle especially blaunched. Bitter Almonds doe open the stoppings of the lungs, liuer, milt, kidneys, all other inner parts and are good against the cough, shortnesse of winde, inflamation, and exulceration of the lungs being mixed with Turpintine and licked in. Almonds are good for them that spit blood taken in with fiue amill. Bitter Almonds taken in with sweete wine, as Bastard, or Muscadele, prouoke vrine, cure the hardnesse of the same, and painefulnesse in making thereof, and are good for the grauell, and stone. Eate fiue or sixe bitter Almonds fasting to withstand drunkennesse that day, Apply them with oyle of roses and vineger to the headach, apply them with hony to corrupt and spreading sores, and the bytings of mad dogs. They clense the skinne face from all spots, pimples, lentiles. Blaunch Almonds and Peach kernels in hote water, and stampe them and streine out the oyle, and vse it for the thicknesse of hearing, with tents of fine linnen cloth new made euery day, and keepe them in Bitter Almonds in a pessarie bringeth downe the termes, with wine they are good for wheales and little sores, the same eaten take away ache, soften the belly, cause sleepe, prouoke vrine, stop vomiting of blood. Drunke with water, or licked in with hony and milke as an electuarie, as much as a hasell nut, they are good for the liuer, the cough and the windy colick. Sleepe to cause take blaunched Almonds, one quart, Hempseede halfe a pound, thrise washt in faire water, Dates stamp them together with one ounce of Poppyseede bruised, and steepe them in good ale three or foure houres, then seethe it and streine it, and drink thereof. The gum drunk is good against vomiting of blood with vineger, it healeth the skirfe and skab of the skinne, drunke with sweete wine, or Malmesey, it helpeth the stone. Sweete Almonds doe increase the substance of the braine, cause pleasant sleepe, and scoure the passages of the vrine and are good for leane folke, the oyle of them is good for a dry cramp. The oyle of bitter Almonds is fittest for the wormes, running and deafnesse of the eares. Almonds eaten with figs clense the breast and lungs, and doe helpe shortnesse of winde. Almond cawdels comfort the principall partes of the body, and cause sleepe. Almond milke will cut, clense and scoure grosse humours, and may be made in the decoctio~ of hens, partridges, or chickins, to strengthen nature, or with cold herbs, as Cycory, Endiue, Violet leaues, &c. to cause To clense the reines stamp Almonds with fine Venice Turpentine cleane washt, eat it for the collick, strangury, and stone: quench gold, siluer, steele, or flints in Almond milke, wherein is put powder of Rice, and drinke it to stop the flixe. Almond brothes or cullisses, helpe shortnesse of breath, the cough, griefes of the lungs, liuer, milt, kidneys. With Almonds and amill is made march payn, fitter for sicke folks then for night bankets. Almonds in meates are good for a rawe stomacke, the iliake and the stone: The iuice of bitter Almonds is good for the sciatica. The oyle is good for the griefes and ache of the eares, head, hips, and kidneys. Stamp one pound and strein them with a pinte of water warme, and as much white wine, and halfe an ounce of Camphire, and one pynt of Magerom water, and keepe it in a close glasse, and wash the face therewith for the heate thereof. Put oyle of rosted Almonds into a red onyon and rost it, strein it, put three drops into the eare cold as often as need is against deafenesse. For the blooddy flixe, seethe Germander in red wine, and drinke it often dayly, and eate parched Almonds after it. For the Sciatica fill pigs cleyes with Almonds and burne altogether on a hote stone, and mixe the powder with Vnguentum Genistae, and anoynt therewith. Stamp one pound of blaunched Almonds, streine them with a pottell of Muscadell, the yolks of eight egs newlaid, put in good store of Sugar, seethe it a walme or two, take thereof foure spoonefuls morning and euening to helpe the consumption. For the stone drink two ounces of oyle of Sweete Almonds, with asmuch Aqua vitae. To make oyle of Almonds or of Nuts, blaunch them, and put them into a pot full of holes in the bottome, and set it ouer a pot of seething water, and streine out the oyle and vse it. Vse Almonds in medicines for the cough and the lungs, and for the heate of the plague, consumptions, and weaknesse of the backe. Matrix to clense, stampe Bitter Almonds and put them in as a pessary, the same in like sort helpeth the mother. To stop a fluxe seethe Almonds in hony till they be blacke, and eate them. Stampe Almonds with their skinnes, and make thereof Almond milke with water of hulled Barley sodden, and eate it with Sugar, and powder of the ryndes and scorches of a Pomegranate for the blooddy flixe. blaunch Sweet Almonds dissolue them in Fennell water, and distill them through a limbeck, put Sugar to it, and boyle it till it be thicke, and let them eate it. For the burning sores of the matrix in women with childe, stamp Sweete Almonds and boyle them in water with the marow of an oxe, and put a little meale to it, and anoynt therewith colde, and after wash with the decoction of myrtels. For the griefes of the head and necke, mixe oyle of sweet Almonds three ounces, with meale of March mallowes an ounce an halfe, and a sufficient quantitie of waxe: make it an oyntment at the fire, and anoint therewith warme. For the cough and shortnesse of winde of colde cause in children, anoynt their breasts with the oyle of Almonds and of Lillies mixed together. For wormes in children put in a suppositer of bombast dipt in oyle of Bitter Almonds, for their cough and reume, giue them milke of blaunched Almonds well sodden in Fennell water. For the swelling of their nauill after cutting of it, seethe Spike celtike in oyle of Almonds, and a litle Turpentine and dip well therein and apply it. For the ruggednesse, roughnesse and hardnesse of the skinne and chaps of their lips and handes, anoynt with oyle of Sweete Almonds. Vomiting blood Wheales Windinesse Wormes Of the vse of Oyles dissolue Sugar in water of Violets, Roses, or Cynamom, and put thereto a drop or two of some oyle that you meane to trie, and make tables either square or round thereof, and minister them artly. and put them into a pot with holes in the bottome, and set it ouer a vessell of seething lyquor, and presse out the oyle, the presse must haue two strong cheekes, and betweene them two plates of iron, hote, but not burning, and the Almonds in a bag of canuas, but if the things to be pressed be of a dry substance, they must be sprinkled with Aqua vitae and first made hote in an earthen pan, as take Almonds iiii.li. doe off the pilles with a knife, stamp them well in a marble morter, and sprinkle them with the best Aqua vitae, and Rose water of each an ounce, and heate it so that your hand may not be holden in it, then presse out the oyle into a porringer, and wash it if you will in an earthen pan, with raine water till it be white, this cleareth and beautifieth the skinne in any place. Take Almonds x.li. clensed well, powder of red Sanders sixe ounces, Cloues one ounce, White wine foure ounces, Rose water three ounces, let them lye close beaten in a morter well couered ten dayes beating them ouer once euery day, then heate it and presse out the oyle as before, it causeth a comely, red, beautifull skinne. gum Dragagant two ounces, whites of new layd egs two ounces, scraped Almonds vi.li. beate them well together, and couer them close sixe dayes, beating it, and stirring it about once euery day, then heate it, and presse out the oyle, it cleareth the skinne, and maketh it white and comely, and smooth without danger. or Cinnamom, or Muske, or Amber, or Storax, or Beniamine, or Maces in Rose water, vntill it hath receiued their strength, and dry it againe, and steepe it of new foure or fiue times, then put thereto foure times so many scraped Almonds stamped, then presse out the oyle, and set it in the sunne to purifie for a time. The oyle of Cloues it selfe, hath all the vertues of Balme, it healeth fresh and greene wounds, it staieth the issues of blood and water in wounds, it comforteth within the natural partes, it purgeth melancholy blood, it comforteth the heart and head, especially it helpeth the giddinesse of the head, and weaknesse of sight, three or foure drops taken fasting in a spoone with some pleasant syrrop, daintie thing, or wine, with the broth or cullis of a Capon, it helpeth the collick and suffocation two or three drops taken at once. In tables or lozinges taken morning and euening, strengtheneth the head, stoppeth reume, it healeth wounds without stitching. ALoes purgeth cold flegmatike and chollerik humours, especially from the stomacke, and is the chiefe of all purging medicines which for the most part doe hurt the stomacke. But this doeth comfort, clense, and dry vp and driue foorth all superfluous humours two drams thereof being taken with water, or with Cinnamom, Ginger, Maces, Cubebs, Galingale, Aniseeds, and such like spices, as asswage and take away paine from the stomacke, and cause flegme to be expulsed. It is also good against the Iaundies, spitting blood, and all other issues of blood except emerods. The powder thereof strawed on new blooddy wounds, stoppeth blood, and healeth the wounds, and layd vpon old sores it closeth them vp, and is excellent against vlcers of the secret partes and fundament. Boyled with wine and hony it healeth the outgrowings rifes of the fundament, and stoppeth the abounding fluxe of the emerods being layd vpon them. But receiued into the body, it causeth them to bleede and breake out: with hony it dispatcheth all dead blood of bruises. against all inflamations, hurtes and skabs of the eyes, and the running and darknesse of the same. Mixt with oyle of Roses and Vineger, and layd to the forehead temples, it swageth the headach. Mixe it with wine, and rub the head often therewith to keepe the haire from falling. Apply it with wine to the sores and pustules of the mouth, gums and throat, and the kernels vnder the tongue. Apply it outwardly to stop bleeding of wounds, and to clense and heale them. Mixe powder of Aloes Cicatrine with iuice of Colworts, and make pils thereof as big as Beans, and take them to bedward three at once, to auoyd all paine of the head. Mixe it with Malmesey and apply it, to ioyne together againe the skin that couereth the knop of boyes yards. For riftes and hard lumps of the fundiment apply Aloes. Eyes skabd, bleared itch in the corners, vse Aloes, burne it in a burning hote vessell, and stirre it often with a feather till it be all alike rosted, and so it is a good medicine for sore eyes. Mixe it with Dragons blood and Myrrhe, to heale stinking sores old sores. Mixt with ye white of an egge it stoppeth bleeding both of the emerods of any cut or wound. It is euil for them that are of a hot nature, but good for them that are moyst and colde. litle of it tempered with Rose water, and put into the eyes that are dropping and watry, cureth them. Mixed with Saffron and Myrrhe and made into pilles, it is the most excellent medicine against the plague. With hony it taketh away the marks of stripes, and doeth clense sores and vlcers. It is not good to be taken in Winter but in the Spring and Haruest. The waight of a French crowne mixt with Meed, and drunke in the morning doeth purge choller and flegme. The course Aloes is to be giuen halfe an ounce at once to Horses and great beastes tempered with ale. Drinke a little Aloes with warme water to auoyde vomiting. For rubbing and itch by night, purge and bleed, and anoynt with Aloes and Myrrhe dissolued in water of Hony. For imposts of the yarde, and winde in the bottome of the belly, let blood, and anoynt with Aloes dissolued in wine: and for the winde foment with water of the decoction of Aristolochia For the Feuer quarten take Aloes often, for losse of speech in sicknesse mixe it with water, and role it in thy mouth. For swelling of the belly, mixe Myrrhe, Aloes Epatica and Saffron with the iuice of Beans and apply it, or take foure peny waight of Aloes Cicatrine, with faire water first sodden sweetned with Sugar. Apreseruatiue, take Aloes Cicatrine two ounces, Saffron fiue drams, red Myrrhe foure drams, make them into powder, and take thereof three peny waight with one spoonefull of water of Scabious, another of water of Wormewood before meate euery moneth once. To draw an Earewig out of the eare, put in powder of Aloes with vineger. Mix powder of Aloes Cicatrine with white wine, and let it stand all night, then streine it, and put thereof into the eyes to destroy the pearle and webbe, apply it with hony to the griefes of the gums and the exulcerations of the yard. Headach, temper two parts of Aloes with a third part of Mastik, and some iuice of Wormewood, and make pilles thereof as much as Peason, and take fiue or seuen of them to bedward. Kanker, mixe powder of Aloes, quick Lime, and Orpiment, vse it til the dead flesh be eaten out, and then temper Ceruse with oyle, vse it til it be whole. Sores, temper Aloes with yolks of egs and apply it: it killeth worms, in the body. Liuer and milt griefes, take Aloes Epatica, with the iuice of Smallage warme. Wormes, take powder of Aloes with hony, or mixe it with the iuice of Wormewood, strike it on a red lether three fingers broad, and apply it to the nauill three dayes. Warme as much Aloes Cicatrine on a kniues point as a Beane, make it into three pilles with a little Red rose water, and take it with the pap of an Apple and Sugar, and within halfe an houre take a draught of possit ale to purge well: Headach and watching vse powder of Aloes with oyle of Roses, or take three pilles as much as Beans made with the iuice of Colworts. Eyes dim and bloodshotten, apply Aloes with the white of an egge: Eyes itch put in Aloes with Fennel water being kept in a latin bason fifteene dayes. Eyes ach and bloody, apply Aloes with a little Opium and womans milk that suckleth a boy: Stomack griefes vse Aloes: Belly bound mixe Salgem Aloes; the gaule of a Bull and oyle together, and anoynt the fundament to haue present helpe. Aloes: Drinke Aloes Epatica with Sage and Sugar, to restore the liuer. Wormes to kill rost a peny waight in an Apple, and eate it fasting three mornings, or vse the powder thereof with Myrrhe. powder incarnatiue to be cast into wounds, take Myrrhe three drams, Aloes foure drams, Frankincense two drams and vse it, for the hicket and lothing Aloes helpeth the stomack aboue all other things: Scab of salt flegme anoynt with Aloes, vnquenched Lime and common oyle. Wormes to kill apply a plaster of Aloes and Fenigreke on leather to thy nauill, fundament sores vse Aloes: Stomack to clense and to kil worms, take one dram of Aloes Cicatrine with hony. Wounds to heale vse pouder of Aloes Sarcocol, Sa~guis Draconis. Worms to kill, make pilles of Aloes and powder of Wormwood, and role them in butter, and swallow them downe: Fundament fallen, cast on powder of Myrrhe, Aloes, Gaules, and Frankincense of each like much. Eares deafe put a little Aloes into hote water, or white wine, and drop it in and prouoke sneesing with powder of Euphorbium: Cholick, apply a plaster of warmed hony Aloes. Lice, Crablice, and Wormes to kill, anoynt with Aloes and Rose water. Priuities vlcers, and to incarnate fresh wounds, vse Aloes with burned Dill: Eyes dull and watring, put in Aloes with Rose water. Wormes, stamp Aloes with Bitter Almonds, and apply them to the nauill, or apply it with Hony and vineger, or Hony and an Oxe gall. The iuice of Broome with oyle and Aloes killeth lice: Stomack paine, take euery day two scruples of pilles of Aloes washed, Or take Aloes washed halfe an ounce, Hony Rosat, three ounces, seethe them in two pound of water to the one halfe, and streine it, and drinke thereof euery morning two ounces: Eyes teares and itch, steep Aloes epat. in Wine and Rose water, and wash or foment therewith. Crablice to kill, powder of Aloes Ceruse with oyle of Roses or Swines greece, and anoynt. Head whirling noyse, and paine of the eyes, take pils made with Aloes halfe an ounce, Mastik x. grains, as much as a small Beane, and take euery night fiue of them: Eies web, temper pouder of Aloes Cicat. with White wine, and let it stand all night, and in the morning streine it and put it into the eye. Olibanum, Mastik Ana, with vineger and whites of egs, and apply it with stuphes to the temples. Liuer and milt stopt, take as much Aloes as a Beane euery other day with ye iuice of Smallage and some Mastik or gum Arabik, or Aniseeds. Swelling of blood letting, apply Aloes with yolks of egs with vineger, it killeth scab and itch: with iuice of Burre, being taken inward, it helpeth the Gout: Eares noyse, drop in a litle Aloes with warm water, and prouoke sneesing with Euphorbium. Wormes boyle Aloes with Coloquintida and butter, and streine it, and anoynt the stomack and belly therewith against the fire, or apply Aloes with the iuice of Wormewood, or red lether to the nauill, or drinke powder of Aloes and Myrrhe, or of Aloes, Myrrhe, and Brimstone. Face Saseflegme, mixe the iuice of Wormewood, Red Docks with Aloes and anoynt. Eares worms, put in the iuice of Wormewood and Horsemint with vineger and Aloes. Belly bound anoynt with the gall of a Bull or Oxe, Aloes, Salt, and oyle Oliue by the fire. Blood to stop, mixe Aloes with Mastik, Hares haire, and the white of an egge, and apply it: Purgation, mixe one ounce of Aloes, with one dram of Turpentine, the gall of a Bul or Oxe, and anoint the brest to purge vpward, and the nauill to purge downeward, and three fingers lower to prouoke menstrewes. (see Purge.) noyse Haire falling Hicket Horses Iaundies Inflamations Itch AMaradulcis, or Woodnightshade, the decoction thereof in wine drunke, openeth all the stoppings of the liuer, and is good against the Iaundes comming of obstruction. For all inward brusings, dislocations, ruptures and hurtes, of the inner partes, for it dissolueth the congealed blood, bringeth it forth with the vrine And it doth cure and heale wounds and stripes. Chop one pound of the wood thereof, put it into an earthen pot, with a pottell of white wine close couered, sauing a hole in the middest of the lid, stopping it close rounde about with meale and water, and seethe it to the third part or more, and drinke thereof first and last morning and euening for the Iaundies that haue continued long, and for olde rotten Feuers. AMoniacum, take one dram of it to losen the belly, and to driue forth colde slimie flegme from the farthest partes, for shortnesse of breath, the stopping of the brest, the falling euell, the goute, the sciatica, griefes of the braine, sinowes, and extreme partes. the breast, and cause easie spitting, or take it for the same purpose with the decoction of hulled Barly. Take a little of it at once against the hardnesse and stopping of the milte, to expell a dead childe, and the vrine, but being taken too much or too often, it causeth one to pisse blood. Steepe it in vineger, and apply it to the swellings and hardnesse of the liuer and milte. Mixe it with hony or pitch, and apply it to dissolue hard lumpes or swellings, the knots that come of the goute in the ioynts and extreame partes, and to consume all colde tumors and wennes. Put it into all oyntments and plasters that are made to chafe warme, to swage paine, to soften and drawe. Apply it with oyle Cyprus and Nitrum, to the Sciatica, and vpon all paine and wearinesse of any part. Put it into collyries eye medicines, to cleare the sight, and auoide webs. Melt it with Assafetida waxe oyle, and apply it to the milt to make it soft and neshe. For daseling and all diseases of the eyes and head, take one dram with honie, mixe it with hony, anoint the goute to auoid the knots thereof. For wormes take pilles thereof made with honie, and dissolue it in vineger, and apply it to the nauel. To make the teeth fal out, anoint therwith and the iuice of Henbane. Milt griefes, apply it with Assafetida dissolued in vineger, and put thereto waxe and powder of Coste and of Wormewood, or only with Assafetida and waxe. Make pilles thereof with the iuice of Wormewood and Arsmart, and vse them to kill wormes in the belly. Roste the roote of Monkes Rubarbe, and mixe it with Amoniake, and anoint skrophules therewith, and also apply it plasterwise. Breath short Colde griefes Dead childe Eyes dull Face deformed Falling euell Giddinesse Goute Sinowes griefes Skrophules Swellings Teeth to fall Vrine stopt Wennes Wearinesse Wormes ANemone, the roote chewed, draweth much moysture into the mouth. The same boyled in wine prepared called Passum, and laide vpon the eyes, cleareth the sight, and voydeth the webbs and spots. The leaues and yong branches boyled with cleane husked Barly, causeth abundance of milke: the same put in as a pessary prouoketh termes. The iuice of the roote put into the nose purgeth the braine, and skowreth away filthie sores and leapries. Flowers stopt see Braine Leaprie Milke to cause Sores Angelica. ANgelica is good against all poyson and venemous bitings, so that it is better to haue it Magistrantia, Louage, Gentian, Elecampana, Aristolochia, Petasites, then al Arabike and forraine wares. It is called the roote of the holy Ghost, and of all heale: it expelleth poyson and rotten blood, and warmeth the body. Halfe a dramme of the roote, with one dramme of Triacle drunke with three or foure spoonefull of the water thereof, and the body well couered to sweate, and forbearing other things three houres after it, driueth foorth the plague, and deliuereth the sicke body, if no Treacle can be had, take a whole dramme of the powder of the roote. The roote smelled vnto being steeped in vineger, and a little of the vineger drunke fasting now and then in the plague time, preserueth the body from the plague. The water or powder of the roote deliuereth the body from torments comming of colde, the pluresie, ruptures, griefes of the lunges, whereof come grieuous coughes, the dropping of the vrine, the strangurye, the stopping of the flowers, swellings and windines, and such like, and so doeth decoctions and potions made with the roote thereof sodden in wine or honie. Put the water into hollowe teeth for their ache, and into the eares for their ache. Put the iuice or water into the eyes to cleare them and sharpen the sight, and to take away the webs mystinesse: put the iuice, water, or powder into olde and deepe vlcers, to couer the bare bones with flesh. Apply the water to the goute, sciatica, or any ache or bruises, to dissolue humors that are gathered together: mixe the powder with pitch, and apply it to all venemous bitings. The seedes haue the same vertues that the rootes haue: the rootes, seede or water, is excellent good against all inward diseases: it scowreth the gatherings of the plurisie when it beginneth: it helpeth corrupt lungs, it is good against the chollike and strangurie, it prouoketh termes, it helpeth inflamations and swellings. Drop the iuice of the roote into the eyes to quicken the sight, and to clense them from all filth, and put it into teeth that ake to auoide the ache. The water or powder is excellent good against rotten vlcers and kankerous sores to clense and heale them: put a piece of gold into the iuice of Limons houres, and drinke it with a little wine and powder of the roote of Angelica, to helpe the plague though all hope were past. The roote taken fasting, or but holden in the mouth, preserueth the body from all infection of the plague or poyson. If any be infected, let them drinke one dram of the powder straightwayes in Winter with wine, and with water of Scabious, or of Carduus benedictus in Sommer, or with Rose water, and couer him well to sweate both for the plague and poyson. The leaues stampt with Rue and Honie, are very good for the bitings of mad dogs, serpents, and vipers, if shortly after the hurt taken, the partie drinke of the wine wherein the leaues or roote haue beene sodden. For the pestilence, any sudden pestilent ague, or too much sudden sweating, drinke halfe a dramme of the pouder of the root with one dram of Treacle, and iii. or iiii. spoonefull of water of the roote, and couer thee well to sweate iii. houres. It is good for all inward diseases, especially such as come of colde cause, and for women in trauell, it expelleth winde. The roote or seede may be sodden in wine or water as the disease requireth, and so it healeth all inward The powder of the roote is good against all swooning passions of the heart, it is gathered in Autumne, and kept two or three yeeres, it cleanseth the lungs, breast, guts, reines and bladder. The hearbe sodden in water, healeth all inwarde wounds, strengtheneth the heart, and dryeth vp all superfluous moysture, as the dropsie and tympany. It helpeth against vomiting and weakenesse of the stomake, and being sodden with Rue, hony and wine, it deliuereth from the bitings of serpents, snakes, &c. and also any pricke or wound. It quencheth all carnall rage of youthfull lust, if one eate halfe a dramme of it: it hath many other vertues, for the which fewe hearbes are to be compared vnto it. put in a peece of the roote, breath stinking of garlike chawe it, it may be vsed for like purposes as Carduus benedictus. Powder of the leafe or roote cleanseth and healeth rotten vlcers, kankers and sores, and couereth the bones with flesh, (See Blessed thistle. Swooning and all passions of the heart, drinke two ounces of Angelica water, with a little Cinamom water, and one scruple of powder of the roote sundry mornings. Colde griefes Cough colde Deliuerance Dropsie Eares ache Eyes dull Flesh to growe Feuers, (see Plague) Flowers stopt Prickes Preseruatiue see Plague Reines griefes Sciatica Serpents Sicknesse generall ANniseedes dissolue windinesse, belching, and blasting of the stomake and belly, and helpeth their griping and torments, stoppeth the laske, prouoketh vrine, and voydeth the stone, and the hycket or yexing, being taken drye or with wine or water. It cureth the stoppeth the whites, is good for the dropsie, openeth the pipes of the liuer, stauncheth thirst, and is good against all poyson, and stingings of scorpions, and bitings of all venemous beastes. The seedes eaten plenteously prouoke lust, and doe breede milke. Chewe the seedes to make the breath easie and sweete, drie the seedes and mixe them with honie, and vse the same to cleanse the breast: mixe them with honie and bitter Almonds to cure the olde cough. Let children that be in danger of the falling euell, vse to holde the seedes in their hand, to auoide the perill of that disease: mixe the seedes with hony, vineger and hysope, and gargle therewith for the squyncy and swelling in the throte. Binde the seedes in a linnen cloth, and smell to them to keepe thee from euill dreames, starting in sleepe, and to cause quiet rest: smell to the perfume of it to cure the head ache, put it into the eares with oyle of Roses to cure their inward hurtes woundes. Drinke it with Ptisane, or cleare temperate wine to open the stopping of the reines and matrix, vse it in Ptisands for the Feuer quotidian bredde of flegme. Drinke it with good white wine and suger for the chollike, windinesse of the guts, and to stop the whites. Make powder thereof with Fenell seedes, Galinggale, Spikenard, Tamarisk, Nutmegs Cardamom, and it with wheate flowre water and red wine, and make cakes thereof, and bake them and eate them dayly for the running of the reines, wasting of nature, moyst dropsies comming of winde and colde, the tympany and swelling of the belly, and be purged once a moneth with conuenient Electuaries. The same eaten or drunke, are good for the sight, the lungs, reines, stomake and bladder. Vse them in bread either broken or whole for the chollike and stone: mixe powder of Anniseedes and Cumminseedes with waxe, and apply it to blacknesse that commeth of bruses. Vse to eate the seedes to heate the liuer, and to helpe digestion. Seethe them in wine, and drinke it with Cinamom and Mastike against grieuous belchings of a colde stomake. Seeth them in water with Harts tongue, and drinke it for the stopping of the liuer and milte, for the dropsie and the whites. Seethe powder of the seedes in a bag in wine, apply it hote to the matrix to cleanse it, and to bring downe the termes. Take the seedes with Castorie for the swelling of the stomake and bowels: eate or drinke the seedes with vineger and hony to helpe the strangling of the mother. Seethe them in wine, and drinke it for the impostumes of the stomake, and the cough: drinke the powder of them with wine against poyson, with oyle of Roses it helpeth the paine of the eares. The fume thereof receiued into the nose helpeth the head ache: the best of them come out of Candie, and are cleane and well smelling. Anniseedes helpe the stoppings of the liuer and milte, breake winde, cause vrine and sweate, and loosen the belly. Seethe one ounce with three stickes of bruised Licoras, and two handfull of leaues in a quart of water to a pint, and drinke thereof fasting for flegme and stopping of the stomake. Seethe a handfull of the seedes in a quart of Malmesey with a handfull of vnset Hysope, till it be thicke, and spread it on a toste of bread of Wheate with some butter, and apply it in a linnen cloth to the stomake for the cough, but for a stitch apply it without butter. Drinke powder of Licoras and Anniseedes with possit ale made with Sacke and Ale, for the stuffing of the lungs euery morning. Drinke powder of Anniseedes and Cummin seedes fiue dayes morning and euening with wine to helpe for the windinesse and chollike of the belly. To purge the stomake, seethe Anniseeds Polipody ana three ounces in a quart of water to the one halfe, then streine it and suger it and drinke it. To auoide windinesse, thirst, oppilation of the liuer and milte, to prouoke lust, vrine and termes, to cleare the sight, For the dropsie, fill an olde cocke with Polipody and Anniseedes, and seethe him well, and drinke the broth, it helpeth also the chollike. To increase milke, vse powder of the seedes: for windinesse in the belly, drinke powder of the seedes of Annise, Fennell, and Cummin with wine first and last: for the hicket, or yexing, smell to dried Anniseedes: For the Emerods, burne the seedes and apply them with hony: for the falling sicknesse, vse Anniseedes and Rue in thy meates: mouth stinke, wash it with the decoction of Anniseedes: heart cardiake, mixe ye iuice of Betony with Treacle, powder of Cloues, Cummin, and Annise dayes. Stomake slimie, and to helpe digestion, in Winter eate Anniseedes vpon tostes of bread dipt in wine. Belly ache and chafing of the liuer, and to helpe digestion, vse Anniseedes any way. Chollike and Nephretyke, drinke powder of the seedes with the iuice of Perslie: for the dropsie, vse much water in ye wine decocted with Anniseedes, or drinke powder of the seedes of Annise, Fennell, Peony. Gout, stampe Sage leaues with Anniseedes, and seethe them in wine, and apply it. Pipes stopt, seethe Anniseedes and Licoras in running water to the one halfe, then streine it and drinke it at euen hot, and at morning colde. Stomake rising, seethe long Pepper, Graines, Saffron, Ginger, Anniseedes and Licoras, with Sugar in good Ale till it be thicke, and drinke thereof and be whole. Reume Sleepe to cause Squyncy Starting Stingings Stich Stomake griefes APples: abhorring meate, make a syrupe with the iuice of sower Apples and of a Pomegranate and Sugar and vse it. Cut Apples thinne as a peny, and seethe them in a panne with Virgins waxe, and eate it as hote as may be suffered to stop the bloody flixe. Mixe Chalke with ye iuice of Wildings or Crabs, and apply it to take away any paine of burnings, and bledders, or blisters. Rost Frankincense in a red Apple, and apply it to the tooth ache. For horcenesse rost a great Apple, and slice it hote into a dish of water, eate it to bedward, couer thee well to sweate. Pare Apples and slice them and frie them with virgins waxe, and eate it hote to cure the fluxe diaria. of Aloes cicat. in an Apple, and eate it three mornings. Eares worme, make a ripe well smelling Apple hollowe, and apply it to the eare, and the worme will come into it. Fluxes, apply plasters of sower Apples to the reines and nauell. rost as much waxe as a beane in an Apple, and eate it. Seethe Apples to pap, and to vi. li. of it, put iiii. li. of hony, and seethe to perfection and vse it. Eyes heate and running, cut off the paring thicke and apply the inside to bedward to helpe it speedely. Cough, rost Butter, English Saffron, and as much as a Nutmeg in a great Apple, and eate such a one morning and euening. Eyes to comfort, distill a pecke of rotten Apples, and vse the water. Rost iii. or iiii. graines of Olibanum in a well smelling Apple on the embers, and eate it to breake the impostume of the plurisie, or any other with speede. Seethe the inward yellowe barke with wood, bone, or horne with Alome to colour it yellowe. Face and distill the bloomes in Balnio Mariae, and wash with the water morning and euening dayly. To ripen an apostume, rost an Apple in the embers, and mixe it with butter and hony, or the yolke of an egge sodden, and apply it. For griefes of the breast and breast bone, take out the core of a ripe Apple, and fill it with powder of Licoras, and Galingale, or Cinamom and Hony, all well mixed together, and rost it and pill it and eate it as oft as neede is. For the chincough and other like, and for paine in the breast, rost sallet oyle in a great Apple in the embers, and apply it flat on the breast as often as neede is. Liuer hot, seethe the iuice of Apples both sower and sweete, with almost twise so much sugar into a syrupe, and take a litle of it fasting dayly with lukewarme water. Apples doe coole and comfort the stomake, especially such as are sowrish, astringent of taste. And they may be vsed in hote Agues, and other heates of the stomake against thirst, but otherwayes hurtfull to the stomake, causing windinesse and blastings in the belly. Sower Apples boyled and eaten colde after meate, loosen the belly gently. Apples eaten before meate, doe nourish very little, because they be watrish. The leaues are good to be applyed to hote tumors and apostumations in the beginning, and to woundes to keepe them from euill heate and swelling. Appletree, but especially of the Quincetree, doe stop and binde. The tart and sower Apples doe binde, but the ripe Apples are of a contrary. They that are taken at the spring ingender choller, hurt all the synowes, and breede inflamations and hote burnings. All Apples hurt the synowes, the vnripe are very noisome, if a man eate, so that he fill himselfe with Apples, they ingender the stone. But they are good for them that swoone, and haue a weake heart. The pap of an Apple with Rose water applied to the eyes, doeth quench their burning, and taketh away their rednesse. Apples be good in winter, and prouoke vrine: eate them with a little salt. Tarts of Apples with Anniseedes, make a sweete breath: a colde rosted Apple eaten to bedward, looseneth the belly. To keepe Apples long, lay them in hony, so that they touch not one another. Put frozen Apples into colde water, and they will come to their owne nature againe. Horcenesse Impostume Liuer hote Lothing Nose red Plurisie Stomake hote Thirst Voyce lost Veine stopt Wood to collour Wormes Woundes Arache. Take the seede with honied water to open and comfort the stopping of the liuer and the Iaundies. Apply the bruised leaues to inflamations and hote swellings at the beginning, namely that Arache of the Garden, the wilde Arache at the going away of the same swellings. Apply it with hony, vineger, and salt Peter, to the wilde fire, to the goute: but the much vse of Arache bringeth many infirmities. Apply the iuice to the holy fire, other inflamations to cease and qualifie them. Apply the hearbe to the priuie places of women to amend the euils within, and to cease the paine foorthwith. Vse the hearbe in pottage to loosen the belly, and to coole it and asswage diuers swellings. Stampe the hearbe and apply it to drawe out splent, pricke, or naile, and to heale the wound. Boyle it with hony, and apply it to rough nayles, to loosen them without paine. Seethe the seedes, and drinke the broth for shortnesse of breath, to expell wormes, and to cause vomite. Make pottage of Mercury and Arache, and eate them often for costynesse and pinching paine of the bladder. Vse pottage of Beetes, Arache and Mercurie, to be deliuered of the Ague in short time. Stampe the leaues, and apply them to kernels and freckles. Apply plasters thereof to curded milke in the breastes, being sodden in water, and drinke yt iuice of Arache with thy brothe. To cause an easie vomit, and to cleanse the stomake, seethe the seedes in water without salt, and put thereto a little oyle of nuts, and eate some course meate, and fill thy stomake, and then take the medicine, and labour a little. The seedes stampt, sodden and drunke, taketh away the Feuer quartaine. The seedes drunke with honied water, healeth the Kings euill. Bladder griefes Brestes sore Breath short Feuers quartaine Frecles Goute Kernels Kings euill Liuer hote stopt Matrix and griefes Nayles rough Prickes Purgation Swellings hote ARon, or wake Robin, the vertue is in the seede, roote, and leaues. Applied with the dung of Oxen or Kine, it helpeth the goute in the feete. The roote is gathered and laide vp as the rootes of Dragons and Sowbread. For the inflamation of the eares, boyle the knots and leaues in wine with common oyle, and put Cummin seede to it, and apply it plaster wise. For the Emerods and Figge in the fundament, boyle it with Mulline in wine or water, and vse it. For olde apostumes, stampe the hearbe with olde Swines grease, and apply it hote. For the scrophules, stampe ye hearbe with Squilla, and olde Bores grease, and apply it. To cleanse the face and skin, make fine powder of the knots of it, and mixe it with Rose water, and drie it in the Sunne, and doe so foure or fiue times, and then wash with the same powder Rose water. Powder of the seedes mixt with oyle, and dropt into the eare helpeth the sorenesse thereof. And mixt with cleane hony, it cleanseth the darkenesse of the eies, and sodden with oyle and applied hote, it cureth the Emerods. The roote, especially of that kinde that hath ye spotted leaues, either drie or greene taken one dramme at the least, is a most present remedie against all poyson and the plague: some put thereto as much Treacle. spoonefull or more of the iuice of the hearbe drunke, hath the same properties. Put a litle vineger, and it will not blister the tongue. Take one dramme of the powder, with two drammes of sugar for the hickit or yexing, to cut grosse humors, to cleanse the lungs, to helpe the cough, to purge the stomake of flegme and melancholie. The roote either greene or drie stamped and taken, doth mightely purge women after their The iuice or the distilled water hath the like effect, which also helpeth the swelling of ye cods, being drunke two or three ounces at once with a litle vineger. There is no better medicine against the plague sore Carbuncles, then the fresh leaues stampt and applied. And the same either greene or dry, doth helpe olde and rotten sores of the feete. The water and iuice purgeth healeth all maner of sores. The leaues and rootes sodden in wine or oyle, and vsed in insessions, healeth the Figs of the fundiment, and the falling downe of the same. Some women put the leaues among their Cheese to kill the wormes thereof, and to keepe it from corruption, and to make it last long. Stampe halfe a pound of the sodden or rosted rootes, seethe them with i. li. and a halfe of hony, and vse it to helpe them that can not draw their breath. Daungerous coughes, catharres, and reumes, griefes of the breast, and crampes: for it ripeth and consumeth all grosse humors, and scowreth all the inner parts. Seeth it with Rose leaues, oyle, and wine, and Cummin, and apply it to heale the swellings of the tongue eares. Kirnels, or Kings euill, stampe it with Bores grease, and apply it. Breath strait Carbuncle Catharre Cods swolne Cheese rennites Coughes Crampes Eares griefes Kings euill Lungs griefes Nose polip Plague Plague sore Polyp Poyson Purgation ARchangel: Emerods, cast Brimstone vpon hote coles, and lay blinde Nettles thereon, and sit ouer the fume thereof, and doe so thrise, and be whole. To heale a fistula, seeth it in Wine or ale, and vse the decoction, and apply the hearbe. Drinke the roote thereof with wine and pepper, to cure the ache of the reines. To stop the whites, seeth red Archangel in drinke, and drinke it morning and euening. Wits lost, cut the haire from the molde of the head, and apply it, and sleepe and be whole. Bruse Archangel white and red with salt, and apply it to hard wennes, botches, and apostumes. The leaues of white Archangel stampt with salt, healeth bruisings, burnings, wennes, swellings, goutes and wounds, sores and fistulaes. The roote stampt with salt, draweth foorth thornes and prickes. The herbe stampt with salt, helpeth the swelling of the throte, and the biting of a dog, (See Nettle. ARsmart, or Cyderach, stampe the greene herbe, and apply it to greene or fresh wounds to coole and comfort them, and to keepe them from impostumation inflammation. Eares wormes, drop in the iuice with as much vineger warme. Liuer stopt, drinke two drams of Arsmart with a little vineger. Flowers stopt, stampe it with wine, and apply it to the matrixe: Wormes to kill, stampe it with Rue Wormemood, and frie them with butter, or grease, and apply them to the stomacke. Womans belly great, not being with childe, seeth Arsmart, Rue and Hysope, ana one handfull in a quart of Ale to the one halfe, and drinke thereof first and last. Gout, mixe the distilled water with the gall of an Oxe, a little oyle of Spike, anoint therewith blood warme, and apply a blewe wollen cloth on it. Apply a handfull of Arsmart weeted in water to a wound or sore, and after burie it in a moist ground, and as it rotteth, the sore will heale miraculously. Anoint an ach with a spoonefull of Aqua vitae, and two spoones full of the distilled water morning and euening, fiue or sixe dayes, to heale it for euer. ARtichokes eaten rawe, doe amend the sauour of the mouth. And the heads sodden tender and boyled after with vineger and butter, and seasoned with salt, are greatly commended. Some eate them rawe with Pepper and salt, and fine powder of Coliander seede cast vpon them. Steeped, or rather sodden in wine and eaten, they prouoke vrine. Boyle them with flesh broth, and serue them with a sawse of butter, or oyle, or salt and vineger. Boyle the roote after the pith is taken out in wine and drinke it, to auoyde ranke smell of the arme pits. Steepe the yong shels or nuts in strong wine and eate them, to prouoke vrine. Boyle the roote, the pith taken out in water, and drinke it to strengthen the stomacke, and to confirme the place of conception, and to make it apt to conceiue men children. The first springs or tender impes sodden in good broth with butter, stayeth the voluntarie course of the naturall The roote maketh vrine sweete, and clenseth out melancholy flegme which aboundeth. The roote sodden in wine to the third part and drunke after the bath, or after supper or dinner, clenseth the vrine abundantly, and purgeth the reines and bladder, and so healeth the stinking of the whole body. To cause vrine, and to helpe the Gomer passion, seethe Artichokes in wine and drinke it. Make holes in Bayes and put in the seeds, and wrap them in doung set them in the ground and they will be passing well smelling and pleasant, or steepe the seeds three dayes. ASh: milt paine, seethe the rynd in wine, and drinke it fasting, sixe or seuen dayes, and anoynt the place with Dealthea. Eares deafe, mixe the sappe of greene Ash burned, Aqua vitae, and the iuice of Houslecke ana one spoonefull, with a spoonefull of the grease of an Eele that is red beneath the nauill, and put therof with tents into the eare. Plague: distil three ounces of the sap, with as much white wine, and drinke euery three houres, and at the ende of xxiiii. houres thou shalt be cured. Bitings or stingings of Serpents, stamp the leaues and apply them, or drinke the iuice. Vomit to stop, seethe the tender leaues in strong vineger, then stampe them and apply them to the stomake or belly. For wheales and blisters in the face, stamp the fresh leaues in the midst of the spring, let them stand to mollifie fiue daies, then distil them in Balneo Mariae, and wash therewith three weekes be whole. For the Megrim and Toothach, asshes of the barke with spettle and apply it: Winde in the guts: drinke the red seede with wine. Eares paine, put in the sap of burned Ash. And with the grease of an Eele, and oyle of Bitter Almonds for deafenesse. Stomake griefes generall, drinke powder of the seedes of Ash, Flaxe, and Cummin of eche like much with hote water or hote wort. Milt griefes, seethe a bough in wine or water, and vse it. Greene sicknesse, seethe powder of the Keyes with Betonie, red Sage, red Mynts, and Magerom in running water from a pottell to a quart, and drinke thereof a good draught with Sugar warme morning and euening. Blood to stop, smell to Mosse that groweth at the roote of an Ash tree. Feuer Quarten, seethe the middle barke of an Ash with Centory, Rue, and Wormwood in water or wine a long time, then streine it and drinke it with clarified hony. Milte griefes, take faire Barowes grease and asshes of Ash, of each two pound, seeth them in a gallon of running water to the one halfe, then streine it, and let it stand all night, then fleete off the grease, and streine it often, and keepe it in boxes, and anoynt therewith, and seethe a good quantitie of the rootes of yong Ash plants with as much Wormwood in a gallon of wine, to the one halfe, and drinke thereof at euening hote, and at morning cold. Eares sounding, bore a hole in the midst of an Ash in May, and put a reede in it, and let it stand foure or fiue dayes, and gather the water, and receiue vp the fume, and also dip tents therein, and put them into the eare: Milt hard seethe the barke in wine and drink it. Matrix grinding, seethe Asshen asshes in water, and dip a cloth therein, and apply it all ouer ye belly. precious water for sores: fine asshes of greene Ash with faire water, and stirre them often dayly, to the clearest of it put a litle vineger and Allum, and seethe it keepe it to wash sores withall. Emerods to stop, vse powder of Akorns, Ash keyes, a litle Bole Armoneak in warme broth or drink, or rere egs. To breake a byle or sore within one houre without paine, put asshes of the inner barke of greene Ash into a clout like a nut, and moysten it in hote water, bind it to the place: prooued. Black Iaundies, drinke the sap with a good draught of Ale and some Saffron two houres before meate, and there will rise shortly blisters all ouer the body, and when they are ready pricke them and let the humour come out. Liuer and milte griefes, stamp the inner bark of greene Ash, and strein it with white wine, and seethe it till the third part be wasted, and drinke it with Sugar Eares ach and dull put in the sap. Teethach and hollow, put in Triacle, and then put in a stick of Ash burned at the ende hote burning. Wormes, seethe the rynde of a Pomegranate, and Ash rootes in wine and drinke it, the same helpeth the Tenasmus. Milte griefes, seethe the rynd in Wine and drinke it. Burnings, boyle thicke Creame, and the Mossie barke of an Ash, till it come to an oyle, and so keepe it for that vse. For the swelling of the stomake and to cause appetite, stamp the rootes of Ash and of Fennel of eche like much, and drinke it with wine. For the stone, drinke powder of the barke of a yong Ash that beareth keyes in winter and sommer, and vse it also in brothes. Eares deafe, put in the sap of greene Ash with hony. Seethe the rynde in wine, and drink it for the torments of the milt: no Serpent will come neere the Ash tree, nor the shadow of it. Eares dull and for wormes in them, put in the sap with hony three houres, then turne it downe and doe so often. For Festers, Mermoles, sores of the yard, and all other sores, take Ash that beareth no keyes for a man, but for a woman that which beareth keyes, burne the bowes to asshes, and with cleare well water make strong lee therewith, and put thereto a third part of strong vineger, and anoint the sore therewith whatsoeuer it be, and lay Diaculum aboue it, it healeth all sores. The barke sodden in wine is good for all griefes of the milt. The leaues and barke boyled in wine and drunke, doe open and comfort the liuer and milt, and healeth the diseases of the sides, and so will they doe, being boyled in oyle and layd to. The leaues and barke with the tender crops taken in the same maner, are good for the dropsey, for they purge the water: It is good for fat and grosse folkes, to drinke three or foure leaues with wine dayly to make them leane. The iuice of the leaues, crops, and bark drunk in wine, preserueth from all venom and venomous bitings. Lee made with the asshes of the bark, cureth the white scurfe such like roughnesse of the skin. The seede prouoketh vrine, increaseth naturall seede, and moueth Venus, especially being taken with a Nutmeg. The leaues of the wilde Ashtree boyled in wine and drunke, are good against the paine of the side and the stopping of the liuer, and slake their bellies that haue the dropsie. If a man or beast be bitten of any venemous beast, let them drinke the iuice of Ash tops with good wine if they haue no Feuer, or els with wine delayed with water and stampe the yong sprigs and apply them to the byting: the same drinke is good for the dropsie. Milt swollen, drink dayly in a cup of Ash. To become leane, drinke the iuice of Ash leaues now and then with wine. Leapry, anoynt with asshes of the barke mixt with water. ASsafetida, is good to be smelled vnto against the suffocation of the mother. Flowers to cause, stamp it with a warme pestell, and put thereto Ellebore blacke or white, and make it a suppositer and put it in, if this serue not, then vse Verdigriece. Feuer quarten, mixe it with Rue and Pepper of each two drammes, temper them with hony, and take as much as a Chestnut two houres before the fit. Matrix falling after childbirth, lay one ounce on a pan of Charcole, and sit ouer it as warme as you can suffer three or foure times, and then steep. Taken with a rere egge to bedward, it openeth the liuer, and helpeth shortnesse of breath: mother suffocat. apply it to the nauill. The fume thereof taken at the nose is good for the Lytargie. Breathshort Feuer quarten Flowers stopt Lytargie Liuer stopt Matrix fallen Suffocat. AVens, or her be Benit: Fistula if it be outward put in the iuice, if it be inward drinke it. To auoyd moles and spots of yong children which they haue in their mothers bellies, gather the rootes and leaues in March, or May, stampe them and distill them through a limbeck, and wash therewith often. Feuers, stamp Auens, Feuerfue, and yarow ana one handfull, and strein it with ale, and drinke it two houres before the fit. Bones broken, drinke the iuice of Comfety morning euening three dayes, want thereof Sanada, then drinke Auens, Plantine, and Brusewort morning and euening dayly as long as neede is: Yarde canker, wash it with the iuice of Auens. For all superfluities gathered about the heart, liuer, stomake and sides, stampe Auens and Feuerfue, and them with stale ale, and drinke it morning and euening. Speech lost by the palsie, drinke Auens, or Baldemonye with warme water: Feuer hote: stampe it with red Wormewood ana one handfull, and streine it with a pinte of white wine, and drinke it at two or three times. Ache, seethe Auens and in water, and wash therewith foure or fiue times. Drinke the decoction of the roote for all inward wounds, griefes of the breast and sides, and all cruditie, and wash wounds therewith. Skabs dry, seethe it with Mouseare ana like much in running water, and wash therewith. Megrim, seeth it with Bay leaues ana an handfull in a quart of good white wine, apply it. The powder thereof drunke with white wine warme, helpeth much against the Feuers: it helpeth wounds and Kankers being drunke. Seethe it in wine or water, or both, and drinke it to dissolue congealed and brused blood, and to cure all inward wounds and hurtes, and also wash outward wounds therewith. Seethe the roote in wine and drinke it to comfort the stomake, to cause digestion, to open the liuer, and to clense and purge the breast from all grosse flegme. Drinke the dried roote with wine against poyson, and the collike, and to comfort digestion. The roote put into wine giueth it a pleasant taste and smell, refresheth the heart, causeth myrth, openeth the liuer, helpeth the stomake that is hurt with cold and grosse humours: and the roote sodden in wine clenseth and scoureth wounds, Fistulaes, and Kankers, and the foule spots of the face being washt therewith, and helpeth the paine of the breast and sides. ASarabacca: Feuer quarten, take one dram of the powder with white wine, one houre before the fitt, to purge it: dropsie, an excellent remedy. Infuse one ounce in a barrel of sweet wine three moneths, then streine it, and drinke of the wine morning and euening dayly. Feuer quarten: hyll thee warme in thy bed an houre before the fit, drink a glasse ful of Malmsie or Muscadell with halfe a Wall nut shell full of the powder of it, and couer thee well to sweat, and stamp Sage, Rue, and Bursa pastoris with white vineger, and apply it to thy wrists xxiiii. houres, and doe so thrise and be whole. Or stampe the greene leaues, and seethe them a litle in wine, and drink it two houres before the fitt, and lye on thy belly, it causeth vomite, and dissolueth the Feuer. The roote boyled in wine, prouoketh vrine and is good for the strangurie, the cough, shortnesse of breath, difficultie of breathing, conuulsions, cramps, and shrunk sinewes being drunke. And also is good against venom and venemous bytings, the dropsie and the Sciatica. Drinke it with honyed wine to driue downe the flowers, seconds, and other superfluities of the matrix. The leaues stamped and streined with wine and drunke, causeth to vomite vp tough flegme and choller. The leaues stampt and applied helpe the headach, inflamations of the eyes, breasts that are full of milke to dry it vp. The wilde fire especially at the beginning, drinke the iuice of sixe leaues with a pinte of Whay especially of Goats milke in the morning in Sommer to cast foorth yelowe choller and vnnaturall flegme. Steep thirtie greene leaues in newe wine all night, then streine it, and drinke it in the morning to bring forth abundance of humours from the breast. The wine being powred into a close pot with a piece of fat porke and sodden, and the porke eaten and the wine drunke, or the wine may be drunke after the porke, simply diluted or steeped all night with the leaues not sodden with the pork but streined and drunk after it. It helpeth in this maner the Iaundes, the feuer tertian, the beginning of dropsies, tympanies, Quotidians, Greene sicknesse, Quartens, Wormes and smelling of the stomake, for all which there is no better remedie. The iuice streined with Mill called Misselio and streined with a litle Make powder of the rootes with Cinnamom, Sugar, and Aromatik spices, and take one dram of it to prouoke vomite and to purge choller and flegme both vpward and downeward. Seeth the roote in wine with hony, and drink it to clense the lungs, and for the cough, and shortnesse of breath. Giue the rootes to Sheepe and great cattell to eate with salt to helpe them against their griefes: Vse it also sodden in wine with hony for the dropsie, obstructions of the lungs, Liuer, kidneys and bladder, and to clense them and the matrix, and to expell the termes, seconds and dead births both in men beasts. Seethe the roote in lee, and wash the head therewith to helpe the braine and memorie. Bitings venemous Braine to comfort Bladder stopt Breasts sore Breath short BAytree, seethe the leaues with Sage in white wine, and drinke it with grosse powder of Bayes before the fitte to helpe the Feuer.
