Some steepe the brused leaues twigs in vineger fiue or sixe dayes, and presse out a iuice, of which two ounces and a halfe drunke, is good for the sciatica: but it were better to mixe it with oyle and apply it. The fresh iuice of Broome rape, doeth cure all new woundes, vlcers, and corrupt sores. The iuice pressed out of the roote and dryed with a litle hony in the sunne, cleanseth It may be also taken out of the rootes that be halfe drie with oyle, and will serue to all intents as the iuice. The same Broome rape doth scoure and driue away all spots, lentiles, frecles, pimples, and wheales, or pusshes, as well in ye face as in all other partes being often anointed therewith. The seedes must be corrected with rosed hony, or Rose leaues, or Aniseede, or Fenell seede. Kidnes griefes Kings euill Knees ache Legs ache Lice to kill Liuer griefes It helpeth also the inward skabs of the bladder, especially taken with the The same eaten with oyle and vineger, are good for the strangury and stone. Frie it with sheepes suet, and apply it to bruses and swellings. BRyan, stampe it and apply it three dayes to the knees that are swolne. THe roote, especially the iuice thereof, doeth mightely purge tough flegme, prouoketh vrine, cleanseth the braine, breast, and inward partes. The roote taken dayly one dram a whole yere together, helpeth ye falling sicknesse, ye Apoplexia Vertigo. dayes, healeth ye milt that is stopt and hard: and so it doeth being stampt with Figs applied. An Electuary made thereof wt hony, is very good against shortnesse of breath, ye old cough, paine in the sides, inward burstings and congeled blood of bruses. The same roote vsed in a pessary, draweth downe the termes, seconds, and dead births, and so doth a bath of the decoction thereof, and also cleanseth the matrix from all vncleane filth, if they sit ouer it. The same stampt with salt applied, is good for noughty fretting sores that are corrupt and running, especially in the legs. The leaues and fruit are good for the same purpose applied in like sort. It cleanseth the skin from wrincles, frecles, sunburning alspots and scars being mixt with the meale of Orobus and Fenigreeke, and so doeth the oyle wherein the roote hath beene sodden. The same stampt and mixt with wine dissolueth clottered blood, and all skarres, bruises, and newe swellings. It draweth out splents and broken bones, and openeth noughtie vlcers and agnayles, that grow about the rootes of the nayles. the itche, leaprie, and noughtie scab. The first springs are very good to be eaten in Sallads for the stomake. The roote of blacke Bryony is as good for all the griefes aforesaide as the white, but not so strong: yet it preuayleth much against the falling euill, giddinesse or turnings of the head, to prouoke vrine and termes, to open and waste the stopt and swolne milte. And the tender springs thereof are very good also to be eaten in Sallads to purge watrish humors and superfluities, and to open the belly neither more nor lesse then the white Bryony. Bryony must be corrected with Mastike, Ginger, or Cinamom, and taken with hony, or with the decoction of raisins. Bryony sodden as Amaradulcis being prepared, doeth gently loosen the belly without perill, and prouoketh vrine. The iuice of the roote gathered in the spring time drunke with honied water, driueth foorth grosse flegme. An oyntment made thereof with oyle Oliue, and swines grease, is good for the palsie. The oyle thereof helpeth all maner of deformities of the skinne. So doth the roote with oyle of Tartar, and meale of Fenigreeke: or sodden in white wine from a quart to a pinte, and then streyned, and some Camphire put to it, and the place washt therewith euery night with a spondge. The beries broken doe clense the skinne, from skurffe and leaprie. The iuice of the beries baked in bread, causeth plentie of milke in nurses breasts that eate it, or vsed in frumentie. The roote is good for senowes that are cut to make them supple, and to haue their kindly course, especially the iuice of the roote gathered in Aprill or May, and the griefe anointed therewith against the fyre, and then applied with linnen cloutes. For the Goute, slice the rootes thereof and of wilde Dockes, and seethe them by themselues in water three houres, then stampe them small with soote of a chimney, and the milke of a Cowe of one hue, and the vrine of a fasting man, and apply it at euery Take Sallet oyle, or for want thereof Neates foote oyle two quartes, Bryony rootes cleane scraped, and washed, and stamped, seethe it with a soft fyre, till it be almost halfe wasted, then streine it and put in another roote, and seethe it to a pinte and a halfe, then a third roote, and seethe it to a pinte, then streine it and keepe it well, and anoint any ache therewith wheresoeuer it be against the fire a long time. Wounds growing together, put in the powder thereof to open them. Sausflegme, stampe the roote with great salt, and let it lie and rot dayes, then streine out the iuice and mixe it with vnguentum Album, Sulphur viuum, and hony of eache like much, and anoint therewith, apply plasters thereof in the nights. For all maner of goutes, take in winter the roote of Bryony, stampe it with two handfull of great salt, and let it stand so thirtie dayes, then streine out the iuice and anoint therewith against the fire, and mixe thereof with sheepes tallowe clarified together, and apply it to the sore to abate the paine quickely. Seethe the rootes in thine owne vrine, till three partes be wasted, and anoint the ache of the reines therewith. Face spots, or blemishes, anoint with the iuice of the rootes. Frensie and madnesse, boyle the roote and apply it to the head. Face wrincles, grinde white wine with a little Bryony, and a drie fig, anoint therewith, and goe till thou sweatest. Wounds ache, stampe the roote with faire running water, and streine it and warme it, and apply it as warme as may be suffered, the wounde being first washed. Wartes, burne the leaues and stones, and mixe the ashes with the iuice, and anoint them often, and they will fall off. Leapry, mixe the iuice of Bryony with powder of white and blacke Ellebore, and hony, and anoynt. Apostume generall, slice it thinne, and seethe it in a childes vrine, and let it stand houres, then stampe it and streine it, and vse it. Colour to be good, mixe powder of the roote of Viticell with Rose water, and dip a cloth therein, and wash therewith. want of sleepe, make lee with the ashes of Colewoort rootes, Nettle rootes, Bryony rootes, wash therewith often. Dropsie, take the iuice of Bryony with hony, or vse the decoctio~ of it. Feuer quarten, stampe it apply it to the pulses and temples before the fit. Scrophules, stampe ye roote with swines grease, and apply it. Mother suffocate: heate an ounce of ye roote in white wine, and drinke it twise a weeke to bedward a yeere together. seethe Watercresses in water, and drinke it with powder of the berries. Mother rising, seethe two partes of the iuice, with one part of Sallet oyle, till the iuice be consumed, and annoynt the place therewith where it riseth. Swelling by blood letting, heate the leaues in water, and apply them. Head ache hote or colde, stampe the rootes and boyle them in olde oyle and a little wine, and streine it and anoint therewith. To auoide blacke spots and skarres, boyle the rootes of Bryony both white and blacke in oyle, as long as it yeldeth any iuice, and anoint therewith. To cleanse and whiten the skinne and make it soft, stampe the roote and apply it. Teeth ache apply the powder of it with the iuice of Cheruile. Bursten Correction Cough olde Crampe Colour bad Dead birth Deliuerance Dropsie BVckthorne, ye beries doe purge downewards mightily flegme and choller with great force, much troubling the body, and sometimes causeth vomite, and therefore is not to be giuen but to them that be strong. The beries before they be ripe, soked in Alom water, make a faire yelowe colour, and when they be full ripe, they make a greene colour, which in France is called Vor de vessye, in Spanish Sapgreene. BVgle, and Sealfe Heale, bruised, drinke the decoction of Bugle. It healeth all wounds both inward and outward, it openeth the stoppings of the liuer and gall, and is good for the Iaundies and Feuers of long continuance. It cureth rotten vlcers and sores of the mouth and goomes being washed therewith. The greene and fresh herbe stampt applied, healeth wounds, galles, and scratches, and so doth the powder of the herbe. The iuice cureth the sores and vlcers of the secret partes, being often dropt in, and so doeth the bruised hearbe. Wounds of all sorts, stampe it with Yarrow and Sanicle, of eache like much, and straine it with wine and drinke it dayly. Being drunke and applied, it healeth and draweth out broken bones in the head, it destroyeth reume, and helpeth head ache. Wounds to heale, drinke it by it selfe, or with Pimpernell, Sanicle. Wounds to heale without plaster, drinke Bugle, Yarow, and Fenell ana like much with wine thrise aday: but if the head be wounded, vse no Fenell. Wounds of al sorts, stampe it with Yarow Sanicle, of eche like much, and streine it with wine, and drinke it dayly. Bones broken Chafings Feuers olde Gall stopt broken sores Iaundies Itche Liuer stopt Mouth sores Priuities sores Reume Skabbes Sores Wounds BVglosse, drinke it with wine to helpe the griefes of ye lunges and the drie cough. Seeth it in water hony for the cough, and roughnesse of ye throte. Steepe it in wine drinke it with Mellicrat. to cause mirth. Drinke it often in wine to purge red choller comming of heate, to helpe the Cardiake passion and to auoide hurtfull humors from the lungs. Drinke the iuice with warme water, to auoide the swelling of the feete. Steepe it in wine and drinke it to maintaine a good memorie, to comfort the heart and ingender good blood. Drinke ii. or iii. ounces of the distilled water, morning and euening with Sugar for the bloody flixe, straitnesse of breath, and abstraction of minde, weakenesse of the braine, all hote sicknesses, agues, griefes of the liuer and milte, to purge the blood, to auoide pricking of the heart and stomake, the Iaundies, to cleanse the leapry and skab, to mittigate distilling of the head, to cease the paine and burning of the eyes, the same being also applied with linnen clothes, and for the ringing and sound in the eares. Distill the flowers in Balneo Mariae, and it is a precious water to be drunke morning euening with powder of pearles or Manus Christi made with pearles to comfort the heart and braine. The hearbe, roote, and seede, or any part of them sodden in wine and drunke, defendeth the heart from poyson. The water or conserue of ye flowres, doe strengthen the heart, and are good against faintnesse and sounding, causeth mirth, voydeth melancholy, purgeth the blood, and is good against all hote feuers. Milke to encrease, bruse the seedes and drinke it with wine. Bytings and stingings venemous, drinke and apply the distilled water and the leaues. Buglosse prouoketh vrine, quencheth thirst, and the stalkes eaten either rawe or sodden, are good for the diseases of the liuer. The asshes of it are good for the sores and swellings in childrens mouthes. Seethe it with Sugar and Hydromel, and vse it for the sharpenesse and roughnesse of the throte. The asshes of the flowers are good for all griefes of the mouth and gomes, especially of children. Roste the roote in the embers in a weete cloute, mixe it with as much rosted apples and a little butter to asswage the paine of a white flawe, and to ripen all froncles or felons, and to take away the roughnesse of the tongue. Steepe Buglosse in water and wine of a Pomegranate, and holde it in thy mouth to delight thee when thou hast a Feuer. Stampe the flowers of Borage or Buglosse when they are full ripe, and put thereto thrise so much Sugar by litle and litle, and sunne it in a Gally pot twentie or thirtie dayes, and it will last a yeere. Their water drunke with wine, comforteth the braine, heart, and memorie, and wit, ingendreth good blood, voydeth melancholie, madnesse, and frensie. Buglosse easeth the payne that commeth of repletion of the veines in euery part, heart trembling and panting, especially for women which are much subiect thereto, make a drinke with two ounces of the cleare iuice, and two drams of Sugar, and drinke it euery night blood warme to bedward tenne dayes together. Seethe the leaues and rootes in water, and quenche steele therein, to make it hard and sharpe. Goute, drinke the iuice with warme water, and apply the substance. Stomake colde, and braine moyst, mixe sixe drams of Aqua vitae, foure drams of Buglosse water, Cinamom, and Saffron, of eche one peny waight, and steepe them together Madnesse, take Aqua vitae two egge shels full, wine thrise as much, powder of Sene two drams, and take it iii. mornings. Heart stiche, eate potage made with Buglosse, butter water, morning euening warme. Heart feeble, vse Buglosse, or the powder thereof in thy brothes. To refresh the body, stewe an olde henne with good store of Buglosse, and drinke thereof morning, noone, euening. Coldnesse by long sicknesse, seethe one handfull of Buglosse in a quart of wine, and streine it drinke it morning euening. Feeblenesse of the heart, shortnesse of breath, and sighing, drinke the iuice with hony. For passions of the heart, eate it or drinke it rawe or sodden to put out the noysome humors. Liuer milt griefes, vse Buglosse in thy pottage, and looke that thy belly be soluble. Belly bound, stampe great, and seethe them with Buglosse, and vse the broth. Tongue rough Tooles to set Venom Vomiting Vrine stopt White flawe Womens griefes Bullfoote. FOr the griefe of the lungs and spitting of blood, mixe it with Hogs lard chopped, and a newe laide egge, and boyle it or bake For the Kings euill, stampe it well with the roote and all, with flower of Lynseede and Barowes grease, and apply it morning euening, and after it is healed, wash it with white wine x. or xv. dayes. To heale wounds speedely, anoynt the tops of the leaues with hony, apply them, assoone as they be drie, apply fresh. To plucke out thornes or prickes apply it with Swines grease. Feuer tertian and quarten to auoide, drinke the iuice thereof x. dayes. Breast griefes, drinke the iuice of Hysope, Horehound, and Bullfoote. The leaues punned with hony, doe cure S. Anthonies fire, and all other inflamations. The perfume of the dryed leaues receiued through a Tunnell vpon the quicke coles, helpeth shortnesse of winde, the drie cough, and breaketh impostumes of the breast without daunger, and so doeth the roote laide on hote coles. Seethe it in meede, and drinke it to cast out a dead childe. Drinke three spoonefull of the distilled water for the inflamation of the Liuer, the gnawing of the stomake, the venome of ye burning feuer, and the same also applied outwardly with linnen clothes. The herbe distilled with flowers of Eldren, and Solatrum, of eache like much. The vertues thereof cannot be sufficiently esteemed, the same is good especially against inflamations, carbuncles, the holy fyre, the piles, hote apostumes and burnings, and so is the iuice of the leaues. The same is good also against all hote aches of the head, and heate of burning Feuers, and against all whelkes and pusshes comming of heate, and against all hote griefes of the secrete partes: for the pyles and emerodes, and such like. The fume receiued through a tronke, helpeth and cleanseth the lungs quickely, and healeth rotten and olde coughs. Cough of the lungs, take of the fume of the powder of it laide on a chafingdish of coles through a tunnill, at morning, noone, and euening iii. or iiii. dayes, if the cough come of hote reume, it will drie it vp: or seeth ii. handfull of Bullfoote in a quart of cleare posset ale, with a sticke of licoras cleansed and bruised, and when the one halfe is wasted, drinke it at morning, afternoone, and to bedward, by a little at once, but yet a good quantitie in the whole. Seethe Bulfoote, and Penyroyall, with a little salt in water, and drinke it fasting to auoide all euils from the heart. THe iuice of great Burre drunke with hony, prouoketh vrine, and swageth the paine of the bladder. The same drunke with olde wine, healeth the bytings and stingings of venemous beastes. The leaues punned with a little salt, is good against all venemous bitings of mad dogs or serpents. The powder of the seede drunke with the best wine that may be gotten fourtie dayes, is good against the sciatica. dram of the roote punned with the kernels of a Pine apple, is a soueraigne medicine against the spitting of corrupt matter. It is good for such as haue ache in the ioyntes and bones that haue beene out of ioynt or broken. The greene leaues punned with whites of egges, cureth burnings old sores. The leafe laid on the top of the head draweth the matrixe vpward, layd to the soles of the feete, it draweth it downeward, and so it helpeth the suffocation, the falling or displasing of the matrixe. Seeth the roote in Ale, and so let it stand houres close stopt, and then drinke a good draught three or foure times to helpe the yellowe Iaundies speedely. Drinke powder of the seedes with pure white wine to purge the grauell from the reines, but more speedily with Aqua vitae, The iuice of the lesser Burre with red stringy rootes drunke with wine, is good against all venemous bytings, and the grauell and stone. The fruite stampt and applyed to colde swellings, doeth consume and scatter them, and is good against the Kings euill, swellings, wenns, and scrophules in the necke and throat. The ripe seede of great Burres in powder drunke, is good for them that haue the stone. The fresh leaues are good for olde vlcers and sores, and for ioynts that are lose, and broken members, and for all heate, and ach being applyed. The root taken with Pineapple kernels in quantitie of a dramme, is good against the coughing out of matter and blood. The roote is good to be layd to the ach that commeth by wrenching and streining. The leaues are good to be layd vpon olde sores. Drink one dramme with Pineapple kernels, to helpe the cough, spetting of blood and matter, filthinesse of the stomake, and contraction of of the finewes, and arteries. The leaues or iuice doe heale old rotten fores and stinking filthy vlcers. The decoction of the roote is good to wash vlcers and wounds withall. The root stampt with salt and applyed, is good against the bytings of mad dogs. The root vsed inward or outward, preuaileth against the bytings of Serpents. The root sodden in wine and drunk one houre before the fitt, deliuereth from the horrour of the Feuer quarten. And the root stampt with Swines grease, helpeth the squincy and swelling in the throat. The Ditch burre, or lesser Burre with red rootes, is good to be layd to swellings. The barke of Burre roots drunke, wasteth the swelling of the milt. And the decoction of it sodden in wine, and the mouth washed therewith, fastneth lose teeth. Drinke the distilled water of burre foure ounces, with halfe an ounce of white crude hony, foure or fiue houres before meate warme thirty dayes together against the catharre to cure it, except it come of the poxe or hectyke, for the which also it will doe good, if not cure them, Seethe the roots with red Nettle crops in good stale ale, and clarifie it, and drinke it before the colde fitt of the Feuer quarten, and after the great heate is past, drink possit ale made with Marygolds and Fenell, and doe so foure times if neede be. the roots with Sage leaues and apply it to saint Anthonies fire. Grind the rootes of Burres and Planten with vineger and salt, and anoynt therewith the freckles, red blaynes, and sausflegme of the face. Seethe the rootes in water, and set thy feete therein vp to the ancles as hote as may be suffered to helpe the bloody fluxe. For the gout nd Sciatica, seethe the roots in strong wine and apply it. Stamp the barke or pill, and streine it with newe Ale, and drinke it against all gouts, prooued. Foment with the decoction of the pill of the rootes in wine wheresoeuer the griefe be, or stampe the rootes and seethe them in Ale, and streine it and drinke it at euening hote, and at morning colde for the aforesayd. For ache of the reines, drinke the roote with Ale and butter at morning colde, and euening hote. Sciatica, seethe the rootes in strong wine, and apply it. Bloody fluxe, chop the rootes as much as a peny lofe, seethe them in a newe pot with good Wine, and sit ouer the vapour of it, it stoppeth also the termes, or seethe the rootes or seeds, or both in raine water, or conduit water, and drinke it fasting. Belly and guts paine, drinke a sciat of the iuice of the leaues. Backe ache, stampe the rootes, and seethe them in Ale, and drinke it at euening hote, and at morning colde. Pyles, take vp the fume of the rootes of Burres and Veruen, with Frankincense layde on coles. Feuer, stampe three rootes of Burres, and seethe them with halfe a pinte of Ale, and drinke thereof leuke warme before the fitt. Speech lost, holde the iuice of the herbe and roote vnder thy tongue, and be whole. Cough and pose, vse powder of the seeds with Wardens or Peares, or drink it morning and euening. Pursinesse of winde, and to breake flegme and much corruption, drinke powder of the seedes as much as you can take vp with two fingers and a thumb, first and last at morning and euening with White wine or olde Ale: prooued. Impostume to breake, seethe the roote in Ale, and drinke it nine dayes to breake, and auoyde it downewards. Squincy and griefes of the throat, drinke powder of the seedes with Ale as often as neede is. Face blaines, stamp the roots of Planten Burres with salt of ech like much, with vineger, anoynt at night to bedward. Belly or guts fretting, seethe the root of Burre and Elecampana, in wine, and drinke it warme morning and euening. Bloody fluxe, stamp the roots, and seethe them in water to the one halfe, and stand in it, but not to the ancles, for then it bindeth too much, and bringeth danger of death by costiuenesse. Mad dog Matrix griefe Milt swollen Necke swollen Pyles Pose Pursinesse Ringworme Reume S. Anthonies fire Sciatica BVrsa pastoris, blood to staunch, hold thy hands full of it: nosebleeding, bind it about thy necke, and hold thereof in thy hand, and also vse it in thy meates, and apply vineger and water to the Spetting blood, seethe it with Planten, and Knotgrasse in raine water, and streine it and drinke thereof with Sugar, at morne, noone, and euen. Blood to stop, apply the iuice with powder of Antimonium, or dip an Elderne pith in the iuice, and cast on powder of Sinnach, and put it in. Chafing in the flanks, wash or bath with the decoction thereof, or of Planten, or Horsetaile, or Knotgrasse. Feuer hote, stamp one handfull with as much Smallach, and as much Frankincense as a wall nut, and as much Bay salt, and apply them to the wrists two houres before the fitt. Nosebleeding, apply the iuice with Bol armoniake to the temples with the white of an egge. Or mixe powder of Bursa pastoris with the iuice thereof, powder of Camphire, and Nettleseedes, and make little tentes thereof and put them in, or put in powder of the flower, rynd, and kernels of a Pomegranate with the iuice of Bursa pastoris. Teeth ache, stamp a good handfull, and apply it to the soles of thy feete. For one that is newe bursten, seethe Bursa pastoris, Mugwort, Ribwort, and Polipody ana, one handfull in a pottell of strong Ale to a quart,, then streine it, and drink three spoonefuls fasting warme dayly. Blood to stop, holde thy hands full of it, and looke to the sunne, and be not straite girded. Flowers to stop, put in a pessarie of the iuice, and Goats doung. Bloody fluxe, drinke the iuice, or bake cakes of wheate flowre with the iuice of it and of Yerrow and Planten ana like much in the embers, and eate them hote, and drinke the iuice of them with Red wine warme three dayes: prooued. Teeth ach, grind it with Sage and Mints ana like much, and put it in a linnen bag, and hold it to thy teeth, and shut thy mouth while one may say three Pater nosters, then open thy mouth and let out the glutt, and doe so as often as neede is. Bloody fluxe, drink it with Red wine, or milke, or drinke the iuice with twise so much Red wine when thou goest to bed, to heale the flixe speedily. The decoction thereof drunke, stoppeth the laske, the bloody flixe, spetting blood, pissing blood, the flowers, and all other issues of blood, most excellently well howsoeuer it be taken, but especially with Red wine or Planten water. Stamp it with vineger and fresh Swines grease, to quench all inflamations or heate of the body, as shingles, &c. The iuice alone doeth heale a newe Nothing is better to stop the flowers, then to make a fomentation or moyst bath thereof, and to sit ouer it close, and to drinke of the same clarified in Red wine. Seethe the dryed herbe in Red wine, or raine water wherein hote steele hath bene often quenched, and drinke it to all kindes of fluxes both white and red, the termes and all other gnawings of the bowels. Nose bleeding put in the iuice with a tent, and the like into wounds warme. Vse it in plasters for the sores of the head. Drink the iuice for straitnesse of breath, the strangurie, to stop reume, and prouoke vrine. It preuenteth the fitts of the Feuers being taken one houre before the fitt. It cureth creeping and running sores, fistulaes, spetting of blood and matter, the holy fire, swellings and hardnesse, shingles, heate of the stomake, new wounds, hote apostumes, reumatike sores and vlcers of the eares, and all kindes of fluxes. Head sores Holy fire Inflamations Nose bleeding Pissing blood Reume BVrnet openeth the stoppings of the liuer, causeth vrine, and helpeth the Iaundes. Stamp it and seethe it with wine or milke, and streine it, and drinke it hote for the grinding of the belly. For all sores, wash them with the iuice of Burnet and Sugar. To heale the Plurisie and putrifaction of the matrix, distill it in the end of May, and drinke the water foure ounces morning and euening. Burnet drunke, cureth the bloody flixe, spetting blood, pissing blood, the flowers, and all other fluxes of blood, and so doeth the powder of the herbe and seede drunke with wine or water wherein iron hath bene often quenched, and so doeth the herbe alone being but holden in the hand. Wounds, stamp the greene leaues and apply them to keepe them from apostumation, and inflamation, and to hote tumours, botches, swelling and vlcers. It is very good to heale wounds vsed both inward and outward, to auoyd inflamation and bleeding. The leaues steeped in wine and drunke, doe comfort and reioyce the heart, and helpe the trembling thereof, confirmeth the stomake. It is very good in the plague time, and so is the water thereof. It stoppeth the flowers and all fluxes, and represseth cholerike vomitings. The leafe in Ale, Beere or Wine, is good against the reume and flixe of the body, and against the hote running gout, vsed both inward and outward. Burnet openeth the stoppings of the liuer, causeth vrine, and helpeth the Iaundes, and with White wine and hony it vnbindeth stitches of the ribs and teats. BVtchers broome, or Knee holme: Kankers in wounds, apply powder of the roots. Yard inflamed, stamp the leaues and boyle them with Rose water a litle wine, apply them. Seethe it in wine, and drinke it to prouoke vrine, to breake the stone, and driue out the grauell and vrine. For the Iaundes and headache, and to prouoke the flowers. The leaues and fruit be of the same force that the roots be of, but not so strong. Flowers stopt Headach Iaundes Kanker Stone Strangury Vrine stopt Wounds Yard inflamed Butterburre. BVtter burre: Plague, drink the powder of it with wine, it helpeth the pestilent Feuers, prouoketh sweat, dryeth vp all venom and euil heate from the heart. It killeth wormes, and is of great force against the suffocation of the mother. It cureth all naughtie vlcers, and all filthy fretting sores or consuming poxe and inflamations, the powder being cast into them or on them. The same cureth the farcion in horses either giuen inwards or applyed outwardly. The roote is good against all venemous bytings and poyson being vsed either inward or outward. Being sodden in wine drunke, it helpeth the difficultie of breathing, it killeth broad worms like gourd seeds, driueth downe vrine and termes. The powder of the root doeth effectually heale al running sores and moyst wounds. Oyle of the root of it is good against all shaking and colde feuers being anoynted before the fitt, and the same scoureth away all the filthinesse of the skin, and is good for the extreme coldnesse and shakinng of the ioints and sinewes. Stamp the herbe and apply it to any sores that be extremely hard to heale. of the powder of the root with wine, and couer thee well to sweat. The same powder is also good against the strangling of the mother, and killeth wormes both in men and beastes, and helpeth them that are shortwinded. (See Nep.) CAlament drunke three dayes, helpeth the Iaundes, and the stomake, causeth digestion, and stayeth vomiting, and being drunke and applyed, it helpeth venemous bytings, and wounds. Stomake ache, seethe it with Reasins, and dry Figs in wine, drink it first and last, or vse it in brothes. Wounds to heale, stamp Nep and drink it with Ale. Wormes, drink it with wine. Feuer quarten, drink the iuice of Nep with wine to sweat it away. Seethe it in water and hony, and drinke the broth to prouoke the flowers. Lytargie, drink asshes of the skin of a Hare with Calament. Breasts swollen, stamp it with Wormewood, Sage, and tosted white bread and vineger, and apply it as hote as may be suffered. Stomake griefes, stamp Nep, and seethe it in Wine and drinke it. Cough and impostume, eate rosted figs with powder of Nep. Bleeding inward, stamp it and streine it with Ale or Wine, and drinke it three or foure times a day, and the blood shall come outwarde. Dead childe to expell, drinke it and Betony with Ale. Sciatica, stamp it and apply it. To preserue from the lepry in the beginning chewe it fasting, and holde it, and thou shalt neuer be leprous. Woman mischieued in childe birth, stamp good store of Nep with a little Veruin, and streine it with White wine or stale Ale, and drinke it first at and last at morne and euen as long as neede is. Bruses and brused blood, stampe Nep leaues with salt and apply them. Yexing, drinke Nep with Wine: cough colde, stamp as much Nep as two wallnuts with two egges, and make a tansy and eate it. Matrix colde and moyst, vse pessaries or subfumigations of Nep, it helpeth conception. Wormes and superfluous flesh in sores, apply powder of wilde Calament. Wounds bleeding inward, drink the iuice fasting by it selfe, or with Cheruill and Wine. Calament or Nep boyled and drunke or applyed, is good against venemous bytings. Drunke with Wine aforehand it preserueth from poyson, and chaseth away all venemous beastes from whence it is strawed or burned. Drunke with honyed Wine, it warmeth the body, cutteth grosse humours, driueth away colde shiuerings, and causeth sweate, and so it doeth being boyled in oyle and all the body anoynted with it. Drunke as aforesayde, it helpeth brusings, digesteth congealed blood, and is good for burstings, paine of the bowels, shortnesse of breath, stopping of the breast, and the Iaundies. Boyled in Wine and drunke, it prouoketh vrine and termes, expelleth the dead birth, so it doeth in a pessary or in other suppositer. It is good for lazers and lepers to eate of it, and to drinke it in whay of sweete milke after it. Eaten rawe or sodden with meates, or drunke with salt and hony, slayeth and expelleth all kindes of wormes out of all partes of the body, and so doeth the iuice drunke and layd to where they are. Boyled in Wine, it helpeth bruses, and blacke spots being often It helpeth the strangury or stopping of the vrine, the stone, conuulsions of the stomake, wheasings, paines of the guts, stopping of termes, tertians, the kings euill, being drunk in wine, or the powder or syrop vsed. The water is but weake, except to stop vomits. The oyle is a present helpe against the Sciatica, entreth quickly. Drink the iuice with wine, to kill wormes, resist poyson, cause sweat, open the liuer and milt, and to heate the kidneys that haue taken colde, or seethe the herbe with wine for all the aforesayd, and to clense the breast, prouoke vrin, heale ruptures, help the Iaundies, to restreine cholerik fluxes, to comfort the stomake, for the Feuer tertian, the stomake being first clensed. Matrix griefes of all sortes, stamp the leaues and flowers of Calament, and seethe them in water with powder of Cauell, and streine it, and drink it warme with sugar morne and euen. Lytargy Liuer stopt Matrix cold and moyst Milt stopt Pyles Pissing bed Poyson CAlamus aromaticus doeth clense, dry, and waste all windinesse within the body without hurt. The root sodden in wine and drunk, helpeth the white morphue, causeth a good colour in the face. It doeth helpe to purge, clense, and dry the water betwene the skin and the flesh, being sodden with the seeds of Smallach, Parsly and Fenel, and streined, and so it helpeth cramps also, and griefes in the sinewes. Being drunk in wine, sodden with Sage and fresh Capars, it helpeth the coldnes of the milt, liuer and reines. The powder thereof drunke, augmenteth seede of generation, and purgeth the termes. Nothing is better for the dropsie then Ale of Wormewood or of Sage, drunk with the sayd powder. It also clenseth the bladder and voydeth the stinking of the vrine. It is a noble herbe of great vertue, chiefly the roote. Boyled with Parsley seede, it is good for the strangury, paine in the reines and bladder, the dropsie. The same taken any wayes, is very agreeable to the inner partes of the stomake, liuer, milt and matrix, and for all ruptures. Breath stinke, chew it and hold it in thy mouth. Liuer and milt stopt, stamp it and steepe it in sufficient vineger, and seethe it in the same vineger to the one halfe, and to one pound of Calamus put six ounces of hony, and boyle it to a syrop, and take an ounce and a halfe euery morning and be whole. Calamus aromaticus causeth vrine and termes taken in warily, or fomented out warely, and is good in plasters for the liuer and stomake. It is good for strangurie and griefes of the kidneys. Seethe it in Wine and drinke it against the white morphue. It helpeth sores of the bladder, and expelleth stinking vrine, and with conuenient things, it helpeth the dropsie. Morphue Seed to increase Sinewes griefes Stomak griefes Strangurie Vrine stinke Windinesse Caltrop. CAltrop or starre thistle: drinke powder of the seed with wine, to expell the vrine, for the grauell and the strangurie. CAmomill: stinking sweat, seethe Camomill Wormwood with some Alom in water and wash therewith. Feuers, seethe Camomill, Isop, and fiueleafe ana, one handfull in a quart of Ale, and make it an Alebrew and vse it. Ache, stamp it and apply it by it selfe or with Pepper. Milt paine, drinke one dram of powder of the flowers with three ounces of White wine, and a litle of a childes vrine morning and euening. Itch and ill humours, seethe Ladies mantell, Camomill flowers, and Iacea ana one handfull in good Wine, and drinke foure ounces euery morning, and also wash therwith twise, and be whole. Bruses, boyle Camomil, Wormewood, wheat branne ana one handfull in wine after in hony, apply it. Stomak impost. drink vi. ounces of the distilled water euery morning at the breake of day. Strangury and stone in ye reines, drink one ounce of the water when need is eate a litle sugar after it. To make ye oyle of it, put iii. ounces of the flowers after one dayes gathering in one pinte a halfe of sallet oyle in a glasse, set it in the sunne xl. dayes, it openeth the pores, resolueth vapours, stoppeth flowing of humours, correcteth euill qualities, comforteth the sinewes, mitigateth ach or paine. Aches swellings, seethe the flowers of Camomill Roses in white wine, apply it plasterwise. Kernels in the throat, mixe pouder of it with hony, take a spooneful of it morne euen, and let it go down by a litle at once. Feuers cold, seethe it and wormwood in a quart of Ale to ye one halfe, then streine it drink it first last. Head vlcers or biles, seethe it in vineger or water and wash therwith. Headach, stamp it with red Fenel, Sage Cummin, apply it. Chollik, stone, stopping of the vrin, stamp Camomil and wild Mallowes ana one handfull, seethe them in water till it be thick, put them into two pockets, sprinkle them with white wine, apply them one after another from the nauil to the yard as hot as may be suffred. Seethe Camomil, Rosemary, Time ana, one handfull in a pinte of Malmsey, take vp the fume therof into the eares that are dul of hearing, or apply a ball of brused Camomil. Seethe two handfuls of Camomil in strong Ale, and apply it hote as may be suffered, or take vp the fume thereof into the mouth for the headach, and when it is cold heate it againe and hang a cloth ouer thy head. Sinewes shronk, for swelling in the necke, grind it with as much water cresses, of eche one handful smal, fry them wt wheat meale and hony, and apply it hote as may be suffered: prooued. Stitch, stamp the flowers with a litle vineger, apply them hote in a bag, or seethe three handfuls with as much wormwood, some Mallowes, one handfull of Rosemary in a gallon of water to the one halfe, put them into two or three bladders apply them hote one after another. Worms, seethe Camomil, Tansy, Peniroyal ana, like much, in one pinte of Malmsey to ye one halfe, then strein it, drink therof. For the cholik at all times, fil a stillatorie with Camomill, one handfull of Mints, all shreaded smal, put thereto a quart of White wine and distill it, and drink the water. Head pusshes and wheales seethe it in vineger and wash therewith. Milt griefes, drink one dramme of the powder fourtie dayes. Vrine stopt, seethe it in wine or water, drinke thereof often, it helpeth also the stopping of the liuer and milt. Flowers stopt, seethe it in water and bath therein. with oyle oliue, and let it rest xii. dayes, then seethe it and streine it, and doe so the second time, let it stand xvi. dayes, then seethe it, and streine it vse it. Headach, seethe it in water and wash therewith luke warme and apply the herbe till the ache cease. Headach of stopping, seethe the flowers in lee wash thy head therwith, apply the flowers, and steep a piece of bread in wine, eate it with powder of Cinnamom. Madnesse, seethe Camomill flowers and Veruin ana one handfull in a quart of water or lee, wash thy head therewith. Sweat to cause, vse Camomil the flowers thereof in baths. Liuer cold with stitch palenes, purge thy body, set thy feet in warme water wherein Camomil hath bene sodden, warme, them, beware thou take no cold. Loynes ach of cold cause, Seethe the flowers in wine with as much water, and stamp them well, seethe them againe in the same liquor till it be wasted, and apply it as hote as may be suffered a foote broad, and then vse hote oyntments or oyles. Feuers of dry cause, or heauinesse, seethe Camomill and Dill ana, two handfuls in water, sit ouer it vp to the knees, couer thee well that the water may strike vp through thee, then rub well thy legs downewards walke, vse meates that warme moderately, beware of colde. Feuer quotidian with great thirst, set thy feet in the like water aforesaid dry them and rub them with salt, as much oyle of Violets. Camomill drunk with wine, breaketh the stone, helpeth the Iaundes, the ach and griefe of the liuer, sores of the mouth, headach, megrem, and expelleth vrin. good plaster for the stomak: stamp Camomil, Mints, sage, good store of wormwood with sowre bread, boyle them in vineger, apply it warme. The decoction of the flowers, herbe root drunk, prouoketh terms, expelleth the dead fruit, driueth out vrine, breaketh the stone, and so doeth the bath of the decoction thereof. The flowers herbe boyled in wine and drunk, expelleth the wind, cureth the cholik paine in the belly, and so it purgeth beautifieth those that haue an euill colour after the Iaundes, and all griefes of the liuer. Drink one dramme of the herbe and flowers with wine, against all venemous bytings. Seethe it in water apply it to the region of the bladder for the paine thereof, and to driue forth the vrine grauel. it in the mouth for the vlcers thereof, or wash the mouth with the decoction thereof. Mixe it with oyle, take it in a glister against all Feuers comming of obstruction or stopping of the skin. The oyle thereof swageth all ache, it cureth brused and wearied partes, it softneth all hardnesse swellings, and openeth all that is stopped. Seethe it in water, and wash pusshes of the head therewith to heale them. Strangury stone in the kidneys, drink Camomill water with sugar fasting, till the paine be gone. Stamp it and streine it with white wine, and drinke it to expell a dead child presently, to clense the bladder. Wash one handfull and bruse it, and seethe it in a pinte of Ale to the one halfe, scom it streine it, and drink it one houre before the fitt of an ague with sugar, and couer thee well to sweat three dayes together fasting. Seethe the herbe flowers in wine and drink it to helpe the stoppings of the liuer milt to purge choller to expell termes to help the torments of the smal guts, to heale ye griefe of the kidneis bladder, to mitigate the inward griefes of the matrix, for straitnes of wind, sighing, wheasing, the griefes of the lungs, the fluxe lienteria, to warme the cold stomak to driue away many inward griefes. Seethe the flowers with vineger hony, drink it dayly morne and euen for the falling sicknesse. There is no medicine more vsuall amongst men then Camomil for all griefes. Smell to Camomill wash thy head therewith, or with the lee thereof, for the weaknesse of the head and braine. The oyle of the flowers thereof, softneth all hard swellings and humours, and mitigateth aches. Anoynt the headache with the oyle, and all other aches, bruses, shrinkings, hardnesse, and stoppings, &c. Take the flowers of Camomill, or any other flowers, or fresh greene herbes, chop them small, and boyle them artly in oyle, coole it and presse, and put therein fresh flowers, and sunne it, and vse it. Take powder of any simple wood, as Sanders, Aloes, Tamariske, or Guiacum, soke it in oyle of sweete Almonds ten dayes, then heate it, and presse out the oyle, the like may be done with any flower or herbe. CApars: the barke of the roote is good against the hardnesse and stopping of the milt to be taken with Oximel or mixed with oyles, or oyntments fit for that purpose and applyed. The roote vsed in drinke is good for the Sciatica, the palsie, and bruised blood, it prouoketh termes and vrine mightely, that it waxeth bloody if it be much vsed, it cleanseth olde vlcers and rotten sores that be hard to heale. And laide to with vineger, it voydeth foule whitespots and morphue, the fruite and leaues haue the like vertue as the rootes, but not so strong. The seede boyled with vineger and kept warme in the mouth, swageth toothache. The iuice of the leaues, flowers, and yong fruite dropped into the eares, killeth wormes in them. The Capers preserued in salt or pickle, as they be brought into this countrey, being washed, and boyled, and eaten with vineger, are meate and medicine: for it causeth appetite, openeth the stopping of the liuer and milt, consumeth colde flegmes in the stomake, but they nourish little or nothing at all. Eate Capers, and drinke the water of a smithes to heale the swelling of the milte, though it haue continued seuen yeeres. Rawe Capers eaten, trouble the stomake, wherefore they must be sodden mixt with oyle and vineger and so eaten. The continuall vse of them is good for them that haue the palsie, the goute, and that are flegmatike and splenetike, for excesse of termes, the sciatica and stopping of the vrine. Drinke two drams of the fruite fourtie dayes with wine to waste the milte, and driue downe the vrine and bloody excrements, for the sciatica, weakenesse of the sinowes, ruptures, crampes, to prouoke flowers, to purge the head, and loosen the belly. Capers sodden in vineger, helpeth the tooth ache, and so doeth the dryed barke of the roote, which decoction serueth also to cleanse all maner of filth of the skinne, all filthie sores and white skurfe and hard swellings. The fruite or leaues applied with Barly meale, is good for the hardnesse of the milt, wennes and kernels. Flowers to cause, stampe the barke of the tree, and steepe it all night in white wine, and streine it, and drinke it fasting two or three mornings. Distill them when they are greene, and wash haire with the water in the sunne, and it will be greene. Kings euill, vse the decoction of the barke of Capars, and Sperage, and anoynt with oyle of serpents. Ache Appetite Belly bound Bones ache Bruised Bursten Crampe Colour greene Eares wormes Flowers stopt Goute Greene colour Hardnesse Head purge Kernels Kings euill Liuer stopt Milt griefes CArdamom, or Graines of Paradise, are good to be drunke against the falling sicknesse, the sciatica, the cough, resolutions of the sinowes, ruptures, paine of the belly, to kill wormes, and prouoke vrine. Drinke one dramme in wine, with as much barke of Laurus to breake the stone. Graines are good for a colde stomake, and are much like Pepper in operation. Chollike, seethe white time and Parslie in Ale, and streyne it and drinke it with powder of Graynes. Braine weake of reume or pose, put powder of Cardamom to oyle of Muske into an Egge shell, till it seethe, and anoint therewith: it is cheefe of all seedes. Put powder of it into the nose to comfort the feeble braine. Griefes of the heart, lungs, and stomake, and to preserue from all euill humors, take Cardamom, iii. ounces, Galingall, vi. ounces, Sugar, iiii. ounces, Saffron, i. peniworth, and take halfe a spoonefull of their powder morning and euening, till you be whole. Belly ache Braine sicke Bursten Chollike Cough Falling euill Reume CAmepitis, ground Pine, hearbe Iue, or fielde Cypers: liuer, milt, kidneis, and bladder stopt, seethe it and Germander in oyle, and apply it and vse the powder of the hearbes as an Electuarie with hony. Drinke the distilled water of Camepitis, and anoint the place with it to helpe the goute. The leaues drunke with wine seuen dayes, healeth the Iaundies. And drunke with Mede or Mellicrate fourtie dayes, it healeth the sciatica. Woundes and corrupt vlcers, stampe it greene with hony, and apply it. Pappes hard, stampe it greene, and apply it, and so it healeth also all venemous bitings. Dead childe, and inwarde bruises, seethe it in vineger and drinke it. Bladder stopt Breastes hard Bruised Dead childe Flowers stopt Goute Iaundies Kidneis stopt Liuer stopt Milt stopt Sciatica Sweate to cause Vlcers Woundes Charloke. CHarloke Rapistrum, is not vsed in medicin, but some vse the seede thereof for Musterseede, and it may serue in steede thereof, but it is not all out so good. CArrots: mother, drinke one spoonefull of the iuice of ye rootes of wilde Carrots, with a litle drinke, apply the drosse to the priuie place. Sodden tenderly in meate, they are pleasant, and holsome, they nourish well, warme all the inner partes being eaten moderatly. The feedes of wilde Carrots dronke or applied to the matrix, bringeth downe flowres, it prouoketh vrine being drunke, and is good against all venemous bitings and stingings. He that taketh it aforehand, shall not be bitten of serpents: it is good for conception. And laide to the conuenient place, it bringeth foorth the childe that sticketh in the birth. The Garden Carrots hath the same vertues, but not so strong, but yet more fit for meate, and prouoketh venery. The rootes especially of the wilde Carrot, prouoke vrine, taken in any sort, and increaseth loue. The powder thereof drunke with honied water, openeth the stoppings of the liuer, milt, and kidneys and is good for the grauell the Iaundies. The seede of ye wilde prouoketh termes, helpeth the suffocation of ye mother: being drunke in wine, or vsed in pessaries, it prouoketh vrine, casteth out grauell, and is good for the strangury and dropsie, and for the paine of the sides, belly, and reines, against all venome, and venemous bitings. The seedes of garden Carrots haue like vertues, but not so strong. The seedes especially of the wilde sodden in wine, draweth downe the termes and vrine, and water of the dropsie. The roote vsed in meates, is good against the dropping of the vrine, it may be kept in vineger hony as other rootes. The seede, hearbe, or roote sodden and applyed, bringeth downe the dead birth, the seconds, and the flowers. And stamped with hony and applyed, it is good against the pockes, kankers and fretting sores, which eate the flesh and skinne. The seede sodden in wine helpeth the chollike, and winde in the stomake and the hyckit. Grauell Hyckit Iaundies Kanker Kidneis stopt Liuer stopt Luste to cause CArway: To cleare the sight, hold thy eyes ouer the vapour of the seedes powdred and sprinckled vpon hot Barley bread. Carway breaketh winde, helpeth the cough, and is good against the frensie, and venemous bitings, with Alome it helpeth scabs and tetters, and restoreth haire. The seede is good for the stomake and the mouth, it helpeth digestion, prouoketh vrine, and dissolueth all windinesse of the inward partes, and is of the vertue of Anniseedes. The rootes boyled, are good to be eaten as Carrets. The yong stalkes are wonderfull pleasant in a Sallad vnsodden. The hearbe serueth to make sweete and well smelling pottage, it maketh a sweete breath. Both seedes and the hearbe are good against hote swellings. Seethe it in wine, and drinke it to purge the reines. Breath ill Cough Digestion Eyes dull Frensie Haire fallen Skabbes Swellings Tetters Vrine stopt Windinesse Cassiafistula. CAssiafistula: to purge a woman with childe, stampe halfe an ounce, seethe it in white wine, streine it, and let her drinke it and lye vpon her bed, if the childe be full of venom all about, it shall be clarified and liue, and the woman whole: proued. The inner pulp is a very sweete and pleasant medicine, and may be taken of all people that are weake, and women with childe, without danger. It looseth the belly and purgeth choller chiefely, and sometimes flegme gathered about the guts, one ounce being taken: it is very good for hote Feuers, the Plurisie, the Iaundies, or any other inflamation of the liuer, especially mixt with waters, drinkes or herbes that be of cooling nature, it is good for the reines or kidneis, it expelleth the grauell and stone, preserueth against the stone, mixt with the decoction of licoras, or the rootes of Persley or Cythes, or a decoction of all together and drunke. Throte swolne, Garlike with Cassia to dissolue and breake the Apostume. It may be eaten alone, or tempered with Endiue water, or Goates wheye, or Barley water. It is good in washing and clensing glisters to soften hard Apostumes being laide to. With Hierapicra, vse it for paine in the guts, with syrupe of Licoras for the reines. That which is shining blacke is best, it cleanseth the blood, and quencheth the blood and choller, and is good in Agues before bloodletting. But to some it is a poyson, especially such as haue slipperie and weake guts, to such it must be giuen with Myrabolanes, Rubarbe, Mastike, and Spikenard. But to them that are much bound, with oile of Almonds, or with Mussilage of Fleawort, it is excellent for ye stopping of the vrine being taken with medicines therefore, as Persley, Alisander seede, Fenell seede, and such like, because it worketh very slowly, some increase the strength thereof with Hysope, or the wheye of Gotes milke. Many giue it with Hierapicra, or with syrupe of Roses solutiue, or the syrupe of Cycorie with Rubarbe, or such like: the dose is commonly one ounce, two houres before dinner. CAts taile, or red Mace, the downe thereof mixt with Swines grease wel washed, healeth burnings skaldings. And the same downe healeth broken and hollowe kibes being laide on. CEdria, the liquour of Cedar swageth toothache being put therein. Eares noyse and dull, put it in with the decoction of Hysope in wine. Being put into dead bodies, it preserueth them from corruption, but it consumeth and corrupteth the flesh of liuing bodies. It killeth lice, and all such vermine, and preserueth against wormes and mothes and such like being anointed therewith. The fruite is good to be eaten against the strangurie, and to prouoke vrine and ye termes. MIxe the iuice with hony, and seethe it in a vessell of Copper or Brasse, and drop it into the eyes to cleare the sight, and to auoide the spots, skars, blemishes, bloodshooting web. Mixe it with wine, and wash fretting and consuming sores therewith to heale them. Seethe ye roote in white wine with Anniseedes, and drinke it for ye stopping of the liuer the Iaundies. dayes to all Ringwormes, Tetters, Impetigo, and Serpigo, and blacke spots, wheresoeuer they be morning and euening to heale them. Seeth it in white wine and receiue the vapour thereof into the mouth to heale the kanker, and to asswage the paine that commeth by watching. Stampe it with olde grease, brimstone, and salte, and anoint all balde places therewith, and to helpe the skabbes and griefes of the head. Seethe a good handfull of the rootes in a pint and halfe of Rose vineger, and put thereto one ounce a halfe of Treacle, and drinke thereof ii. or iii. ounces, couer thee well to sweate against ye plague. Apply the herbe or iuice to heale fistulaes, creeping sores, pockes kankers. The roote with the hearbe stamped and applied to the nauell, helpeth the torments of the guts. Seethe the hearbe in wine, and apply to the belly against the chollike. Eies bloodshot, stampe Celondine with Wormewood, with the white of an Egge, and Rose water, and apply it when you goe to bed. Breast kanker, apply the iuice with ye dung of a white Goose. Anoint any chaps wheresoeuer with ye iuice thereof vineger when you goe to bed. Drinke the iuice of it to driue forth ye water of ye dropsie by vrine. For the headache, boyle Celondine with butter, and streine it keepe it in a close boxe, and anoint therewith: it is a precious oyntment, and also wash the head with the decoction thereof afterwarde. Iaundies: seethe the roote in stale, and drinke it three dayes. Kanker, wash it well with wine or vineger, and then apply the iuice of the hearbe and rootes thereof. The iuice drieth vp wounds, and with swines grease it healeth them vp. Iaundies, seethe the roote hearbe of Celondine chopped small one pottell, in water in a close vessel, and make thereof to bathe therein. Take powder of Columbine seedes two drams, Saffron one penie waight, vineger water one ounce, Celondine water two ounces, and drinke it first and last, stampe the greene roote as much as a Walnut, and streine it with a dishfull of milke or wine, and drinke it iiii. houres before meate, and walke after it. Legs blacke and swolne, stampe it with Horehound, and hearbe Benit, and seethe it in water to the one halfe, and wash therewith iii. or iiii. times eueryday. Sores olde and stinking, mixe the iuice of it and Planten with Hony, and the yolke of an Egge ana with Barley flowre, and apply it rawe. Skabs to heale, anoint with the iuice and Brimstone. For all diseases of the liuer, lungs, Iaundies, all other griefes, seethe the iuice of it with possitale, and clarifie it drinke it with Sugar. To make one to breake winde, make powder of the roote, Ants egs, and a little ginger, and giue it in meate or drinke, and he shall fart till he drinke water. Ringwormes, anoint with the iuice of Celondine, or mixe musterde with blacke sope, and the iuice of Celondine, and apply it. Eies web and pearle, streine the iuice of it with Aloes, drop thereof into the eie. Gout burning, stampe Celondine and frie it with guilts grease, and put thereto as much powder of brimstone, as will hill the sore, and anoint therewith. Skab generall, anoint with the iuice of Celondine, Rue, Centorie, and Wormewood. Face freckles, anoint with the iuice of Celondine and wine, dayly till it be well. Iaundies, stampe Celondine with ye rootes thereof one pound, of Licoras raced, a quarter of a pound, seethe them in a gallon of water to the one halfe, and drinke thereof. Itch, take white vineger one pinte, Rosemary and Celondine ana one handfull, boile them streine them, and put in a quantitie of white Coprose, while it is hote, and wash often therewith. For all sores, especially greene sores, put in the iuice of Celondine and Houseleeke ana into the wound, and apply the bruised herbes. Head pushes, sores, or biles, beate olde grease, Brimstone, Celondine, and salt, and anoint therewith. Eies sight to restore, mixe the iuice with the gall of a Cocke and honie, and anoint. Squincie, swelling in the mouth, and to purge the head, stampe the roote, and seeth it in wine and gargarise therewith. Eies dull, put in the iuice of Celondine (See in Alisander. Fellon, apply the iuice of Celondine and Planten, and it will goe away. Iaundies, seeth the rootes of Celondine, and Nettles in white wine, and put honie to it, and drinke it morning and euening. Teeth to fall out without paine, rub them with the iuice of Celondine, and apply the substance. Canker in the pap, anoint with the iuice of Celondine and Gotes doung. Drinke it with thine owne vrine if thou hast drunke poyson. Lay it vnder a sicke mans head, with the heart of a Moldwarpe, if he be in danger of death, he will immediatly crie out or sing, if not, he will weepe. Tetter, Ringworme, or such like, and blacke spots, stampe it, and apply it morning and euening fourteene dayes. Bitings or stingings venemous, stampe it with as much Planten and some stale vrine, and applie it and drinke the iuice of Planten. Eyes pinne, or webbe, drop in the iuice of Celondine. Ringworme, stampe it betweene two stones, and applye it often. Stampe it with olde suet, and applie it to skabbes and vlcers, and woundes to heale them speedily. Yarde canker, boile the iuice of Celondine and Planten, and a little salte, and apply it betweene the yarde the skinne thereof. Skabs to drie vp and heale, anoint often with the iuice of Celondine. Canker, seethe the powder of Celondine and Roses in vineger, till it be thicke as mustard, and anoint. Blacke Iaundies, kneade Rie meale with the iuices of Celondine, Smalage, and Wormewood ana one handfull, and bake it on the hearth, and receiue vp the vapour of it at the mouth, hanging a kerchiefe ouer thy head, and doe so foure or fiue times, and bee whole. For all diseases of the liuer, lunges, Iaundies, and all other inward griefes, seethe the iuice of Celondine with possit ale, and clarifie it, and drinke it with Sugar. Face freckles Fellon Fistula Goute hote Greefes generall Guts paines Headache Head griefes Head to purge Head pushes Iaundies Legs blacke Leprie Liuer stopt Mad dogs biting Morphewe Mouth canker Plague Poyson Ringwormes Sores greene Squincie Stingings Teeth ache Teeth to fall out Tetters CEntorie: for wormes that eate ye haires of the head and face, mixe the gall of an oxe or sheepe with Centorie, and boyle them in wine or vineger, and anoint therewith. Eyes red and dull, put in the iuice of it and of hounds tongue. Eares dull, put in the iuice with the gall of an eele with tents. Appetite to cause, seethe Centorie and Planten, and Pepper in wine, and drinke it luke warme three nights to bedward. Coughes drie, seethe it in stale ale and stampe it and seethe it againe in the same ale, and streine it and put thereto a third part of honie, and boyle it till it be as thicke as honie, and take thereof iii. spoonefull fasting to clense the stomacke from gleete be whole. Reines griefe, drinke the iuice with vineger: biting or stinging, the iuice with water. To prouoke appetite, and to cleanse the stomacke and breast, and to purge the backe and reines, and heale them, seethe it in water and drinke it. Wormes, seeth it with Wormewood in milke, and drinke it fasting. Braine weake, mixe Centorie, Rue, and Fenell seede, with strong vineger, and drinke it in the mornings, and shaue thy head, and apply thereto a blacke Cocke clouen through the midst foure twentie houres, and then bleede in the master veine of the head and in the arme likewise. Breast griefes, seethe it in white wine, and stampe it and seethe it againe therein and streine it, and drinke two or three spoonefull with Sugar candie as oft as neede is. Eyes watring, apply Centorie to the nape of the necke. Flegme to breake and voide, seethe it in white wine or ale with Licoras, and streine it and drinke it with Sugar morning and euening, and for horsenesse with Sugar candie. Stinging of a Snake or Adder, steepe it in newe Ale and streyne it and drinke it, and also stampe thereof with gray salt, and apply it to the wounde. Feuer quarten, stampe it and streine it with ale, and drinke it before the fit. Feuer quotidian, drinke as much powder as one small Walnut with wine, and drinke a little more wine after it to cleanse thy mouth. Feuer of the gall, drinke one dramme of the powder three mornings fasting with white To cleanse the head, cheast, and stomacke, seethe iii. handfull in a gallon of water, to the one halfe, cleanse it, and put thereto one pinte of hony clarified to the one halfe, and drinke two spoonefull at once first and last. Dropsie, distill it with Sage and water Cresses, of eache like much, and drinke the water first and last. Palsie, seethe it in wine and oyle, and apply it for ache of the backe, and all euils within the body, drinke it with colde water. Spitting matter, seethe it in oyle of Masticke, and anoint the chest therewith where it is sore. Eares wormes put in the iuice of Centory and Leekes. Drinke the iuice foure mornings to haue a cleere voyce, and to cleanse the breast meruailously. For all griefes in the stomake, and to cause appetite, stampe two handfull, and seethe it in three quartes of Ale to the one halfe, then put thereto one pinte of hony, and take thereof euery morning three spoonefull. Stampe Gentian one part, Centory two parts, and distill them, and drinke the water morning and euening to preserue the bodie from all diseases, to voide all impostumes, to cause a good coullour, to resist the plague, to helpe the ptysicke, to cleanse the stomacke and milte from watrish humors, to breake the stones in the reynes, and to prouoke the flowers, and to purge the belly, voide choller, and cleanse the blood, to heale all inward woundes, to cleare the sight, and cure venemous bitings, but to cure the wounds, put powder of Centory to it, and vse it nine dayes. Wormes, seethe it in water to the third part, and drinke it. Eyes griefes, anoint with the iuice and hony. Wound swelling, stampe it and apply it. Feuers colde, anoint the pulses and plants with the iuice. Blood casting, drinke the iuice of it and Cheruile with Pease broth. Breath stinking, belching, and losse of appetite, and to cleanse the chest and stomacke, seethe it in wine or water, and drinke it. Thirst continuall, stampe it with the roote of Louage, drinke them with wine or water iii. nights to bedward. Eies to be cleare, put in the iuice of Centory the greater with hony. Drinke the iuice or powder with wine to helpe all venemous bitings, but with vineger for inward poyson. Anoint the sores of the bitings with the iuice of it. To open a wound, stampe it well, and applie it. The water of it helpeth the griefes of the liuer and milt, causeth appetite, and is good for the wormes, and salsflegme. Brest flegme, and the stomake, steepe the tops of greene Centory in ale or beere all night, drinke it fasting, but in winter take the roote with white wine. Breast to clense, seethe Centory Hysope in white wine, and drinke it iii. dayes. Seeth it in water or wine to purge downeward chollerike, flegmatike, and grosse humors, for the sciatica, purge therewith till the blood come. It is very good against the stopping of the liuer, the Iaundies, and hardnesse of the milt. The decoction drunke, killeth and expelleth wormes, and is good for the crampe, and all diseases of the sinowes. The iuice applied in a pessarie, prouoketh termes, and expelleth the dead birth. Stampe the hearbe greene, and apply it to heale fresh and newe wounds, and olde vlcers that are hard to cure. The pouder thereof in plasters and oyntments, powders such like, filleth vp hollowe fistulaes, sores with flesh, and doeth molifie all hardnesse. Drinke the syrupe thereof with a litle vineger and salt to clense the body. The leaues and flowres sodden and drunke, is good against all rawe humors of grosse flegmes watrie or windie, it doeth clense blooddy matter within the body of man or woman. The powder in a pessarie draweth foorth the dead birth. It is holsome against the plague in the Winter time. The decoction of it is good in glisters for the sciatica. The iuice put in with wooll, draweth downe the termes. Centory is good against the stopping of the milt and liuer, the chollike, the ache of the mother, spitting blood, and to kil wormes. And applied to the region of the milt, it doeth soften it. The iuice may be streyned out and dryed against the Sunne for all griefes aforesaid in this wise: gather it when it is redy to seede, steepe it fiue dayes in water and seethe it, till the better halfe be wasted, then streyne it, and seethe it againe to the thickenesse of hony, and so keepe it: the like may be done with any herbe or flower. Breth stinking see breast clense Bruised Choller Chollike Consumption Cough drie web Face deformed Feuers cold of the gall quotidian quarten Fistula Flegme see purg. CEtrache: milt stopt, and feuer quarten, take the leaues fourtie dayes with vineger, or boyle it in wine, and apply it to the It also is very good for the strangurie, stone in the bladder, heate of the vrine, yexing, stopping of the liuer, and the Iaundies: but it is not good for women that would haue many children. Feuer quarten Iaundies Liuer stopt Milt hard Stone Strangurie Vrine hote Cherytree. CHerytree: Ringworme, and Tetter, dissolue the gumme in vineger, and anoint therewith. Eyes mystie, dropping and red, put in water of the flowres distilled in May, morning and euening colde. Stampe the middle rinde, and streine it with white wine, and drinke it iii. or iiii. times to voide the stone, grauel, and vrine presently. Headache of choller, bleede in the veine of the liuer, and eate sower Cheries. Iaundies, seethe a handfull of the leaues in a pinte of milke, and drinke thereof a good draught morning and euening. For the heate of the liuer and stomake, and the hote feuer, and to cause appetite, eate conserue of Cheries in the mornings sixe houres before any other meate. For heate in the night by the feuer, holde the conserue in thy mouth. Feuers of hote blood, drinke the syrupe of Violets, and water wherein blacke Cheries haue beene sodden. Falling euill, drinke the water of the leaues or flowers. The gum dissolued in olde wine and drunke by sups, easeth the sharpe arteries of the breast, and voydeth belching lothing. Sweete Cheries eaten fasting with their kernels, looseth the belly so strongly, that the feete being sore shall bee healed thereby. Cheries sodden in vineger with Peares and drunke with Masticke, doe greatly binde the bellye. The gumme doeth mightely breake the stone, and loose the grauell. Make Conserue of Cheries as of Barberies, but not with so much Sugar. Cheries eaten before meate, loosen the belly very gently, but they nourish but litle, and are hurtfull vnto moyst and vnhealthy stomakes, especially the small Cheries, which doe often breede agues, and other maladies. The red sowre Cheries doe likewise loosen the belly, and are more holsome and conuenient for the stomake, for they doe partly comfort, and partly slake thirst. The blacke sowre Cheries doe strengthen the stomake more then the rest, and being dryed, they stop the laske. The gumme of the mazer or wilde Cherytree, of the Spanish Cherie, and our common sower Cherytree is good to be drunke in wine for the grauell and the stone, and excoriation of the throte, lungs, and breast, the cough and hoarsenesse. The water distilled of the fresh and newe gathered Cheries, is good to be powred into the mouthes of them that haue the falling sickenesse, as often as the course of the fit doeth trouble them. Cheries breede good blood, cause appetite, cut flegme and grosse humors, expell vrine, and soften the belly, being eaten when they are fresh: and being condited with sugar, they are good for them that be sicke of inflammations and extreame heates. And being dryed in an ouen, they are good against all flures. The distilled water of the wilde blacke Cheries, is good for them that haue lost their speeche. The gumme dissolued in wine, is good for the olde cough. Tart Cheries be more holsome then sweete, and eaten before meate, they mollifie the belly, and prepare digestion, and are most excellent in hote burning choller, and are good also after meate. The gumme sodden in Wine and drunke, helpeth olde coughes, causeth good coullour, sharpeneth the sight, helpeth digestion, and clenseth out grauell from the reines. The stones breake the stone, if they be eaten drie or made milke. Preserued Cheries and Plummes, are without danger: but beware of surfetting by Cheries rawe. CHeruill eaten with other meates is good for the stomake, it giueth taste to meate, and causeth appetite. Strangurie, boyle it in wine and drinke it, and also apply the herbe to the region of the bladder. It is good for them that be dull, old without courage, to reioyce and to comfort them, and increase their strength. It dissolueth bruised blood, especially with the powder of the burned eyes of crabs, and the coles of the Linden tree. It is good for the plurisie and pricking in the side. Being vsed in sallads, it is good for the stomake and head. The leaues bruised and applyed, are a good remedie against bruises, it is good for the stone in the kidneys. Liuer and milt stopt, eate Cheruil and vse powder of the seedes of it. Swellings sudden in the lims, Seethe Cheruil, Hartstong chopped smal with dregs of ale, wheat bran sheeps sewet, till they be thicke, and apply it. For a woman that hath her throwes before her time, seethe a good handful in a quart of Claret wine, drinke thereof at all times needfull. Mouth ranker, apply the iuice of Cheruill and Woodbine often to it. The herbe is very good against Carbuncles, and venemous bytings. Drink it with wine to prouoke vrine, and to take away the ache in the reins and bladder. It also expelleth winde and helpeth the griefes of the liuer, and all kindes of madnesse, and staieth vomiting. And stampt with vineger it destroyeth the wildefire, and healeth the canker and all other wounds. For wounds that penetrate, drink the iuice of Cheruil, or the decoction, or water thereof, or of Cheruill. To know whether a wounded man shall liue or die, let him drinke it, if he cast it not vp he shall liue and be cured, let him drinke dayly Pimpernell, Sanicle, and Bugle. Wounds bleeding and sore within, drinke Cheruil, and Nep in wine. For all griefes of the mouth, seethe it in water and wash therewith often. Leane to be, take one egshell full of the iuice euery morning fasting. Mouth Canker Plurisie Reines ache Sides ache Sides pricking Stone CHestnuts are best kept and preserued amongst Wallnuts, eate them fasting with hony for the cough. Flux to stop, boyle the middle red barke in water to the third part and drinke thereof. Chestnuts of all wilde fruites are the best and meetest to be eaten, for they nourish reasonably well, but they be hard of digestion, and doe stop the belly: with the meale of Chestnuts and hony, is made a good electuarie against the cough spetting of blood. The powder thereof with barly meale and vineger applyed, doeth cure vnnaturall blastings and swellings of the breasts. The polished red barke boyled and drunke doeth stop the laske, the bloody flixe and all other flixes and issues of Chestnuts make fat, stop flixes, and harden the milt. Stamp them with hony and salt and apply it to the biting of a mad dog to heale it. They cause lust, and offend the head and milt. Prick through the husks with a knife and rosted and eaten with hony fasting, they are good for the cough, but their chiefe force is in binding stopping flixes. CHickweed, great Chickweed stampt applyed to the eyes, or the iuice thereof is good against all their inflammations and hote vlcers, and likewise for all vlcers and inflammations of the priuie partes. Boyle small Chickweed in water and salt, and wash the hands often therewith for their heate and skyruy itch. Ioynts ach and swollen, seethe it with Camomil and wheat bran in grounds of Ale or Beere and apply it. Stamp Chickweed and apply it to wounds to keepe them from impostumation and to drawe the corruption out of them. Seethe it with vineger gargle therewith often warme, to drawe flegme from the head, and to helpe the tooth ache. Seethe it in wine and drinke it to clense the reines of the backe. Apply it with barley meale to the inflammations of the eyes. Apply it to all inflammations or gatherings of blood and choller. It is good for wounds, it withstandeth swellings, it draweth out pricks and splents. The iuice helpeth tooth ache put into the nostrell of the contrary side to the ache. The iuice with fine hony, cleareth the eyes, and taketh away the white or red spots thereof. It is good for the stone in the kidneys, the dropsie, griefes of the liuer and kidneys, the swelling of the fundament. The iuice put into ye nose, purgeth rotten filth from the head, drunk with mulse, it scowreth the belly. and of Purslen, and is good against consumptions either vsed by it selfe or drunke with wine. The same is good to be giuen to yong children that bee troubled with sicknesse and great inward heate, and to preuent the cramps. The iuice it selfe or the water or herbe is good against hote wounds or vlcers, and therewith may be made cooling oyntments as is sayd in housleeke, as good as Populeon. Seethe it bruised in running water to the one halfe, and wash therewith three or foure dayes as hote as may be suffered for the heate wormes in the hands. Vvula fallen, rost one handfull in the embers, and apply it to the bone of the necke as hote as may be suffered, and lay a plaister of sower leauen to the molde of the head ix. dayes. Eye perle, apply it with the gleyr of an egge, a litle dry Saffron, and a spoonefull of womans milke, with flaxe vpon the eye. Stone and Strangurie, stampe one handfull with blacke sope and fresh butter of eche as much as a nutmeg, and fry them, and apply them to the nauell. Teeth ache, seethe the leaues and rootes in water and gargle therewith. Bruise and apply it with grounds of Ale or Beere, and wheat bran thrise a day of a reasonable thicknesse. Stone and chollick, take Chickweed one handfull, bright sope, and sweet butter ana as much as three nuts, fry them till they be browne, apply it to the nauell as hote as may be suffered. Headach, anoynt with the iuice of Chickweed, ground Iuy and Housleek two nightes, to auoyd it. Iaundies, stamp it and streine it with stale ale or white wine, and drinke it first and last fiue dayes. Child iaw fallen, moldfall, or roofe fallen, rost one handfull in the embers, and apply it to the bone of the necke, and apply sower leauen of white bread to the mold of the head ix. houres to raise it. Seethe the leaues and rootes in water, and hold it in thy mouth to voyd the toothach. Eyes blood and white spots, put in the iuice of Chickweed and blackbery tops. Seethe Chickweed and apply it to the pecten yard, if the paine increase, the stone is in the bladder, if not, it is in the reines. Flowers stopt, rost it in the embers and apply it to the matrixe. Cramp, eate the iuice with fresh beefe or mutton or in a sallad. CInnamom comforteth the stomacke and principall partes of the body. An excellent water of Cinnamom, beate one pound of good Cinnamom somewhat grosse, and steepe it in a pottell of good rose water with as much Sacke or Canary wine, or els in a gallon of wine without rose water in a close vessel xxiiii. houres, then still it in a limbek, and keepe a pinte of the first water by it selfe, for the latter wil be weaker: some put one pound of good Sugar candy to it with the Cinnamom to steep to make it pleasant, and that is the best way. It hath innumerable vertues especially to restore and preserue: it strengtheneth the brain, stomacke, liuer, milt and sinewes, one spoonefull taken nowe and then. Cinnamom helpeth the stopping of the liuer, flixes of all sortes, the dropsie, all paine of the guts, lungs and breast. It causeth a sweete breath, and is good in sops and blaunch powder. Eares griefes, vse it with oyle: flowers and vrine stopt, vse it with Myrrhe. Stomacke colde, make powder of Cinnamom, Galangal, Mints, and Sugar, and vse it vpon tostes with Ale or Wine. Mix powder of Cinnamom and Corall with vineger of squilles, Yard apostumed, blow in powder of Cinnamom that hath lost his vertue, and of the pil of a Pomegranate betweene the skin and the yarde. Acorns, with two drams of Cinnamom, and a quantitie of fine chalke, and seethe them in Sacke, and drink it and none other drink xxiiii. houres. In paste, one pound of the powder of it with oyle of sweet Almonds till it be like an oyntment, and warme it, and let it stand in a earthen vessel wel glased and close couered xiiii. dayes, then heat it and presse out the oyle, it preserueth the stomack from corruption being vsed both inward and outward. Belly griefes Breast griefes Breath ill Chaps Chollick Dropsie Eares griefes Fluxes generall Lungs griefes Milt griefe Sinewes griefes Sicknesse generall Stomack griefes Liuer paine, vse the broth, decoction, or powder of Cicory or Endiue with water hony. Breasts to be round, little, and hard, anoynt them with the iuice. Headache, anoynt with the iuice, oyle of roses and vineger, apply it. Iaundies, seethe the roots flowers in wine with as much water, drink thereof morne and euen. Liuer griefes cut three or foure roots, and seethe them in a quart of water till the third part or more be wasted, then coole it drink thereof in the mornings, but not too much at once. The iuice openeth the stoppings of the liuer, milt, kidneys, and bladder caused of heate. The iuice put into the eyes, sharpeneth the sight, and put into the eare or nostrell on the contrary side, it helpeth the tooth ache. Liuer and milt griefes, drink the iuice in the mornings with sugar. and Endiue, doe comfort a weake and feeble stomack, doe coole refresh a hot stomack. Drink the iuice of Cicory for the heat of the liuer, the Iaundies, hote feuers, tertians. Stamp the greene leaues of Endiue and Cicory, and apply them to hot inflammations, impostumes or gatherings of euill humours of the stomacke, the trembling of the heart, the hot gout, and inflammation of the eyes. And with parched barly meale to all chollerick inflammations, S. Anthonies fire, and such like. Apply the iuice of the leaues in Cicory and Endiue, with oyle of roses and vineger to the forehead for the head ache. And with ceruse and vineger to all tumours, impostumes inflammations that require cooling. Seethe the herbes and eate them for the heat stopping of the liuer and milt, and to comfort the stomacke. Vse Cycory and Endiue any way to coole the heate of the liuer, to open and strengthen it, and to preserue health, especially in the broth of a Chicken, or drinke a good draught fasting with sugar, or the syrop, or the greene herbes vsed as Sage in Ale. Seethe a handfull of Cicory in water, and drinke it to drawe downe choller.
