Seethe the herbe and roote of Cicory in Wine or water, and drinke it hote against the obstruction of the liuer and mile, especially in the beginning of the dropsie. Apply Cicory leaues to all impostumes, swellings, inflammations and pusshes of the priuities, the hote goute, the scabs of childrens heads, and to all aches comming of heate. Seethe Cicory in Wine, and eate it with meate to helpe digestion. Stamp the root and flowers, and apply them to the goute to ease it foorthwith, and to the holy fire to allay the great heate of it. Mixe the iuice of Cicory, Endiue, and Hartestong with sugar, and seethe it with a litle water vineger, and vse often to drinke it for the stopping of the liuer and milt, after that take the purging pilles of Rubarbe, and after that some Triasandali. Drinke the boyled iuice of Cicory to losen the belly, and to helpe the stomacke, liuer, and kidneys. Apply the distilled water to the pestilent pusshes with linnen clothes. Bruise the herbe and root, and make thereof round cakes which afterwards mixe and dissolue in rose water, and anoynt any scabbed place therewith to heale it and make the skinne faire. Gather the flowers betime in the mornings, and distil them in Balneo Mariae, and vse the water for the pinne, webbe, mystines, and vlcers, diuers other griefes of the eyes. Cast the flowers of Cycory among a heape of Ants or pismires, and they wil soone become as red as blood. CIcers white, apply a plaister of the meale to the apostume of the cods. Scabs in the head or els where, wash with the decoction of Ciches peason. CYperus, or English Galangal, make powder of ye root with Amber Pepper, drink it for the grauel, stone stopping of vrine, and to swage the paine. Matrix paine of wind, drinke one dram of the root with good white wine. The roots boyled drunk, prouoke vrine and termes, expelleth the stone, is good for the dropsie, poyson, venemous bytings and stingings. Vse powder thereof to old running sores of the mouth and secret partes that waste the flesh, layd on with wine. It is very good to be put into hote oyntments plaisters. The seeds drunk with water, stop the flixe and all superfluous running foorth of flowers, but too much thereof taken causeth headach. The roots laid among clothes, giueth them a sweet smell. Powder of the root mixt with as much powder of Bayes, and drunke with the vrine of a chast boy and also applyed on the belly, helpeth the dropsie marueilously. CIpers tree: the fruite taken into the body stoppeth the laske and the bloody flixe, spetting blood all issues of blood, and so doth the decoction thereof made in water. The oyle wherein the fruit or leaues haue bene sodden, doeth strengthen the stomack, stoppeth vomiting, stoppeth the belly all other fluxes of the same, cureth the excoriation going off of the skin from the secret partes. Cipres nuts cure them that are bursten and haue their gut fallen into their cods being applied, so doth the leaues. The fruite thereof taketh away the polip in the nose. The same bruised with fat dry figs doeth cure the swelling of the cods, and with leauen put thereto, it dissolueth botches byles being applied. The leaues boyled in sweet wine or honyed water, doeth helpe the strangurie and issue of the bladder. The same stampt small cureth greene wounds, stoppeth their bleeding being applyed. And with parched barly meale it is good to be layd to the wildfire, carbuncles and other vlcers and hote fretting sores. The leaues fruit layd to with vineger maketh haire blacke. Byles Bladder griefes Blood to stop Bloody flixe Botches Bursten Carbuncles Cods swollen Nose polip Priuities griefes Sores Stomack weake Strangury Vlcers Vomiting Wildfire Wounds Citrons. To giue Wine a sweete odour sticke it or an Orenge full of Cloues, hang it into the vessel, so that it touch not the Wine, stop it vp close that the odour go not out. CLary: fry the leaues with newlayd egs butter, with powder of Cinnamom, and eate them morne and euen, first last vii. dayes to stop the running of the reines. Distill the flowers with Cloues, wine, and a little water, and vse the water for dull eyes. Wash a canker or fester with the iuice, and put in powder of the same herbe and vse it. Feuers flegmatick, make an electuarie of the iuice of Clary, Smallach, and Fenell and vse it. Reines running, make a tansy of Clary and eate it. Reines wasting, pricke the leaues, fry them with two or three yolks of egs and powder of saffron, and fry them with fresh butter eate it fasting. Feete bruised and sore, anoynt with the iuice of Clary. Seethe Clary Nep of eche a handfull in possit ale and drinke it to bedward with Grayns, long Pepper, Ginger. Whites to stop, fry it with butter and eate it fasting with Cinnamom, it is a restoratiue. In what sort so euer it be taken, it prouoketh the flowers, expelleth the seconds, and prouoketh lust. Boyled in Beere in stead of Hops, it causeth drunkennesse, headach, and it hath all the vertues of wild Clary. The seeds stamped with water and applyed, draweth forth pricks, splents, and thorns, scattreth all swellings, so doeth the greene herb stampt applyed. The seed especially of Occulus Christi drunke with wine prouoketh Put two or three seeds into the eyes to clense them and draw out mothes. Chop the leaues small, and boyle them in sallet oyle and anoynt the backe therewith for the griefe thereof. Clary with hony scowreth away the pinne hawe and web in the eye. Clary is good for the backe, and is a restoratiue in a a waste. bundle of the leaues boyled in broth or fryed with yolks of egs, and being often vsed bringeth great ease. Clary put into newe must a certaine time, or els sodden therewith, is good for them that haue cold stomacks, and for barren women, and such as are troubled with the whites, and it cutteth flegme. The powder of Clary put into the nose, bringeth downe much water from the braine, and causeth sneesing. It is good in womens baths that want their flowers being sodden with Penyroyall and other herbes of like vertue. Seethe it with Planten in red wine, drink it to stop the whites. Seethe it in wine drink it against colde griefes, to stop the whites, it hath the nature of Dittany. With hony it clenseth the bloody spots in the eyes. Consumption of nature, make a tansy of xii. or xvi. leaues of Clary, foure new layd egs, and sweet butter, vse it to restore nature. Seconds Sneesing to cause Sores Stomack cold Whites to stop CLauer or Trifoyl, boile it wt the flowers, or by it self in honied water or wine, drink it to swage the hot burning fretting of the bowels, or seethe it in water, take it with a glister for the same purposes. The flowers or leaues sodden in oile, applied, doth ripen hot apostumes swellings other tumors breaketh them, Wash thy head with the decoction thereof and apply the herbe vnto the forehead for the swimming, giddines turning thereof. The seeds and leaues sodden in wine and drunk, helpeth the diseases of the sides, the falling sicknes, the dropsie, the strangury both in men women, and purgeth the humours menstruall. Drinke three drams thereof with wine, to helpe all venemous bitings, and it wil suffer no venom to come within the body, and so it helpeth both tertians and quarten Feuers. It preuaileth much against poyson or venom, if xxv. grayns of the leaues or seedes be drunke. That with the red flowers or Hony suckles may be vsed for Fenegreke. Seethe it well and apply it to any inwarde impostume to breake it. Eyes griefes, put in the iuice of that which hath white spots on it. Stampe it finely rawe with hony, and anoynt to restore the haire, and to keepe it from falling: prooued. Head giddy daseling swimming, seethe it in water and wash therewith and apply the herbe to the forehead. Feuer tertian, stamp three slips, drink the iuice with water. Eyes perle or web, put in the iuice, it cleareth the sight, (See Honysuckle, Trifoyl. Treacle, or garden Clauer, ye leaues, flowers, or seeds drunk in water, is good for the paine in the sides, the plurisie, strangury, falling sicknesse, the dropsie, suffocation of the mother. The leaues taken with Oximel, is good against venemous bitings, so is the decoction thereof with the root being also washt therewith. The leaues and roots are mixt with Treacles Mithridates, and preseruatiues made against poyson and the plague. Drink three crops with wine before the fitt of the feuer Tertian, foure before the fitt of the feuer Quarten. Boyle the leaues in wine, and drinke it for the white fluxe of the matrix. CLoues comforteth the heart stomacke and liuer, they helpe digestion stop the belly, they quicken the eye sight, scoure away the cloudes and hawes. The oyle of Cloues is good for a colde stomacke and braine, and all cold griefes. Cloues comfort the sinewes and dissolue superflous humours: and being sodden whole in milke, or the powder eaten in milke, they comfort the debilitie of nature, and stirre vp Venus. They are vsed both in meate and medicine to giue a sweete sauour, and likewise to distilled waters and powders. To dry vp rheume, mixe powder of Cloues, Mace, Nutmegs, and Rosemary with sweete Sallet oyle till it bee some what thicke, and apply it to the crowne of the head. Vomiting, drinke foure grayns of Cloues with foure or fiue spoonefuls of red wine. Stone, put powder of Cloues into Goats blood, and dry it in the sunne, and drinke the powder thereof with the iuice of Mugwort. Mother suffocat. take vp the of Cloues, grayns, Frankincense, other sweet smelling things into the body. Stomacke griefes generall, seethe Cloues halfe an ounce, sugar aquartre: of a pound, Treacle a peniworth, a litle in a quart of Malmsey, and drink thereof dayly warme, vse good meates. Braine weake, vse Cloues and in brothes also in the nose. Gums gnawen, seethe powder of Cloues in rose water, dry it, do so often, then vse the powder of it. stinke, wash it with vineger and water, then chew Mastick a good while, then seethe Cloues Aniseeds and Mints in wine, and wash therewith. To comfort the stomack after vomiting, take pouder of two Cloues with one spooneful of the iuice of Mints morne and euen. For agewes and all other sicknesses, take powder of Cloues and Pepper of eche like much, as much as will lye on a groat or six pence at once fasting, drinke not two houres after it. Stomack weake, steep hot bread in good wine, and cast powder of Cloues and Nutmegs on it, and apply it. Cardiack pas. Digestion Eyes dull Feuers generall Fluxes Gums griefes Heart cardi. COleworts: put them into scalding water, let them be but halfe sodden, powre out almost all ye water from them, then put thereto a litle salt, oyle and Cummin, heat them together a litle more, when the broth is somewhat cold, fup thereof also eate the Wort, to prouoke vrin, and doe so dayly till you be well. Bruise the tender leaues and stalks, and apply them to all swellings, vlcers and cankers morne and euen to heale them. But the cankers must be first washt with warme water. It helpeth also bruises and cankers of the paps, but if this medicine be too sharp, put barly meale to it and apply it. Beate Coleworts rawe with Rue, and the herbe of Coriander shreaded together, or a litle salt and barly meale with Oximel mixed together, and with the whole anoynt the gout and ache of the ioynts to helpe them in short time. Stamp the same herbes with wine and strein out the iuice, drop it warme into the eares to help their deafnesse in short time. Mix the iuice with the purest hony, drop thereof into the corners of the eies to help diuers griefes of them. Drink the iuice xl. daies with white wine to cure both the Iaundies the diseases of ye milt. Mix iii. parts of the iuice with ii. parts of Allom infused in vineger, and anoynt therewith the foule scurfe and leapry to heale it. Mixe the iuice with meale of Fenegreke and vineger, and apply it to gouts, aches of the ioints, and filthie vlcers to clense heale them. Draw vp the iuice into the nose to purge the brain. Drink the iuice wt wine to help the biting of an adder or snake. Hold iuice with oyle in thy mouth to heale the blisters therof. Rost the greene stalks roots in the embers temper them with barowes grease, apply it to heale ye continuall paine stitches in the sides. Eat Coleworts raw with vineger often to help the griefes of the milt. If it be eaten alone, it ingendreth troubled blood and melancholy, yeeldeth smal nourishment, but the tenderer that it is sodden with fat flesh or hens flesh ye holsomer it is. The first broth of ye herb softneth the belly, prouoketh vrin, but the eating of the substance bindeth the belly. To dry a moyst belly, boyle the herb a while, powre out the broth, powre in quickly other seething water, boyle it till it be very tender, then eat ye substance thereof seasoned with Pepper salt to bind the belly, but eate the substance broths together and then it worketh temperately, so that the broth of the first seething loosneth the belly, and the substance of the second seething doeth bind it. To cause children to go soone on foot, let them eate Coleworts tenderly sodden. If thou wouldest drink much at supper, eat the raw leaues wt vineger beforehand, after supper eat againe iiii. or v. leaues raw, they wil make thee so fresh hungry, as though thou hadst neither eaten nor drunk at supper or banket, and so thou mayst drink as much wine as thou wilt not be drunken. If any drop some drops of wine vpon them as they are boyling fast, they will boyle no more but change their colour as it were a thing dead in it selfe. Colewort especially the Cabbage cole boyled, is very good with beefe with vineger Pepper, but the much vse thereof breedeth melancholy, causeth euil dreames, hurt the stomack, dul the sight. But eaten last they preserue ye stomack from surfetting, the head Drink the broth of the second seething tempered with Allom to bind ye belly. Stampe Coleworts, and apply it to a newe and red leapry to heale it. The iuice looseth the belly, the latter seething bindeth it, but especially the first seething with Salt peter, or by it selfe purgeth. Drinke the iuice with wine against the bitings of serpents. Eares deafe, put in the iuice with vineger, it helpeth also their noyse. Hoarsenes cough, boyle it as a syrop with hony, and lick often thereof. The broth of any kinde of Colewort with Sugar, or alone, doeth gently loosen the belly, and cause the flowers to passe, and the same broth is good to wash all wounds often, to clense and heale them. The yong leaues eaten rawe with vineger or perboyled, doe open the belly very gently, prouoketh vrine, and are good for the milte, and taken after meales in the same maner, doe cure drunkennesse and headache comming thereof. The same alone or with parched barly meale, are very good to be layd to blewe markes of bruises or stripes, and other hote inflammations and swellings. The leaues sodden and applyed with hony, are very good for consuming sores and filthy. The seedes taken with Mede, kill all maner of wormes. The asshes of the burned stalkes mixt with old Swines grease, is good for the olde ache and paine of the side. Seethe the tender part of the herbe till it boyle in water, then stamp it strein it, and drink it with a litle salt and Cummin seede three or foure houres after meate two ounces at once to purge choller marueilously, or els take the rawe iuice with Niter Ireos for the same purpose. Coleworts eaten in meates are good for a weake stomacke, they helpe digestion and suffer not the body to be hard. Seethe the herbe or seede in wine, and drinke it hote against the stinging of serpents. Seethe Colewort with an old Cocke, drinke the broth to helpe the chollick, the torments of the belly, the stoue of the kidneys, and for the griefes of the liuer and mile. Eate two or three leaues raw with salt after meate, to auoyd drunkennesse surfetting. or brothes of them that haue the goute, especially with some Rue and Coliander seede, and so it will purge the more effectually. Stampe the leaues with Hony, to heale all inflammations, aches, creeping sores, vlcers and skabs. The leaues applyed to the head, keepe the haire from falling, and so doth the vrine of him that hath eaten much of it daily, not onely the griefes aforesayde, but also fistulaes, cankers, gangreues, wheales, pushes, and other griefes of the skinne, and therefore Cato wisheth children to be washed therewith against many griefes. The ashes of the stalkes thereof, or of Cabbage mixed with Swines grease, helpeth all flowing griefes of the skinne. The lee made of the same ashes, is good for the holy fire, ringwormes, tetters, shingles, and all such like. Coleworts eaten, are good for them that cannot see well, and for the trembling of the members, the tender buds are best. The iuice drunke with wine, healeth the bitings of serpents and vipers. Put the iuice with Daruell meale into the matrixe, to drawe downe the flowers. The leaues layde too by themselues, or bruised with Barley meale, are good for the inflammations and soft swellings, burnings, impostumes, and cholerike sores or quats like wheales and leapryes, and other griefes of the skinne. The leaues chewed and the iuice sucked downe, restoreth the voyce that is lost. Apply Coleworts with the white of an egge, to burnings and skaldings. The iuice with the wine of raisins, is good for the milt and the yellowe Iaundies, and to prouoke vrine and the termes. Lay a Colewort leafe on the crowne of the head, to draw vp the vuula. Snuf the iuice into the nostrels to purge the head, and to voyde paine and reume. The ashes of the stalkes made into a plaster, letteth the growing vp of haires. Wash the head with lee made of the ashes of Coleworts and of red Nettles, and white wine, to take away the paine without doubt. Glaunders and sores in the mouth, wash them or anoynt them with hony the ashes of Coleworts stalkes. Ach and bruises, seeth red Coleworts and Auens in stale ale or water, and apply it. sodden with waxe. Leg marmoll, wash with the iuice of red Coleworts, wilde Tansy Planten. Sinowes broken, hacke red Colewort rootes small, and seeth it in water to pap, and weete a cloth therein, and apply it. Dropsie, seethe water Cresses, red Coleworts and Sowthistle in water, and drinke it morne and euen. Blood to stop of veine or sinowe, stampe red Nettles and Colewort leaues with Swines dung, and apply it. Eyes watering, apply the leaues of red Coleworts, tempered with the white of an egge when thou goest to bed: proued. Surfet, lay three small leaues of red Coleworts in vineger, and eate them with salt. Hoarsenesse, take the decoction of Coleworts with Penidies and syrope of maiden haire. Cough perillous, anoint a Colewort leafe with butter, and apply it to thy stomacke. by drinking hote wines, drinke the iuice of Coleworts, and apply the substance to thy head. Seethe the herbe and rootes of your red Coleworts in water, to the third part, and foment the sinowes therewith that are shrunke, and there is no better medicine for greene wounds, then to be bathed therewith. Throte apostume or squincie, stampe red Coleworts and Eldren leaues of ech one handfull with butter and hony, of ech one spoonefull, and apply it. Iaundies desperate, make lee with the ashes of Coleworts, and weete a cloth therein, and binde it about thy head warme when thou goest to bed eight nights together, and also wash thy body therewith. Loynes apostumed, mixe Coleworts and Fenigreke together, and apply it. Emerods, take vp the fume of Coleworts sodden, in a close chaire. Side griefes, apply sodden Coleworts with hony. Tongue palsie, chewe well the seedes of red Coleworts, and holde them vnder the roote of thy tongue, it purgeth marueilously. For the hoste, clarifie the iuice of red Coleworts, and put thereto Saffron, Suger, and Hony, and make it an Electuarie and vse it. Belly bound, put the pith of the stalkes into thy fundament. Burning, anoynt with the melted fatte of Bacon, and apply a Colewort leafe. For great paine in the eyes, mixe ashes of the leaues with the yolke of a rosted egge, womans milke, and a little hony, and binde it too. Ache in the backe, belly, and sides, apply the ashes of the branches with stale grease. Milt griefes, eate them with vineger rawe. Matrix windie, seethe a linnen cloth in lee of the ashes, and apply it. Feuer continuall, seethe the leaues with oyle of Roses, and apply it to the stomacke to mitigate the heate. Colewort ought not to be sowen with Rue, because they accord not together. Emerods, sit ouer the decoction of red Coleworts, and wash therewith also. To purge choller and flegme, put a bundle into seething water, while one may goe v. or vi. paces, then stampe them and streine out the iuice, and keepe it in an earthen vessell in the open ayre, then put a little salt and bruised Cumminseede to it, and drinke it in the morning, and walke vpon it iii. or iiii. houres, but you must wash your hands, armes, legs, and feete ouernight with hote water, and goe supperlesse to bed. To drie vp milke, bathe the breastes with the decoction of the leaues. Strayning to goe to the stoole, seethe them in water, and then frie them in oyle and sit ouer it, it helpeth also the Emerods being sodden in water and butter, and the fume receiued vp. Haire not to fall, seethe the stalkes and rootes of red Coleworts in water of a spring to the one halfe, and wash therewith often. Blood to stop Braine to purge (see head) Breast griefes Breast stopt Bruses COlophony, a searecloth for the spleene or stitch, or winde in the body, and to staunch blood, melt it in an earthen pot, and strike it on leather, apply it: but for bleeding, apply it to ye reines and betwixt the shoulders vp to the necke. thereof bindeth the belly, and helpeth the falling of the fundament and matrix, and furthereth conception. Tenasmus, anoint the paynes with hony, and cast powder of Colophony and Cresses, of each like much on it. Shortnesse of breath of colde cause, take vp the fume thereof, the matter being digested and dissolued. Bleeding Breath short Cough Conception Fluxes Fundament fallen Milt Matrix fallen Stitch Windinesse Cockle. COckle: eyes pearle, chewe Cockle in thy mouth, and put in the iuice thereof morning euening. Freckles, mixe Cockle meale with as much of the gall of a Cocke, and apply it one night to take them away. Stampe the meale with the rootes of Daffadil hony, and apply it to any pricke or thing that sticketh in the flesh. Impost to open, apply ye meale sodden with the doung of a Wooddoue in wine. To heale sore tetters, apply ye meale with brimstone vineger. To open the matrix cause conception, seethe Cockle, Myrrhe, white Frankincense, and Saffron in wine or water, and anoint therewith. Conception to cause, take vp the fume of Cockle and Frankincense. Goute, bathe it well with water, seethe oyle in water hony, mixe it with Cockle, apply it. Sores and Tetters to heale, mixe Cockle and brimstone with vineger, and annoint. Headache of reume or murre, blowe in powder of Cockle that groweth among corne. Vrine stopt, apply the meale thereof with hote water to the share. Eye pearle Face freckles Flowres stopt Goute Headache Matrix stopt Prickes Skabs Loynes ache, seeth Garlike Coriander of eache two ounces in a quart of wine till the third part be wasted, then streine it drinke it morne euen. If thou fearest ye comming of an ague, swallowe downe three graines of Coriander fasting. Head swimming dasling, bake it in bread and apply it. Belly swolne, boyle powder of Coliander seede with butter to an oyntment, and vse it. Face salsflegme, mixe Coriander with ye iuice of Hemlock, red Docks with fresh grease a litle quicksiluer, and anoint. Flowers to stopt drinke powder of Coliander, Sanders, Saffron with red wine in the mornings. The iuice drunke, suffereth no fumes to ascend to the head, and for the falling euill. Flowers to stop, drinke as many seedes as thou wouldest stop them dayes. Feuer tertian, take iii. graines of Coriander with a reare Egge after iii. or iiii. fits. Scrophules, Glandules, or kernels, kneade Beane flowre with the iuice of it, and bake it and applie it hote. Carbuncle, or other grieuous byle, apply powder of the seede with hony to destroy it quite. Breath stinking, seethe the seedes in Sacke, and drinke three spoonefull at euen hote, and at morne colde, and forbeare excesse of meates, late sitting vp, early rising. Mixe powder of the seede with vineger, and cast it on meate to keepe it long from corruption, or couer it with meale floure of branne, it may be so kept all sommer. Vvula fallen, seethe powder of the seedes with Rue in water of Myntes, and holde thereof in thy mouth colde. Conception, steepe the seedes in vineger, and drie them, and mixe the powder with powder of Akorne cups, and vse it morne and euen in pottage and drinke. The seedes in receiptes may well be kept two yeeres. The seedes in meates helpe digestion, and are good for the paine in the stomacke and windinesse, and so is the wine of the decoction thereof. The powder of the seedes cast vpon meates, causeth them to digest the better, and with sweete wine it moueth lust, but too much vse of it breedeth the frensie and raging, and the much eating of the herbe and seede together, is venemous to dogs, and killeth them. Coriander comfects represse ye vapors ascending to the head, and therefore are good for the falling sicknesse. The seede may not be eaten rawe but steeped in vineger, or couered ouer with Sugar. Prepared with vineger, and bruised and taken with the iuice of Planten, it staieth great bleeding at the nose. Looke how many graines of the seedes a woman doth take, and so many dayes her course shall runne. The hearbe must not be taken inward, because it hurteth the head the blood. The iuice with vineger doeth coole and heale the holy fire. The seedes a litle bruised, giuen in reasins, doe kil wormes in children. Mixe the iuice with the iuice of Lettuse and of Planten, the white of an egge oyle of Roses, and apply it to hote apostumes, burnings, swellings, blisters, shingles to heale them. Coliander steeped one night in wine or vineger and dried, is good for the stomacke, and against all euill ayre. The hearbe with the meale of Beanes or Fitches, Rose oyle applied, taketh away all inflammations swellings. Apply it with bread or Barley meale to the wilde fire, spreading sores, night plowkes, and with hony and reasyns to inflammations of the stones and carbuncles: with Beane meale it driueth away kernels, hard swellings and wennes. The iuice with white leade or lytarge, vineger oyle of Roses healeth inflammations of the vttermost skinne. It maketh flesh wherewith it is sodden, to haue the taste of spice. Drinke the parched seedes with wine to kill and expell wormes, to stop the bloody Flixe, and all other extraordinarie issues of blood. The fresh and greene hearbe sodden with white bread crums, or Barley meale, consumeth all hote tumours, swellings, inflammations &c. The Comfects eaten after meales, strengtheneth the stomacke. With beane meale it dissolueth the kings euill, hard lumpes, wennes and kernels. Kings euill Loynes ache Lust to cause Meate to keepe Nose bleeding Plague sore Plowkes Seede to increase Shingles COloquintida, the pith or white pulp thereof taken about one scruple, purgeth mightely grosse flegme, choller, slime stinking corruption scrapings of the guts, sometime causeth blood to issue, so it doeth if it be soked or boyled in honied water, or any other liquor so drunke. It is good against al cold dangerous diseases, as ye apoplexia, the falling sicknesse, giddinesse of ye head, paine in fetching of breath, the chollike, loosenesse of the synowes, and places out of ioynt: and for the same purposes it may be taken in glisters suppositories. The oile wherein it hath bin boyled, taketh away the paine in the eares, and the noise. The pulp or pith may be taken with gum Dragagant and Mastike, and after made into balles or trochiskes with hony for the vse of medicine. Steepe one apple of Coloquintida in {per}tis and water twelue houres, then streine it and drinke halfe a pinte of it in the morning to purge melancholie and choller adust, but it is a very grosse purgation: but the trochiskes are better to purge with. Seeth a dramme of Coloquintida in powder with mirts and Oate water to a thicknesse, and make thereof pilles, and vse them. Seeth it in vineger, and holde it in the mouth to kill wormes in the teeth. It killeth wormes in the eares, and also in the bellie, beeing vsed in drinkes or plasters. It is perillous to women with childe, and to weake folkes. Knit a piece in a cloute and steepe it all night in a draught of white wine, and streine it and drinke it in the morning to purge a strong bodie from much filth and the Iliake passion: But there must be foure or fiue branches of Issop steeped therewith. It will doe the like, being sodden in sweet water. Mixe it with an Oxe gall, aloes, honie, meale of Lupines, and oyle of wormewood, of eche a dramme and a halfe, and applie it to the bellie to loose and purge it, to kill wormes, and to expell them. Steepe the spongie part therof with the kernels foure or fiue houres in a draught of wine, and drinke it to bedward to purge flegme, choller, and grosse humours, and to helpe the dropsie. The balles broken and powred in by glister, purgeth and taketh away the palsie, the Sciatica, and the chollicke. Seeth it in honied water, or sweet wine, and coole it in the open ayre, and drinke it to purge grosse humours, and things like shauings. suppositer thereof plucketh downe the excrements of the bellie: a glister thereof healeth all the diseases of the guttes, kidneys and loynes, and the palsie the seedes being cast out. Mixe it with a Bulles gall and honie, and applie it to a bellie that is costiue. Steepe a penie weight pulled in pieces all night in ale, and streyne it and drinke it to purge the bellie, or drinke powder of three or foure of the kernels. Seethe it in vineger, and holde thereof in the mouth to helpe the toothache. Seethe it in oyle and drye a cloute or cotton therein, and put it into the natural place to prouoke the Flowers. To kil fleas, steep an apple of it in water twelue houres, seeth wormwood therein, and sprinckle the house therwith. Purgation, take powder of three seedes with as much Diagridium as a pease with a reare egge. Dropsie Eares paine wormes Falling euill Fleas to kill Flowers stopt Giddinesse Iliak pass. COlumbine, for the iaundies and the liuer, take powder of the seeds of saffron, of ech a peny weight, wine, water and vineger, of eche one eggeshel full, drinke it first and last. Take one scruple of powder of the seede, with two eggshels ful of wine first last to driue out the iaundies by vrine. For the water canker in ye mouth, drink the seeds. Emerodes, stampe red dock leaues, vnset leekes, Columbine rosted in the embers, and applye them. Squincie, drinke the seeds ofte~ with good ale, or stamp the seeds herbs with hony, and take it with milke or drink. Frensie, at the first drinke the iuice of Columbine, vse pottage of sage, valerian or rue, and be whole for euer. Ioints broken, drinke the seeds with feuerfew in stale ale. Deliuerance to cause, drinke Columbine. Swelling, drinke the iuice with fiue leaues of the same hearbe and stale ale. Headach, stamp Columbine, and fry it with May butter, and anoint therwith. Palsie, seeth Primrose, Columbine, peony, lauender saffron in ale, and drinke it before and after meate. Columbine is good against the iaundies, swooning, it openeth the liuer, is good for the inflammations and sores of the iawes, windpipe. Scratches gallings, stamp the floures with wheat meale and apply it. Iaundies, and stopping of the liuer, many diseases that may come therof, drink a dram of the seed with a half peny weight of saffron with wine, couer thee wel to sweat. The water of the floures is good for the same purpose for swooning. Seethe it in milke, sweet wine, or oximel, and drink it or gargle with it to help the Struma or painful swelling in the throate, called ye kings euil. The iuice with wheat meale applied warme, drieth vp moist It is good for yong children to drinke it against the redgum or fellon. Byles Breath stinke Chafings Deliuerance Eyes running Emerods Fellons Fistula Frensie Gallings Headach Iaundies COmferie, the roots stampt and drunke, are good for spitting of blood, al inward wounds ruptures. The root boiled drunke, clenseth ye brest, cureth the griefs of the lungs, so it doth mixed with sugar, syrrops or hony, often licked. for al tumors hote inflammations, especially of the fundament, stamp it with ye leaues of groundswel apply it. To stop the bloody fluxe terms, seethe the root in water drink it. It helpeth together broken bones, it stoppeth all fluxes of blood, vomiting blood, the iuice being drunk with red wine and a litle mastick. Hoarsenesse, eat powder of it, and of Elecampana with hony fasting. Bones broken, stampe it with dasies, egrimonie, and vineger, apply it til it be whole. Roste the roots of elecampana and Comferie, of eche like much, or seethe them in water to the one halfe, then put thereto a third part of clarified honie, make it in an electuarie, and vse it morne euen for the chincough. Fluxe to stop, apply the iuice of Co~fery both plantins with the burnt clay of an old ouen or fornace to the belly. Burstings broken bones, eat the rosted roots with hony. Matrix rent by trauaile of childbirth, put in powder of Comfery and Cynamom. Matrix griefes, drinke Comfery with Ale or water three daies. Bloodyfluxe wash the root in cold water, scrape it with a knife of bone or iuorie, or of a harts horne, and eate thereof two ounces or more: but eate no vineger that day, for that ta+keth away the vertue of the roote. Bursten, put the iuice into thy bread, and eat the roote either rawe or roasted. Teethach, seethe it in vineger, hold thy mouth ouer it. Brused, drinke two spoonfuls of the iuice of Comfery, scabious morn and euen, or stamp Comfery, housleek, orpin floure, apply it. Flowers to stop, seeth Co~fery in ru~ning water, drink it. If a man that is wounded drink Comfery keep it, he shal liue, if not, he shal die. Veine broken in the brest, frye the roots with eggs meale, and eate them. Or seeth the~ and slice them, and dry them, vse the powder of them with wine and water. Flowres to stop Fluxes Fundament griefes Hoarsenesse Inflammations Lungs griefes Matrix griefes rent Spitting blood COral: drinke Coral pepper with water, thou shalt haue the cra~p no more. Heart burning, let a man hold red Corall in his mouth, a woman white Corall in hers. Heart cardiack, apply Corall red or white with oile of roses. Teeth ach, mixe powder of mastick, gals Corall with hony, and rub therewith where need is. Teeth to fal out, put in powder of red Corall. powder when he is new borne, with the nurses milke, and it shall neuer haue the falling sicknesse. Corall strengtheneth the stomacke, stoppeth spitting of blood, preserueth the heart from pestilence, stoppeth termes, is good for the falling euill, withstandeth lightnings being borne on one, and stoppeth bleeding at the nose. Matrix fluxe, purge the cause, then take pouder of sanguis Draconis, bol armoniack, white amber, red Corall, drinke a dram with two ounces of plantine water. Or take old conserue of roses two ounces, plantine seeds, two drams, sanguis draconis, bol armoniack, ana a dram a halfe, white and red Coral ana one dram, make a confection with syrrop of mirtles, drinke it morne and euen as much as a mean chestnut two houres before and after meat, weare Corall about thy necke and hand. Teeth to be white, rub them with powder of white Coral, white marble, cuttle bone, masticke, bay salt, and the pils of a Cytron, ana like much euery morning, and after wash them in white wine, sodden with oil camomil. Hang it about thy neck down to the pit of the stomack to cause digestion. Drink the powder with water to appease the griefs of the stomack belly for euer, and to dry vp the flegme. Coral drunke stoppeth the termes, it comforteth the heart stomacke, dissolueth the feuer, in Lozenges it is restoratiue. Impost. drink the powder with the iuice of a ha~dful of scabious roots, and as much aqua vitae. It comforteth the eyes, and drieth vp the teares, it cleanseth vlcers. Gums bleeding, apply the powder by it selfe, or with honie. Nosebleeding plague Spitting blood Stomacke griefes Teethach foule to fal Vlcers Whites COrnefloure, or blew battel, stamp it apply it to the pain, rednes, inflamation, running of the eies, or to any hot apostume about the eyes, and so is the distilled water or iuice good for the same purposes. Seeth the floure and seed in wine, and drinke it against all venimous bitings and stingings. Drinke halfe a dram of powder of the seeds to purge chollar downward. Apostume Bytings venimous Eyes griefes Inflammations Purgations Swine sicke Cornerose. COrnerose, or wilde poppy, is in nature much like to poppy. Boile fiue or sixe heads in wine, and drinke it to cause sleep, or take the seed with hony. Stampe the leaues green heads, and apply them to all euill hote swellings, vlcers, and wilde fire. The seeds put into honied cakes loosen the belly gently. The powder of the flowers is good for the plurisie, and so is the syrop of the same flowres. To make redde butter for the diseases aforesaid, put thereto the red leaues: and likewise into cheese, to cause sleepe. The iuice of the leaues wil make butter or cheese greene and profitable for the diseases aforesaid. Mixe the iuice with myrthe, saffron, and oyle of bitter almonds, and put it warme into the eare to restore hearing, if it be curable. Seethe the seeds in Mede, and drinke two ounces and a halfe to loosen the bellie gently. Seeth fiue or sixe heads in wine, till the better half be wasted, and drinke thereof, and apply it to the forehead to cause sleepe. Stampe the seeds with honie, and eate it to loosen the belly gently. The distilled water drunke, helpeth all inward heats and inflammations of the mouth, throate and liuer. The same applied with hemp hards, helpeth the shingles, the holy fires, the inflaming fire, and the bleeding at the nose. The same water helpeth all inflammations, and exulcerations of the eyes, mouth, throate and secret parts. Applied to the forehead with hempe hards, it is good for ye frensie. The iuice of the flowres with brimstone and is good against scabbes, and foule Plurisie, drinke powder of the redde flowres dried in the sunne, and vse it in meates, and anoynt with oyle of Lysarts warme. syrrop for the stomake, to digest a surfet, put a quart of claret wine into a basin, steepe it ful of the leaues of red poppy, that groweth in wheat, on a chafingdish of coales, lay two flat white stickes ouer the basin, and take a piece of white cotton a span long and an inch broade at the one end, and smal at the other end: put the broade end into the liquor, and the small ende into a glasse, then whelme a basin ouer the stickes, and so boyle it till the liquor bee boyled vp, or distilled into the glasse: and to euery pint of the liquor put one pound of sugar, and boyle it to a syrrop, and keepe it in a close glasse, it reuiueth one that is in a deadly swoone. COtton weede is good to be drunk with tart wine against the bloodie flixe, the common flixe, and the termes. It is good to be put into the fundament for the Fluxe tenasmus: apply it to olde rotton sores. COuslip, Oxlips and Primroses, are now vsed amongst herbs, but not much in Phisick. Drinke the iuice nine dayes together to helpe the falling sicknes. The floures co~dited with sugar, are good for the Apoplexia, often swooning, all inward griefes, the palsie, and to comfort the heart: the hearbe also applied outwardly. Headach of heate, vse the water, the same taketh away all spots and wrinckles of the face and skinne: falling euil, drinke the iuice with powder of a kites liuer Canker in the hand or ioynt, stampe the Primrose roots with clarified hony, and apply it morne euen til it be whole. Speech lost by sicknes, hold the iuice of Couslips or sage in thy mouth. Teeth ach put the iuice of Primrose into the contrary nostril. Crampe stretching of the sinews, seethe it in water, and bathe therewith, or with camomill flowres sodden in water: or wash with the decoction of Primrose. Speech lost, stampe Primrose and sage, and anoint vnder thy tongue. Head impostume, put the iuice of primrose into the nose to break it. Palsie benummed limmes, distil the floures with oyle oliue in a glasse in the sun, and to two spoonfull of it put one spoonful of aqua vitae, and anoint therwith. Headach and to cleanse the braine, put the iuice of Primrose, with Cowes milk into the nose with a feather. Head megrem, stampe the roots of Primrose with rosemary leaues, and boyle them in good ale dregs and hony, and apply thereof or foure dayes as hote as may be suffred: or mixe the iuice of Betony and Primrose rootes, and Cowes milke, and put it into the nose bloodwarme with a fether: or put in Primrose leaues with milke. Voyce lost, mixe the iuice of Primrose with wine or water, and holde it in thy mouth. Dog bitten with a mad dog, giue him the iuice of Primrose, with milke within Make Conserue of the floures with sugar to helpe against feeblenes, swooning, and to restore strength. Take Couslip flowres, stamp them, and set into the sun in a close glasse fiue or sixe weeks: this oile helpeth the gout of the feet other members: it cureth also fresh wounds, if the same be infused in oyle oliue. It will then serue for many griefes, gather the flowres drie. COwparsnip or Wilde carrat growing in medowes: swellings cold, stampe it apply it. Some seethe it in drinke with leuin, and vse it in sted of ale or beare. The seed drunke, scoureth out flegme, and healeth griefs of the liuer, the iaundies, shortnesse of winde, the falling euill, and strangling of the mother. The perfume thereof wakeneth them that are fallen into a dead sleepe. Frensie, litargy and headache, seethe it in oile, and anoint therewith. Creeping sores and tetters, apply it with rue. Liuer griefs and iaundies vse the roots of it. Shaue the root, and put it into fistulaes or false wounds, to take away their hardnes. Eares mattering, put in the iuice of ye grene filmes. The iuice may be dried in the Sun, kept as other iuices be. Drinke Eyes sore Falling euill Fistula Flegme Frensie Hardnesse Headache Iaundies CRabs or Wildings: face swollen, distill them in a limbecke in the ende of Iune, and wash therewith often. CRanesbill or Acus moscata, apply it to all wounds vlcers. Drinke one dram with wine to expell all windinesse of the mother. Bruises and blacke spots, bathe them with the water thereof, and apply it foure or fiue dayes. CResses: stampe them with pitch and apply it to breake heale apostumes. Flux to stop, stampe the seeds boile them with hony, apply it to the wombe, it neuer faileth, being applied hote in a cloth. Teethache, put the iuice into the eare on the same side. Bloudy flux, eat a peny weight of the seeds three dayes fasting, and drinke wine or water after it, and it shall either staunch or turne to another, or els it is death or not curable. Gout, seethe them with leeks red mints, wash therewith morne and euen. Head wormes, stampe them with goose greace, and vse it. Gout olde, stampe them with sewet, and apply it, or stampe the leaues with bran vineger, and apply it. Carbuncles and venimous bitings, stampe it with bran and apply it, or stampe the herbe seed together, and apply it. To stop the bloudy flux and all other fluxes, three drammes of the seedes with as much hony, and make it sharpe with vineger, and drinke it once or twice: prooued. Braine to purge, blowe in powder of Garden Cresse into the nose. Flux diaria, drinke powder of the seeds with wine or vineger, or drinke the said powder with powder of planten seeds red wine. For all skabs, skalles and sores of the head, mixe powder of the seeds with fresh goose greace, and anoint, or with the iuice and goose greace. Bloud to stoppe, drinke a little of the seeds with the iuice of planten. Speech lost, anoint or rub the tongue with the iuice of Cresses powder of Castorie. Vomit to cause, seethe the seeds of Dill Cresses in water, and put a little oile to it, and drinke it luke warme. To know whether a wounded man shall die or not, let him drinke red wine, then eate a peny weight of the seed, and do so three dayes, if he stanch not, he may not liue. Palsie maleflanke, seethe the seeds in wine, and apply it to the side palsie members. Vrin stopt, seethe it with wine and oile oliue, and apply it to the share. Fundament fallen of cold cause, put it in againe, straw on the powder, or anoint the raines with hony, cast on the powder with Cummin, or powder of Colophony. Burne the stalke to kill venimous beasts with the fume thereof. To breake the stone, make powder of Cresse seeds, Parsly seeds, Annyseeds and blacke Flints, vse it morne and euen. Bitings of mad dogs, seethe the seeds with Penyroyall in water, drinke it to cast out the venim. Fluxes general, drinke powder of the seeds with ale morne euen. The seeds especially are vsed in medicine, and may be kept fiue yeres. The greene herbe is also of great effect, being somewhat dried before it be ministred. The seeds bruised and drunke in wine, expelleth the dead yongling, drunke with vineger, it helpeth the griefs of the milt. Eat it with the best hony to helpe the cough, and open the brest. Chew it holde it in the mouth for the palsie in the tongue. Cresses may not be eaten alone, for then they diminish the strength, and breed euill humours. The seeds taken whole, stay the distilling of the head without harme. Put the seeds into the nose in powder to purge the braine, and helpe the headache. Seethe them in wine apply them hote to the palsie members in a bagge. Sciatica and chollike, seethe the seedes in wine, and apply them in a bagge hote, or seethe the greene herbe in wine and oile, and apply it hote to the belly for the chollike and strangury. The herbe drunke with Mints in wine, doeth driue out both long and flatte wormes in beasts. Teethache, drop the iuice into the eare. Eat the herbe often in sallets to haue a sharpe and ready wit. Eaten with Lettuse it is of vertue like Rocket, and is good amongst colde herbes. The seed looseneth the belly, killeth and expelleth wormes, diminisheth the milt, and expelleth the flowers, seconds, and dead childe. It is good against venimous beasts, and the perfume thereof Take it with broth of a chicken, or any other moyst broth, to ripen flegme and auoyde it, and so to cleanse the breast. Milt hard, apply it with hony, and so it scowreth away foule spreading sores, dissolueth colde swellings and keepeth haire from falling. Apply it with vineger hony to the sciatica, old headache, old and cold diseases. Stampe it with goosegreace to heale the wormes of the head. The seed is of vertue like senuie seede, it expelleth wormes, is ill for women with childe, it prouoketh termes and venerie, it scowreth away leapry scurfe, and sores called Fauae like to hony combes, it ripeneth and bursteth carbuncles, it driueth foorth the griefs of the lungs, being sodden with suppings. Applied with parched barley meale and vineger, it is good for the sciatica and disperseth swellings. And with brine it driueth forth angry sores and cats haire, the leaues and branches are good for the same purposes while they are greene, but not so strong, for then they may be eaten with bread. The seedes cause abortion, with vineger it taketh away the scab. With hony it taketh away ache in any place. Sodden with vineger it dissolueth scrophules, and ripeneth colde apostumes. Take a dramme of the powder of the seedes with red wine sixe or seuen mornings two houres before meat to stop the laske. Seethe the seeds in white wine, and drinke it to stoppe the gonorrhea or wasting of nature, and to driue forth the vrine. Stampe the root with swines greace, and apply it warme foure houres to the paine of the ioynts, and the sciatica: but for women but two houres, and goe presently to sweat in a bath, and then anoynt with oile of Cresses and warme wine sodden. Seethe Cresses in wine, and drinke it against paine of the ioynts, the dropsie, timpanie, gowt, swelling, palsie, pocks, apostumations, rumes, bloudy fluxes, bruises, moistnesse of the braine and eyes &c. (See Rocket Senuie. Kernels Leaprie Litargie Lungs griefs Lust to cause Mad dog Maleflanke Memory Milt griefs CRowfoot leaues or roots being stampt and applied, causeth blisters and vlcers, and therefore are good to be layd to corrupt nailes and to warts to make them fall off. also may be vsed to foule skurfe or tetters, wheales, gaules, skabs &c. being stamped, but it may not lie long, but be taken away immediatly. Stampe Crowfoot green, and apply it to hard vlcers swellings, and to eate out dead flesh, warts, wennes, and all such like, prints of wounds, little marks like pricks. The powder of the root put to the tooth that aketh taketh away the paine, but it breaketh the tooth. The iuice taketh away skabs and crusty scurfe: and tempered with swines greace, it helpeth the swelling of the throat. Binde it with a red thrid about the neck in the wane of the Moone in the first part of or both for the falling sickenesse lunacy. The same root steeped in wine is good to be drunk in the plague, to cause sweat, but not good in a hote feuer. Stomacke hote, stampe Crowfoot with crummes of bread, apply it. Toothache, gather the roote in May, dry it in an Ouen, and keepe it all the yeere, and when need is, apply it being bruised with waxe and pitch, &c. three houres on the top of the tooth two or three times. Falling sickenesse Flesh dead Haire to restore Lunacie Nailes corrupt Plague. Sneesing to cause Stomacke hote Teethache Tetters Throat swollen Vlcers hard Warts Wennes Cubebs. CVbebs strengthen a weake and windy stomacke, they skower the breast, helpe the milt, expell winde, and helpe the colde griefs of the matrix. Head and braine to strengthen clense, chew them with Masticke. For trembling of the heart, melancholy, and the falling euill, there is no better medicine then Cubebs with Balme water. Heart faint, take foure drammes of Cubebs with the iuice of the roots and leaues of Parsnip. faint Head griefs Matrix griefes Melancholy Milt griefs Obstructions Stomacke weake CVcumber wilde: head sores, biles, &c. mixe ashes of the roots with water, and wash therewith. Headache, boile the root with water and oile, and apply it. Eares griefs, put in the iuice of the leaues, it killeth wormes therein also. Face wrinkles all griefs of the skin in any place, mixe powder of the root with water, and wash therewith, and wash it againe with other colde water, and do so thrise or three dayes. Teethache, vse the decoction of it with wine or water, and hold it in the mouth, or put it into the eare on the same side. Gla~dules, kernels, scrophules, and olde hard swellings, stampe the root with barley meale, apply it. Dropsy of colde cause, vse wine of the decoction of the root to purge out the swelling. Ringwormes, tetters and skabs, seethe the roots to the third part, stampe and straine them, and put thereto litarge of siluer and brimstone in powder, of ech like much, and a little waxe, and rub the place therewith. Milt griefs, take powder of it as much as you can take vp with three fingers, with wine before breakfast. Face wrinckles and deformities, wash it with colde water, and anoynt it with fine powder of the root and honye three dayes. CVcumber of the garden, the whole substance thereof eaten in Summer is good for them that vse much exercise, but not for the flegmatike. The water or iuice of them helpeth the feuer and ceaseth thirst. They which are hard and heauy are not so good as they that be ripe. Cough, drinke the seedes with wine and as much bruised cummin as may be taken vp with three fingers. Spitting bloud and matter, drinke the seedes with a little cummin. Vrine stopt, seethe the seeds in wine, and drinke it. The same helpeth biting of dogges, the seeds and leaues being also applied. Pushes hote, stampe the seeds with hony, and apply them. Drinke the seedes with milke or sweet wine, to loosen the belly gently, and for the blistering, rawnesse and stopping of the bladder. The iuice with the seeds mixt with meale, and dried in the Sunne, is made into a sope to make the face and skinne white and neate, but it must be anoynted with wine. Their seeds are good for the strangury and griefs of the reines and bladder. (See Mellons, Gourds &c. Burning, sprinckle on the ashes of a drie Cucumber. Face deformed Feuers Frensie Hote griefs Lungs griefs Madde Pushes Skabbe Skinne defor. CVmminseedes: if one that hath eaten Cummin doe breathe on a painted face, ye colour will vanish away straight. Ache or goute, seethe two handfull of the powder in a pottell of white wine to the one halfe, and drinke thereof a good draught first and last Eares deafe, stampe halfe a pound grossely, and put it into a bag, and sprinkle it with Rose water Malmesey and bind it fast to the eare hote, lie on it all night, and doe so thrise and keepe thy chamber iii. dayes. Bruses blacke spots, boyle powder of Cummin salt ana one ounce in For all aches and swellings, stampe it with the leaues of Colworts, drinke it with wine co~tinually. Vomiting much, seeth it with Mints in wine and drinke it or eate it. Eies blooddy, boile it in white wine and put thereto the iuice of Rue, and put it in or apply it. Blooddy fluxe and bleeding at the nose, steepe it in vineger iii. dayes, then drie it vse ye powder of it. Belly or stomacke ache, bake cakes of meale of wheate, rye, or otes, slice them anoint the inside with hony, and cast on it powder of Cummin, apply it hote to the nauell twise or thrise. Stomacke to comfort after purging, seeth crums of bread with Cummin in ale sup thereof. For all griefes of ye stomacke, make powder of the seedes of Cummin, flaxe smallage, of each like much, drinke one sponefull Sides griefes, see the powder of Cummin in white wine in a linnen bag to ye one halfe, dip a greene felt in the wine, apply it often hote. Flanke sicknes, drinke Cummin and Rue with wine or stale ale, when thou fearest ye comming of it. Belly loose with fluxe vomiting, seethe it in wine, drinke it or eate it. Sweate to cause, mixe the fine powder with oyle, and anoint thy hands feete when thou art warme in thy bed, and couer thee well. Head ache or migreme, cast powder of it on a peece of sliced beefe, and apply it two fingers broade from eare to eare one night and be whole Belly wormes, seethe it with more gall oyle, and apply it to the nauell Milke to cause, seethe one ounce with of water to ye third part, and drinke thereof often. Appetite to cause, seethe powder of Cummin, Ginger, Licoras ana one peniworth in hony till it be thicke, mixe a litle geane Triacle with it, eate thereof first and last. Cummin expelleth winde all other euils from the stomacke, and prouoketh vrine. Eares dull, stampe it seeth it in vineger in a bag, and apply it as hote as may be suffered to the eare. Liuer chafed, stampe it with Sengreene, seeth them in vineger apply it hote to thy side, as often as neede is. Cods swolne, seeth it beane meale with hony and apply it. Ache in any place apply the powder with hony. strawe the powder on a new laid Eg hard rosted, cut in the mids, apply it to the nape of ye necke. Breath stinking, seeth two handfull of the powder in a quart of white wine to a pint, drinke it hote nine dayes fasting. Swelling, fry ye powder with beane meale and hony, and apply it. boyle gray bread and powder of Cummin in vineger til they be thicke, apply thereof. Breath stinking, seethe the powder in vineger, take v. spoonefull at once Eyes ache dull, and congealed blood, stampe it with Rue the yolke of an Eg, and apply it, or mixe the powder with crums of bread, the white of an Eg, apply it. Eares deafe, stampe it with onyons oyle, and rub the eare and apply it hote. Flux and vomiting, eate Cummin or boile it in vineger and drinke it. Paine after childe birth, seeth onyons in water stampe them wt Cummin and oile apply it, or seeth Egs mightely in water, and mixe their yolkes with suet, ye iuice of Mugwort and Cummin, and apply it. For swelling aboue or vnder ye eyes, and bloodinesse, mixe the powder with virgins waxe and apply thin plaisters therof warme as often as neede is. Eies bruised or hurt, mixe ye powder with May butter, and apply it till the swelling be past, and then apply Saffron with womans milke. Eares apost. to breake it, mixe the powder with wheate flower, hony, and sheepes tallow apply it. Eares deafe noise, seethe the powder in ye iuice of Leekes, and put it in warme. For the hoste, seethe Sage, Rue, Cummin, and Pepper with Hony, take thereof morne euen dayly. Appetite to cause, seethe Peniroyall and Cummin ana like much with some Pepper in Ale, and drinke it at euen hote, and at Iaundies, seethe a henne with yellowe feete in white wine with Sage, Cummin, and saffron, eate the flesh and drinke the broth. Reines ache of wind, apply a plaster of Rue, Cummin, Calament, wheate bran with white wine. Backe paine, straine thine owne vrine through a cloth, and put thereto a fourth part of vineger with powder of Cummin, and the iuice of Parsley, boile them together streine them, anoint therewith against the fire. Yard ranckling, boyle beanes cleane hulled with Cummin, apply it, forbeare garlike pepper. Cods swolne, seethe barley meale with hony, put powder of Cummin to it and apply it. Heart cardiake, mixe the iuice of Betony with Treacle, powder of Cloues, Cummin and Annise, and vse it Yard standing or satyriasis, seethe Cummin with wine or water and drinke it also apply it. Eare apostumed, frye wheate meale and powder of Cummin with hony Capons grease or Hennes grease and apply it. Vomite to stop, apply Mastike, Cummin, and Bayes, with the iuice of Rue plaster wise to the stomacke. Belly windy, seeth the seedes of Cummin, Fenell, Anise in wine, and drinke it. Strokes blacke not broken, fry ye iuice of wormewod, hony, virgins waxe, barowes grease, powder of Cummin, of each like much, apply it. Ache of cold, seeth Cummin in thine owne vrine, apply it often warme. Stomacke weake, boyle red mints Cummin with vineger crums of bread apply it. Conception to cause, take vp the fume of the seedes of Cummin, Parsley, Fenell, Alisander, of each like much into the matrix. Face brused or hurt, mixe powder of Cummin Anise with waxe apply it. Headache, heate powder of Cummin in a pan sprinkle it well with the best red wine that can be had, apply it in a linnen bag as hote as may be suffered. Stitch, fill a dish with hote ashes, cast Cummin on it, lay a wet cloth ouer it, apply it, and seeth red Thyme and Cummin with Malmesey, and drinke it. plaster for the stomacke, stampe Cummin, Wormewood, Mints and Frankincense ana one handful, with dried crums of fowre bread vineger, and apply it in a bag sprinckled wt vineger. Sweate to cause, frye powder of Cummin with oyle barowes grease, and anoint therewith the plants of the hands and feete. anoint a Rye toste with aqua vitae, and cast powder of Cummin on it and apply it. Breath euill, seeth two ounces of powder of Cummin in a pottell of white wine to the one halfe, and drinke a little of it warme to bedward xv. nightes. Head megreme, apply the fine powder of Cummin with the gall of an Oxe to the nape of the necke. Eyes blooddy, apply the powder with Wormewood the white of an Eg with flaxe hurdes. Teeth yellowe and stinking, seethe two handfull in wine, and drinke it xx. dayes. Belly ache, seethe Cummin Rosemary in wine, and drinke it. Belly swolne, seethe it in stale ale and drinke it warme. Breath short, seeth it wt Pulyol Calamint in wine and drinke it, couer thee well to sweate. Drinke Cummin with milke to be deliuered of a dead childe. Eares deafe, boile Cummin the iuice of Leekes in a hollow Onion streyne it and drop it in. Eyes ache swelling, apply powder of Cummin: it helpeth any ache or swelling. Eyes bruised, roste the powder of Cummin with the white of an Eg, cleaue it in two partes and apply it. Feete swolne goute, spread powder of Cummin with oyle on a Wort leafe, apply to the soles of ye feete: proued. Goute, mixe fine powder of Cummin with hony, apply it. Apostume, seethe Wormewood Cummin in wine apply it, or seethe Onions Cummin in wine and apply it to ye place: proued. Mouth griefes, seeth powder of Cummin in wine to the one halfe, and drinke it morne euen. Paps griefes and swelling, mixe hony powder of Cummin with the iuice of Onions Smallach crums of hote bread, and apply it. Pap apostumed, seethe Cummin in oyle wt beane meale apply it. Milt swolne, seethe a bag of Cummin in white wine, and apply it hote. Stitch, drinke Stitchwort, apply Cummin sodden in thine owne vrine to thy backe. Ache of the stomake and small guts, put ii. parts of Bayes, one part of Cummin to hony a litle, apply it to the stomacke. Swelling of the stomacke belly, seeth it in ale and drinke it hote. Swellings of all sorts, seeth Otemeale with sweete milke, Cummin, saffron, apply it. Ache and other griefes of the matrix, stampe Paritary with hony and Cummin and apply it. Cods swolne, boyle crums of browne bread and beane meale of eache like much with newe Worte, and when it is almost boyled, put thereto some Cumminseede and a Braine to comfort and restore, steepe it iii. dayes in vineger, and drie it and chewe thereof, and hold it long in thy mouth, and then swallow it downe, and doe so often. Vomiting of colde and moyst cause, make iiii. bags of a spanne square, quilt into euery one, one ounce of Cummin, seethe them in a quart of vineger, and binde them to the wristes and insteps warme often: and eate some gray peason sodden with Cummin, and drinke some good strong drinke, at euery breakefast eate one peny waight of beaten Saffron to comfort the braine and stomacke, and stop vomiting, and these take away all gripings. Vrine stopt, heate a new bricke glowing hote, sprinkle thereon good wine wherein Cummin hath beene sodden, and sit ouer the fume of it that it may goe in. Hardnesse and griping of the body, seethe the seedes of Cummin and Fenell in sallet oyle, and anoynt therewith. Chollike passion, seethe crums of cleane wheaten bread, and powder of Cummin with white vineger, and apply it as hote as may be suffered. Cummin may be kept fiue yeeres and vsed in meates, and drinkes, and sawces, to comfort and helpe digestion. Seethe the seedes of Cummin and Fenell, with drie Figges well bruised together in wine, and drinke it against the winde and torment in the guts, and for the cough comming of colde. Cheekes swolne, stampe the seedes with Figs, and seethe with wine and apply it. Head colde reume, apply powder of Cummin and Bayes warme to the head in a bag to helpe it without fayle. Bruises, melt waxe with fine powder of Cummin, and apply it warme. Seethe it and Fenigreke in wine, to voide the swelling and griping of the guts. Strangury and other passions of the bladder, seethe it in in wine and apply it to the nauell. Seethe the seedes in water, and wash therewith to be clearer and fayrer. Nose bleeding, seethe the bruised seedes in vineger, and apply to the nose warme, and to the matrix to cease the reds. Cummin may be vsed in meates as Pepper, being sodden with Pease, it expelleth winde, flegme, and grosse humors, and taketh away the lothing of the stomacke. Seeth it in wine, drinke it to helpe the Iaundies the vertigo. Cummin skattereth breaketh all windines of the stomacke, belly, guts matrix, and is singular good against the gripings and torments of the belly, either drunke The same eaten or drunke, is good for the cough and colde, and stopping of the breast, and drunke with wine it is good for them that are hurt of any venemous beast. It slaketh and dissolueth the swelling of the cods being applied. Mixe it with Darnell meale the pulp of reasins, and apply it to a womans belly to stop the inordinate course of the flowers. Eyes red, apply the powder with iuice of Rue with cotten. Mixe Cummin and Hony of eache three ounces, Turpentine two ounces, and Bay salt one ounce on the fire, and apply it to any swelling that commeth of a stroke or fall. Eate it after Garlike to take away the smell thereof. Frie it with Barley meale and hony, of eache like much, with a litle sheepes suet, and apply it to the swolne cods. Byles Bitings venemous Bladder griefes Blooddy fluxe Braine to restore Breastes griefes apost. Emerods to flowe Face bruised see swelling, clensing see eyes, painted Feete swolne Flanke sicke Flowers to stop CVrrants differ not much in vertue from fraile reasins (See Sene) Eate them with meate to voide belching and stop the fluxe. To voide flegme and ingender good blood, eate euery morning DAffadill: swellings great in all partes, stampe the rootes, and drinke them with water, saffron, and sugar, and be whole. Stampe the blades and seethe them in a pinte of ale or wine with a spoonefull of Graines bruised, and drinke it before the fit to helpe the ague. Apply the roote with oyle to the paine of the heart or liuer. Apostume to ripen, stampe the roote with Hony and meale of Orobus, and applie it. Boyle two drammes of the fresh roote newe gathered in wine or water with a litle Anise or Fenell seede, and a little Ginger, and drinke it to driue foorth by seege tough and clammie flegme, and to helpe all diseases The roote broken with a litle hony healeth cut synowes, ioynts that are out, and old aches of the ioynts being applied. With vineger and Nettleseede it taketh away the spots, and morphue of the face. With Darnel meale and Hony, it breaketh apostumes, and draweth out prickes and splents. Brests swolne, and all inflammations, bruise the roote and apply it. Belching Breastes swolne Burnings Cuts Face deformed Feuer Flegme Flesh to growe Heart greefe Inflammation Ioynts out Liuer greefe Morphue Prickes Purgation Sinowes cut Skin foule Swellings Vomit to cause Woundes DAmsons are most wholesome of all Plums, which eaten before meate coole the stomacke and loosen the belly, (See Plumtree. Mouth heate, seethe Damsons, Violets, and a litle Sorell in water, til the Damsons begin to breake, then streine it and seethe the liquour againe with a fewe Barberies streine it and drinke. To drye them, gather them in Somer, and slice them, and lay them on a boorde in the Sunne, and sprinckle them often with vineger, and let them drie so, then put them in a boxe of wood, and sprinckle them with a litle vineger, and vse to eate of them dayly against the heate of the stomacke. Seeth the leaues or rinde of the roote in wine or water, and wash the mouth therewith to helpe the and loosenesse of the gummes and all the mouth without paine. When they be ripe, gather them slit them, and sprinkle them often with vineger, drie them in ye sunne xv. daies, then keepe them in a wodden vessel one yeere: for so long they will last, then are they good in sharpe feuers for costiuenesse comming of dry choller, if they be new, eat them, if they be old, boyle them in water and drink it for the feuer tertian, stopping of the liuer, the Iaundies, sharp feuers, costiuenes, want of appetite, and many other griefes. Set i. li. in a pot in an ouen with a batch of bread, then streine it, and put as much hony to it, and so make it in conserue. It is good against choller and heat of the stomack and liuer and other hote griefes. Seethe the leaues, bark or root in water or wine, and wash the mouth therewith to fasten the teeth, and keepe the mouth from all paine. Gout paine, seethe it in wine apply it, or stamp the leaues and roots, strein them with wine and seethe it with May butter anoynt often. Dropsie, seethe it in wine or water and drink a good draught morne and euen xx. dayes and be whole. Gout, stamp iii. li. with i. li. of May butter, and let it stand ix. dayes, then boyle it halfe an houre and streine it and anoynt. Ach and bruses, stamp good store with some Balm and Smallach, and i. li. of May butter, let it lye in balls ix. daies, then stamp it againe and fry it and strein it, and keepe it in a vessell of earth or glasse and vse it. Gout cold in any place, and ach of the bones, stamp iii. handfuls with one handful of Horehound, strein out the iuice, and boyle it with a pinte of swines grease halfe an houre, then strein it and vse it, (see Eldren. Legs swollen, the iuice with barly meale and vineger waxe of eche like much, and boyle it, and apply it. Costiuenesse, drink the iuice with hony. Danewort is good for the dropsie, tetters, and scabs, draweth euill humours out of the body. Bruses swellings, seethe the roots in water and stamp them with bores grease and apply them. Dropsie, stamp it and seethe it, and lye therein, and hyl thee well to sweate. seethe the middle rind in water apply it hote with bores grease plasterwise. Dropsie, drink the iuice of the root with wine iiii. dayes to help it, though it haue continued a yeere, or vse the syrop of the iuice of it. Gout, seethe the iuice wt as much wine to the thicknes of an oyntment, or hony anoynt there with. Stone, chop a bushel smal, put it in a bag, seethe it in water, bath therein ix. daies apply the bag where the stone is. Feuer quotid. steep ii. ounces of the whitest pith in half a pint of the best aqua vitae iii. dayes, then strein it drink thereof, if it chafe too much, put some wine or other drink to it. Head vanitie, anoynt the temples wt the iuice, salt, hony, wax, incense boyled together. Backache, seethe it to pap stamp it, fry it with sheeps tallow, put wheat bran to it and apply it. Cods boylerye meale with the iuice, hony vineger till it be thick apply it. Dropsie, seethe great store in water make a bath of it, lye therein all night, and couer thee wel wt the herbs and water, also drink the iuice thereof. Sleep to cause, (see in Lettis, Eldren, &c. rub them with ye root. Stomack swollen belly bound, drink the iuice wt hony ix. dayes. Dropsie, seethe it in wine or water, and drink it to haue present help. Cods swollen, apply the iuice with beane flower, common oyle. Matrix swollen, impostumed hardnes: Foment, with the decoction of the root. Feuer quotid. stamp the root seethe it in ale or white wine, drink it before the fit, sleep not. The leaues new buds, haue the same vertues that ye leaues and crops of Eldren haue being taken after the same maner. Take vp the fume of the decoction thereof for the swelling paine of the belly matrix being set in a close stoole. The fume of it burned, driueth away serpents other venemous beasts. Seethe the leaues in wine, apply them to the torment of the gout, or seethe the iuice of the herbe root with wine and butter, and anoynt therewith iiii. or v. times euery day. Mother windy and other griefes of it, sit in the decoction of it. Apply the tender leaues to swage inflammations and burnings biting of dogs. Gout, apply the leaues with bulls tallow, or goats sewet. Eldren are very hurtful to the stomack, yet the tender leaues sodden and eaten like a sallet, purge flegme choller. The iuice of the Beries stampt with fresh grease and barly meale, do clense rotten sores, cooleth the burning of a gout paine in the ioynts. The tender crops at ye spring time are vsed in meats to soften the belly without danger. The same sodden with wine mixt with hony drunk, is good for the cold dry cough to clense the breast. Dropsie, seethe the root in wine, drink it morne euen: it is excellent good. Squincy, gargarise wt the water, or wt the decoction of the leaues some Piretrum put to it. Seethe or steep ye leaues in water and sprinckle it about the house to kill fleas and gnats. Feet swollen Fistula Fleas to kill Gnats to kill Gout Head griefes Haire to be blacke Inflammations Ioints out Kernels Legs swollen Scrophules Scabs Sleepe to cause Sores rotten Squincy Stone Stomack swollen Swellings DAndelion, is in vertue much like to Cicory, and may be alwayes vsed in stead of it. downe the staring of the haire of the eybrowes, and causeth newe haires to grow. Head hot griefes, temper it with rose vineger and vse it, and so doeth Sowthistle and Cicory. Feuer tertian, drinke the iuice three or foure times before the fit, especially with powder of chrystall and wine. Seeth it well in water, and vse it for the knitting of wounds and for burstings for ruptures, &c. Bitings venemous, stamp it and apply it. Feuers, drinke the water of it and of Sorell, Sowthistle and Endiue all mixt together. Kings euill, seethe it in wine with the dung of an asse and Linseeds, and drink it. Reume in the head, apply a bag of Darnell salt, and Anniseeds. Scrophules wheals, seethe it with Linseed, Pigeons doung quick brimstone in wine and apply it. The meale applied with salt Radish roots stayeth wild scurfe fretting sores. The same with brimstone and vineger applied, cureth spreading scabs and leapry, and scurfe. With Pigeons doung, oile, Linseed boyled applied, it helpeth wennes hard tumors, and draweth forth all pricks splents and thorns, and doeth ripen open impostumes tumors. Sodden with Mede or Oximel, it swageth the paine of the gout sciatica. Put into Ale or Beere, it causeth drunkennes, and troubleth the braine. Apply the meale to rotten burning and deadly sores to cure them. Conception to cause, vse perfumes of the same, with parched barly meale Myrrhe or Saffron. The meale sodden in wine with Linseed and Doues doung, dissolueth hard lumps and wennes, and breaketh such places as are hard to ripen. The root sodden in wine and drunke after it hath stoode certaine dayes, killeth wormes. The seeds ground with salt, vineger, and quick brimstone, healeth ringwormes and tetters. The decoction of small Dasies with their leaues, or boyled alone in water drunk, helpeth agues, all inward inflammations of the liuer, &c. The herbe in meates pottage loosneth the belly gently. Maudlinwort, or the herby part of the wilde Dasy, is good against all burning vlcers, impostumes, and inflammations of the eyes their runnning being applyed. Vse the iuice for the palsie, the gout and the sciatica. Dasies red or white, single or double be all of like vertues, they are vsed in potions for fractures of the head and deep wounds in the breast. Put the iuice of the herbe and root into the nose to purge the braine. Vse the greene herbe with sharpe things to supple the bound belly, or the decoction thereof with fat flesh. The herbe healeth swellings of the throat paine of the neck. Stamp it and apply it to break and heale botches. Stamp the herb the root, but do away the red spotted, and seethe them and clarifie them and put thereto hony yolks of egs as much as the herb, and put wheat flower to it, seethe it til it be thick, vse plasters thereof to all cuts sores. If a wounded man drink the iuice, cast it vp, he shal die, if not, he shall liue. Wounds, drink the iuice, and apply thereof with sweet milk and wheat flower. Seethe the herb with Parsly roots in water, especially with Radish water, and drink thereof morne euen, to cause vrin. Bones broken, stamp Dasies, Cumfery, Egrimony wt vineger and apply it till it be whole. handfull of the lesse Dasy with milke, stoppeth all issues of blood inward and outward in ix. daies. Breaking out, stamp the leaues, and fry them with fresh butter, and streine it, and anoynt therewith. Hands broken out with heate and wormes, and blanes, stamp wilde Tansy and Dasy flowers in colde running water, and wash therewith. Ribs broken, drinke the iuice of it and also mixe thereof with sweete milke and wheate flower, and apply it. Head megrem, put the iuice of the herbe and roote into thy nose lying on thy backe. Breast swollen and hard, mixe the iuice of Dasies and Morell with barly, dregs of vineger, and a hard sodden egge, and apply it. Yard sore and full of of holes, stamp good store of Dasies and apply them often. Pyles, stampe the leaues and rootes with hony, and apply it. Streining to go to the stoole, to stop the blood of the emerods, seethe Mawdlin in tart wine, foment therewith. DAtes be hard of digestion, they stop the liuer and the milt, they breed wind in the belly head ach, breed grosse blood, especially being eaten green, but when they are through ripe, they are not so hurtful. And being wel digested in a good stomack, they nourish indifferently. Dry Dates do stop ye belly, stay vomiting wambling of the stomack, especially of women wt child being layd as an emplaster to ye stomack or belly, mixed wt other medicines and eaten. Also they restore strengthen the feeblenes of the liuer milt wt conuenient medicines either inwardly or outwardly. The leaues and branches of the Date tree doe heale greene wounds, close vp vlcers coole hot inflammations. Dry Dates are good to be eaten against spetting of blood, griefes of the stomacke, the bloody flixe, the roughnes of the throat. The stones burned in an vnbaked pot quenched in wine, or the asshes burnt wil serue for Spodium. But they are good in a co~sumption or lask, especially sodden in milk or in Muscadel. The pouder of the stones with Sanguis draconis in rasp wine, or red wine, is passing good in ye same cases. The electuary called Diaphenicon, half an ounce taken, purgeth flegme choller. Tie one stone bored through to ye necks of beasts, they shall not be hurt with their fetters, or if they be, they shalbe cured. Burn the stones apply the powder to the vlcers fistulaes of the fundament, or vpon the hole of the fundament be whole. Stone in the kidneys, make pouder of Date stones white Allom, vse it with rosted figs at night onely. To stop the whites, take powder of Date stones, halfe an ounce, Dragons blood one dram. Mix it with red wine take one dram of it by the break of day, as much when thou goest to bed. To cause deliuerance of a dead child, drink water of Rue, with powder of two Date stones. For a consumption, take Dates ii. li. wash them slise them, seethe them in a quart of hony clarified, till they be dissolued, then put in by litle litle, fine pouder of long Pepper, Cloues, Mace, Nutmeg of ech halfe an ounce, stir it til it wax thick, vse it first last. If you take thereof vpon a full stomack you shall not surfet (See Almonds. The powder of them drunke with wine easeth women in trauaile. Horse griefes Inflammation Liuer bad Milt bad Purgation Sores Stomacke bad Stone Throat rough Vomiting Whites Woman in trauell Wounds Deadnettle. DEadnettle (See Archangel Matrix white fluxe, drink three ounces of the water. DEwe: to cause the haire to grow long, wash the head with the Dewe in medowes all the mornings of March thrise a day. DAucus: Breath streite and vnsauerie, seethe it with figs and drinke it. Dry cough, seethe the root with wine and figs, and streine it, and drink it. DIagridium, sixe grayns taken purgeth downe vehemently chollericke humours, and is good for the Iaundies, pluxisie, frensie, hote feuers, and all griefes comming of heate. Apply it with hony and oyle to dissolue all colde swellings, And with vineger to heale all spreading scabs, hardnesse of the skin. Head ach old, apply it with oyle of Roses vineger, put it into the matrix, to prouoke the termes, and expell the seconds dead Take it with the pulpe of prunes, or with conserue of roses, or with masticke, and the iuice of quinces. There is good that is whitish, but much is sophisticated with the iuice of spurge Colophonie &c. Cast the powder of it on a bruised mallowe roote, and put it into the Matrix to bring downe the flowers. Costiuenesse, seethe a good quantitie in water, and seethe therein a capon and eate it and sup the broth. Hecktike, drinke a litle of the powder with the decoction of Lycoras. DIll: drinke the broth of the leaues and seedes when it is ripe, to breede milke, to cease gnawing and windinesse, it stoppeth the bellie and vomiting, prouoketh vrine, swageth the Hycket, it dulleth the sight, and beeing often drunke, it stoppeth the seede.
