Seethe it in water and sitte ouer it for the greefes of the mother. Hard bunches and knobbes about the fundament, apply the ashes of the seedes plasterwise: it doeth the like in all other places. Greene Dill, swageth ache, prouoketh sleepe, and ripeneth rawe humours. The oyle is good for wearinesse in Winter, for it softeneth and moysteneth, it is good for flegmatike agues, and all colde diseases and swellings. The decoction thereof with sugar, is good for the Strangurie, and Dissurie. The decoction of the tops and crops with the seede boyled in water and drunke, causeth plentie of milke, expelleth winde, swageth gripings, stoppeth vomitings and laskes, and prouoketh vrine. Chafe well the seede, and smell to it to voyde the Hicket. Ashes of the hearbe do close vp and heale moist sores, especially Boyle Dill in oyle to resolue, digest, and swage payne, prouoke lust, and ripen all rawe and vnripe tumors. Seethe it in oyle to release shrinking and astonishing of the sinews, and many other passions. Mixe powder of Dill with acorne cuppes, and drinke halfe an ounce with halfe a pinte of Ale or Wine, to cure the bloodie Fluxe. Sleepe to cause, anoint the head with the oyle. Eares payne, droppe in the oyle. Sleepe to cause, weare a garland of greene Dill to thy head. Seethe the herbe and seed in wine, and drinke it to helpe straitnesse of pissing, and to increase milke. Boyle a handfull of Dill in Wine, and applye it to the payned Matrix. Seethe Dill with poppie seede, and drinke it to staye vomiting, griping, and windinesse. Seethe Dill with sugar in wine and oyle, and drinke it to driue downe the Flowers and seconds, and to helpe the mother, but drinke but two drammes at once. Mixe powder of the seedes with as much powder of nettle seede, and mixe it with water and hony, and apply it to the piles to heale them in short time. Stomacke colde, seethe nutmegges and maces with Dill seede and feuel seed in wine and drinke it. Bellie grynding, drinke the iuice of penyroyal and plantine, boyled with powder of Dill. Seethe the seedes in water and dip olde silke therein, and wipe the emerodes therewith, and make a suppositor of the same: it helpeth also the tenasmus. Ashes of the seedes helpeth the scalding and all other griefes of the yarde and priuie partes. plaster of the powder with Sheepes tallow, and blacke sope, helpeth the emerodes. Lothing, seethe the leaues in water, and drinke foure ounces and an halfe, and smell to the hearbe and seede to auoyde the hicket. Lungs griefes, drinke powder of the seeds morne and euen, and so it helpeth pissing in bedde. Hicket, applie powder of the seedes with the iuice of mints to the stomacke. Belly loose Benummed Byle Bloodie fluxe Colde griefes Dissurie Eares paine Emerodes Kernels Knobbes Loathing Lungs griefes Lust to cause to voyde Milk to cause DIttanie drunke with water or wine, causeth speedie deliuerance, and easie, though the childe bee dead, or out of due course, and expelleth the seconds, penyroyall doeth the like. Deliuerance, and to saue both the woman and the childe: stampe Dittanie, veruine, and hyssope ana one handfull, and streyne it with ale, and drinke a good draught in thy trauell. Ptisicke, and spitting of blood, drink Dittanie often with womans milke. Teethach, seeth it in white wine, hold it in thy mouth. Flowres stopt, seeth it with sauin in wine, drink it. Pricks and thorns, stamp it with Polipody, and swines greace, apply it. It helpeth all venime, and poyson, and driueth out pellets, and all other prickes, the place beeing also anoynted therewith. Dead childe, and seconds, put in the iuice and powder especially of the roote. Sleepe to cause, mixe it and with oyle of roses and anoynt. Sciatica, stampe the roote with soft greace of a goose, or capon, and applie it. Sciatica, apply it with clecampana foure houres, and then open the blisters. DOcks and Sorell: the leaues of all Dockes sodden, and eaten, loosen the bellie gently, and so doeth the broth of them. Head apostume and swellings, stampe the greene leaues and a litle saffron, and oyle of roses, and applie it. Bloodie flixe, or laske, seethe the seedes in water or wine, and drinke it, it helpeth also the wambling payne of the stomacke, and venemous bytings. Eate the seedes afore hande, and no byting or stinging shall paine thee. Seethe the roote in wine, and drinke it to heale the Iaundies, prouoke vrine and termes, and to breake and expell the stone and grauell. The roote boyled in vineger, or bruised rawe, doeth heale all skurfes, as itche, and maunge, and griefes of the skinne, beeing applyed. The decoction or broth of the roote helpeth all maunge, festering, and consuming skabbes being washed therewith. Teethach, seethe the roots in wine, and holde it in thy mouth, and put thereof into the eare for the paine thereof. Boyle the rootes and applie them to harde kernels and swellings behinde the eares to consume them, stampe them with vineger, and apply them to the hardnesse of the milt. Flowers to stop, stampe the rootes and apply them to the Matrix. Kings euill, or swelling in the throate, hang the roote about thy necke. Headach, stampe sorell with oyle of roses, and apply it. Whatsoeuer meate is sodden with any kind of Docke, will become tender, though it be neuer so olde. Conception to cause, tie the seeds to the left arme. The rootes eyther newe or drie put into wine, will turne it from white to redde. The great garden Docke drunke in wine, purgeth flegme, choller and water downeward. Carie the feedes of sorell gathered by a chaste boye about thee, and thou shalt haue no pollution of seede neither by night nor by daye. Swine pockes, hang sorell rootes about thy necke, or plantine rootes. Drinke one dramme of the roote of the garden Docke, or Monkes rubarb to purge withall. Chollicke, seethe the leaues of Dockes, and mallowes in water, and stampe them and applie them. seethe the roote in strong vineger, and stampe it and applie it: the leaues so vsed, doeth the like. Vrine stopt, stampe the rootes, and seethe them with wine, and applye it aboue the yarde. Face salsflegme, mixe the iuice of redde Dockes and wormewood with aloes, and anoynt. Goute, seethe the leaues of great Docke in Maye with wine or Ale, and drinke it. Scabbes and Itche, boyle the iuice of redde Dockes, with giltes greace, till the iuice bee consumed: then put thereto a little Turpentine, and mortified, and vse it. Leaprie, stampe the rootes of sharpe redde Dockes, and rounde Dockes, their pith taken out, and boyle them with vineger and salt butter till the vineger bee consumed, and vse it both for the Impetigo and Serpigo: or boyle the iuice of sharpe leaued Dockes with Swines greace, till the iuice bee consumed. Then streyne it, and put thereto Turpentine, and mortified, and anoynt therewith the Morphew, white or blacke spottes and Leaprie. Leaprie, boyle the iuice of sharpe Dockes, Fumiterre, and Scabious ana like muche with swines greace, till the iuice bee consumed, then streine it and anoynt therewith morne and euen. Stitch, stampe redde fenell, and redde Dockes, and frye them with Maye Make oyntment of the rootes of Celondine, and redde Dockes, with wormewood, of eche like muche, tempered with Maye butter, and vse it, prooued. Wormes in the handes, Boyle the iuice of wormewood and redde Dockes with Maye butter, and stirre it: and when it is thicke like a salue, keepe it to thy vse. Emerodes, Roste the leaues of redde Dockes, Columbine and Leekes in the embers, and stampe them, and applie them, and bee whole in three dayes. Impostume to breake, stampe the rootes of redde Dockes with Licoras and anniseedes of eche like much, and seethe them in water till the thirde part be wasted: then streyne it, and drinke it daylie. Kinges euill, seethe redde Docke rootes in white wine, and drinke it dayly. Handes scabbed, stampe sharpe leaued Dockes, and Fumiterre, of eche like muche, and make it an oyntment with Maye Butter, Swines greace, and some roche allume, and anoynt therewith. Itche, boyle the rootes of sharpe leaued Dockes or Sorell, and washe therewith. Iaundies, washe the rootes of the reddest Dockes, and put them into a vessell of good ale, and when it is stale, drinke thereof dayly. Goute, grinde the ouer barke of redde Docke rootes with vineger, and boyle them to the one halfe, and straine it and anoynt. Brayne to purge, put in the iuice of Rue and redde Dockes into thy nose. Breast and breath stopt, make pannecakes with Dockes and egges, or meate, and vse them. Iaundies, lay the rootes all night in ale, and drinke thereof. Apostumes to ripen, Roste the rootes or leaues of Dockes, and Lilies in the embers, and applye them with Swines greace. Coddes swollen, stampe the rootes with Swines greace, and applie them. To knowe whether the Goute be hote or colde, roste the tender stalke of a redde Docke in a leafe of the same Docke, and applie it to the holes eight fourtie houres, and if it fall not away, it is the Goute, Festerhote. Scabbes, stampe redde Docke rootes with fresh butter, and boile them and straine it into colde water, and gather the oyle and anoynt therewith. Bloodie flixe Brayne to cleanse Brest griefes Breath stopt Burning Biting venimous Chaste to be Chollicke Cods swelling Conception to cause Emerods Face salsflegme Flowers stopt to stoppe Goute Stomake paine Stitch Stone Swelling Swine pockes Teethach Throte swollen DOdder, boyled in water or wine, and drunke, openeth the Liuer, milt, kidneys, and bladder, and gaule, and veynes, and purgeth cholericke humours byseege and vrine. It is good for olde feuers, and the Iaundies, especially that which groweth on hoppes and brambles. The other sortes haue the properties of the things that they growe vpon. Seethe one handfull in wine, and drinke it against all obstructions: the Iaundies, the dropsie, &c. The distilled water is verie good against the French pockes, to prouoke sweate, and to withstande the Feuer The same vsed in bathes is good against melancholy, the iaundies, that is olde, and the ague in children: it must be taken with anniseed. Seethe it with mirrhe and oyle, and vse it for the ache of the backe, brest and other limmes. or mathes, the iuice drunke, it helpeth the canker, pyles and emerods, the falling euill. Headache, and to cause sleepe, anoynt with oyle of roses, and castorie. Plague hote, drinke as much powder of the roote as will lye on a crowne with vineger, but in the colde plague with wine. Haire to growe againe, seethe raddish leaues with as much roots wel in water, and wash therewith. Put powder of the rootes into woundes, that beeing healed breake foorth againe, by reason of a putrified bone. Fundament falling, and for the sig, drinke the iuice and applie the substance. It is called Cotulafetida, or stinking camomil, mathes, or Dogfenel, and is good against the loosenesse and falling downe of the matrix, being sodden in water, and the feete washed therewith. And being smelled vnto, it helpeth the suffocation thereof, and it hath the nature and all the vertues of Castorie. Drinke the iuice of a handfull of it with a pint of Malmesey against the Ague, the plague, and to comfort nature euerie morning. Falling euill, giue him the iuice to drinke in the fitte, to cure him Seethe it in wine, and drinke it for the stopping of the liuer and milt, the strangury and the fluxe. Seethe it in water and wine with barley and licoras, and drinke it to helpe the colde humors in the spirituall members. Drinke the iuice thereof nine dayes with ale and hony to cast out an impostume. DRagagant is good for the cough, roughnesse of the throat, hoarsenes being likt in wt hony. Steepe a dram in wine, and drinke it with some powder of a Harts horne burnt washed, for the paine of the kidneies and bladder. The clearest is best, it helpeth vlcers and blearednesse of the eyes, vlcers of the intralles. Drinke the powder of it against the crampe, and breaking of veines inward. Dissolue it in Rose water, for chaps excoriations with some starch. To make the face white, and to auoid ranknes, steepe it a night in Rose water, and in the morning put a little borace or camphire to it, and strike the face therewith. With Fenell water it helpeth the griefs of the reines and bladder. One dramme with cleane hony cleanseth the lungs, cleareth the voice, and helpeth the cough. Lips chapt, dissolue Penides in water with gumme Dragagant, anoynt. Dissolue it in Rose water, and straine it and mixe therewith powder of Amidum, and anoint therewith the sores clifts of the mouth and lippes. Seethe it in wine with Stecados, and drinke it to warme and clense the brest, and stomacke, bowels, for the chollike, the stopping of the milt and vrine, the strangury and dissury. Chaps, steepe it in hote water, and anoint with the mussilage. Skin off clensing Sores Spitting bloud Strangury Throat sore Vlcers Veine broken Voice bad Vrin stopt Dragons. DRagons stampt with oile and put into the eyes, taketh away their ache. The root stampt with the root of a white Onion and hony healeth all wounds that the kanker hath bene risen in. He that rubbeth his hands with the root in May, take adders, and they shall not venim him. Biting of a Dogge or Adder, drinke Dragons, Rue and Betony. Chollike, seethe it in wine or water, and drinke it. Drinke the iuice against all venimous bitings, poison and venim. Dragons bound to the priuity of a woman in labour, causeth present deliuerance, but take it away speedily lest the matrix follow. The root boiled or rosted, and mixt with hony, and licked, is good for the straitnesse of breath, dangerous coughs, and catharres, conuulsions, and cramps, they consume grosse and tough humours, and scowre and clense the inner parts: they haue like power, being sodden three or foure times, till they haue lost their sharpnesse, and then eaten in meat. The same dried and mixt with hony, scowreth malignant and fretting sores that are hard to cure, especially mixt with the root of Briony: and it taketh away all white spottes and skurfe being rubbed therewith. The iuice of the root putteth away all webs and spots of the eyes, and is good in eye medicines. The same dropt into the eares with oile, taketh away their paine. The fruit cureth malignant vlcers, and the polip in the nose, kankers, malignant vlcers that consume. The leaues layde among cheese, keepeth it from perishing or rotting. Some holde that he that carieth the leaues or roots about him, cannot be hurt of vipers serpents. New cheese wrapt in the dry leaues, will not molde nor putrifie. With the roots leaues are made oiles, ointments and plaisters excellent good to heale vlcers, biles, fistulaes, pocks, kankers, fretting and consuming sores, and all such like. The leaues with hony take away the spots of the face. The leaues applied to venimous bitings, draweth out the poison, and healeth the wound. The water drunke with Venice treacle or mithridate, is good against the pestilence. The sauour of the herbe is hurtfull to women newly conceiued. Apply the iuice with lint to the nolimetangere in the nose. Kanker in the body, drinke nine peny weight of powder of the root with white wine three mornings warme. Eares ache, put in the seede with oile. Head purging, put in the iuice with wooll into the nostrels. DVcks meate or water Lentiles: drinke the distilled water two or three times a day, against all inflamations and heats, especially of the plague. The same applied to the region of the liuer, helpeth the inflamation thereof, and the inflamations swellings of the cods, impostumes and gatherings of humors that run from place to place, to the wilde fire and great burnings, to the gouty members both alone and also mixt with meale of parched barley, or wheat flowre. It gleweth or maketh fast the bowels of yoong children, and the falling of the fundament. Liuer hote Plague Swellings Wilde fire Yard swollen Dwarf gentian or Sope wort gentian. DWarf gentian or Sope wort gentian: the decoction of the leaues or root drunke, cleanseth the breast, and is good for the falling sicknesse, and all poison, venim, and corrupt aire: and so is the powder of it. Seethe it in wine, and wash wounds, and corrupt vlcers therewith, or straw on the powder to heale Chop it small, and giue it to swine and other cattell to eate against the murren and other like diseases, and in a contagious time. Brest clensing Falling euill Poison Swine sicke Venim Vlcers Wormes Wounds Earthnut. EArthnut: the vpper part draweth vp by vomit cholar and flegme, and the nether part purgeth downeward: the whole purgeth both wayes. EArthbinde: Headache of rume, put in the iuice of white Earthbinde into the nose. EYebright: distill the leaues, stalks, and flowres, and drop the water into the eyes, to cleare them, and auoid all their paine, and drinke three ounces an houre before night, and wash the eyes therewith to preserue the sight. Eate powder thereof dayly with a reare egge or potcht egge to restore the sight. Or drinke halfe a dramme of the powder forty mornings to restore the sight with the water of the same herbe. To breake the pearle or web, mixe the iuice with gilts greace and goose greace, of ech like much, boile them well together, and keepe thereof in a close vessell, and put thereof into the eye when thou goest to bed. Eyes sore, frie it with fresh goose greace, anoint therewith. Eyes dim, put in the seeds of Eyebright to cleare them. Eyes dull, seethe it well in water, and drop thereof into the eye. Web, stampe good store of it with greace of a bore, capon, or goose, and boile them together, and when it is colde, put it in boxes, and put a little of it now and then into the eyes, or frie it with greace of a goose or heron, and anoynt the eyes. Eyes dull, droppe in the iuice with wine, to make them cleare. Mixe three parts of the powder with a fourth part of Maces, and take euery morning a spoonefull by it selfe, or with sugar or wine, to cleare the sight and memory. Eate powder of Eyebright with a reare potched egge certeine dayes together, to restore decayed sight: or drinke halfe a dramme of the powder with the water thereof forty nights together to the same effect. TO strengthen and clense the liuer, drinke the decoction of it at morne and euen. Bitings venimous, seethe it in wine, and drinke it. Olde wounds, stampe the leaues with swines greace, and apply it to warme. Drinke an eggeshell full of the iuice to cast vp all poison, and to heale all venimous bitings. Stampe the herbes and rootes of Betony, Egrimony, and Mugwoort, with olde greace and vineger, and apply it three or foure times to auoyde the paine of the backe. Drinke it or the powder of it to heale the fistula in the eyes, and all other places. Apply it with vineger to warts, to take them cleane away. Seethe it in redde wine, to cleanse all woundes being washed therewith. Stampe the leaues, and apply them to sores that be euill healed, or ioyned, to open them againe. Seethe it with Alome, and wash therewith the ranckled and swollen yard and coddes warme. Seethe it with wine, and drinke it against the obstruction and stopping of the liuer, and the chollike. The distilled water helpeth the cough, and the iaundies, and killeth wormes. The leaues stamped with swines greace, healeth cuts, vlcers and wounds. with Wheat branne in olde dead wine, and applied to the ioynts that be loose, doeth much helpe them: and so it doeth being sodden with Butter, Vineger, and Wheat branne. Egrimonie comforteth the liuer, stomacke, and bowels, and is good against the ache of them, the griefes of the milt, and for long feuers. And drunke with wine, it is good against the euill habite, and the dropsie, and the vlcers of the intralles or bowels. Plucke it vp with the roote thereof, and stampe it, and binde it to thy heele, to cause speedy deliuerance of a dead childe, but take it away speedily, least that the matrix follow. For the fistula, hang it about thy necke, and also put it in. Gummes griefes, apply the iuice of Egrimonie. Knees ache, or gout, seethe it in water, to the third part, and drinke a cuppe full thereof fasting, and apply the hearbe warme. Boile Egrimonie with hony, and apply it to the head ach, and megrem. Apply Egrimonie to a broken head, to drawe out the boanes, and heale it speedily. Put the iuice of it into a Kanker that is olde, with a pipe of brasse, and binde a plaister thereof about it, to heale it. Pissing bed in youth, drinke two drammes of Egrimonie in wine or broth. Fistula in the head, drie the roote in the smoake, and hang it about thy necke. Nose bleeding, holde it and the roote of it in thine hand. Nailes falling off, and aking, and to make them growe, apply the powder. Backe ache generall, stampe the rootes of it and Mugwoort with Swines greace and Vineger, and apply it to thy backe. For a woman that can not holde her vrine, Stampe it with Salt, and seethe it in olde wine, and drinke it when it is sodden to the thirde part. Bitings venimous, drinke two drammes of the powder, with two measures of Wine called ciats, to cast out the venime. Apostume generall, seethe it with Houseleeke and Fiueleafe in Redde Wine, and apply it. Madde dogges biting, wash the wound with the bloud of the same dogge, and applie the iuice of Planten and Egrimonie with newe Honie, and the Whites of Egges. Warts, stampe Egrimonie with salt, vineger, and brimstone, and apply it. Backache, stampe Egrimonie, Mouseeare, and Smalach, and their roots with bores greace and vineger, and apply it: or stampe Egrimonie and Louage of ech like much with barrowes greace and red vineger, and fry them well together, and apply it. Drinke Egrimonie with wine, to helpe all venimous bitings and carbuncles, or drinke an egshell full of the iuice to expell it vpward easily, and all other poison. Egrimonie is a speciall good thing against hollow woundes and vlcers, and fistulaes, the powder thereof being put into them. Glandules, scrophules, and kernels, drinke the iuice with whey nine dayes in the wane of the Moone. Belly ache, eate Egrimonie, or drinke the powder of it with water. Stampe it with vineger to helpe the wounds made with iron. Vse it in meats to helpe the ache of the milt. Liuer stopt comming of flegme, seethe the powder of Egrimonie in white wine, and drinke it. Eyes hurt or blasted, apply the iuice of Egrimonie with the white of an egge. Pricks, stampe Egrimonie, and apply it. Biles to auoid, stampe Planten and Egrimonie with goose greace, and anoint therewith. Bones broken, stampe Daisies, Egrimonie, and Comfery with vineger, and apply it till it be whole. Backe ache, stampe the leaues roots of Egrimonie and Mugwoort with olde greace and oile Oliue, and apply it in a bagge. Bottes in horses, let him eate Egrimonie earely in the morning fiue or sixe mornings together, and let him eate nothing els vntill it be noone. Yard or coddes swollen, seethe Egrimonie or the water thereof, till it almost boile, with a quantity of Alome, and bathe it therewith with a linned cloth, well and warme, and apply thereof with a cloth wetten therein. Itch, seethe it with Sage in raine water, and wash therewith. Yard kanker, stampe it with Houndstong, and Pimpernell, and the pappe of sodden Linseed, and apply it. Headache, seethe it in water, and drinke it at euen hote, and at morne colde. Ptisicke, and spitting of bloud, drinke the iuice with wine, and Hony, and Fenell rootes nine dayes. For all griefs of the stomacke, Stampe it with Mouseare, and barrowes greace, and vineger, and fry them together and apply it to the backe as hote as may bee suffered. Sores to heale, stamp it well with May butter, and make it into bals, and lay them to mould well, then seethe them wel and streine it, and anoynt therewith. Haire to growe, stampe it with Goats milke, and anoynt therewith. Eyes dull, vse the water with twise so much water of white hony suckles or Clauer. Drinke it with vineger fasting dayly in the plague time, both to helpe the disease, and to preuent it. Bloody fluxe Blood spetting Bones broken Bots in horses Carbuncles Chollicke Cods swollen Head broken Head fistula Haire to grow Iaundies Ioints to strengthen Itch Kanker Kernels Knees ache Leg sores Liuer stopt Pricks Ptisicke Sores olde Sores to open Squincie Stomacke griefes The iuice of wild Cucu~bers dried: take x. grains to purge flegme, choller, and watrish humors, and to helpe the dropsie and shortnes of breath. Delay it with sweet milke and powre it into the nose to take away the ill colour of the eyes after the Iaundies, and to swage headache and purge the brain. Put it into the matrix with honied wine to expell the termes and dead child. Apply it with oyle or hony, or the gall of an oxe or bull to heale the squincy swelling in ye throat. The iuice of the bark and root doeth purge as aforesaid. The root soked in vineger and made soft applied, helpeth ach and swelling of the gout, and sodden in vineger, it swageth the toothach. The powder of it with hony clenseth voydeth foule scurfe, spreading tetters, maundge, pusshes, wheales, red spots, all other blemishes of the skin in any place. Drop the iuice of the leaues into the eares to voyd their pain. Elaterium must be taken with Mede or sweet milke, a little salt Anniseeds, or with Gum, Dragagant, salt, and Anniseeds, from vi. grayns to xii. one good grayn is inough for a child. To purge the belly, put twise so much salt to it as much stibium as will colour it, and giue a pill as much as a pease, and after drinke one ounce and v. drams of worme water. But to prouoke vomit, take the water that Elaterium is steeped in, and dip a feather therein, and put it to the root of the tongue, but if the receiuer be hard to vomit, dissolue it with oyle or oyntment of the Flower deluce, and forbid them to sleepe: if he cannot cease vomiting, or purging, giue him wine and oyle, or cold water, or barly meale vineger and water, Apples, &c. (See Cucumbers. Ache Apostume Dead child Eares ache Flowers stopt Gouts Headache Iaundies Maundge Purgation ELecampana is good for all griefes of the breast, lungs and heart. Breast lungs griefes, boyle it lycoras in pouder ana like much, with good store of hony, put one ounce of ginger to it after it is sodden thick vse it. Scabs generall, seethe it tender, put thereto sheeps tallow, tye them in a cloth anoynt therewith by the fire. Eares wormes, put in the iuice of Elecampana, Rue Wormwood. Cough dry, vse powder of Elecampana Comfery with hony. Scabs generall, slise the root and seethe it to pap stamp it, strein it with swines grease, and put thereto some mortified quick siluer anoynt. Scabs, seethe the root to pap, it with oyle oliue anoynt. Mother suffoc. seethe powder of Elecamp. pepper wt wine or ale drink it: prooued. Frensy wt paine of the stone, seethe ye leaues in wine and apply them. Pricks, stamp the root with reed roots hedghogs grease, hony and apply it. Elecampana fastneth loose teeth, prouoketh vrin, causeth deliuerance of a dead child, is good for the cough. Face falseflegme, seethe iiii. ounces of Elecamp, in white wine, stamp it strein it, put thereto powder of Sulphur half an ounce, of Mercury an ounce, them wt as much swines grease stir it wel, keep it in bores, being first boyled cooled and vse it. Scabs pilling of the skin nailes, seethe the root in water to pap, grind it with oyle or grease, and anoynt be whole. Canker, to destroy it, anoynt with the iuice of Elecamp. Radish with wheat flower, and the white of an eg. Dropsy, drink Elecamp. Belly guts freting, seethe the roots of it Burres in wine drink it morne and euen. Conserue of Elecamp. is made wt the pap of the root, ii. or iii. times so much sugar, it comforteth the stomack nourishing members, it looseth tough flegm, marueilously, and consumeth it by seege. Fistula to heale, stamp the root of Elecampana and Lignum vitae, and seethe them in white wine and vse it with a syrindge. Itch, put powder of Elecampana, brimstone, and bay ana like much into a bag, and dip it in falles oyle; and rub any itch therewith warme, or do the like with Elecamp. bay salt oyle of Iris, which also helpeth Chincough, seethe the roote with as much Ginger in water to the one halfe, and take the pap thereof with a third part of hony boyled scommed and make it an electuary and vse it v. or vi. dayes morne and euen, a good quantitie at once. Stomack to clense, seethe Elecampana and Radish ana halfe an handful in a quart of water, a pint of hony, a farthing worth of brused Licoras, drink thereof first last. Child bursten, distill the root in a limbeek, drink iii. ounces of the water. Loyns paine, drink two drams of the root in wine. Ruptures in the body, distil the root from Iuly to September, the leaues in the end of May, and drinke an egshel full of the water morne and euen. Dead child to expell, drink ii. or iii. ounces of ye water of the root. Coughs cold, make an electuary of the powder or pap and Licoras vse it. Scab and itch, stamp the root with swines grease and anoint. Fluxes to stop, stamp it with as much of the kernels of nuts, seethe them into an electuarie and vse it. Fistula to heale, stamp the leaues with salt apply them. Vse Elecampana to comfort ye spirituall members, for the sinewes to clense them, the breast lungs, for all euil humors in the stomack, stopping of the liuer milt, for all cold griefes and windines. Coughs stopping of the brest, powder of Elecampana Licoras with twise so much sugar and vse it. Consumption, boyle powder of Elecampana and Tormentil with hony and vse it. Health to preserue, eate it in pottage one or twise a weeke. The decoction thereof drunke, prouoketh vrin termes, is good for inward burstings drawing together of any part. The root taken with hony in an electuary, clenseth the breast, voydeth tough flegme, is good for the cough shortnes of breath. The confects of it are good for the stomack to help digestion. Seethe it with Rue and vse it against the windy chollick ruptures that come of the wind. Vse it in baths to wash clense the body from filth, itch, and scabs, and to keep the body warme, and to make them red that were pale. The oyle thereof helpeth the torments, wind of the guts, is good for the sinewes. The powder of the root mixt with sugar and hony, is a blessed medicine against shortnesse of breath, sighing, and coughing, it clenseth the breast, and healeth the impostumes of the lungs, matrix and other partes, or intralls. Bitings venemous, and inflammations, and swellings of the secrets both of men and women, stamp the greene leaues and apply them. The roots, and all other roots must be gotten at the fall of the leafe. CHoller or flegme to purge, boyle the leaues and tender crops of common Eldren in some broth or pottage and eate thereof. The greene middle Barke of the branches, doeth not much vary from the leaues crops, but that it is stronger in operation, purging with paine and violence. The seed especially, the litle flat seeds dryed one dram drunk at morne with wine, are good for the dropsie, and are good for them that are fat would be leaner being vsed a certaine space. Swellings and hote tumours, stamp the greene leaues apply them. Gout paines, stamp the greene leaues apply them with Deares sewet or buls tallow. Sleepe to cause, warme the leaues betweene two tiles, and bind them to the nape of the necke. Drop in the iuice into the eares to kill the wormes therein, and to clense out the matter and filth. Dropsie, seethe the roots and drinke the broth at morne, noone, euen to cure it perfectly. Headach, heat the leaues betweene two tiles and apply it. To preserue life long, gather the flowers on Midsommer day, and drinke a spoonefull thereof with a draught of Burrage water morne and euen xxx. dayes. Burnings or scaldings, boyle the inner rynd with sheepes tallowe, and sheepes doung and anoynt therewith, and it shall not be seene. The leaues sodden in Wine and taken before meate, helpeth the dropsie, and is good against venemous bitings. The same sodden in water and the vapour thereof taken vp into the matrixe, doeth soften, open, and amende the hurtes that are commonly about it, and so doeth the fruite being drunke in wine. The tender and fresh leaues applyed with barly meale, swage inflammations, and are good for burnings and bitings of dogs. The same doeth glew together all hollowe and gaping sores like fistulaes. The powder of the leaues and tender crops gathered at the spring of the yeere and taken with Pease broth, doeth soften the belly. The water is good to wash the head or any other place, against such griefes as come with the heate of the sunne, and so doeth the Mushromes or Iewes eare, being steeped in water of Eldren flowers or of Roses. The leaues or water applyed, help the bitings of serpents and vipers, and healeth vp running sores or fistulaes. Eares running, put in the iuice of Eldren and of Violets. Swelling in the throat, apply the greene Barke with salt. Milt stopt, seethe the root in white wine to the third part and drink it. Liuer and milt stopt, seethe the leaues with Smallach and drink the broth. Knees swollen, seethe the leaues in water and bathe therwith. Knees ach great, and legs likewise, stamp the leaues with Fiueleafe, and Penyroyall with barrowes grease and apply them. Feet swollen, bath them in the decoction thereof or of the leaues. Burning or scalding, take the inner Barke, a quarter of a pound of sheeps sewet, and sheeps tretles ana halfe a pound, frye them and streine it and vse it. Leapry of flegme, seethe the leaues in strong wine and bath therewith. Morphue, drink three spoonefuls of the water fasting, and walke till you sweat, steepe ix. Oke apples slised in a pinte of white vineger three dayes and wash therewith. Burning and scalding, boyle the inner Barke of Eldren with newe grease, put thereto Mastick, Frankincense and waxe, and boyle againe vntill it be melted, and anoynt often therewith. Dropsie, vse syrop made of the tendrels of Danewort and Eldren, or seethe halfe a pound of the inner Barke next the wood in a pottell of the clarified iuice of water Cresses till the third part be wasted, then put thereto a quart of good Hidromell, and one pound of hony, and seethe them together, clarifie them, put it into a cleane vessell when it is cold, and stop it close: it is the best medicine that may be had. Vse the middle Barke of Eldren to cure the dropsie, but if it haue continued a yeere it is hardly curable. Or vse the seeds of Eldren or wine of the decoction of Eldren roots, or of Isop Eldren. Eyes dull, drinke the roots of Eldren, and make lee of the asshes of them, wash the head therewith for the swimming thereof, and of the eyes. Feete swollen apply the middle Barke of Eldren with bores grease bring first boyled in water. Gout, stampe the Barke of the rootes with white wine, and apply it. Make powder of the Beries dryed in the Sunne where no raine commeth, and drinke the same with good Wine to cleare the voyce. Vomit to cause, take two drammes of the greene Barke of rootes of Eldren. To cause sweate, lay some of the leaues and flowers vnder the nether sheete. Feuer quotidian, take powder of the inner barke of Eldren rootes, with an egshell full of aqua vitae three mornings fasting to purge the flegme whereof the Feuer commeth: or seethe the sayde Barke in a quart of Ale or Beere one handfull, and drinke it. Belly bound, dry the flowers two or three dayes in the sunne, keepe them in a bladder, and when neede is dry them as Saffron, and take thereof with Ale or pottage to haue three or foure stooles by and by. Reines impostume, wash olde guilts grease twise or thrise in water, and stampe it with greene Barke of Eldren and Wallwort, and anoynt the reines therewith, and apply a plaister of wheate flower and butter. Belly bound, mixe powder of a milstone with the iuice of the middle Barke of the Eldren, and apply it to thy stomacke to cause vomite, and to thy nauell to purge downewards. Itch, boyle the middle Barke with oyle Oliue, and keepe it, and when neede is put thereto powder of Masticke and Oliban and vse it. Sleepe to cause, mixe the iuice of Lettuse and Eldren with oyle of Violets, set them in a pot into a vessell of seething water till it be thick, and anoynt thy forehead and temples therewith. Apostume to draw outwards, stamp the leaues of Eldren and Briers, with white Mustard seede, and apply it. Legs swollen of trauell, or humours with heat, wash them with the decoction of the leaues or Barke of Eldren and salt. Bloody flixe, lay Eldren flowers three houres in vineger, then stampe them and streine them, and drinke it with wine or Ale. To keepe them all the yeere, steepe them seuen houres in vineger, then dry them in the sunne, and when neede is, make powder thereof, and drinke it with red wine or vineger. Burnings and scaldings, stamp Smallach and the greene Barke of Eldren ana like much, and fry them with the doung and sewet of sheepe, and strein it and anoynt therewith till it be whole: prooued. with salt and pepper ana like much, and apply it. Chollike and Iliacke, apply powder of a milstone with the middle barke of Elderne. Chollicke and stone, drinke powder of the flowers with water of Woodramsons morne and euen. Dropsie, scrape the roote cleane, and slice it and steepe it in white wine, and drinke the wine. good ointment: Receiue Elderne berries, one gallon, blacke sope one pound, set them in the ground three weekes in an earthen pot, then melt it and streine it: if you will make it hard, put thereto tallowe and pitch and vse it. Eares impostume and deafenesse, put in the iuice of the buddes, leaues, barke, or young branches blood warme: prooued. Legges swolne, dropsie, goute, ache, and feuers: Stampe the leaues of Eldren and Bloodworte with Bay salt and and frye them with Bores grease, and apply it plaster wise. Seethe the greene leaues in water to pap, and lay them on a peece of red clothe, and anoint the Emerods with oyle Oliue, and then apply it as hote as may be suffered, and as it cooleth, apply newe and doe so all night, if neede be to cure it in one night. Flies to auoide, seethe the leaues with and Cummin in water, and sprinckle the house or chamber therewith. For the windie dropsie, mixe two ounces of water of the roote of Danewoorte with foure ounces of Elderne, and drinke it thirtie mornings together early in the morning. Dropsie and oppilation of the liuer, distill the flowers in Balneo Mariae, and drinke three ounces morning and euening. Bruise, stampe the leaues with the white of an Egge, and applie it. stampe the leaues of it, or the young shootes and toppes thereof with nine leaues of Sage, and fifteene cornes of Pepper and apply it betweene the cheeke and the teethe that doe ake. Warts to auoide, put three droppes of the blood of a Warte into an Eldren leafe, and burie it in the earth, and the Wartes will vanish away: or put three small stones into a leafe and lay it in the way, and hee that taketh it vp shall haue the Wartes. Chollicke, drinke the greene barke with stale Ale. Goute, anoint it often with the iuice of the berries Swelling, bruise the leaues with ground mustard, and applie it. Wartes, wash them with the iuice of the berries when the berries be blacke, and doe so euery night, and so binde them to in the nights. Feuer generall Feuer quotidian Fistulae Fleas to kill Flegme to purge Flies to auoide Goute Haire to be blacke Iliacke Inflammations Itche Knees ache Knees swolne Leane to be Leapry Legs swolne Throate swollen Voice to be cleare Vomite to cause Wartes ELlebore white, the roote causeth to vomite vp mightely all superfluous, slimie, venemous, and noughtie humors, and is good against the falling sickenesse, frensie, olde paine of the head, madnesse, sadnesse, the goute, the sciatica, all sortes of dropsies, poyson, and all colde diseases that be hard to cure, and such as will The roote with oyle or oyntments, is good against all roughnesse of the skinne, wilde knobs, foule spots and leapry. The same cut in slices and put into fistulaes, taketh away their hardnesse. The same put in as a pessarie, draweth downe the termes or dead birth. The same boyled in vineger and holden in the mouth, swageth And put into drie medicines, it doeth cleare and sharpen the sight. The roote punned with meale hony, killeth mise rats, and such like, and driueth them away: and likewise waspes flies, if it be boyled in milke and they eate thereof, for then they swell and breake. It is not good to be giuen vnprepared, nor to yong, old, or sicke folke: they that be weake, that spit blood, or be grieued in their stomacke, nor to women with childe, nor in winter, but in sommer only, and before supper. Put it into the greater end of a radish roote one night, then presse it hard out, and take one dram of it in milke or frumentie to helpe the falling sicknesse, vertigo, melancholie, madnesse, white leapry, windes in the guts, dropsie, tympany, goutes, quartens, cough, and many such like griefes. It is giuen fasting by it selfe, or with sesame seedes, or with broth, or with sodden barley, or with mede, or with pottage, or with a lentill broth, or any such like supping. Some giue it with a great deale of broth or supping. Some giue a little meate immediatly before it, especially to them that are weake, so it may be taken without ieopardy. Vomit to cause, put a suppositor of it into the fundament. houres in wine, or Oximel, and drie it, and drinke halfe a dram of the powder of it with wine to helpe madnes, melancholy, such griefes as be writte~ of in black Ellebore. But to take it without danger, steepe it ii. dayes in wine, or seeth it in the broth of flesh, and take a siat thereof to purge both vpwarde downeward. Put it into the nose with Margerom to cleanse the braine and head. The roote sodden with lee, or mixt with any ointment killeth lice and nits, and taketh away the scurfe of the head. Ellebor white, healeth the scab morphue, tetters, purgeth choller flegme, and being applied, it cureth ye Emerods. Mixe i. dram wt syrup, of ii. parts of hony, i. part of vineger, to purge flegme and melancholie to helpe madnesse and reume, and to worke both vpward and downeward. It is corrected with long pepper, hysope, daucus, and aniseede. It worketh better and with lesse danger, if it be boyled with the broth of a Capon or any other meate, and then the broth drunke. Head skalde, apply white Ellebore with as much swines grease. Vomite to cause, take one scruple with pease broth, or one penie waight with some broth. Steepe two drams in two ounces of aqua vitae, in a close vessell dayes, then streine it and drinke two drams of it with one ounce of wine to comfort and purge the body. Head wormes falling of the haire, stampe it with swines grease, and apply it all ouer the head. Head to purge, blowe powder of Ellebore, Pepper, Castory into thy nose. Mixe the iuice with course meale as it commeth from the millstone and butter, and apply it to the stomacke to purge vpward, and on the nauell to purge downeward. Leapry, or any other deformitie of the skinne, seethe it with Louage and Fenell in wine, and wash therewith. Steepe white Ellebore in milke, and put white Arsnike to it, and sprinckle it to kill Flease. Eares paine, seethe it halfe in vineger and put it in. Face freckles and other spots, seethe one ounce in halfe a pinte of strong white vineger to the one halfe, then mixe therewith hony three spoonefull, Mercurie sublimate one peny waight, and seethe it till it become thicke, and anoint therewith the morphue, freckles, staynings, and all deformities of the skinne. Feuers quarten Fistula Flease Flies Flowers stopt Freckles Frensie Gnats Gouts ELlebore blacke: the roote steeped in wine, made into powder, and drunke, helpeth them that be mad, melancholy and witlesse, the falling sicknesse, swimming in the head, giddinesse, goute, dropsie, feuers quarten, leapry, crampes, torments of the intralles. Put it into the matrix to drawe downe the termes, and into malignant vlcers fistulaes, and old woundes to cleanse them. Stampe it with vineger, and apply it to heale skabs, spots, leapry, tetters, and ringwormes, and it doeth merueilously heale gangrenes, and is vsed in eating medicines. It purgeth flegme and choller downeward, either by it selfe or with Scamonie, or with one dram or one scruple a halfe of salt. It is also good with Lentiles, or broths which are taken for purgations. It is good to be put iii. dayes into fistulaes to skoure them. And put iii. dayes into the eares that are deafe, it helpeth them much. Laid to by it selfe or with vineger, it healeth kernels, skurfe, and leapries. Dropsie, apply a plaster thereof made with Barley meale and vineger. The pith ought to be taken out of blacke Ellebore, as wel as out of ye white. Blacke Ellebore hath all the vertues of the white Ellebore, and more. Drinke iii. penie waight to cast out wormes, to clense flegme and melancholie and the dropsie. In a pessary it cleanseth the matrix, and draweth downe the dead birth. The iuice helpeth horses of the bots, swine that be infected, and put into their eares, it helpeth paine of their heads. It is so bitter, that no beastes nor foules dare eate thereof, but only quailes. Taken inwardly, it purgeth grosse, thicke, and chollerike humors, and helpeth madnesse, melancholie, the goute, and sciatica, being taken in pottage, or sodden with boyled meate, and the broth drunke or taken with long pepper, hysope, daucus, and anyseedes. Cattel sicke or hurt, cut the beast in some place, and put in powder of blacke Ellebore to drawe out the poysoned humor, and to helpe presently. Face spots, mixe powder of the roote of blacke Ellebore, one dramme of Irios, two drams with hony, and anoint at night, and in the morning wash it with water. Eares ache, seethe one dram of the rootes well in one pound of vineger, and receiue vp the fume, and when it is almost colde, put two drops into the eare, or seethe Ellebore, Castorie, and Piretrum, with strong wine and drop it in, and prouoke sneesing. The powder of it killeth Rats. Bearefoote purgeth by seege mightely both melancholie, and other superfluous humors. Taken inward, it purgeth the neather partes of the body from grosse and thicke flegme, and chollerike humors. The roote of common Bearefoote steeped in wine and drunke, doeth loosen the belly like blacke Ellebore, and is good for all such things as it is good for, one dram thereof taken with wine. The same boyled in water with Rue and Egrimony, healeth the Iaundies, and purgeth yellowe superfluities by seege. The same thrust into ye eares of oxen, sheepe, and other cattell, helpeth them against the diseases of the lungs, and draweth all the corruption into the eares. If in the plague time the roote be put into any part of the body, it draweth thither all the corruption and infection as it doeth in beastes in the time of any murren, infection, or rot. Wormes in the head, apply it all ouer the head with Swines grease. ELme: head skurfe, seethe the middle barke in water and wash therewith. Burning or skalding, doe off the vppermost barke of yong Elme, and slice the greene barke, steepe it in running water two or three houres till it become a ielly, and anoint with it often to haue speedy remedie, or cast on ye ashes of the rinde, it healeth them without skarres. Eares dull, doe with it as with Ash. The leaues falling before their time, doe foreshewe a death of cattell. To mittigate all kindes of griefes, gather the water in the cods of the leaues, keepe it in a glasse close, sunne it twelue dayes and anoint therewith. Skurfe or skales in the head, or browes, or bearde, anoint with the iuice of the leaues. Fistula and canker, stampe the barke with wormewood and water, and apply it. Burnings, seethe the rinde halfe a day in water, and gather the thicke creame on the water, and anoint therewith. The leaues heale greene woundes being laide to, and so doeth the inner barke laide to. The brothe of the leaues, barke, or roote, is good to bathe armes or legges in, that are broken or bruised, for it healeth broken bones speedely. Leapry and skurfe, stampe the leaues with vineger and apply them. Drinke one ounce of the barke with wine or water to expell colde flegme and loosen the belly. The liquour in the leaues to cleanse the skinne, and beautifie it, and skowreth away all spots, freckles, pimples, and spreading tetters being laid to, and also healeth fresh and greene woundes being powred in. The greene leaues stampt with vineger and anointed, healeth the leapry effectually, and binde wounds together. ENdiue, the leaues sodden are vsed in medicine, but not the roote nor the dryed leaues. Endiue comforteth the heart and liuer both in heate and colde. Kings euill, drinke the syrupe of Endiue with water of the decoction of hearts tongue, it is a singular remedie. Liuer hote, apply the hearbe, or for want thereof, the bruised seedes. Cardiake passion, stampe it with vineger, and apply it to the left pap. Apply it with vineger, and Ceruse, to the holy fire, hote apostume and headache comming of heate. Drinke ye hearbe with wine for griefes of the liuer and bladder. Drinke it ii. or iii. dayes for spitting blood, and excesse of sperme. Drinke the distilled water ii. ounces, morne euen for straitnesse stopping of ye breast, and so it is also good for women with child to strengthen them their senses. Drinke iiii. or v. ounces morne and euen to helpe ye plague and the kings euill, to quench thirst, qualifie the heate of the liuer, the The water drunke, helpeth the stitch at the heart, the iaundies, the inflamed liuer. Liuer to cleanse, take wood of saunders, with water of cheruile and endiue, of ech an ounce and a halfe at thrise three mornings. Liuer chafte, vse it in brothes, and steepe it in water, and drinke it. Cough, shortnesse of breath, and paine of the stomacke, apply it plasterwise to the stomacke. Dropsie of hote cause, eate it and drinke the decoction thereof. Drinke the iuice with hote water for the stopping of the liuer and milt, the iaundies, the feuer tertian, and great heat of the stomacke and liuer. Milt stopt Plague Side griefes Spitting blood Stitch Stomack hote EPithime, wash haire with the decoction thereof, to make it yelow. Vrine distilling, seethe it in good wine and oile oliue, and apply it hote betweene the nauill and the priuities. EVphorbium, Teethach of humors, launce betwixt them, and rub ye place with a litle of the powder on thy fingers end weted and dipt therein. Pricking in the sinewes, mixe olde oyle an ounce, with waxe three drammes, and Euphorbium one dramme, Headach, anoint with old oile and three or foure graines of Euphorbium. Wearines, weaknesse, and nummednesse, take waxe an ounce, Euphorbium a dram beaten in a morter with fiue or sixe droppes of oile, and temper them ouer the fire with as much oile as will make it a searecloth, and apply it to the reines of the backe. Goute, take waxe a pound, oile oliue ten pou~d, good wine two pound, boile it til the wine be consumed: then put thereto fine powder of Euphorbium foure ounces, anoint therewith. Glandules, schrophules, and kernels, mixe the iuice of wild lilie with Euphorbium, and take seuen pilles thereof thirty mornings, to expel them quite, that none remaine. Haire falling, anoint with Euphorbium and oile. Eares dul, put in powder of Euphorbium with the iuice of housleek. Lust to cause, stampe it with bayes arom wel with oile, anoint the virge therwith. Feet, or any other member sleepe, mixe Euphorbium with as much Agryppa, and boile them in wine, till the wine be consumed, and anoynt therewith. Feuer quotidian, mixe half a dram with an egge shel ful of aqua vitae, and take it three mornings together to purge the slime wherof it commeth. Lyturgie, holde the powder to thy nose in a cloute to cause neesing. Fistula to heale, make a tent of Euphorbium, masticke, and French sope ana like much, and put it in. Euphorbium purgeth tough, colde and slimy flegmes, and choller from the sinewes and farre parts, and is good for old headach, palsie, crampe, weakenesse, that followeth the French pocks, the pain of the sinewes, and extreme partes that are of long continuance, and the iaundies, and is good also against the plague, and such like contagious sicknesses. Make a plaister thereof with twelue times so much oyle and a little waxe, which is singular good against all paynes and aches of the ioyntes, takings, lamenesse, palsies, crampes, shrinking of the sinewes, and all aches and disorder of the same. Mixe it with Boares greace, oyle debay, or Wolfes greace, or such like, to cure the skurfe of the head, and baulde places, to cause the haire to growe againe, beeing anoynted with it: not onelie the head, Mixe it with oyle, and stroake it on the temples for the Lytargie, sleepinesse, and raging, to waken them and quicken their spirites againe. And applie it to the necke, or nape of the necke, to restore speeche lost by the Apoplexia. Mixe it with vineger, and stroake it on the place to take away all foule and euill fauoured spottes of the bodie, especially the white skurfe and skale of the skinne. Mixe it with oyle, and vse it against falling of the haire and baldenesse. It may bee mixed with as much masticke and gumme Dragagant, and put into the middest of an vnbaked loafe, and so baked, and the crumme taken, and made into small pilles, which are singular good against the weaknes that followeth the French pockes, and all payne of the outward parts. It may be mixt with as much masticke, and made into pilles with the iuice of orenges, and so it is excellent against the plague. Seethe it with oyle of eldren, beane flowre, and earth wormes, and vse it against pricking in the sinewes. Crampe Choller Eares dull Fistula Falling euill Flegme French pockes. Skinne clensing Sleepie members Speech lost Taken Teethach Wearinesse Eringium. ERingium, the leaues are good to be eaten in sallads. The rootes boyled in wine, and drunke, are good for the chollicke, and gryping of the belly, and expelleth winde, prouoketh termes, and is good against the stone, and grauell, and paine in making water: it prouoketh vrine, expelleth the stone, and cureth the griefes of the kidneys being drunke fifteene dayes together, and is good for the griefes of the liuer, and all venimous bytings or poyson, especially drunke with the seede of wilde carrots: it helpeth also the crampe and the falling sicknesse. Bytings venimous, especially of Frogges, stampe the greene hearbe, and applie it. The roote preserued or comfited, is good for olde folkes, and others that are wasted and withered, to restore them againe, and so is the roote of the thistle Centum capita: but not so good. The roote drunke, expelleth the vrine and termes, it is drunke with wilde carrot seedes against many griefes. Apply it to wartes and swellings, to cause them to fall: it may bee kept in vineger, vrine, or sugar, or honie, as Sperage and Sampere are kept, and condited. Seeth the root in wine, and drink it against against the griefes of the liuer, mylte and lungs, the torments of the bellie and inflammations. Drinke a dramme with some bruised seedes of wilde carrots to resist poyson that hath beene drunke. Drinke the rootes with Hydromel for the cricke in the backe, and the falling sicknesse. Bones bare without flesh, stampe the roote, salt, and swines greace, and applie it. The yong leaues may be boyled, and with salt and oyle preserued for sallads. The hearbe with the roote, must bee gathered when the Sunne is in Cancer. They be blacke without, and white within; very aromatike like spice. The herbe or roote made in powder, infusion, or decoction, and drunke, cleanseth the reines, bladder, and Matrix, and prouoketh termes. It greatly preuaileth against the chollicke, and torments of the bellie, being drunke with Hydromel. The roote must bee tender sodden and preserued in sucket, for meate or medicine in Winter, and to restore nature. Drinke a dramme of the roote with wine against the stinging of any venemous beast or worme, or the Feuer. Drinke it sixteene dayes morne and euen, to cure all griefes of the Liuer griefes Lungs griefes Matrix to cleanse Milt griefes Poyson drunke ERisimon, licke in the seede often with honie, to cleanse the breast and lungs, shortnesse of breath, and the olde cough, the seedes beeing first steeped in faire water, and then dryed by the fire, or lapped in paste and baked, for else it will bee too hote. Vse the same seede so prepared, against the iaundies, gryping in the bellie, the sciatica, and all venimous bytings. Mixe the seede with honie and water, and vse it for hidden cankers, harde swellings, impostumes behinde the eares, olde and harde impostumes of the breasts, and genitors applied, for it wasteth colde swellings. Bellyach Bytings venimous Breast griefes Breath short Coddes swollen Cough olde Hard swelling Impostumes Iaundies Kanker Lungs griefes Sciatica Swelling Esula. ESula, the iuice, seede or roote, purgeth chollericke and sharpe humours, like the Tythimalles, and are in all thinges of the nature of the Tythimalles. The seede and leaues doe the same things that the iuice doeth. Bellie wormes, kill them with other things, and then take two drammes of Esula to expell them. Steepe the barke of Esula, or Tythimall in vineger foure and twentie houres, and drie it, and make it into powder, and put thereto anniseedes, or fennell seedes, dragagant, and masticke, and minister it with some colde liquor, as of endiue, or cicory, or orenges, and so it will not inflame the throte. FEarne: wormes to kil, drink an ounce of powder of the rootes dissolued in wine. Burnings, burne it and apply it with the white of an egge. Wounds, festers, and cankers, stampe them with their roots, wash the griefes with the iuice, and apply the drosse. Mother suffocat. seeth louage, hissop, wormwood, and Fearn leaues, apply them to the nauil and shares. Chop a basket ful of Fearn and seeth it in a bag in the third part of a tun of water, and bathe therin to restore the strength of the sinewes. Milt paine, seethe the root in water and drinke it. The root of male Fearne, called Osmund rosal half an ounce taken with honied water, killeth, and expelleth wormes. The leaues of both Fearns put into bedstraw, driueth away punises, all other such worms. Worms broad, drink foure ounces of the root of male Fearne with twelue graines of Diagridium, or twelue graines of blacke ellebore, but take garlick before it. Wounds made with reede, drinke the root and also apply it. Wormes both round and broad, drink three drams of the roote of female Fearne. powder of the roote, the same healeth the galling of the neckes of oxen. Belly bound, seeth the young greene leaues with other worts, vse them. Burnings, apply the iuice of the roots with rose water, or cold water to heale it when all other things faile: it doth the like with water of cowes dung. If a horse be sick, and it is not knowen whereof, put a portion of the roote vnder his tongue, and he shal by by cast out his excrements both waies, and so rise and do wel. Powder of the root is good for all moist vlcers both of man and beast. The powder of brakes doeth heale dangerous sores both of men, kine, swine, &c. Barren to be Belly bound Burnings FEnegreke, Apostumes, and the plurisie to dissolue them, boyle it with linseed, oyle of violets and butter, and applie it. Gut to cleanse, seethe halfe an ounce of the meale in a pinte of water, and to the cleerest of it, put one ounce of honie and drinke thereof morne and euen. Guttes fretting, drinke halfe an ounce of the meale, with two drammes of honie, with warme water first and last, to purge out all superfluous slime, and auoyde the paine. Impostume inward to breake, seethe the meale with water that mallowes haue beene sodden in, and apply it. For the hoste, liuer, and lungs, and milt, stampe bayes, Fenegreke, pepper, and boile them in ale, and take a spoonful of it euery day. Reines apostums, stamp mallowes holy oke, with Fenegreke, bearfoot, and swines greace, and apply it. Apost. generall, seethe it with holy oke linseed, stamp them with butter or swines greace, and apply it, being first boiled with barlie meale. it and honie in the iuice of Hoorhound and water cresses to an electuarie, and vse it. Plurisie, applie the roote of holie oke with Fenigreeke, branne of hempeseede and butter. Voyce to bee cleere, seeth it with hyssope, and peniroyall, and white wine, and drinke it. Gonorrhoea, seeth the seedes in water till the third part be wasted, and drink foure ounces morn euen three or foure dayes to cure it. Bruise, seethe it with wheat bran, hony, and larde in white wine, and apply it to aches, bruises, or goutes, &c. Byles and botches, seethe it in linseed with cowes milke and water, and apply it. Belly bound, seeth it in water and drinke it to losen the belly without perill. The decoction, or broth of the seeds drunke with a litle vineger, expelleth all euill humours that sticke in the bowels. The same decoction first made with dates, and after with hony, til it come to the thicknes of syrrop, doeth clense and cure the griefes of the brest, so that the patient haue no feuer nor headach, for then it is euil. The meale sodde~ with meed helpeth cold hard apostumes, swellings. Sit in the decoction thereof, or bathe in the decoction of it for the impostumes, vlcers, and stopping of the matrix. Mixe the straining or iuice with goose greace, and put it into the matrix, to soften al hardnes pain of the necke thereof. Wash the skurfe skale and nittes of the head, with the decoction therof. Apply it with brimston hony to pushes, pimples, spots, wheales, maunge, skurfe itch of the face or els where to heale it. Rawnes, vlceration, and feeblenes of any part, apply greene Fenegreke, with a litle vineger. The seedes prepared as lupines, may be eaten, and is of like vertue, and loseneth the bellie gently. The yong crops are good in sallades with vineger and oyle: but beeing too much vsed, it bringeth headach, and ouerturneth the stomacke. Sodden in honied water, and drunke, it softeneth all inwarde impostumes, and helpeth the payne of the intralles. Vse the decoction of the meale for the griefes of the lunges and the olde cough. Seethe the seedes in water, and straine it, and vse it to heale spreading sores of the head, and the skurfe, and skall, and to make the haire to growe. Put the same with Goose greace into the Matrix or fundament, to inlarge them in the passage place. Vse the meale in glisters for the torments and exulceration of the bowels. The meale sodden with wine and Saltpeter doeth quickely take away the skalles and skurfe of the head or beard. The oyle thereof cleanseth spots and skarres of bruses or wounds, and the hote apostumes of the priuities. Reines running Skinne off to clense Speech lost Sores Swellings FEuerfue: take two drammes of the powder of it with hony, to purge by siege melancholy and flegme, and to helpe giddinesse and swimming or turning in the head, for shortnes of breath, pensiuenesse and sadnesse. Seethe the herbe without the flowers in water, and drinke it for the stone. Seethe it in wine, and apply it to the nauill, heart, or side for the suffocation, hardnesse, and stopping of the mother. Sit in the decoction of it for the hardnesse, and swelling, and inflammation of the mother. Stampe the greene leaues with the flowers, and apply it to the wilde fire, and other inflammations of cholar. with Salt, and apply it to the wrists of children at euery xxiiii. houres ende especially to auoyd the ague. Drinke the iuice or powder to loose the belly, to driue downe flegme choller, to kill wormes, clense the matrixe, and helpe colde feuers. Giue it with salt to cattell to helpe their swelling and difficultie of breathing. Stampe the greene herbe and apply it to the greefes of the belly. It hath also the vertues of wormemood and of centorie: and Tansie hath the same vertues. Drinke the herbe and flower for shortnesse of winde and the stone: but Tansie is better for men, and Feuerfue better for women. Feuerfue comforteth the stomacke, and is good for the Feuer quotidian, the crampe, and coldnesse of the stomake, it cureth venemous bitings being applied. Stampe it and apply it to wounds wherein are broken bones, and to knit and heale them. Stampe it and apply it aboue a botch to remooue it from place to place. Stomacke gleet stampe it with Auense, and drinke it with stale Ale morne and Euen. Feuer quotidian, stampe it with as much Smallach, and streine them with water, and drinke thereof when the fitte commeth thrise and be whole, or drinke the iuice of it and Smallach of ech ii. handfuls with small Ale warme before the fit, and couer thee well to sweate. Gout, stampe it with as much Saint Mary Garlike and applie it. Vomiting, take it iii. dayes with a rere Egge and bee whole. Eares ache and dindling, put in the iuice and stope it in. Fluxes generall, seeth it in water, and sit ouer the fume of it. Heart greefs, seeth it in wine with salt and drinke it. Drinke the iuice of Motherwort and Feuerfue with grosse Pepper in olde Ale and be whole. Gout, anoynt with the iuice and a Neats Gaule mingled together warme. FEnnell, head pushes and vlcers, seethe the seedes with wine in a glasse, and anoynt therewith. Eyes watering, seethe the rootes with Betonye, and wash therewith. Eyes greefs, seethe the roote in water, and put in a drop. Eyes blemish, bruise Camphere and streine it with the iuice vse it. Vomit to cause, stampe the roote of Fennell and Mugwort with wormewood leaues drinke it with warme water and honie, to prouoke it presently. Eyes watry, seeth it with water in an earthen pot, and put it into the eyes. For the host, griefs of breast, heart, stomacke sides, and to cause appetite, seeth ii. parts of the iuice with iii. parts of hony to the thickenes of hony, and put Pepper to it, and eate iii. spoonefuls euery day. Stomacke swollen, seeth the rootes of Fenell Smallach in wine of ech like much, temper them with water, drinke it fasting. Stampe Louage, Persly, Fenell of ech like much, and temper them with water, drinke it for the griefes of the bladder to void the vrine well. Cods swollen, seeth the roots of Persly and Fenell in water, and dip clowts therein and apply it often. Headach, seethe red Fennell, Feuerfue and Sage of ech like much in strong Lee to the one halfe, and wash therewith as hote as may bee suffered: or stampe red Fenell, Camomile, Sage and Cummin, and apply it. Heart burning, chewe crops of Fennell, and sucke downe the iuice, and spit out the rest. Belly windie, seethe powder of the seedes of Fennell, Annise and Cummin in wine, and drinke it. Stytch, stampe red Fennell and red Docks, and frye them with May Butter, and apply it. Brayne feeble, mixe Centorie, Rue, and red Fennell seedes withstrong vineger, and drinke it in the mornings. Cough and Kings euill, stampe Isope and Fennill roots, and straine them with ale, and drinke it at euen hote, at morne colde. Head white skall, shaue it, and apply Coprose with the iuice of Fennill. Vomit to stop, stampe Fennill, and drinke it with wine. Milke to increase, seeth the roots of Fennill and Parsnip in the broth of a chicken, and eate them with a little fresh butter. Eyes dim and dazling, seethe the iuice of Fennill roots with as much hony, to the thicknes of hony, and keepe it in a brasse vessell, and when need is, mixe thereof with womans milke that suckleth a boy, and apply it. To open the pipes, stuffe eight figges with Fennill seeds, and seethe them with a little Isope and two branches of Organy in a pottle of water to the one halfe, then straine it, and put thereto Suger candie, drinke thereof warme. Headache, seethe Rue and Red Fennill, and wash the head therewith. Liuer and milt griefs, vse the decoction or powder thereof, or of the rinde of the root. For the ptisike, dryskab, burning or skalding, presse out the oile betweene two hote tiles or plates, and vse it. Leane to be, seethe it in water, and straine it, and drinke it first and last. Ptisike dry and cold, drinke the iuice of the roots with white wine. Stomake colde, vrine stopt, and for the stone, seethe it with Parsley Smalach, of ech like much, and drinke it. Dropsie, seethe the seeds in water, vse much of it in thy wine, or vse powder of the seeds of Fennill, Anise, and Peony in thy drinke, or seethe Fennill roots in thy wine. Eyes griefs, apply the iuice of Rue and Fennill with cotton. Eyes bruised and redde, mixe powder of Cummin with the iuice of Fennill rootes and white wine, and seethe them with a gentle fire, and straine it two or three times, and put one droppe of it into the eyes. Flowers stopt, seethe Sauin with the rootes of Smalach, Parsley and Fennill in wine, and straine it, and drinke it. For all headache, seethe Rue Fennill in water, and wash thy head therewith. Liuer stopt of colde cause, clense it with the seeds of smalach, Fennil, Dill. Megrem, stampe long Planten, Fennill, and Betony with womans milke, and apply it, and as the griefe remoueth folow it therewith till it come to the ridge bone. Stomake colde, seethe Nutmegs and Maces with Fennill seeds and Stomake weake, seethe Maces in the iuice of Fennill, and drinke the decoction with wine. Strangury, seethe the leaues of Fennill, Smalach, and Parsley with Wheat branne, and apply it: or seethe the roots of Fennill, Parsley, Smalach, and Water cresses in white wine, and drinke the broth, and apply the roots with the leaues of Water cresses plaister wise. Trembling, vse the seedes of Fennill and Parsley mixt together. Vomit to stoppe, seethe two parts of the iuice of Fennill with one part of Hony, till it be thicke, and vse it morne euen. Headache, bathe sometimes in a bath made with Fennill. Loines ache, seethe the roots in water, and drinke it morne and euen. Vrin to cause, stampe Smalach, Parsley and Fennill, of ech like much, and seethe them, and put Butter to them, and apply it to the lomes and secret parts hote. Strangury, vse the roots. Eyes bloudy, anoint with the iuice of Redde Fennill roots Hony. Vomit to cause, seethe two parts of the iuice with one part of Hony, till it be thicke, and drinke thereof morne and euen. Stomacke swollen, stampe the roots of Fennill and Smalach, of ech like much, and straine them with wine, and drinke it at euen warme, and at morne colde. Milke to increase, drinke the iuice of Fennill and Veruin. Lungs and milt to restore, seethe two parts of the iuice with three parts of Hony to an electuary, and vse thereof morne euen. Liuer wasting, seethe Water cresse, Red Fennill, and Sorrell, with a chicken, in an earthen pot, and vse it nine dayes. Liuer milt stopt, and for the dropsie, make a sirrup with the iuice of Fennill Dawke, and vse it. Slender to be, eat two or three cloues of Garlike, with as much Bread and Butter, morne and euen three houres before and after meate, and drinke water wherein Fennill hath bene sodden, morne euen foureteene dayes. Dropsy, drinke three halfepeny weight of powder of the Adamant, with the iuice of Fennill, to expell the water. Cough extreame, seethe the roots with bruised Aniseed Licoras in White wine, and drinke a good draught to bedward, and in the morning eat a Figge and a Date rosted, somewhat hote, two or three houres before meat, and doe so three or foure times. seedes in Barley water and drinke it, or seethe Ryce in milke with croms of white bread, Suger and Fennell seede, and vse it. Or drinke powder of Fennell seede and Christall of ech like much with wine. Eyes dull and giddie, let a childe eate sweete Fennell seedes euery morning, and then licke the diseased eyes. Horsenesse and straitnesse of the breast, seeth Mullyn, Fennill, and Lycoras in water or wine till it be tender, then streine it and suger it, and drinke thereof. Chollike, make powder of Fennell seedes ii. ounces, Mynts as much as can bee taken vp with three fingers, and drinke thereof i. dram with vi. ounces of warme wine. Leane to be, Drinke Fennell, and eate the seedes daily. Cough perillous, Stampe the roots and streine them with wine or ale, and drinke it nine dayes morne and euen. Stomake swollen, dry cough, and headach, stampe the roote of Fennell and Smallach, and streine them with white wine and drinke it fasting. Stomake swollen and gleete about the Heart, Liuer, Lungs, and Mylt, boyle two ounces of the iuice with three ounces of Honie till it waxe thicke, and vse it as an electuarie first and last, the body being first well purged. Vomiting and weakenesse of the stomake, to cleanse the Lungs, to comfort the Mylt, to destroy Rume, and for all griefes of the braine, seethe two parts of the iuice, with one part of Honie, till it be thicke, and drinke thereof morne and euen with sodden water. Eyes dull, make an oyntment of the iuice of Rue and Fennell with hony, and anoynt therewith, or eate them, and let thy breath goe into thine eyes. For the feuer, poyson, and to cleanse the stomacke and sharpen the sight, eate Fennell seedes, but it must bee vsed as medicine, and not as meate. Byting of an Addar, stampe Rue and redde Fennell with Butter and fyre it, and streine it and drinke it, and bee whole. To keepe a horse from all diseases, giue him good store of Fennell baked in his bread, and let him eate it three dayes, euery day aloafe. Eyes ache, mixe the iuice of red Fennell with Alome in a brasen vessell, and set it in the sunne xii. dayes, then keepe it in a boxe, and vse it when neede is. Eyes sore, anoynt with the iuice of Rue, and Fennell, and honie of ech like much. Milke to cause, seethe it in wine and drinke it. Leane to bee, seethe it in water and drinke it first and last. Chollike, drinke powder of the seeds of Fennell, Parslie and Alysander. For swelling in the stomacke and to cause Appetite, stampe the roote of Fennell and of Ash of eche like much, and streine it with wine and drinke it. Headache, seethe Rue and Fennell with water, and wash thy head therewith, and apply the herbes. The seedes comfort the stomacke, openeth the stoping of the Reines and Bladder, the iuice helpeth webs in the eyes. Drinke it with wine or water to expell all poyson and venome out of the body. Droppe it into the eares to kill wormes in them. Drinke it with wine to helpe the dropsie and all swellings, and to stoppe vomiting. Drinke it with wine and water to increase milke, with oyle it helpeth a swollen yard. Headache, drinke Fennell and Rue with Pepper in wine: Eyes dull, drop in the iuice of the rootes morne and euen. Vrine to cause and to expell the stone, drinke the iuice of Fennell, Smallach, Parsley and Pimpernell of eche like much with water. Biting of an Adder, seethe Rue, Betony and Fennell, in Butter, and drinke it. Stomake ach of colde or winde, eate powder of Filipendula and Fennell seedes together. The seedes, herbs, rootes and rynde, are vsed in medicine: gather the seedes in September, they may bee kept three yeeres. Boyle the herbe or seedes in faire water, and drinke a euery day to auoyde vnnaturall heat, and to clense the sight. The whole rootes may be pluckt vp in May and kept three yeeres. Stampe Fennell, and mixe it with olde Barrowes greace, and anoint the face therewith lightly, to auoyde the red spots like Leprie. To prouoke Vrin termes eate the seedes, likewise for the stopping of the Liuer and Milt, and the shedding of Vrine. Mixe the iuice with warme Milke, and giue it sucking children to helpe the hardnes of fetching breath. Seethe the rynde of the root and drinke it morne euen for the paine of the stone when it commeth of hote cause. Eate Fennell to comfort the stomake helpe digestion, or eate or drinke powder of the seeds. Seethe the rootes till they be soft, and apply them to womens Paps that begin to opostumate to heale them without harme. Put the iuice into a Tinne Poringer, and sunne it xv. dayes, and droppe thereof into the eyes to cleare their dimnesse, but if Aloes epatike be put thereto it is much the better: or boile the iuice betweene two dishes, and gather the dew of the vpper dish, and keepe it in a viall, and vse it, it mendeth the eyes greatly. Crampe and dropsy, seethe the roots in wine, and drinke it. Seethe the tufts in wine, potage, or ale, to helpe the bladder, reines, and stone, and to increase milke and natural seed. Fennill is good to wash the feet withall to bedward, and for Barbours baths, with Balme and Bayes. Stampe Fennill, Parsley, Water cresses, of ech like much, put there to White wine, and crummes of Barley bread, let it stand all night in a stone Morter, then straine it, and clarifie it, and drinke it to clense the reines from grauell, and stone, and cholar, for the strangury, and to cause much vrine. Fennill is good for fat men, to open the vaines and guts. Mixe the iuice of the roots with clarified Hony, and anoynt the eyes therewith for their rednesse. To increase milke, and prouoke termes, seethe the leaues in water or wine, and drinke it often. Seethe the seeds of Fennill, Anise, and Cummin in wine, and drinke a good draught first and last foure or fiue dayes to auoid winde in the belly marueilously. The decoction of the crops, easeth the paine of the kidneyes, expelleth the stone, vrin, and termes, and so doth the root, which is also good for the dropsie. Drinke the leaues or seeds with wine, against all venimous bitings or stingings. Drinke the seeds with water, for the paine and wambling of the stomake, and desiring to vomit. The herbe, seeds and root are very good to open and comfort the liuer, lungs, and kidneyes. Mad dog biting, stampe the root with Hony, and apply it. Stampe the leaues with vineger, and apply them to the wilde fire and all hote swellings. Stampe them together with waxe, to auoide the blackenesse of strokes and bruises. Seethe Fennill in wine, and bathe the ache of the yarde therewith, or stampe it with oile, anoynt therewith. the iuice of Fenell in the sunne, and vse it in collyries for the eyes to quicken the sight. Apply the broth of the tops to the backe for the ache of the kidneis, and to driue forth water. Drinke Fenell in an ague with cold water, to slake lothsomenesse and the heate of the stomacke. Some cut the stalke and take out of it a iuice like a gum, which is very good for yt eyes. The vse of Fenell in wine, is good for the dropsie, the griefes of the liuer and lungs. The broth of the rootes in water or wine, is good for the griefes of the kidneis and bladder. The herbe or decoction thereof applied to ye pecten, driueth forth vrine, ye seede stirreth man to procreation. The seede or broth of the herbe is good for a plurisie. Seethe the seede in wine, and drinke it against venemous bitings stingings, to expell all poyson and venom, termes, stone, vrine, and viscus humors. The seedes and flowers that grow in the middest of it, are the best parts. The same sodden in water and drunke, taketh away the heate and lothing of the stomacke, and helpeth the hote and drie cough. The seede chewed by it selfe, or condited with sugar, cutteth tough flegme, and maketh it easie to be spit out, and sharpeneth the sight, and so doth the distilled water dropped into the eyes morne and euen. Eyes wormes, drop in the water or iuice. Stampe the rootes with hony and apply it to bitings or stingings of mad dogs, or serpents, the same being first washed with vrine or vineger. The iuice may be drawen out of the roote, herbe, flower, vnripe seede, and dryed in the sunne, and kept to be vsed with other medicines when occasion serueth. Oyle of Fenell, presse it out betweene two hote stones or irons, it will keepe long, and is good for the ptisike, drie scab, burning and scalding.
