Ache see in their place Adder biting (see bite) Backe griefes (see cough, ptisike Breastes sores Brayne weake Breath stinke Bruises Burnings sore watring web wormes Face deformed Feete to wash Feuers pushes sores scall Hoarsenesse Horsekeeping Hoste (see breast) Hote griefes Impostume Kings euill Leane to be (see lust to cause) Shaking Sicknesse generall Sides griefes (see liuer, milt, chollike Scab drie (see face) Scalding Skin deformed (see face) Sclender to be (see lea. Stitche Stom. colde FIgs newe gathered, nourish more then other fruites, but they breede wind loosen ye belly gently, abate heate, quench thirst, but taken of too much, they hurt the stomacke, and make it weake, and without appetite. Dry Figs nourish better then greene and new, yet they breede no good blood, for they that eate them much, become lowsie and full of vermine. Figs eaten before meate loosen the belly, are good for the kidneis, and driue foorth grauell with the vrine. They prouoke sweate, and thereby expell stinking humors, and therefore are good for yong children for the small pockes, measels, and wheales, to bring them foorth speedely without perill. They are good for the throte and lungs, the cough, shortnesse of breath to voide flegme &c. whether they be taken rawe, or rosted, or sodden with hysope and drunke. Bruised inwarde, seethe them in water, and drinke it to mitigate the paine. Stampe them with salt, rue, and nuts, and vse it to withstand all poyson, venome, and corrupt ayre. For hoarsenesse, sharpenesse of the throte, all swellings, and impostumes of the mouth, throte almons, iawes, and swellings of the tongue, gargarise, with the decoction of Figs, or holde it in the mouth. For ache of the teeth and iawes, holde Figs in thy mouth. Apply them with wheaten meale to soften and ripen impostumes and angry swellings behind the eares, especially with Linseede and Fenegreeke put thereto, but the rootes of Lilies put thereto, ripeth and breaketh impostumes and botches: with Barley meale, they scatter and consume swellings. Sodden in wormewood wine with Barley meale, and applied to the belly they are good for the dropsie. Stampe them finely with Mustarseede, to helpe the ringing noyse and sound of the eares, and mend the hearing, being applied outwardly. Dryed Figs soften, consume and make subtill, and may bee very well vsed both inwardly and outwardly to ripen and soften impostumes, and dissolue them. Kings euill, swelling, kernels in the throte, and all other tumours, stampe the leaues finely, and applye them. The milkie iuice helpeth all deformities of the skinne, Leapries, spreading sores, Tetters, small Pockes, Mesels, Pushes, Freckles, Lentiles, and such like scurfe and spottes of the body and face being laide to with parched Barlie meale, and with fat or grease, it taketh away Wartes, it cureth the tootheache, being applied with Bombase or Cotten, or a little pellet made thereof, and put into the hollowe toothe. It openeth the veines of the Emerodes, and looseth the bellye being applied to the fundament, and so doe the leaues if they be put into the fundament. It is good to bee applied with meale of Fenigreke and Vineger vpon the hote goute, especially of the feete. The same iuice is good to be put into all venemous bitings of Serpents and madde dogges. The ashes of a mixt with oyle and waxe cureth burnings. And lee made with ashes of the Figge, healeth scuruinesse and festered foule fretting sores being washed therewith. Dod. Head scurfe, stampe the leaues and branches, and streine them with water and a litle vineger, anoint therewith. Figs, and seethe them in a cup of Beere with some bruised Licoras, and Aniseedes, keepe it warme by ye fire, and drinke thereof warme to bedward and eate the Figs, and so it helpeth the cough in three nights. little of the wood of the tree put into a pot, maketh the meate to be soone sodden. Stampe a handfull of Figs, till the kernels be broken, and temper them with a litle fresh grease, and apply it to a sore breast as hote as the woman may suffer to auoide the swelling and paine. Rub warts with Figtree leaues and bury them, and the warts will goe away. Seethe Figs in wine with hysope streine it, and drinke it to helpe the griefes of the throte, lungs, and olde rotten coughs. They are good against reumes and flowings of the belly. They are very good for the throte, kidneis and bladder, for them that be ill coloured with long sickenesse, shortnesse of breath, the dropsie, and the falling sickenesse. Stampe them with snailes, swines grease, and beane flowre, and apply it to a swolne throte to ripen it, and helpe the squincie. The same made warme and drunke with hysope, purge the breast, are good for the cough, the belly, olde diseases of the lungs. Sodden with Rue, they are good in glisters against the gnawing of ye belly. Sodden and applied, they driue away hardnesse, and so soften the swelling behinde the eares and other swellings. With the shell of a Pomegranate they purge away agnayles, and such angry swellings. With Coprose they heale running issues of the legge, which are almost vncurable. Sodden with wine, worme wood romane, and barley meale and applied to the belly, they are good for the dropsie. Burnt Figs applied with a plaster of waxe, are good for kibed heeles and itchings. The milkie iuice broken with an Almond and drunke, openeth the mother. The same laid to with the yolke of an Eg, draweth downe the termes. It scowreth away lepries, freckles, skurffe, and deformities of the face, and skabs, and running sores of the head laide to with barley meale. Figs stampt with leuin and salt, soften plague sores and other vlcers apostumes and breaketh them. Fig tied to a Bull, will make him tame though he be neuer so wilde. Figs are best eaten fasting with nuts or almonds, so they clense ye brest and lungs. And eaten fasting with powder of ginger, pepper, time, or peniroyal long before meate, they are good against oppilations of the liuer milt, congealed matter in the body, distillations or reume falling into ye brest stomacke, they clense the reines and make ye body soluble. Figs al night in aqua vitae and eate them in ye morning against shortnesse of wind the cough. Seeth Figs in water a litle vineger, stampe them and apply them to the swines euil, kernels, swellings in the throte. Poyson to withstand, eate euery day xx. leaues of Rue with iii. Seethe halfe a pound of Figs with one handfull of hysope, one sponeful of hony in a pottel of white wine to the one halfe, and drinke ii. or iii. sponefull first last to helpe the reume the cough. Chollike, grinde Figs with mustardseede and fenigreeke, and apply it cold: proued. Mithridates medice against ye plague, mixe xx. leaues of rue with ii. Figs ii. walnuts, and a litle salt, eate it be sure from venom that day. Figs, and put them in a cup of Beere with a litle powder of Licoras Aniseedes, and eate them drinke the drinke warme Shoulder ache, grinde Figs reasins of the sunne in a querne with mustardseede, of each like much with strong vineger, and apply it with a lambes skin. Stampe the fresh branches and seethe them with vineger, stampe them well, and apply them to the mentagra or lychen, which is a foule breaking out of the face, with a scab beginning at the chin. Liuer stopt, eate drie Figs with Pepper amongst thy meates, or els the seedes of Cuscuta preserued with fine sugar. For the ptysike, olde catharre, the cough, and other griefes of the lunges, boyle one handful of hysope with iiii. Figs, some reasins in water, and a litle hony, and drinke thereof a glasse full fasting. Tongue palsie, mixe one dram of the pulp with vi. graines of Euphorbium, and hold as much as a beane vnder thy tongue, spit often. Breast stopt with cold, seeth Figs with bruised mustard seede in wine, and drinke it luke warme. Bitings venemous, stampe them with rue and nuts, and apply it to all venom. Bones broken, seeth Figs and poppy seedes in water apply it. Side impost. stampe them with oyle or greace apply them. Make tents of the rindes of olde Figs, and put them into fistulaes, and lay a Fig plasterwise aboue on it. Flegme or reume in the stomacke, stampe radish rootes with drie Figs, and a litle hony, and boyle it into an electuarie and vse it. Cough of outward cause, take a dishfull of beaten Barley, iiii. ounces of reasins, and xii. Figs washed in warme water, seethe them in a newe pot with iiii. quartes of water, one hower, then streine it seethe it againe with vi. ounces of sugar, but let it boyle but once, and coole it and drinke it morning and euening, to soften and cleanse the breast: if it waxe too thicke, put more water to it. Cough impostume, eate rosted Figs with powder of Nep. Loynes apostumed, stampe barley meale iiii. ounces, Figs ii. ounces, the iuice of mallowes vi. ounces, and apply it with a sponge or cloth. To open the pipes, cleare the voice, rost powder of hysope in Figs, and eate euery day one. Hoarsenesse, stampe Figs, and seethe them in wine or ale, and drinke it. Straitnesse of the breast stomacke, seeth fat Figs well stamped in wine, with some bruised mustardseedes, drinke it warme to bedward, or seeth fat Figs with hysope and lycoras, with barley in water, and drinke it. Reines impostumed, vse Oximel with the decoction of reasins and mayden haire. Apostume to breake, stampe hony and fat Figs with swines grease, and apply it as the best medicine. Emerods to prouoke, rub Fig leaues first in thy hands, and then vpon the veines of the fundament, and then binde them to it. Hoarsenesse, rost sugar in Figs on the coles, and eate them hote. Breast to purge, seethe Figs and hony in white wine, and drinke it. Cough, fill a drie Figge with the seedes of Tansy, and seethe them in white wine with one ounce of lycoras with a soft fyre to the one halfe, and drinke thereof euery night. Impost. stampe Figs with fresh grease, and apply them hote to the side or griefe, and drinke ye iuice of Feuerfue. Stomake colde griefes, seethe hysope, Figs, hony together and vse it. Chollike, stampe Figs with mustardseede vineger, and apply it colde. Cough, seethe x. good Figs in a quart of white wine with lycoras, any seedes, and sugar candie, of eache like much to the one halfe, and drinke iii. or iiii. spoonefull morning and euening. Apost. to ripen, stampe fat Figs with swines grease, and frye them together, and apply it. Squincie, gargarise with the decoction of dryed Figs, and a dogs dung to open the apostume, or put mustard seede into Figs, and eate them at night to dissolue the grosse humors, and to open the lights, and helpe the breathing. For stopping of the liuer, shortnesse of breath, and spitting of blood, seethe drie Figs in white or claret wine with mustard, and drinke it euery night, first eating the figs, and then drinking the wine. Plurisy, stampe dry Figs with suet, or oile and gumme, and apply it. Laske to stop, drinke ashes of Figtree branches with water. Swelling about the yard, mixe Figs with wheate flowre and oyle, and apply it. To cause deliuerance of a dead child, take the white iuice of Figs, or powder of Dittanie with water in an ague, but with wine without an ague. Goute, stampe a litle bread, drie Figs, hony vineger together, and binde it to. For painefull pushes on the legs, stampe drie Figs with flowers of Iuie, and apply it. Bladder griefes Blood clensing Bones broken Botch (see apostume) Breastes sore Breast griefes Melancholy Milke to curd Milt stopt Mother stopt Mouth griefes Necke apostume Shortnesse and straitnes of breath of cold cause, vse powder of it and Gentian in brothes and drinks. Chollicke passion, seethe it with and Time and apply it. The knots that hang by the roots vsed in powder, are good for fistulaes and hollow sores both inward and outward. Emerods, anoynt with eeles grease and cast on powder of the rootes. Poyson to auoyd, stamp the herbe and root in the end of May and distill it, and drinke sixe ounces at a time: it helpeth also the plague. It breaketh winde about the liuer and milt, and destroyeth the stone. The roote boyled in wine and drunke, helpeth the dropsie, strangury, paine of the bladder, stopping of the vrine and the stone. Drinke the powder thereof with Fennel seede against all colde and windy griefes. Vse powder of the root often with meates against the falling sicknesse. The leaues and seeds sodden with wine and hony and drunk, bringeth downe the seconds, helpeth the dropping and stopping of vrine, the strangury, and griefes of the bladder and Iaundies, and so doeth the root sodden in wine. The powder of the root licked in with hony, helpeth the cough, yexing, and shortnesse of winde. The powder drunke with wine is good for the falling sicknesse and the Iaundies. for ache of the backe and kidneys, windynesse of the stomacke, the stone, strangury and stopping of the vrine. FItches are not vsed in medicine, but giuen to horses. But parched and taken with hony, as much as a great nut at once fasting they are good for a consumption. Apply the meale with wine to venemous bitings the place being first wel clensed. Apply it with wine and hony to the swelling of the paps, and to spreading sores: it clenseth spots, as Lupines doeth, and may supply the want of Lupines, with vineger it helpeth the tenasmus, and is good for the stopping of the vrine. Boyle them in wine wherein saffron hath bene boyled, and stamp them apply them to any bruse. Eyes rupture in the tunicles, mixe the meale with Frankincense and the white of an egge and apply it. Bitings venemous Breasts swollen Bruses Bursten Cattell feeding Consumption Eyes hurt Sores Tenasmus Fiueleafe. The roots boyled in water, till the third part be wasted, helpeth the raging ache of the teeth, and the sores of the mouth being well washed therewith then drunk, so it stoppeth all bleeding, bloody flux other fluxes, the sciatica. Seethe the root in vineger to soften fretting sores dissolue wennes, colde swellings. It cureth euil fauored nailes, the inflammations of the fundament or mother, al naughty scurfe being applied. Drink the iuice of the yong roots for the griefes of liuer, lungs, all poyson. Feuer tertain quarten, drink the leaues with honied water, or wine wt pepper. And drink it in the same maner xxx. daies for the falling sicknes. Stamp the leaues and apply them finely to burstings falling of humors into the cods. Stamp ye leaues with salt hony to heale vp wounds, fistulaes, spreading sores. Drink the iuice of the leaues to cure the iaundies, comfort the liuer. Seethe it with vineger to heale the running sores, wens, windy swellings, impostumes, hot inflammations, agneils in the fingers or toes, hard lumps that put forth blood in the fundament or mother, also scabs scurfe. Drink v. ounces of the iuice to heale the iaundies quickly. Drink ye iuice xxxiii. daies to heale the falling sicknes perfectly. The root, water iuice, serueth for all things that Tormentil serueth for. Hands trembling, wet them often in the distilled water of it. Drink ye syrop of it xii. times to help the squincy all fluxes termes. The leafe taken wt wine twise, helpeth the ephemera, iii. the tertian, iiii. times ye quarten. Throat sore, seethe i. handful wt asmuch Columbine in a pint of new milk, and drink thereof hot often. For head ach, ach of the lims, and sorenes of the mouth, tongue throat, seethe it in wine, drink it iii. dayes morne euen be whole. For ach gnawing, drink the iuice with ale. Nose bleeding, drinke the iuice with ale, and apply the iuice to thy forehead. To kill a canker, seethe it in white wine wt swines grease and apply it. Mouth, throat, and tongue sores, rub with hony and the powder of it. lycoras well brused with stale ale, and streine it and drinke it as hote as may be suffered, and as often as neede is. Mouth or tongue scalded, seethe it in water, and hold thy mouth ouer the vapour of it, also wash thy mouth therwith thrise a day. Stone, seethe it and the root of it in wine and drink it fasting to breake and expell it. Byting of an adder: stamp it and drink it with wine. Belly ache, hardnesse, and swelling and bound, drinke two spoonefull of the iuice. Chollick, seethe it in ale or wine and drinke it. Ilyak, seethe it in wine or ale and drinke it. Kings euill, drinke the iuice or broth with salt and hony three cyats and vse it. Mouth and throat sore, bruse it and seethe it in water, and drawe in the vapour of it and also gargarise therewith often, so it is good for the squincy. Vomit to stop, bake the leaues wt whites of egs eate them. Womans belly hard, stamp it drink it wt hot milke. Fluxe, vse powder of it with the iuice of Planten. Flowers to stop, seeth it wt rain water bath therewith. Chollicke, drinke powder of the roote, and long Pepper with good ale. Flix Diaria, drink the iuice with sweete milke. Mouth canker, boyle it Honysuckles, Roch allom, hony in vineger running water, wash thy mouth therewith. Nose bleeding, drink the iuice anoint the nostrels wt it. Emerods, seeth it in goats milk, vse it iii. daies when they bleed. Nailes to grow, stamp it wt any grease apply it. Iaundies, drink iiii. ounces of ye water or decoction of it. To heale inward ptures, to dissolue congealed blood distil it with the root thereof in the midst of May in a limbek and drinke foure ounces morne and euen dayly. For great griefes within the body, boyle it with Penyroyall and Poppy leaues of eche like much in wine, and foment therewith. Seethe it in vineger gargle therewith for all griefes of the teeth, gums, mouth and throat. Pissing blood, seethe it with Reed mace in wine and drinke it. FLags or yelow Flower de luce, or common Flags haue the nature of the roots of Tormentill and Bistort, and being boyled in the water and drunke, it stoppeth the bloody fluxe, and all other fluxes of the belly and all bleeding and the flowers howsoeuer it be taken, yea, if it be vsed but outwardly in plaisters or bathes. Teeth ache, put the iuice of the yelow Flag into the eare on the same side. Freckles, seethe the roote of stinking segs in in Cowes milke, and vse it, (See Acorus, Flower de luce, Gladen.) Bloody fluxe Flowers to stop Fluxes Freckles Whites Reines running Flaxe. Seethe the seede in water and apply it as a pultisse or plaster to appease al paine, to soften cold swellings, apostumes of the eares, necke, and all other places. Stamp the seeds with figs and apply it to ripen and breake all apostumes and to drawe foorth thornes and pricks being mixt with the root of wilde Cucumber. Apply the same with Cresses and hony to rough and euill fauoured nailes to make them come off, and to heale them. Stamp it rawe and apply it to all spots in the face. Seethe it in wine and wash vlcers and old sores therewith to keepe them from corruption, festring, and ranckling. Seethe them in water, and drop thereof into the eyes to cleare the sight. them in glisters for the paine of the belly and matrixe, and to cure wounds of them. Mixe them with hony, and take it as an electuary or lotion, to clense the breast, to helpe the cough, and eate them with raisins for the consumption or ptisicke, Feuers and hectick. Apply the meale of it with Mallowe rootes and swines grease warme, to ripen and breake apostumes. Vse the decoction thereof to clense, mollifie, and ripen the apostumes of the matrix. The oyle serueth for Printers inke, Painters colours, for vernishing of boards, for the Armorer in making cleane harnesse and weapons, and lamps. The oyle washt in fiue or sixe waters with a sticke till it waxe white, and then with a spoone taken foorth (for it will swim aloft) wil heale burnings, scaldings, and inflammations, it mollifieth hard sores, and is good for bone setters to strengthen the sinewes, ioints and bones, for conuulsions, emerods, &c. If it be drunke after poyson, it will cast it vp by vomit clense the stomack. With powder of a Bores tooth, applied with a fether, it healeth ye squincy presently. The drosse of the seeds after the oile is streined forthsteeped a while in raine water, amendeth al the spots deformities of the skin being washt therewith. If it be taken in cakes with Pepper plentifully, it causeth lust. Let women sit in the decoction thereof for the inflammation and heate of the matrix. Drinke two or three ounces of it with barly water for the plurisie, but let the oyle be fresh and not olde if it be taken inward. The seedes lickt in with hony as much as a nutmeg at once, helpeth the cough, and causeth lust. Anoynt with the oyle against obstructions, chollicke, and hardnesse, or vse the decoction of the seede either in glisters or outwardly. The seede or oyle helpeth burnings, softneth all hardnesse or apostumes, mendeth the defaults of the face, especially the seede sodden in wine and the face washt therewith. The seeds sodden with as much Cresse seedes and hony, is good to be applyed to skuruie nailes. Breasts ranckled, apply the meale with the white of an egge, and then apply the iuice of Smallach with Rye meale, and let her drinke the iuice of Veruin, Fenel seed and Seed to restore in ye backe, drink powder of it wt goats milk three or foure times fasting. Seethe the seeds with Fenigreke in oyle of Violets butter, to dissolue all apostumes and the plurisie. Flowers to stop, seethe it in Goats milke and drinke it. Legs swollen, seethe it in water tender, and stamp a great handfull of Hemlocks, and seethe them together apply them till it be nesh and soft. Noli me tangere, dip a cloth in the oyle and apply it. Stinging, plucke out the sting and apply a plaster of Linseed and vineger. Swellings, apply Linseed, Holy oke, and Mallowes boyled together: it healeth sores also. Side paine, seethe the brused seedes in water, and dip a cloth in it and apply it to haue present helpe. Yard burnt, apply ashes of the seedes in a linnen cloth. Vrin stopt, seethe the seedes long in hony and vse it. Freckles, seethe it in vineger and vse it, after wash with womans milke. Quincy, the iuice of wormewood with milke, hony, and meale of Linseede and apply it. Yarde apostumed, apply powder of the seedes with gylts grease. Belly bound, seethe the seedes in water till they be tender, then doe away the water, and fry the seedes with fresh grease, and eate it hote. Gout hote, stampe Linseede, Iuy leaues with oyle Oliue, and apply it hote at euery eight houres ende. Pap apostumed, seethe the seede till it be broken, then powre out the water, and seethe the seeds in milke to pap, and apply it often till it be broken. Apostume to ripen, seethe the seeds in water to pap i.li. then put thereto Holy oke leaues, swines grease, boyle them malax it and apply it. Gout at the bone, seethe it in water till it be thicke, then stamp it and it with sheeps sewet the iuice of Henbane, and herb Benet, seethe them well together apply it. Swelling of a bruse or hurt, stampe the seeds and seethe them in milke and apply it. Gout, take yolks of egs, Linseed, saffron, womans milke of eche like much, work them wel together apply it: prooued. Haire to grow, mixe asshes of the seeds with hony and anoynt often. Quincy hot or cold, apply a plaster of Linseed Goats milke. Hands ranckled scabd, wash with the decoction of the seeds. Wearinesse to cause sweat, apply water of the decoction of the seeds to the stomacke. felon rankling, seethe the meale of linseede and barley in ale, and apply it. Sorenesse, and chafing of the yarde, and for womens breasts, boyle the iuice of morell with linseed, and barrowes greace, and applie it. Paps sore, seethe the seedes or meale, and apply it. Stomacke greefes generall, stampe the seedes of smallach, cummin, and linseede, of eche like much, and drinke it with hote water. Bellie, or wombe griefes general, seethe a bagge of linseede in water two houres, and applie it as hote as may be suffered. Put the seedes into a raddish roote, and set it into fatte earth, and the hearbe will come foorth like Dragons, and taste like vineger and salt, and is vsed for sawse without vineger and salt. Flaxe to be soft as silke, dresse it and kembe it, and couer it ouer with fresh calues doung, and let it so soke fiue or sixe houres, then wash it, and it will be soft as silke. Canker in the yarde or els where, cast on powder of linseede, and apply a plaister of mallowes and wormewood, sodden and stamped with Swines greace. Codswolne, seethe Flaxe and salt in vineger, and apply it. Yarde scalde, or ape galde, burne an olde Flaxen cloth cleane washed, and anoynt it with oyle of egges, and cast on the powder. Haire falling, burne the seedes, and mixe them with oyle oliue, and anoynt therewith. Yarde swolne, seethe the seedes with mallowes and apply it. Nauel of children, swollen by much crying, cough, fall, or bruise, mixe powder of faire olde linnen cloth, burned, and of bitter lupines, and applie it with tow to the nauell. Nailes scallen, and falling off, mixe the seedes, with as much seedes of wilde mints, and hony, and apply it. Backe weake Belly ach bound Bitings venimous Bones broken Brest griefes See cough Brest sores Noli me tangere Obstructions Plague Plurisie Poyson Ptisicke Purgation Painting Ranckling Reines running Sause Sinewes griefes Side paine Scalding Skin deformed Throate swollen See Squincie Vomite to cause Vernishing Vrine stopt Wennes Wearinesse Wounds Yard apostume FLeawort, Psillium: Eyes heate, steepe it in water, and apply it. Haire not to grow, vse the cotton that is found in Fleawort. Eyes teares, heate and itche, steepe it all night in water, and wash the eyeliddes therewith. Fluxe, roste the seedes in an eggeshel, and drinke the powder thereof with wine. the decoction of Fleawort, taketh away all paine of the goute, of what sort soeuer it bee. Feuers continuall, steepe the whole seedes all night in water, and streine it, and drinke it with sugar to quench intollerable heate. Binde as much Fleawort as a filbert in a cloute, and lay it in warme water three houres, and stroke thy tongue therewith to auoyde the heate and bitternesse of the iaundies. Thirst and drinesse of the tongue, tie the seeds in a cloth and steep it in cold water, and rub thy tongue therewith, and drinke the water wherein it hath bene steeped. Seethe or steepe the seedes in water, and drinke it to purge downe a dust or cholerick humors, to swage paine and inflammation of the intrals, hote feuers, all inwarde heates, drought and thirst. Bruise the seeds, and purge them at the fire, and vse them for the bloodie fluxe, vehement laske, especially when they come of violent medicines: mixe the seed with oile of roses and vineger, or water, and stroke it on hote griefs, apostumes, swellings behind the eares, or els where, and headach. Apply the seed with vineger to the going out of the nauel, and burstings of yong children. Apply water, wherein the seed hath bene steeped, to S. Anthonies fire, and all hote swellings, and drop it into the eares that run, or haue wormes in them. Strawe the greene herbe in the house to withstand breeding of fleas. Haire not to growe Iaundies Kernels Nauell out Necke apostume Purgation S. Anthonies fire Swellings FLower de luce, Sixe drams of ye root take~ with water hony, purgeth grosse flegm choler, prouoketh sleep, staieth teares, ceasseth pages missing] stampe them and drinke them with water, and couer thee well to sweate. Flowers stopt, make a pessary of the roote, and anoynt it ouer with oile de bay, or common oile, and cast theron powder of walwoort, and put it in all night till it prouoke it to bleede. Prickes or bones to drawe out, stampe the roote and applie it. Drinke it with ale or wine to cleanse the brest from euill humours, and to helpe the cough. It helpeth crampes, and venemous bytings, it expelleth a dead childe. Drinke the iuice of it and morell, of eche one egge shell full clarified, and sweetned with sugar to heale all dropsies that bee curable both hote and colde, but some take the iuice of Iris one day, and the iuice of morell another day: for Iris looseth, and morell prouoketh vrine: proued. Take an egge shell full of the iuice of the roote rawe, to purge flegme, and watrish humours from all partes of the bodie. And with the iuice of time it is good for ache, and swelling in the head, stomacke, and legges, and bowels, and winde in them: you may put to it a little sugar, or honie, and cloues, or a litle aqua vitae. Mixe the iuice of the flowers with gumme water, and it will bee perfect and durable, blewe or greene. Cough to heale speedily, vse cawdles with the powder of. Dropsie ascites, mixe halfe an egge shell full of the iuice with foure ounces of mellicrate and halfe a dramme of powder of the best rubarb, and drinke it hote in the morning once a weeke: it is wonderfull. Ache in the loynes or haunches, stamp the roots with brimstone, and beares greace, and applie it. Aches generall, stampe the roote with the oyle of it and honie, and applie it. Haire falling, mixe the powder with as much soote of a chimney, and temper them with olde oyle, and anoynt. Fistula to heale, stampe one ounce of the roote with verderam, and oile of tartar, of eche a dramme, and apply it to the sore. Stingings of serpents, apply powder of the vpper partes with wine. Apostumes vnder the eare, boile the root and stamp it with salt, ayply it to dissolue it. Belly torments, drinke a dram of the powder with sowre wine. Belly bound, drinke the iuice with the yolke of an egge as hote as may be suffered. and to bring downe the seconds, stampe the rootes, and boyle them long in vineger, and receiue vp the fume thereof through a narrowe mouthed glasse, or other vessell. FRankincense, cough old, eat iii. graines by it self, or with a rere Egge. Teethach, apply it with the iuice of red nettles and the white of an Egge. Eyes bloody, mixe it with Mastike the iuice of Smallach and the white of an Egge apply it. For a woman that hath bene in labor giuen ouer, and for the Emerods, set it in a close chaire on hote coles sit ouer it, but an earthe~ vessel is better then a close chaire. Eares dull, boile it with oile oliue and skum it cleane, anoint the forehead therewith from the one eare to the other. Vomite to stop, mixe powder of Masticke and white Frankincense with Rose leaues and the iuice of Mints and apply it to the stomake. Fluxe white, mixe i. d. weight of Nutmegs, and ii. d. weight of white Frankincence with the iuice of Quinces, and drinke it. receiue vp the fume of the seeds of Leekes and Henbane, with powder of Frankincense. Fluxe, roste an Onion tender and bruise it, and lap it in a cloth, and apply it to the fundament, and sit downe vpon it as hote as may be suffered a long time, and roste Frankincense in an other Onyon, and put off the couering and apply it hote to the Nauell. Itch, anoynt with powder of Frankincense and oile de Baye. Wounds and hurts to heale, melt virgins waxe, a quarter of a pound, with sheepes sewet ii. ounces, and take it from the fire, and mixe therewith Frankincense i. ounce, and vse it, see in lib. Animalium fol. Eyes watering, mixe it with Mastick, Bolarmon. gum Dragagant, and the white of an Egge, and apply it to the forehead and temples. Vomit to stop, mixe it and as much Masticke with Barlie meale and the white of an Egge, and spread it on Towe and apply it to the mouth of the stomacke. Wounds bleeding, mixe it with the haires of a horse belly, and the white of an Egge, and apply it. Headach great and heauie, mixe it with Aloes and Mastike ana, with vineger and white of an Egge, and apply it to the forehead and temples with stuphes. But if it come of vapours, mixe it with Barly meale and the white of an Egge, and apply it to the temple on the same side that aketh with a Paper. Or mixe it with Pigeons dung, Wheate flower the white of an Egge and apply it. Pissing bed, in a cold cause, drink iii. drams of the powder of it. ach, mixe it with worme wood, hote bread vineger, and apply it. Or with Wheat flowre, the white of an Egge, and Morell red Nettles, or take it Masticke ana, iii. drams, Peritrum vi. drams, mixe them with hony or Treacle, apply it to the tooth. Head skal, mixe it with Pitch and rosen of ech like much with fresh greace, shaue thy head annoint it, when the haires rise like bristles, pluck them vp apply newe plasters, the powder and greace must bee melted together. Stomake griefs, mixe it with wormewood, Mints, Cummin and dried bread crums ana i. handful, stampe them with vineger and apply them hote in a bag sprinkled with vineger. Stone, stampe it with Gromelseed, Parsly seede, red Mints, Violets and Saxifrage, let it steepe in good stale ale all night, drink it first and last. Emerods paine, sit ouer the fume of the powder of it laid on a tile almost red hote, and laide in hote water to the midst. Drinke fine powder of white Frankincense with wine in cold weather, with water in hote weather wherin reasins haue bene sodden, to comfort ye braine, memory stomake. Face swollen with tooth ach, apply it with the iuice of red Nettles the white of an Egge. Vomiting, boile it with the iuice of Mints and a litle vineger, apply it to the pyt of the stomake. Nose bleeding, stampe it with the white of an Egge, apply it. Fundament fallen, receiue vp the fume of it Pitch, and Masticke. Leg swollen hard sore, hold it ouer the fume of it and vermilion, and lay a cloth ouer it. Rume distilling of the head, vse the fume of it, or apply a plaster of it. Ach of all sorts, apply it with the white of an Egge. Vse it to cleere the sight, to heale new wounds stop al fluxes of blood. With milke it healeth all euil vlcers of the Fundament, and dissolueth grosse Flegme, it strengtheneth ye memory. Emerods, sit ouer the fume of it in a close chaire. Tooth ach, lay it and the seeds of Henbane Leekes on hote coles of ech like much, receiue vp the fume of it through a funnil. Chollik, roste it in an Onion apply it, be whole. Head ach, apply it wt Hony the white of an Egge white wine to the temples necke, or beat it wt the white of an egge oile of Roses, apply it to the temples. FVrres or Seethe Leaues in wine or water and drinke it, to stop the Flowers and the Laske. Drinke the seede in wine against all venemous bitings and stingings. GAlbanum is good for the olde cough, shortnesse and streitnesse of breath, Burstings, Brusings, cramps and shrinking of senowes. Drinke it in wine with Myrre against all venom poyson by drinks or shots, to prouoke Termes and expell the dead births, and so it doth in a Pessary or Perfume. Let a woman in painefull trauaile, drinke as much as a Beane, with a glasse of white wine. Burne it in Perfume to expell serpents and venemous beastes: if a man bee anoynted therewith, none of them shall hurt him. If it bee mixt with oyle, and the seede or roote of Angelica or of Spondilium, and they touched therewith, it causeth them to die. The perfume of it helpeth the strangling of the Mother, and the falling euill. Apply it to the nauill, to set the Matrixe in the naturall place. It doth soften and draw foorth Prickles, Thornes, and colde humors. Vse it in all oyntments and emplasters that shall warme, digest, dissolue, ripen, breake and drawe Apostumes and Prickes. Apply it to the hardnesse of the Milt, and payne of the side. Facefreckles or spots or elsewhere, apply it with Vineger and Niter. Eare running or mattering, put it in with oyle of Roses, or of Nardus. Lethargie, smell to the fume of it: make it soft, and apply it to to a plague sore or botch to take it cleane away. Soften it and put in a cloth of silke and so into the mouth of the Matrixe, and let the womans head bee cleane, and a thinne caule, and a cleane kerchiefe on it, without any odours: if in the morning, after shee hath lien with it in this maner all night, her head smell of it in the crowne, shee is apt to conceiue. Mixe it with powder of Piretrum and the milke of Spurge or Wartwort and apply it to any rotten or aking tooth, to breake it, or plucke it out. Dissolue it in Vineger, and vse it to all hardnesse and knots of the ioynts, and to heale Fellons. Milt hard, applie it with Assafetida and Waxe, or dissolue it with as much Armoniake and Vineger, and put thereto Waxe and powder of Wormewood and of Coste, and vse it. Plague sore, apply it with blacke Sope. Belly wormes, take pilles of it and Suger candie beaten together. Apply it vnder the Nauell to prouoke Vrine presently in the strangurie. Take Pilles of it for the olde Cough, and shortnesse of breath, bruses and ruptures, or drinke a little with Myre in Wine. To cleanse it, put it in a bagge, and hang it in a deepe pot, and set it into a vessell of hote water, and the best will bee in the bottome, and the drosse in the bagge: or dissolue it in Vineger and streine it. Heeles kibed, mixe powder of it and Dragagant with Oxe Tallowe and a little oyle of Violets, melt them together and apply it. Temper it at the fire and cleanse it, and apply it to a Byle two dayes without remoouing, and doe so as often as neede is to breake it and heale it fayre. Breath stopt, take two drams of it with a rere Egge, or with Barley water. Wormes, make Pilles of it, and annoynt them with Honie and vse them. Vrine stopt, apply it to the ende of the Yard, but for a woman, to the Nauell. To cleanse it, put it into very hote water, and by little and little the filth separate from the cleane, and so it may bee vsed in Plasters, &c. or resolue it all night in Vineger, or in Vineger and water: and in the morning boyle it and streyne it. The like may bee done with other Gummes that will not bee powdred. Dissolue it it vineger, and apply it to a swollen Pappe to breake it, dissolue it and anoynt in vineger of ech like much and apply it to Apostumes. Put the roote or iuice into the nose to comfort the Brayne. Stomake colde, vse powder of it with Cinamome and Sugar vpon tostes with ale or wine. Stomacke paine of colde cause, stampe English Gallingale, and boile it in oyle, and apply it to the mouth of the stomake, apply it aboue the yard to prouoke vrin, or seeth it in water and drinke it to void vrin. Gallingale stoppeth the flowing of the vrine comming of coldnesse of the reines and bladder. Hycket, seeth one dram of the powder with a pinte of good white wine, and drinke ii. ounces morne and euen two houres before meate. Pepper and Parsly seed of eche two drams, and with newe hony, make it an electuary, take one spooneful morne euen ii. houres before and after meate. Stomack windy ill, vse it in sauses with ginger, Mints, and vineger: it is the best root or spice for the stomack. For the griefes of the brest and brest bones, take out the core of a ripe apple, fill it with powder of Galingale and lycoras and hony all well mixt together, and rost it, and pill it, and eate it as often as neede is. For griefes of the heart, lungs, and stomack, to preserue from all euill humors, take Cardamom three ounces, Galingale vi. ounces, saffron i.d. worth, sugar foure ounces, make them into a fine powder, and take thereof halfe a spoonefull morne euen till you be well. It taketh away the coldnes of the brest, heart, guts, reines, and matrix. It causeth a sweete breath, expelleth winde, helpeth digestion, prouoketh lust, dissolueth the hard milt. It comforteth the braine and memorie being put into the nose. Drinke it with the water or iuice of Planten to stop the bloody fluxe, and strenthen nature, to comfort the braine and the trembling of the heart. Breath stink Chaps Chollick Digestion Eyes dull Fluxe Heart griefes Hicket Lungs griefes Lust to cause Matrix griefes Memorie Sicknesse generall Stomack cold Gall, or noble Mirtle, &c. GAll, or noble Mirtle, or dwarfe Mirtle: brewe the leaues, buds, and flowers in Beere in stead of Hops to make it haue a pleasant smell taste: but it is good to vse therewith some hops or Rosemary, Calament, or Groundpine or such like opening seeds or herbs, as the seeds of Carway, Fenel, or Anise. GAllion stampt and applyed to burnings, draweth foorth the heate, healeth them. Apply it to the nose or to wounds to stop their bleeding. Mixe it with oyle of Roses, and set it in the sunne, apply thereof to wearied members to comfort them. The herbe is very good to be put into rennits to make pleasant cheese. It is good for the holy fire, shingles, and burnings. Seethe it, and wash the feete therewith against wearinesse, and also wash dry scabs therewith. GArlike, breaketh all euill windes in the body, and prouoketh vrin, but it hurteth the eyes causeth thirst. Chollick windy, rost iii. cloues of Garlike in a wet paper in the embers, and pill them, and put them into the fundament somewhat warme. It healteth scabs, morphue or bladders being chafed wel with the iuice. Wormes to kill, apply it with rye bread, salt, and good ale dregs to the nauell or breast to make them come out. Vrine stopt, stamp it with Hocks and vineger, and seethe them in ale till the third part be wasted and drinke it often. Biting of a man, stamp it with Rue, meale and hony and apply it. Chollick, stampe three cloues with a good handfull of Time, and streine them with ale, and make a possit with it, and drinke the ale of it. Horse bots, cut horse haire small, and giue it him with warme milk in a horne, and put in either eare a spoonfull of milke, and a cloue of Garlike, and knit the eare with a list two houres. Wormes, drink sweet milk foure dayes, and the fifth day stamp Garlike with vineger, eat it to kil them all. Head ach of cold, eate Garlike, and the ashes of it with vineger apply it. Pissing blood, seethe the heads with their roots and all in wine and water, drink it three dayes be whole. If a spider be in thy cup, or crept into thy mouth, drink Garlik. Voyce to be clere, seethe Garlike in milk, or pun it by it selfe, eat it with soft cheese. pill a Garlike head, and bind it to the wrist on the same side that the griefe is on, brused as broad as a wallnut all night, let the water go out of the blister, but if it run too sore, lay to the rough side of a wallnut leafe. Stomack with cold humors, eate raw Garlike with salt bread fasting. Loyns ach of colde cause, seethe Garlike and Coliander of eche ii. ounces in wine one quart, till the third part be wasted, then strein it drink it morne euen. Bladder stopt with the stone or slime, and for the stitch and paine thereof, stamp ii. Garlike heads their roots well clensed wt a good handfull of Mallowes, their roots, and seethe them in a new pot halfe an houre with a quart of wine, strein it, and put thereto ii. drams of sugar, drink thereof cold a good draught morne euen as oft as need is, hold a toste of bread to thy mouth, if thou doubt to cast it vp againe. stamp it with saffron pepper, apply it betweene thy teeth. Squincy, stamp Garlike and rub it therewith, and stamp more apply it plasterwise. Fundament fallen, bake Garlike, put it in, when it is gone in, apply of the said Garlike with tallow, when it is in put in a stoppel. Gout cold, stamp pilled Garlike and seethe it with mans vrin and scum it, and apply it sixe houres thrise and be whole. Canker and fester to destroy them mixe Orpiment with Housleeke Garlike and apply it. Biting of mad dog, stamp Garlike cloues with Mints, Morell, salt, and apply it. Plague to resist to kill worms, eat a top of Rue, a Garlike head, a corne of salt xxx. mornings: prooued. Matrix to open, put in a cloue of pilled Garlike. plaisteer of the cloues and leaues, stoppeth the humor causing reume. stamp two cloues, and bind them to the wrist on the same side that the griefe is on. Fundament falling, receiue vp the fume of the warme and cleare iuice of Garlike. Stone, seethe vii. heads in water a good while and drinke it iii. dayes. Flowers to cause, put a cloue of pilly Garlike into the matrix. Mother suffoc. dissolue Treacle, Cloues, and Garlike in strong wine drink it. Feuer certian quotidian, bind Garlike to the outward parts before the fitt come. Eat Garlike drink after it the blood of a cocke with warm wine, no venemous beast shal hurt thee. French Garlike fryed with oyle, killeth ill scabs and breaking out, breaketh apostumes. Eate Garlike breath vpon a painted face and the colour will quickly vanish away. Gout hote or colde, stamp Garlike with as much Housleek and apply it. Chollick, stone, and strangury, stamp vi. cloues, strein them with a draught of Renish wine drink it iii. dayes. Stone, and to expel vrin, burn ye cloues in a pot, drink the powder, or vse it in pottage. in ye nether iawes, pil Garlike bruse it apply it to the soles of the feet to help it speedily. Vrin stopt, stamp Garlike Mallowes and streine them in white wine, and drinke a good draught ix. times. Sow Garlike when the Moone is vnder the earth, pluck it when she is aboue the earth it will not smell, it wil be the sweeter if it be brused when it is set, or oliue stones set about it. To take birds that eat the seeds when they are sowen, seethe Garlike that it may not grow againe and cast it to them, and they that eate it may be taken vp with your hand. Cough, stampe Garlike with hogs grease, and anoint the back feet therewith by the fire. Cocks that eat Garlike are stout to fight, and horses that eate it with bread and wine at the houre of battel, are liuely and fierce. Therefore traueilers and warriers do bite thereof often to cause agilitie and courage. Moules to catch, put Garlike, Onions, or Leeks into the mouthes of their holes, and they will come out quickly as amazed. Coughs, stamp three or foure cloues with bores grease and anoynt thy feet when thou goest to bed keepe them hote with a tosted trencher and warme clothes, it helpeth all coughs in yong and olde. Emerods bleeding, drink the iuice of Yarowe, and cast on burnt Garlike they will dye. Teethache, put a cloue of Garlike into the eare on ye same side that aketh. Cough, clense two or three heads of Garlike and stamp it with hogs grease, and warme thy feet hot, and rub them well therewith, and lap them hot, and couer thee well, rub therewith also the smals of thy legs. Side chollick, seethe foure heads with a pint of white wine, drink thereof, and go to bed and couer thee well. Eares noyse, put in the iuice of Garlike saffron with goose grease. Apostume or swelling in the groyne or share to breake it, mixe two Garlike heads with vnslakt lime and yolks of three egs and apply it. To defend from the plague, eat Garlike drink wine after it. Ringworms, the asshes of Garlike with hony, and anoynt therewith. Flowers and seconds to bring downe, seethe it in water and receiue vp the fume of it. Pissing blood, seethe heads in water to the third part drinke it. Scabs, stamp it finely, and apply it especially with swines blood. Pissing bed, seethe it with sage in wine, till the third part be wasted, strein it and drink it morne euen. Bitings venemous, drink Garlike with wine, and apply it with fig leaues and Cummin, or anoynt the biting of a dog with the iuice, or apply Garlike or Onions with Rue salt, wash the sore first with the iuice of Garlike or Onyons. Flux to stop, pill two heads and stamp them, seethe them in almost a pint of milk with some shauen chalke, drink it once or twise. Bleeding to stop, drink the iuice of Yarowe with powder of burned Garlike. Stamp it, apply it to any venemous bitings of beasts or wormes. Worms in the body, take Garlike with the iuice of Parsly Mints with a litle vineger pepper, and make it a sause, and eat it with bread or meat. Chollick and paine of the reines, seethe it in wine oyle and apply it plasterwise to the belly, and round about the root of the yard. Eate Garlike to withstand all corrupt and stinking ayre. hold a cloue of it in thy mouth when the ache commeth of cold cause. Garlike maketh inflation, dryeth and harmeth the stomack, causeth thirst. Apply it to the skin xii. houres to raise blisters, therefore the eating of it by them that are chollerick is hurtfull, for that it inflameth them, dryeth vp the whole body, especially in hote seasons, and ingendreth leapry in in them, causeth frensy, hurteth the sight, and moueth headach, and it doeth more harme raw then sodden or rosted, but the moderate eating of it in Winter by them that are flegmatick, is right profitable. Rost it stamp it with figs barowes grease to break an apostume as is aforesaid, and to draw forth the matter. Anoynt the head with the iuice to kill both lyce, nitts. Drinke Garlike with the decoction of Agarik, to kill both lyce and nitts. Mix the asshes with hony and anoint thin places of the head to helpe the sheading of haire. Mixe the asshes with hony and May butter and anoynt the scab or leapry and all filthinesse of the skinne, and after goe into a bath or hote house. Seethe Garlike and eate it against hoarsenesse, the old cough, to purge the breast and dry vp the moysture in the stomacke. Seethe it with the leaues and all in wine, and drinke it to procure vrine, termes, seconds, and anoint the belly therewith also, or take vp the fume of it in a close chaire. If any be stung of an adder, or hath drunk poyson, let him eat Garlike and he shal haue no harme thereby. Seethe it with vineger drink it wt hony, to kil, expel al kinds of worms in the body. Seeth it with oyle oliue, anoynt swellings other griefes of the bladder. Seethe it with milk, drink it to heale the blistering of the lungs. Seethe it with Centory in wine drink it to helpe the dropsie gathered of cold cause. Bruse it wt Coliander seed, and so take it with wine to asswage the paine of the loyns, and to open the straitnes in making of water. Seethe it with leaues and temper it with oile oliue, or oyle of Poppy, anoynt the temples therewith for the headach. Seethe Garlike after rost it drye and make it into pouder with Pellitory and Mastick, wash the mouth therewith to help the toothach. If a woman cannot smel the sauor of Garlike being set by her bedside in the night, she is vndoubtedly wt child. Garlik is good to be eaten of laboring men that eat often meats that are cold hard of digestion. Rue eaten after Garlike taketh away the smel thereof, so doth a raw beane, or a Beet root rosted in the embers. Garlike vsed in meat, resisteth all poyson infirmities co~ming by drinking of corrupt euil water, killeth worms venemous things in ye body. And being drunk with wine also applied outwardly, it helpeth the bitings stingings of vipers, serpents mad dogs. eaten, clereth ye voice, helpeth ye cough, is good for ye dropsie, prouoketh vrine softneth the belly. The iuice anoynted, taketh away scabs leapry from the skin, all filthy spots from the face being rubd therewith, but especially the asshes of it with hony. It is a singular remedy vsed any wayes for diseases of cattell. Wild Garlike is more strong to al effects then ye garden Garlike. Seeth it the smel of it wil be gone, but ye vertue remaineth to be eate~ against coughs, paine of the lungs, to cause sleepe. Stamp it wt Mastick, hold it in ye mouth to asswage toothach. Eat it against the falling euil. Mix it with pitch, brimstone, rosin, vse tents thereof to heale fistulaes hote. Stamp vi. cloues streine it with a draught of Renish wine drink it for the stone, chollick, strangury. Stamp a whole head pied apply hot to the soles of the feet for the toothach that commeth of cold cause. Garlik dispatcheth all windines, openeth all stoppings, killeth expelleth broad worms, prouoketh vrin, cleareth the voyce, cureth olde coughs, is good for the dropsy either raw or sodden. Burne the cloues in a pot to driue out vrin the stone. Stamp it with swines grease anoynt the feet backbone there with for the cough comming of colde cause. Teethach, stamp it with vineger apply it, or boyle it in water wt a litle incense, wash the mouth therewith, put it into the hollow teeth, or it with goose grease, and put it into the eare. Headach, bruse it and apply it to the temples. Bruses, black spots, or other deformities of the skin, anoynt wt the asshes of it hony. For the white scurfe, leapry, running vlcers of the head, manginesse, wilde fire, spreading scabs like tetters, &c. stamp it with oyle salt and apply it. Seethe it twise or thrise in water to put away the sharpnesse of it, and so it is much better then raw. It expelleth wind, breedeth no thirst, cleareth the voyce, helpeth the cold cough, prouoketh vrine and the termes, causeth lust, helpeth the windy chollicke and stone, and the sciatica comming of flegme. Seethe it in milke to helpe the olde cough, spetting blood and matter, and for the reume and distillations. GElofers: make conserue of al kinds of cloue Gelofers with sugar, vse it to comfort ye heart for hote feuers the plague. The roote of garde~ Gelofers is good against ye plague. Sta~pe Gelofers apply them to heale wounds of ye head, to draw forth broken bones. The decoction of them is good to wash the head withal. Seeth ye flowers in white wine, drink it against ye terror of ye tertain feuer, the horror of ye quarten feuer warme before the fit, to kil wormes. The oile of Gelofers healeth the biting of a mad dog, the wounds of ye sinowes cold goutes. They with ye purple flower are preserued as roses with sugar, are very good against ye plague or any kind of poison, yt falling sicknesse, ye palsey, and the crampe, and giddinesse. Drinke iiii. ounces of ye iuice of ye whole plant after the first assalt of ye plague to cure it. Put the herbe flowers in vineger certaine dayes to make it pleasant very good to reuiue one out of swooning, ye nostrels temples being washed therwith, and so it also deliuereth from ye plague, being dayly vsed in like maner. The conserue of the flowers, is good against ye weakenesse of the heart, hote burning feuers. Drinke a glassefull of the iuice of winter Gelofer against all griefes. To drawe a womans pap that would rot, stampe double Gelofers, heate them with faire water, plucke out ye stoppell of the glasse, set it on the pap head. dry them boile them in water, drinke it to prouoke vrine termes, to cure hard apost. of ye mother being bathed therein. Seeth ye flowers in oile waxe, vse it to chaps, or rifts of ye fundament, falling downe of the long gut, to close vp old vlcers. Mixe it with hony to cure the vlcers swellings of the mouth. Drinke ii. drams of ye seede to expel ye termes, seconds, dead birth, or put it into the matrix as a pessary. Milt hard, stampe ye roote wt vineger, apply it, likewise to ye liuer for ye hardnes thereof. The flowers may be kept dry to purge ye matrix termes. Seethe the rootes soft in vineger, apply it to hote apostumes, the goute. Seeth ye roote soft wt vineger oile of roses to helpe ye hardnes of ye liuer milt. The oyle of ye flowers is precious for griefes of the reines, bladder, ioints sinowes. Temper ye iuice with hony to heale sores of the mouth head. Seeth the dry flowers in water, and sit therein for the inflammation of ye mother, to bring downe ye termes. In a cerot they heale the rifts of ye fundament, With hony ye sores of the mouth. Drinke the wine of the decoction thereof, or the distilled water v. spoonefull morne and euen, for the griefes of the liuer and kidneys. Drinke the seede or iuice to driue downe the flowers, seconds, dead birth mightely. Seeth the fresh flowers in wine, and drinke it for the inflammation of the matrix. Drinke the distilled water dayly for a certaine time, to strengthen all the inner partes to comfort the blood, to cheere the minde, and take away paine. The iuice of all kindes of Gelofers put into the eyes, taketh away all spots and mystinesse thereof. They with the purple flowre are much of like nature. GEntian: (see Dwarfe Gentian drinke one dramme of the roote in powder with wine, and a litle pepper and rue for all inward poyson, and all venemous bitings. And with water for the griefes of the liuer and stomacke, and vse it for all colde diseases of the intralles. The iuice of the roote dissolueth bruised blood, and helpeth the griefe of the side and burstings. The same iuice cureth festered and fretting sores and wounds being dropped into them. Apply the same with linte to the eyes to swage the paine and heate. It skowreth all filth from the skin, being anointed therewith. Put the roote into the matrix as a pessary to pull downe the dead birth and termes. Stampe Gentian with twise so much Centorie, and soke them in wine v. dayes, then distill it, and drinke the water morne and euen, to preserue the body from the plague, to heale the ptisike, to cleanse the stuffed stomacke, to breake and expell the stone from the reines to auoide watry humors from the milt, to prouoke termes to purge choller and corrupt blood, to heale inwarde woundes and venemous bitings, to cleare the sight, to preserue the body from all diseases, to auoide all impostumes, and to cause a good colour: but in healing wounds apply ye powder of Centory outwardly. There is nothing better for ye iliaca passio, the dropsy, being drunk in wine water, and for al the diseases of the lungs, and for all diseases of horses, kine, oxen &c. Horse pussy, or broken winded, giue him powder of it in his water to drinke. Ptisike, drinke powder of the roote of Gentian, and Filipendula of eache one dram with hony and water often. Mad, drinke the seedes of Rue and Gentian with vineger, and apply a blacke cocke to the head, cut through the middest xxiiii. houres, and ye third day bleede in the head. Or vse Gentian, and Rue, and also wash thy head with the same hearbes, or drinke Gentian often with hony and vineger. Breath short, and straite, vse powder of it in meates, brothes, and drinkes: spiders biting, apply the iuice. Stomacke to clense, vse Gentian and Tormentill, of eache like much in thy potage and be whole. Feuer quarten and quotidian, drinke powder of Gentian and maces, of eache like much, with a litle pepper with glarified Ale and Sugar before the fit. Feuer quarten, seeth the roote in wine, and drinke it before the fit: it is taken to be Drinke Gentian in water and hony to helpe the swelling of the stomacke and body, to helpe venemous bitings, and cause deliuerance of a dead childe. Blood corrupt Breath short Bruises Bursten Cattell sicke Consumption Colde griefes Colour bad Dead childe Iliake pas. Impostume Liuer griefes Lungs griefes Mad Milt griefes Oxen sicke Plague Poyson Preseruatiue Purgation Sicknesse generall Side griefes Skin deformed Sores Spider Stomake griefes stuft GErmander: milt hard, vrine stopt, for the dropsie, in ye beginning seeth it in wine, drinke it thrise euery day. Stampe it when it flowreth, drinke the decoction, also apply the herbe to bruises to helpe them speedely. Stampe it apply it to fistulaes of ye eyes, or make oile of ye herbe, drop it into them to heale them presently, especially if ye body be of cold co~plection. Seeth the herbe in wine, drinke it to auoide ye kings euill. Seeth it in wine wt fenel seedes Sene, to help greatly ye stoppings of ye liuer milt, parsley seedes put thereto, it helpeth ye strangury stone. Palsie, boile it in wine, apply it to help it. Boile ye greene herbe in conduit water, drinke it to helpe ye crampe, ye palsie, the cough, hardnes of the milt, stopping of vrine, and the water betweene the skin and flesh. Seeth it in wine, drinke it against poyson, and apply ye herbe to ye bitings of venemous beasts, wormes serpents. Seeth it in wine vineger, drinke it for ye hardnes of the milt, the old cough, and old vlcers mixt wt hony so drunke Eate ye powder of the herbe wt hony to kil wormes. Reume, heate ye powder in a linnen bag apply it. Mouth blisters, wash with ye decoction of it thrise a day. Scab small, make an ointment of it with swines grease, anoint therewith often. Eies dull, haw pearle, apply the iuice of ye leaues wt oile straked on ye eies. Stampe ye leaues and lay them in oile, apply them to burstings, wounds, consuming sores. Seeth Germander and the flowers of it wt a litle betony in wine or water, straine it, sugar it, or hony it after the maner of a decoction: it doth mightely heale ye cough, ye beginning of ye dropsy, stopping hardnes of ye milt, ye strangury stopping of the vrine termes, it serueth for al griefs ye Betony serueth, especially for women that are cold, troubled wt the whites. Germander dried sodden, is good for women to sit in, or to be applied to their natural place in bags to stop ye whites the gnawing of the matrix. Seeth it wt salt vineger, stampe it with leuin, apply it to ye stomake for ye coldnes of the stomake, the belching, lothing, vomiting. Eate ye leaues by themselfe, or with reasins, the stones taken out fasting to withstand ye plague. They helpe the tertian feuer, open the liuer milt, one handful being boyled with Sene i. ounce, aniseedes ii. drams in a quart of white wine. If ii. drams of parsly seede be put to it, it helpeth also the strangurie stone, and when the one halfe is wasted, streine it and drinke it fasting ii. dayes, ii. houres before meate. Drinke it with vineger to abate the swelling of the liuer against poyson. Drinke it with good wine, also make pils thereof with hony, swallow them to purge sores vlcers. It openeth the stoppings of the ioynts, drieth grosse humors. Drinke the seedes to draw out yellow choller, and to comfort the eyes. Steepe it in aqua vitae, and drinke it to purge melancholy madnesse. Seethe it in red wine, and drinke it often to stop a laske, eate parched almonds, be whole. Wormes in the eye lids, stampe it with old wine and apply it. Flowers stopt, stampe halfe a handfull and streine it with ale, and drinke it with one peniworth of saffron in the mornings. Head fistula, put in powder of Germander, and wash the head with the decoctio~ of it. Ruptures inward, stampe it with a woodden pestell, and steepe it in good white or red wine that is astringent, and drinke thereof often. Gather Germander when it flowreth, drie it in the shade, and mixe one spoonefull of ye powder of it with the yolkes of two egs, and seethe it, and eate it morne and euen eight dayes, and keepe a good diet to cure the falling euill. GInger: eyes dull, grinde white Ginger on a whetstone into a faire bason, and put thereto as much salt, and grinde them well together, and temper them with white wine, and let it stand xxiiii. houres, and put the clearest in a glasse, vse to anoint therewith when thou goest to bed. boile Ginger in hony and vineger, put it into thy hollowe tooth, or boyle ground Iuie and Ginger in wine, and holde thy mouth ouer it, rub thy teethe with the Ginger, or burne Ginger, blacke pepper, and salt of eache like much in a linnen cloute, and lay a litle of the powder on a linnen cloth, and apply it to the tooth. Flowers to stop, lay Ginger, Baye leaues, and Sauine on hote coales, and receiue vp the fume thereof through a tunnell in a close chaire. Eyes dull and red, grinde white Ginger on a whetstone into a brasen morter, put thereto as much salt, and grinde them well together, let it stand houres, then put ye scom into a viall, and wt a feather anoynt xxiiii. well the eyes when thou goest to bed, be whole. Chincough, seeth Elecampana with as much Ginger in faire water to ye one halfe, and stampe it streine it, and put thereto a third part of hony boiled scommed, make an electuary of it, take thereof a good quantitie morne euen. Eies pearle, rub Ginger dipt in white wine on a whetstone of Norway ouer a sawser, with that wine wash ye eies wt a fether to void ye pearle, preserue the eie. Brest to be cleare voice good, mixe powder of Ginger, lycoras, sugar with ye yolke of an Eg, a litle salt, warme it in ye shel, and eate it fasting. Ache, take newe waxe a qz. of a li. oile oliue v. sponeful, Ginger pared grated iii. rases. Melt ye waxe, put in ye oile, heate it a litle, then put in the Ginger, dip a cloth in it, apply it hote, and role it keepe it warme. Hickit, eate euery morning a race of greene Ginger, drinke ii. draughts of malmsey iii. houres before meat. Chollike stitch, drinke powder of Bayes and Ginger, and vse it also in meates. Face salsflegme, anoint wt powder of Ginger pepper, and ye iuice of pimpernell. seethe powder of Ginger, Cummin, and Licoras of each one peniworth in hony, till it be thicke, and mixe a litle geine Treacle with it, and eate thereof first last. Seeth it with Figs in wine, and drinke it to helpe the colde the cough, or eate ye powder in Figs. Vse the powder in meate to withstand swooning, for rawnesses in the stomacke, and to loosen the belly, and cause digestion. Take ii. drams, asmuch sugar with warme water to purge viscus humors. Greene Ginger prouoketh lust, digesteth meate, warmeth the stomacke, drieth vp the moysture that commeth by eating of fruite. It is good for the flegme of the lungs, the olde cough, shortnesse of breath, and all cold griefes: it openeth obstructions, helpeth digestion and appetite, and expelleth grosse humors and winde. Ringwormes, anoint them with blacke sope, and almost as much Ginger iiii. or v. dayes, it helpeth tetters also in like sort. Mixe i. peny waight wt thrise so much sugar, and put thereof into the eyes to consume ye white flegme that groweth ouer the eye in short time. Take Ginger ii. ounces, sugar viii. ounces, Cinamom halfe an ounce, vse it as blaunch powder with rosted wardens, apples, quinces, hensawes, and such like. Stomacke griefes, and to helpe digestion, vse greene Ginger before meates. Eyes pearle, mixe fine powder of Ginger and pepper with the gall of an Eele and fine hony, and vse it to kill it. To driue downe the Emerods, drinke powder of Ginger, long pepper graines, of each like much to bedward warme: proued. Face salsflegme, grinde powder of Ginger brimstone with hony, and the iuice of red nettles and anoint therewith. Flowers stopt, boyle a pottell of the best wine with a good rase of Ginger, and a fewe maces and graines in powder with butter drinke thereof often. seeth powder of pepper and Ginger in ale, and put it into a cloute dipt in aqua vitae, and apply it. Flowers stopt to stop Hicket Lungs griefes Lust to cause Obstructions Purgation Ringworme Sawse Stitch Stomack colde GOoseberies vnripe, stoppe the bellie and all issues of blood, especially the iuice of them pressed out and dried. The iuice of greene Gooseberies is very good for all hote inflammations, shingles, and wild fire, and so be the leaues, but not so good as the iuice. The berries eaten with meats, prouoke appetite, coole the heat of the stomacke liuer, and are good against hote agues. The yong leaues eaten raw, prouoke vrine, and are good for the grauel and stone. They are good in sawses before they be ripe, with flesh and fish for them that be chollericke, hote and sicke. Appetite Bloody fluxe Fluxes Feuers hote Grauell Hote griefes Inflammations Liuer hote Shingles Stomacke hote Stone Vrine stopt Wilde fire Redde Gooseberries. REdde Gooseberies, or ribes doe refresh and coole the hote stomacke, and liuer, and are good against all inflammations, and heate of the blood and hote agues. Chew them and holde them in the mouth for all hote humors and inflammations, and to coole thirst in agues. It stoppeth the chollericke laske, and the bloodie flixe, especially the rob or dried iuice thereof. The rob made of the iuice of common ribes with sugar, is very good for al the diseases aforesaide, it stoppeth vomitings, and is good for hote agues, being drunk with a litle cold water, or holden in the mouth They may be kept either in their owne iuice, or in vergis, or dried in the sun. GOosefoot is in nature much like to morell or nightshade, and in outward causes may be vsed for it. It killeth swine if they eate it, and is very dangerous as Solanum is. GOoseheirif or Cleuer, drink the iuice of the leaues and seeds against venimous bitings. Kings euill, and all kernels and wennes in any place: stampe it with swines greace, and apply it, and so it helpeth swoln paps of curded milke. Sores or scabs in any place, bruise it and lay it in spring water foure and twenty houres, and then wash therewith. Cough and flegme in the stomacke, seeth a handfull in a quart of ale with a litle pared licoras, and some currants to the one halfe, then streine it, and drinke it first and last, at morne and euen. Dropsie, mixe the iuice of it and walwort ana sixe handfull, and drink it ten dayes, and bathe thee euery day with the same hearbes, till the water come out at the soles of thy feete, then bathe no more, but continue the vse of the said drink ten daies out. Wormes in the flesh, drinke the iuice of it and of tansie. Bitings venimous Bleeding Brests swolne Coughs Dropsie Eares ache Iaundies Kernels Kings euill Scabbes Sores Wennes Wormes Wounds Goosetansie. GOosetansie, face pimples, wash it with water of it and of roses. Fluxes, kneade wheat cakes with the iuice of it, and yolks of egges, and bake them and eate them. Liuer to restore, seethe it with newe woort, and streine it and drinke it with white wine or ale: proued, or seeth it with liuerwort ribwort in strong wort, and streine it, and put in sugar, and sometimes drinke thereof, and sometimes set a barme on it, and drinke thereof first and last thirtie dayes, (see Dasie for hands.) Liuer hote, and face deformed, distill it with a quarte of strawberries, and three pintes of new milke, and drinke thereof morne and euen, and washe thy face therewith. Seethe it in water or wine, and drinke it to stoppe the bloodie fluxe, and al other fluxes of blood, and the whites and termes. Boyle it in water and salt, and drinke it to dissolue bruised and congealed blood. The decoction of it cureth vlcers, and sores of the mouth, and the hote humours that fall into the eyes, and stripes that perish the sight, being washed therwith. It hath manie other vertues, as against the stone, inwarde wounds, and corrupt fretting vlcers of the gummes, and secrete parts: it strengtheneth the bowels, it closeth vp greene wounds, it fastneth loose teeth, and helpeth the toothach. The distilled water is good for the freckels, spottes, pimples, and sunne burning of the face, the ach, fluxes, rednesse, and spots of the eies, and to clense the skin, and make it white. Steepe it in white wine, and wash therewith to make the skin white. Freckles Liuer hote wasting Mouth sores Priuities sores Skin to clense Stone Teethach loose Vlcers Whites Wounds Goulds. Boile it in wine to cure the Iaundies, and to restore good colour, and drinke it after long and often bathing. The seed drunk in wine by it selfe, or stampt with the flowers, doeth also cure the iaundies. Stampe the flowers with oyle and waxe to dissolue colde swellings of the head. The leaues and tender branches may wel be vsed in pottage and sallades. GOurds: Deliuerance to cause, tie the roote to her reines, but take it away speedily, least the matrix follow. Anoint any cattel with the iuice in summer, and hote weather, and no flies wil touch them. Face redde, make an oile of two ounces of the seeds, foure ounces of peach kernels, and anoynt therwith morn and euen. Stampe the leaues rub horses with them, and no flies wil touch them, or rub them with lees of wine at morne and noone. Dissolue a dram of the leaues in good wine, and drink it as often as need is for ye prefocation of the mother. Sores moist to heale, put the powder of the rinde. Headach, frensie, want of sleepe, dip a cloth in the iuice of Gourds, and purslan with vineger, and apply it. Pissing blood, drinke powder of the seedes of Gourds, cummin, and mallowes, of ech foure penie weight, with two ounces of milke, and vse to eate good store of milke. Liuer chafed, scrape off the vttermost of a Gourde, and steepe the same scrapings in vineger and apply it. Apply the iuice to a bare place, to withstand the growing of haire. Ashes of dry Gourds doeth quickely heale rotten vlcers of the yarde. Gourdes are not eaten rawe, but sodden, rosted, or fryed. cleane picked from their vppermost skinnes, and sodden in barley water, and streined and drunke, helpeth the griefes of the liuer, kidneyes and bladder, the impostumes of the breast, and prouoketh vrine. But if the patient cannot drinke of this water, then make it into a syrrop with sugar, and so it is good also for all agues. Mixe the meate of gourds, or rather the iuice with milke and vineger, and apply it to the liuer for the heate thereof, with a cloth dipt therein. Gourds ought to bee hanged vp and dried, and when winter commeth, the seedes must be taken out, and rubbed with salt, that so the clammie humour may bee auoyded, and then they are to bee laide vp in a drie place, and so they may bee kept three yeeres. Applie the meate of the gourds to the forehead of young children to auoyde the great heate and inflammation of the head and brayne. Anoynt burning goutes, and the inflammation of the eyes, with the iuice of Gourdes, and drop thereof into the eares for the burning heate in them, either by it selfe, or with oyle of roses hote, the same is good to anoynt the ridge bone, to asswage the burning heate of agues, and for the holy fire, beeing anoynted. The ashes of the rindes cast on the vlcers of the priuie partes, nowe growen to a rottennesse, doeth cleanse and heale them, and so it doeth burnings and scaldings. The decoction of the meate with a litle honie and niter drunke, looseneth the bellie gently. Distill the meate and seedes of ripe Gourds, and drinke foure ounces of the water twenty or fourtie dayes to helpe the stone in the kidneis: and drinke it ten dayes to clense the reines and bladder. Apply the meate of them shreaded small to hard swellings. The water drunke, prouoketh vrine, and qualifieth the heate of the ague: boyle the meate and seeds, and slice them and boile it with onions, butter, and salt, and so it is good for them that be leane. If a gourde be made hollowe, and filled all night with good wine, and drunke in the morning, it purgeth the bellie or bodie. The iuice or distilled water of the meate of vnripe Gourdes drunke, quencheth heate of burning feuers, the same beeing also applied to the heart and liuer. It helpeth also ache of the eares, and of the eyes, and al other parts, and the hote gout. Bruise the meate and apply it to swellings and apostumes. Drinke the iuice of the whole herb boiled with a litle hony saltpeter, to loosen the belly gently. The iuice of the tender branches drunke with sweet wine and a litle vineger, cureth the bloody fluxe. The seeds of Gourds is almost of like vertue with the seeds of Cucumbers. Bloody flixe Brest impostume Burnings Deliuerance Eyes inflamed Face red Feuers hote GRaines, see Cardamom: flowers to cause, drink one nutmeg, as much Graines, and as much saffron in powder, with halfe a pinte of drinke, warme. Emerodes to driue downe, and for the shaking feuer, drinke powder of graines, long pepper and ginger. Impostume in the brest, bake water cresses, sage, and auence a handfull, graines one ounce, clarified honie one pinte in paste, and when it is well baked, it is souereigne for aking. Mother suffocat. take vp the fume of Graines, cloues, frankincense, and other sweete things laied on a fire of charcoale into the matrix: proued. GRasse, Seethe it to helpe the griefes of the milte. GRatiola, or gratia Dei, boyle it and drinke it, or eate it in any kinde of meate to open the bellie freely, and to purge grosse flegme and choller. Wounds to heale speedily, strawe on the powder of it, or vse it in oyles or oyntments. GRomel, Vrin stopt, stamp it with parsley, strain it, and drink it with white wine. It is good for the stone all griefes of the bladder. Vrine stopt, stampe it with parsley and rue, and drinke it with white wine, and be whole. Eate tostes of bread, or sops in wine with powder of the seedes of Gromel, and parsley to voyde the stone after it is broken. Vrine stopt, seethe mallowes, and a good quantitie of Gromell in vineger a good while, and drinke thereof warme. Stampe the seeds and drink them in white wine to break the stone, especially in the bladder, and to driue forth vrine. Bruise the seeds and steepe them all night in white wine, with some fenell, parsley, and sene, and in the morning seeth it, and streine it sugar it, and drinke it to purge flegme and choller, to open and cleanse the reines and bladder, and to expell wind plentifully: it must be boiled in a stone vessel. Stamp the hearbe and apply it hote for the same purpose. GRoundswell: Brestssore, stampe a great handfull, and drink it with white wine, or stale ale morne and euen Feuer, stamp foure handfull with vineger and bay salt ana three spoonfuls, seethe it til it be almost drie, and apply it to thy wrists as hote as may be suffered. Breast to clense, stampe white horehound foure ounces, Grounswel three ounces, walwort ii. ounces, and seeth them with fresh barows greace, and apply it to thy brest, in one night thou shalt auoid much flegme corruption. Wound to heale, stamp it with some wormwood, and old swines greace, and apply it, and so it healeth pushes and whelks. Boile the leaues and stalkes in water or sweet wine, and drinke it to heale the ach of the stomack, comming of choller. Stampe the leaues and flowers alone, or with a litle wine, and apply it to the burning heate, inflammation of the stones fundament. Mixe it with fine powder of Frankincense, and apply it to heale all wounds, especially of the sinews. Eies bleared and dropping, apply the doun of the flowres with saffron and water. Apply it with a litle salt to waste consume the kings euill, or struma in the throate or necke. The small Groundswel is good in sallads with oyle vineger. Stamp Groundswel and seethe it in water and drinke it with pottage to purge hote choller. The heads with the floures tempred with a litle wine and Manna healeth the wounds of sinews. The whole stalk sodden in water and drunk with Malmesey, healeth the cholerick ach of the stomacke. Brest to clense Brests sore Eyes griefes Feuers Fundament inflam. Head scald, (See before) Inflammations Kernels Kings euill Priuities sores Purgation GViacum or Lignum Sanctum: It drieth vp maketh fine and subtill, it melteth or resolueth, skowreth away prouoketh sweat, and withstandeth putrifaction. Vse the broth thereof for the French pockes, for the Gout that is not deepely rooted, the griefes of the Liuer and Milt. Vse the broth for the Iaundies many other griefs that be hard to be cured. It is very good to be sodden in Renish wine. And the powder of it sodden in Beere wort, is drinkeable enough: but whether it be sodden in water or wine, or Beere wort or Ale wort, such herbes must be sodden with it as do respect the disease that it is taken for. For the Gout, Dropsie, Sciatica and Timpany, it is comparable with the best medicines, and likewise for the Ranker. It helpeth the extreme paines of the Ioynts, senowes and veines, muskles, veines, senowes, head and feete, and bones, and no disease is so sharpe and cruell to nature, but this precious wood will heale it both speedily and gently, and swage the paine: The french Pocks, the Gout, the Dropsie, the Strangury, Pissing blood, the stopping of the vrine, Oppilations, Headach, Vertigo or giddinesse: Feuers, Shyngles, horrible Apostumations and swellings of the belly: but strait diet is not to be allowed. For the Rume and grosse humors, fill a diet pot with Cunduit water al sauing a quart, which must be white wine, Lycoras scraped and cut small, one pound, Lignum vite halfe a pound, the barke of it one ounce, boile them one houre and an halfe, then streine it keepe it in a close vessell, and drinke thereof first and last, the best is from saint Iohns Iland: for hote griefes, vse the more water, and lesse wood: for cold griefs, more wood and lesse water. It cureth the Pocks and almost all other griefes: it must be sodden in a close vessell set in seething water x. houres. Diet, vse meates competently to suffice nature, as Mutton, Veale and Hennes sodden in a double vessell, and seasoned with salt and brought to a pleasant taste: but vse no excesse drinke, as much as is needefull for the disease, alwayes warme: but if thou be saint, vse therewith some Renish or small white wine, as much as of the drinke mixt together: but drinke no Beere till thou beest whole.
