It cureth the naughtie skab itche, the white spots of all the body, and also the skurfe and skales of the head, and restoreth haire in pilled places being laide thereto in the sunne. The same with Capons grease is good against blisters, galling of the feete with shooes. The long Onion is more vehement then the rounde, and the red more then the white, the greye more then the greene, and the rawe more then the sodden or preserued in salt. They warme and cleanse the stomacke, bring good colour to the face: they are good for the newe greene sicknesse, prouoke vrine. And eaten abundantly with meate, cause one to sleepe soundly. Drinke iii. ounces of the distilled water fasting with a litle sugar to prouoke vrine abundantly. Seeth Onions wt oyle, white Lilie rootes, butter and wheate flowre to ripen apostumes of hard maturation. Onions in plasters are good for the loosenesse and ache of the ioynts, and for the goute. By themselues, or with hony, they drawe out prickes spelds, with hony they are good for the ache of the stomacke. The iuice with the yolke of an egge, vineger, and hony, taketh away red or wanne pimples or spots in the face and body. Being rosted and mixt with parched barley meale, and the heads of small fishes, they restore blacke skarres to their colour. Being sodden and eaten, they take away the paine of the sides. The iuice is good to be anointed on the squincie, and helpeth bloodshotten eyes when they begin. Put a piece of a bruised Onion into the nose against the dissinesse of the head and braine. Fluxes to stop, take Triphera magna with a great Onion. Eares dull, rost a red Onion with the iuice of Wormewood, and of the heads and rootes of Leekes, doe off the vppermost pill, and streine it drop thereof into the eare. rost an Onion, and apply the one halfe to the one wrist, and the other to the other. Lethargie, put the iuice of an Onion into ye nostrels. Plague to heale, rost Treacle in an Onion in the embers wrapt in a wet linnen, presse out ye iuice, drink one spoonefull of it. Chollike stone, slice an Onion, steepe it all night in white wine, drinke it in the morning, walke one houre after it. To ripen a sore, rost oile Oliue in an Onion, and apply it. rost saffron in an Onion, apply it to the nauell as hote as may be suffered, and weare Knotgrasse in thy shooes. Rost fresh grease in an Onion, stampe it and apply it hote to the nauell to loosen the belly. Eares wormes, rost the grease of an Eele in an Onion, and streme it put it into the sore eare. Ague cake, rost Onions with butter, and streine it anoint the side. To skowre the stomacke, cause appetite, boile iii. great Onions, grind them with thrise so much sowre bread of wheate, and put thereto v. peniworth of saffron, one ounce of ginger, and temper them with vineger, make it so thicke that a spoone may stand in it, eate a litle of it dayly morne euen. Eares paine, or watry, or wormes, drop in the iuice with hony, and a litle powder of Bayes if you will. Burning and skalding to heale in iiii. dayes, cut an Onion ouerwhart, and wring out the iuice vpon the place twise a day. Belly wormes, pill Onions, and slice them small, and powre spring water ouer them, and let it stand all night, and drinke it in the morning to expell all wormes. Burning or skalding, anoint with the iuice apply the substance. Eares deafe, rost ye iuice of Leeke blades, powder of Cummin, in an holow Onion, and put it in. Flowers to cause, eate Onions, or drinke their iuice. Onions tender in the embers, and pill them and presse them flat, and apply them to the stomacke hote as may be suffered twelue houres, and then renewe it, and doe so Goute of colde cause and sciatica, stampe Onions with oyle de Bay, and put thereto some powder of Pepper or of Euphorbium, and apply it to the sciatica: or roste powder of Pepper in a great Onion, and worke them well together, and keepe it in a boxe, and anoint well therewith against the fire wheresoeuer the goute be. Apostume, seethe Onions and Cummin in wine and oyle, and apply it: proued. Cold humors in the stomacke, eate rawe Onions with course bread fasting. Vrine to cause, put the toppe of an Onion into the yarde. Eares watry, apply the iuice with a little Goose grease. Chollike in the stomacke and belly of winde, seethe running water, and seethe therein in foure seuerall partes or waters, presse them betweene two trenchers, and butter them, cast on grosse pepper, and eate them morne and euen. Piles, roste sugarcandy in great Onions in the embers, as it were a Warden, and open it and apply it. Knees ache and swelling, and the feete likewise, anoint with the iuice of Onions Hens grease. Iaundies, roste as much Treacle as a Chestnut, with some powder of Saffron in a great Onion, and streine it and drinke the iuice of it iii. daies be whole. Eares deafe, put in iii. or iiii. drops of the iuice of a red Onion iii. iiii. nights. Saint Omers Onions, and put in good aqua vitae, and roste them and streine them, and keepe the oyle, and anoint therewith. Emerods, roste red Onions apply them hote as may be suffered. Plague, rost Treacle in an Onion and streine it, and drinke one spooneful, and thou shalt soone mend if God will: or drinke the iuice of a white Onion, Hony, vineger, and the iuice of Rue and Yarowe, of each like much in Ale, more then halfe a glassefull warme, and couer thee well to sweate: doe it within the vi. houre after thou art infected or payned. To keepe flies from flesh, lay an Onion vpon it. Horse foundred, stampe an Onion, and steepe it in strong vineger, and make him to swallowe the Onion, and put the vineger into his nostrels, (See Almonds. Eares griefes generall, put in the iuice with hony. Bitings venemous, stampe an Onion with fresh Rue, Salt, and Hony, of eache like much and apply it, it is meruailous. Emerods, apply the iuice with the gall of an Oxe. Vrine stopt in Agues, roste an Onion, and apply it to the bladder. Biting of a mad dog, apply an Onion with Salt and Walnuts. Warts, bruise them with hony, and apply them, especially the red ones. Speeche lost, drinke the iuice with any liquour to restore it. For swelling and paine in the left side, and shortnesse of breath, apply a plaster of rosted Onions. rost Frankincense and Cummin in a red Onion, and apply it hote in a cloth to the nape of the necke: proued. Stone, rost vi. or x. Onions, pill them bruise them, put them in a quart of good Malmesey, stirre them ii. or iii. houres, then streine it seethe it to the one halfe, drinke thereof iii. or iiii. dayes mornings or more. To take away ye heate of fire, stamp Onions with salt and apply it: proued. Itch and skab, mince Onions, seethe them in vineger or water, and wash therewith. Stone to breake, bake a Rye cake, and slice it through the mids, and lay thereon Onions rosted and sliced, and apply the one part to the bottome of the belly, and the other to the reines. Feete galled Feuer Flesh to keepe Flies to voide Flowers stopt Horse foundred Iaundies Ioynts ache stitche Kibes Knees ache and swolne Lame Lethargie Lust to cause Mad dog ORchis, or Standard grasse, the full and sappy rootes, especially of Harebollox, or Gotes orchis eaten or boyled in Gotes milke and drunke, prouoketh venus, doe nourish and strengthen them that haue a consumption, or feuer hectike, but the withered or shriueled rootes represse lust. If men eate of the full rootes, they shall beget sonnes, but if women eate of the withered, they shall bring foorth daughters. The same rootes boyled in wine and drunke, stop the fluxe. The same roote greene consumeth all tumors, and cleanseth rotten sores and fistulaes, being applied, and the powder thereof cast into fretting and deuouring vlcers and sores stayeth the same from further fretting and festering. The same boyled in wine with a litle hony, cureth the rotten sores and vlcers of the mouth. Satirion is much of like nature, so is Palma christi. The round and full rootes of all kindes of Satirion or Orchis, are good in meate and Electuaries to prouoke Venus, but especially with Goates milke, or mixt with white Pepper and Hony. The same bruised and anointed, are good against inflammations and They purge sores that runne, and doe heale them, like as Aron doeth, and Dragons, especially Orchis Odorata. Conception Consumption Feuer hectike Fistula Flux Generating Inflammation Lust to cause OPopanax is very good against colde shiuerings of feuers, paine of the side, ache and gnawing in the guts, the strangurie, inward bruises, being drunke with meede. With wine or meede, it helpeth the skurfe griefes of the bladder. Take two drams or lesse to purge flegme and colde tough humors from the braine, sinowes, and ioynts, and for all colde griefes of the head, sinowes, ioynts, crampes, palsies, &c. and to cleanse the breast, shortnesse of breath, olde and dangerous coughes, hardnesse, and other griefes of the milt and the dropsie, being steeped in wine and drunke. It doeth scatter, soften, and dissolue all hard cold swelling tumors being steeped in vineger and applied. Sciatica, apply it with ye pulp of reasins, and the like to ye goute of the legs or feete. For windinesse and hardnesse of ye matrix, and to expell the flowers, dead birth, and seconds, mixe it with hony, and vse it as a pessarie. To breake carbuncles, plague sores, and other tumors, soke it in vineger and apply it. boile it in vineger, and put it in, or apply it. Biting venemous, mixe it with pitch, and apply it to bitings of mad wild beastes. Feuers colde, drinke it with vineger one houre before the fitte, and anoint the spine of the backe with the iuice of Smallach, and oyle of Dill. weekes space it is good for the dropsie, and swolne milt. And drunke with honied water warme, it healeth the strangurie, expelleth the termes and dead birth, causeth obortion, and is good for other griefes of the matrix. Eyes dull, put it into the eies alone, or vse it in collyries. Drinke as much as a Filbeard to prouoke vrine, and menstrues, and for the coldnesse of the matrixe. Bladder griefes Breast stopt Breath short Bruised Carbuncles Cough Deliuerance ORgany: drinke the decoction of the flowers for griefes of the liuer: put the leaues and flowers into a linnen bag, and seethe it in wine, and apply it hote to the head, and couer thee well to sweate, and so it driueth foorth many griefes of the head and breast, and the straitnesse of breath. Seethe it in wine, drinke it to helpe the stomacke, and ease ye bowels of grieuous paine in making water, and the dropping of vrine. Seethe it in wine and oyle Oliue, and strike it on a linnen cloth, and apply it to the matrix for the hardnesse thereof, and to purge it and to drawe downe the termes. To heale the red leapry, take the iuice of Organy and Horehound, a litle wine, and oyle of Henbane, but yet more then the iuices, and put to them a litle oyle of Tartar, and anoint therewith in a hote house: but if any paine remaine afterward, anoint wt fresh Goates grease melted in a frying pan, lie downe in cleane sheetes vntill it be dryed in: and after that bruise Organy, and mixe it with wheate branne, and heate it in a frying pan, and apply it very hote vpon the blisters and leapry, and binde it to till it neede heating againe, and doe so often be whole out of doubt. good blood, and be of easie digestion, and drinke dayly syrupe of Fumiterie, but in winter syrupe of Egrimonie. Eares paine, drop in the iuice with womans milke warme. Fundament fallen, stampe it with Roses, Calamus Aromaticus, and Wormewood, and apply it. Seethe it in wine with Figs, Hony, and Rue, and vse it to helpe the spitting of matter, continuall cough, shortnesse of breath, to clense ye lungs, and to kill wormes drunke morne and euen, or vse the conserue thereof to the same effectes. Seethe it with figs, and gargle therewith for the Squincie, and with vineger for the Stampe it with figs, and and apply it to the dropsie. Take vp the vapour of it sodden into the eare for the noise thereof: it may be vsed for Time, and Time for it. For difficultie of breathing of colde cause, drinke iii. ounces of the water morne and euen. Matrix hard, boyle it with wine, and mixe it with oyle Oliue, and apply it. Vvula fallen, and pallat swolne, gargarise with the water distilled in a Limbeke in Iune. Chollike, drinke one scruple of the powder of it with good wine. Eares apost. seethe it in oyle Oliue, and put it in. Bloody fluxe, drinke it with wine. Flowers to cause, boyle it in red wine and make a syrupe thereof, and drinke it often, or apply a plaster thereof to the wombe, and ouer the plaster holde thy mouth and nose, and also take the suffumigation thereof for the same purpose. To make any place of the body white, stampe Organy, and rub it therewith. Fundament fallen Head griefes Itche Leapry red Liuer griefes Lungs to cleanse Matrix hard Skin to be white Spitting matter Squincy Stomacke griefes Tenasmus Vrine stopt OPium, which is the iuice of blacke Poppy, cooleth, thicketh, and dryeth. Take as much as a fitch to swage paine, cause sleepe, helpe the flixe, but too much of it is hurtfull, for it taketh away ye memory, killeth. powre it on the head with Rose oile. Eares ache, put it in with oyle of Almonds, oile of Myrrhe saffron. Eies burning inflamed, apply it with the yolke of a hard rosted Eg. Apply it wt vineger to infla~mations, shingles, holy fire, and to heale wounds. Take Opium and Leuin of each ii. drams well beaten wt hony and vineger, anoint the temples pulses therewith for ye frensie, or make a plaster of Opium, Henbane seede with sugar, the iuice of Lettuse, apply it to the forehead, or vse a suppositorie of Opium oyle of violets, or apply saffron, Mandrage, Opium to the head, or take Opium i. dram, blacke Poppy ii. drams, mixe them with Populeon and womans milke that suckleth a wench, apply it to the temples, all these for the frensie. Wash thy face wt the decoction of Poppy, thou shalt either sleepe, or die out of hand. dassing, turning, or giddie, take Opium saffron, ana ii. drams, oile of Roses. iiii. drams, make thereof a plaster with vineger, apply it to the head. Opium wt vineger dissolueth the goute, or mixe halfe a dram of Opium in powder with ye yolkes of iii. egs, oile of Roses, and apply plasters thereof. To sleepe while ye surgian do his office, drinke halfe a dram of Opiu~ with i. pound or more of wine. As much as a wheate corne doth make a man to sleepe without waking, till vineger be put into his nose, and his head and face washed all ouer with vineger. Frensie, hony and vineger, leuen and Opium, of eache like much mixt together, and the pulses anointed therewith. The iuice inner substance especially where the iuice is very good against all contagious and corruptions of the ayre, the plague, and other hote feuers it preserueth, and also cureth the same, it comforteth the heart, and especially the mouth of the stomacke, and helpeth the weakenesse thereof, the trembling of the heart, pensiue heauinesse, and wambling of the stomacke, vomiting and lothing in agues, and such like diseases. The iuice quencheth thirst, and reuiueth appetite, so doeth the syrupe thereof. The pils condited or preserued with hony or sugar, doe warme the stomacke, and mendeth a stinking breath, and helpeth digestion. The seedes withstand all venom and poison, and killeth and expelleth wormes. Hang an Orenge prickt full of Cloues into a wine vessell, so that it touch not the wine, to giue it a fine colour and taste. Appetite Aire corrupt Breath stinke Feuer Fluxe Heart to comfort trembling Pensiuenesse Plague Poyson Stomacke ill Thirst Venom Vomiting Wine to keepe Wormes Orpin. ORpin, or Liuelong, hath the nature and vertues of Houseseeke. Mixe the iuice with strong white vineger, anoint ye morphue euery houre therewith, likewise all filthy and stinking vlcers. It healeth wounds new and old, and likewise fistulaes and ruptures. The water thereof is good against all ruptures and conuulsions, and also for all wounds inward outward. For gnawing of the stomacke, lungs, liuer, guts, matrix, and the bloody fluxe being drunke dayly. wine with hony and drunke, is good for all the aforesaid. The hearbe sodereth and healeth all wounds, especially harneyes and ruptures, and stoppeth the bleeding of wounds, and ceaseth the ache, being stampt and applied. Finger bruised and flesh raysed, stampe it with salt, and apply it in a fayre cloth, and remooue it not till it be whole. OTes may be vsed in plasters and Cataplasmes in steade of Barley. Otemeale tempered with vineger, voydeth lentels spots from the face. Otebread nourisheth but litle, is not very agreeable to mankind. The iuice of Otes in suppings or brothes, is good for the cough. The meale of parched Otes drunke with honied water, is good for the cough. Otes sodden in vineger take away moles, blanes, and spots. Holde any lame member ouer the fume of Otes, and then set the same member into the sodden Otes, after it hath bene a good while ouer the vapour, doe so as often as neede is till it be well. Chollike, parch Otes in a panne, and apply them to thy nauill, as hote as may be suffered. Reines running, stampe good store of Otemeale, and seeth it in a pint of milke, and streine it and drinke it with sugar. Costiuenesse, stampe Otemeale Greyts and seeth them with Buglosse and vse the broth, (See Gouts in Leekes. Legs or feete ache, or swelling, chop red water cresses small, and put thereto thicke dregs of Otemeale as much, and fresh sheepes tallowe, and boyle it till it be thicke, and apply it. Belly grinding, apply Cummin, Bayes, and Otemeale to the place hote in a broad cloth. Artetica passio, seethe crums of bread and Otemeale with wine and apply it. Ach of the Gout, seethe Otemeale and smallach and apply it. Cods swollen, boyle Cowes dung with Otemeale, with milke and dregs of oyle, and apply it. Apostume, boyle Otemeale with sheepes sewet in faire water and apply it. Breath short, make Grewell of Otemeale, water, Puluill and Cummin, and vse it: it openeth well and clenseth out flegme. Bruse, boyle Otemeale with sheepes sewet in water and apply it. Wounds, bruses, and such like, stampe Otemeale with sheepes tallow, and boyle it in water and apply it: if Holyoke rootes be put thereto, it is the better. Swellings, apply the grosse meale with the white of an Egge and vineger. Head ach of melancholy, bathe some times in a bath made with Ote straw, but sit not in it too long nor too hote, and take no cold after it. Throte squincy or apostumed, vse Otemeale grewell well sifted, and put ten or twelue Almonds thereto well beaten, and suger, and eate it with bread, (See Mallowes. Stomacke ill after meate, eate thinne pap of Otemeale made with wine. Legs cold with age or sickenesse, seeth halfe a strike of Otes with two quarts of water, and one quart of wine, and stirre it well that it burne not, and put it into two soft bags, and lap thy legges therein at morne, noone, and euen, as long as neede is. Legs ache and swollen, seeth Otemeale in milke, and put thereto the iuice of Housleeke and sheepes tallow and apply it. Knees, legs or ioynts lame, seethe a blacke sheepes head, and the wooll thereof all chopt a pieces, cast out the bones, and seeth Otemeale therein till it be thicke, and apply it. Legs swollen, seethe Otes in water till they be tender, and holde thy leg ouer the vapour, and let out the water of the blisters, and anoynt it with Butter: the like is good for any lame member, the same being also holden in the Otes hote as may bee suffered foure or fiue times, if To breake a Bile, Fellon or Vncome, stampe a handfull of Otemeale and seeth it in a pinte of sweete milke and sheepes sewet shreaded small, and when it is thicke, apply it to breake it gently, then apply Turpentine vpon Lether pricke full of holes, to cleanse and heale it: it is good also for any bruise or sore. Chollike, parch Otes and apply them hote to the Nauel. Reines running, seethe bruised Otemeale in milke, with a good piece of sugar, and eate it, (See face in Lillie. PAlma Christi: The seedes taken inwardly openeth the belly, causeth vomite, draweth out slimy flegme from farre, and sometimes chollerike and watrish humors. The broth of meate wherein the seedes haue bene sodden drunke, is good for the bellyach, gout, and sciatica. The same in powder taken in whey or new milke, driueth foorth superfluities and chollerike humors, and is good for the dropsie and Iaundies. The oile drawen forth of it called Oleum Cicinum, or in shops Oleum de Cherua, heateth and drieth, and is very good to anoynt and rub all rough hardnesse, skurfe itch. The greene leaues stampt with parched Barley meale, doth asswage all inflammations and swellings and sorenesse of the eyes. And with vineger they cure grieuous infla~mations swellings called S. Ant. fire. The same seedes are good to be taken with Anniseedes or Fennell seedes and some spices, as Cinamome and Ginger, &c. and so it will not torment the stomacke, but worke more gently and effectually. The leaues laid too by themselues or with vineger, swage swollen breast by two much milke. Powder of thirtie cornes pilled and drunke, purgeth both vpward and downeward. The iuice cleanseth the face from pimples and spots, and maketh the skinne smooth from warts being stamped with oyle of Tartar, and the place anointed therewith (See Spurge. Apply the iuice to any wound, to draw out Iron or Arrowe head, if any such be in it. The powder thereof melted with Frankincence and put into a clout and holden on the ring finger, and a ring of gold put on the same finger, and the hand washt in euery corner of the pond, will make the fish come to hand. Belly bound ach Brests swolne Chollike Dropsie Eyes sore Face deform. PEares of all sorts taken before meate, do nourish but litle, but yet more then Apples, especially those that be great sweete. The sower, rough and chokie Peares and others that are not watrie, eaten rawe or baked before meales, doe stop the common laske, and strengthen the mouth of the stomacke. They are good to bee layde to the beginning of hote tumors and greene wounds, and so are the leaues, for they close and heale newe wounds. To keepe Peares long, put them into a vessell that they touch not one another with fine white salt and couer them close: put a Pare into wine, cleane pared: if it swim, the wine is pure: but if it sinke, there is water mixt with it. To keepe Pares drie, seeth them in faire water and Rose water with Hony, with a gentle fire, and let them dreine through a cloth or colander, and then drie them in an Ouen after the batch is drawen foorth: if once doing so serue not, do so the second time, and then barrell them vp. Pares are good in Plasters that are made to stop the course of humors that run to any place. The iuice of the leaues is good for venemous bitings. syrope made of the iuice of Pares, is good against choller, and the chollorike fluxe. Pares breede the chollike: it is good to drinke Hypocras after them. Pares without wine are poyson, but sodden Pares are a treacle or preseruatiue. After Pares drinke, but after Apples goe to the stoole. All kinde of Pares doe binde as Quinces doe, and therefore are preserued in electuaries and syrops, to stop vomiting and fluxes. The leaues are good in baths to sit in, against the falling downe of the Matrixe and other griefes of women. Plasters of the leaues are good to stop vomites and lasks. Pares are worse then Apples, for being eaten raw, they make the blood watrish, and breede winde chollike, vnlesse good Sacke or Canarie wine be drunke after them. Pares and other fruites are to be eaten with salt, being first clensed both outwarly and inwardly. Pares, Apples and Quinces, may be sodden to Pap and streined, and to sixe pound of the Pap, put foure pound of Hony, and seethe them to perfection, and vse it. plaster of yong Pares that haue bene transplanted, is good for the senowes that are prickt. Cough, seethe Pares in wine, Ale or Beere, and take vp the vapour of them at the mouth. Bloody fluxe, seeth drie Pares in water, and drinke thereof, it helpeth also the laske. Stomacke and belly weake, dresse Pares in meate and vse them. Fluxe, seethe them in vineger and drinke it with Masticke, or seethe them in water, and drinke it. Liuer griefes, stampe the kernels and drinke them with Hony. Fundament fallen, bathe it with the decoction of the leaues. PArietary: it is singular good against chollericke inflammations, S. Anthonies fire, spreading and running sores, burnings, and all hote vlcers, being stampt and applied. An oyntment made with the iuice and Ceruse, is good against all hote vlcers, spreading sores, hote, burning, skuruie, and spreading skabs and such like impediments. The same iuice with Deares sewet, is good for the goute of the feete. The iuice with oyle of Roses dropt into the eares, swageth their paine. The decoction or broth drunke, helpeth the olde cough, grauell, stone: the difficultie of vrine being also applied warme outwardly. The leaues stampt, heale all burnings, inflammations, hard lumps, wheales of ye fundament called Pauos. The iuice with Gotes sewet, or with waxe oyle of Pryuet, it is good for ye gout. Gargle with the iuice and apply it also to the inflammation of hote kernels vnder the Iawes. Seethe it in wine or water with Hony or suger, to helpe the olde and drie cough, shortnesse of breath, obstructions of the liuer, milt and kidneys, to cleanse the Matrixe and inward passages, to driue downe the termes vrine, to cease the torments of the Matrixe, the water or powder doeth the like. The herbe with Hony, helpeth the inflammations of the mouth. The iuice put into the eares, taketh away their pricking ach. It helpeth also the shingles, holy fire, hote apost. swellings, inflammations, burnings, especially being tempered with Ceruse: and so it helpeth also creeping sores, Pockes and The herbe with water cresses fried with wine in a frying pan, and applyed to the bladder, driueth foorth vrine mightily, and applyed to the belly, it taketh away the torments thereof. And fryed with Beane meale, Mallowes and Wheat bran, oyle and wine and so applyed, it helpeth the bruised synowes and muskles. Seethe it with wine and apply it with branne to any ache, and to the ache of the stomacke and belly comming of colde: and in this case, the best wine is white wine that is somewhat sharpe. Strangurie and dissury, boyle it in salt water and oyle, and apply it. Boyle it and eate it against the colde, and windinesse of the stomacke: Fritters made thereof are good for the same purpose. No herbe is better to wash glasses, being vsed with some salte. Stampe it and apply it to the Cods vnder the Nauell foure times a day, to auoyd their paine, and the chollike. Drop the iuice with the gleere of an Egge into the eye to heale the web, being beaten together skummed. Chollike, drinke it with wine or apply it or foment with it. Fundament fallen, seethe it in water and bathe therewith and apply it. Stone in the reines or bladder, Stampe it and apply it. For the hoste, boyle the iuice of Parietarie and Planten, with swines grease, and streine it and anoynt the breast therewith by the fire, and be whole. Iliake passion and chollike, boyle it in oyle Oliue, and apply it very hote, and so it looseneth the belly. Wormes in the flesh, stampe it and Yarow with a little salt, and apply them twise or thrise, and drinke the same herbe with wine or ale. Eyes spots, beate the iuice with the gleire of an Egge, and skumme it, and put a drop of the clearest of it often into the eye, especially when thou goest to bed. Chollike, vse to drinke the decoction of it in wine, or vse it in bathes, plasters or glisters. Cods swollen, seeth it with wheate bran in sweete wine and apply it. Eares ach, put in the iuice with powder of Niter. Knees ach and swollen, wash them with the decoction thereof. Reines ach, seethe it in wine and drinke it and apply the herbe. Strangury, seeth it in water and apply it to the bladder. Reines running, stampe it streine it with Malmsie or white wine, or ale, and drinke it often. To pisse well stampe it and frye it, and apply it hote to the shares. the stomacke and belly, seeth it in thy potage and eate thereof. Stone, bath in the decoction thereof, and also drinke it in possit ale. Bruised inward, seeth it in white wine or olde stale, and a part of branne of wheate and Bores grease, and apply it hote, as often as neede is. Reines running, seeth it with Thyme and Parslie, of eche one handfull in a quart of strong ale to the one halfe, and drinke halfe a pinte morne and euen warme ten dayes. Distill it in a Limbecke, and drinke three ounces of the water morne and euen eight or ten dayes, to purge the Matrixe, reines and bladder, and to open the liuer and milt, (See in Mallowes. For cresty growings of the fundament, piles, stampe it with Yarrow and a little salt and apply it. Strangurie, seeth it well in salt water and apply it to the reines, shares and greines. Grauell and stone, vse it in pottage and possit ale, with Parslie rootes and Saxifrage. PArsnips: the rootes sodden tender and eaten, cause vrine, and are good against melancholly. The garden Parsnip eaten with meate, ingendreth good blood, and the wilde Parsnip eaten of women, moueth termes. The roote hangd about the necke, helpeth the swelling of the throte, no venemous thing shall hurt him that carrieth it about him. The seede drunke with wine and also applied to the Matrixe, prouoketh termes, and helpeth the straitnesse of making water, the paine of the side called the plurisy. The leaues stampt with hony and applied, doth clense and heale vlcers that eate greatly into the flesh. The herbe with the root shreaded distilled about the ende of March, and the water drunke three ounces morne euen, and the palsie members also anoynted therewith or bathed, helpeth their shaking. The roots eaten in meates, yeeld better nourishment then Carrots. The water drunke euery night sixe ounces, prouoketh venery and sperme in man, helpeth the straitnesse in making of water: milke to cause, vse the roote or seedes. The roote prouoketh vrine, swageth paine of the side, expelleth winde of the belly, and is good for them that be bruised. The roots eaten, are good for the lungs, breast and reines. The seed of the wilde Parsnip is good against all poyson, it healeth all venemous bitings stingings being drunke in wine, and is so excellent good for this purpose, that when stags or rather wilde Harts haue eaten of it, no venemous beasts may hurt them. termes and vrine, helpe the dropsie, resist poison and all venemous bitings, and helpe conception. This herbe applyed into the Matrixe by a skilfull Midwife stampt, draweth foorth the dead childe. Those of the garden are more apt to meate then the wilde. Milke to increase, seeth the rootes with Fennell rootes in chicken broth, and eate it with a little fresh butter. Swellings of womens bellies as if they were with childe, drinke one ounce of the seedes morne and euen. Parsnips ingender thicke blood and naturall seed being much vsed, and therefore are good for them that haue bene long sicke, and they may bee eaten raw or sodden against melancholly humors, either greene or drie. To prouoke lust and helpe digestion, boyle the roots first in water and slice them, and seeth them againe in fresh water, and put thereto clarified Honie, and boyle them to the thickenesse of Hony, and in the ende, put thereto Almonds if you haue them, and then put thereto Ginger, Galingale, and a little Pepper and Nutmegs, and other sweete sauouring spices, and vse it, or seeth them soft, and cut them small, and seethe them againe in Hony, some streine them and seethe them in water and Hony together, and stirre them well, that they cleaue not to the vessell, and in the midst of the seething, put Almonds in powder, and then Ginger, Nutmegs Cinomom ana i. ounce, it moueth lust helpeth digestion. Bruise the dried roote and drinke it with pure wine, to cause a good memory, to purge the blood, and to prouoke termes. Eate the seedes for the swelling of the stomacke, the dropsie, to consume euill humors, to clense the liuer and void the paine of the loynes and bladder. Vse sallads of Parsly, sorell vineger, to helpe the burning feuer. Eate the herb raw or sodden for the stopping of the bladder, to prouoke vrin and termes, to cleanse the kidnies, to expell winde, gripings of the belly, and swelling of the stomake. The seeds in working are best, then the roots, and then the leaues. For stopping of vrin griefs of the kidneys, apply Parsly. Kidneys griefs, bruise the seeds seeth them in water and drinke it, apply the seedes with the white of an egge to the reines. Neither women with childe or in childebed, nor Nurses, may eate Parsly with their meate, for hindering conception, drying vp the milke of the breasts, causing the yonglings to haue ye falling sickenesse: yet doth Parsly being throwen into fish ponds, strengthen and reuiue the sicke fish. Stampe it and streine it with white wine, drinke a good draught fiue or sixe times to driue out the vrine and stone. Stampe it with the white of an egge, and apply it to the bruise of the eyes colde. Vse it in meates to strengthen the stomake, cause appetite digestion, prouoke vrin. The decoction of the roote or seede, openeth the stopping of the liuer, kidneys all inner parts: driueth forth vrin, grauel stone, is a remedy against all poyson venomous bitings, blasting windinesse. Vse the seeds in electuary, for the cough other medicines for that purpose. Stampe the leaues with bread or barley flower, apply it to red inflamed eyes, and Paps swollen with curded milke. Parsly is ill for them that haue the falling sickenesse, and is vtterly to be shunned of them that haue it: it hurteth the stones, it is good for the Hicket. The seed taken afore hand, withstandeth drunkennesse, it stirreth vp women to conception. Sit in the decoction of Parsly, to draw forth the stone, to prouoke vrine, and heale the kidneis. Vse Parsly against the inflation of the stomacke belly, the chollike paine of the sides, kidneys and bladder. It driueth downe the dead yongling the seconds, either drunke or put into the Matrixe. Stampe Parsly apply it to skabs, morphue and pushes, to cleanse them marueilously. Parsly is good for the dropsie and all obstructions, to expell the vrin, stone, flowers seconds, dead yonglings put into the Matrixe, and for feuers that come by fits. Stampe Parsly with as much Fennell, and streine it drinke it for the griefs of the bladder, to expell the stone vrine, and to heale the stomacke. For the stone chollike and Nephretica, drinke the iuice of Parsly with Aniseedes. Flowers stopt, seethe Sauin with the rootes of Parsly, Smallach and Fennell with wine, and drinke it. Senowes ach, stampe Parsly apply it, when it is hote, apply fresh Parsly as often as neede is. Strangury, seeth the leaues of Parsly, Fennell, and smallach, and mixe them with wheate bran, and apply it. Wounds to cleanse, seeth the rootes of Parsly and smallach in wine, and wash therewith. To refresh the body, make thicke pottage with greene Parsly and flesh, and vse it, or vse Parsly with a good Side paine, seeth a quart of white wine with a sixt part of Hony, one handfull of Parsly, two ounces of Parsly seede in a newe earthen pot, till the sixt part bee wasted, and when it waxeth colde, drinke thereof morne and euen, Vrin to cause, seeth the roots of Parsly the herbe Dasye in water, drinke thereof morne euen, especially with some water of Radish. Strangury, vse the roots of Parsly and Fennell, (See Groundswell. Stone to voyd, make powder of the seedes of small ach Parsly of ech like much, with as much suger; and take thereof on sops of bread dipt in wine after meales, also first last at morne euen. Feuer quotidian, seeth a quarter of a Hen or chicken with water Parsly, iiii. leaues of Letuce, vse it. Eyes blacke bruised, apply it with the white of an egge. Breast payne, stampe Parsly, Isope and Sage, and apply them hote. Belly hard and vrine stopt, drinke powder of the seedes of Parsly, Smallach and Spurge, with wine or water morne euen. Vrin to cause, seeth a good piece of stone Pitch in a quart of white wine with the seedes of Parsly, Annise and suger, to the one halfe, and drinke it warme morne euen. Chollike, bruise white Thyme and Parsly, and streine it with ale, drinke it warme wt powder of graines, or of greene broome seed, when neede is, (See Nettle. Bladder griefes, stampe Parsly, Smallach, and Fennell, of ech like much, and drinke them with water, (See Fennell, Cummin. Biting or stinging of an Addar, drinke the iuice of Parsly with vineger. To clense the Matrixe expell a dead childe and the seconds, put in the iuice with a clout into the Matrixe, also drinke therof with any drink. Gouts and aches, mixe Parsly with oile of Roses womans milke, and anoint therewith. Feuer tertian, drinke the iuice before the fit, (See Basill. Parsly ingendreth blood greatly, is good for the Ptisike the feuer tertian, the grief of the sides, the dropsie: it comforteth the heart and stomacke, and is good in pottages. Pissing blood, drinke Ambrose, Parsly and Saxifrage, with Cowes milke daily. Bladder griefs, drinke Smallach, Parsly and Fennell with water, to expell vrin and the stone. Stone to breake, make powder of blacke Flints, Parsly seed, Fenel seed, and Towncres seed, and vse it morne euen. Stone stopping of the vrin, stampe it streine it with white wine, drinke a good draught fiue or vi. times, or seeth it in white wine wt Thime, and into a good draught, shaue a spooneful of white sope, drink it. Ach in any part, seeth Parsly Wormwood of ech a handful in a quart of ale, with some sweet butter, wash well the place therewith, and apply the herbe as hote as may be suffred. Emerods, stampe a handfull of Parsly with the roots and all, with sallet oyle, and let it stand one day, then streine it anoynt therewith against the fire, keepe thee warme, be whole. Vrin stopt, stampe it with Grounsell, drinke it with white wine. vse it in pottage and possit ale with Parietarie and Saxifrage. To slake the after deliuerance, seeth the iuice of a good handfull of Parslie in a Cawdell or Alebrewe made fit for her, and let her drinke it: if she haue too much of her disease, let a spoonefull of bruised Pepper be put into her Caudell: prooued. To keepe a wound from ranckling, anoynt it with the iuice of Parslie: prooued. Chollike, drinke powder of the seedes of Parslye, Alisander and Fennell. Chollike and stone, boyle Parietary and Parslie ana one handfull, Bay berries bruised halfe a handfull, in white wine and drinke thereof: prooued. Vrine to cause, stampe Rue, Gromell Parslie, and drinke them with white wine and be whole. Palsie, brew sacke with suger, put therto the iuice of a good handful of Parslie, drinke a good draught warme. to cleanse Breast payne Breasts sore swolne Breath stinke Chollike Loynes paine Matrixe to cleanse Memory bad Milt stopt Morphue Obstructions generall PArietarie: (See Stitch, put two handfuls cleane piked from the stalkes in a prety quantitie of Malmsie, and set it in a Chafing dish of coles throughly soked in the Malmesie, and apply it hote as may be suffered: prooued. Seeth one handfull chopt small in a pinte of white wine in a double vessell to the one halfe, and streine it and drinke thereof when neede is. Gouts generall, and all ach and swellings, seeth it in wine or water, and apply it. Stone, seethe Parietary and Mugwort, of ech like much in a pottell of white wine to the one halfe, and drinke the wine, and apply the substance to the Nauell, as hote as may be suffered (See PEaches before they be ripe, they stop the laske, but being ripe, they loosen the belly and ingender ill humors: wherefore they ought not to be eaten after meate, but before. The leaues open the stoppings of the Liuer, and loosen the belly gently, and are good with other conuenient hearbs against the tertian feuers. Wormes, apply them to the Nauell: drye them and strawe them on newe wounds to cure them. The kernels open the liuer and lungs, and is of vertue much like to bitter Almonds. Steepe them in water of Penyroyall, and vse it to recouer speech in the Apoplexia. Stampe them very small, and boyle them in vineger till they be dissolued like Pap, and anoynt therewith to restore haire. Eate euery day fiue or sixe of them with salt before dinner and supper to preserue thee from the paine of the side, and from drunkennesse, and to preserue the braine, prouoke appetite, to comfort the stomacke and breast, and to kill and expell all maner of wormes. Peaches either of themselues or condited, are good to be vsed in hote feuers, but the much vse of them cooleth the body too much, and breedeth rotten feuers. The conserue of the flowers or blossomes, is good for the stomacke. The gumme dissolued and boyled in wine and drunke, is good for spitting of blood, to cleanse and heale the obstructions of the liuer, lungs, and passages of the breast, and to breake the stone: but if some Saffron bee put to it, it helpeth the horcenesse and roughnesse of the throte. The iuice of the leaues drunke and applied to the Nauell, killeth wormes. The same stampt with Rose vineger and applyed, helpeth the head ach. The gumme boyled in vineger and applyed, helpeth Ringwormes, Tetters, Pocks, Whelks, &c. Peaches eaten, are good against the stinking breath of hote cause being eaten fasting. For spitting blood and many griefes of the lungs, vse the gumme. Belly wormes, apply the leaues stampt with vineger, or anoynt the Nauell with the oyle. Scrophules, Glandules or kernels, stampe the leaues with salt and apply them. Iaundies, mixe powder of the kernels with vineger and drinke it first and last. Eate the kernels twelue at once, for the griefes, stoppings and hardnesse of the belly. Strangury, make powder of Peach kernels Akornes of ech like much, drink it with wine, if that serue not, thou hast the stone. Wormes, stampe the leaues with Mints, Wormwood and vineger, apply it to the Nauell. Chollike, and to withstand drunkennesse, eate fiue or sixe kernels before dinner and supper with salt and bread, they kill wormes, cause appetite, and comfort the stomacke and breast. Chollike and paine of the side, eate foure kernels daily. Vrine stopt, make fine powder of the kernels of Peaches and medlers, of ech like much, with as much suger as them both, and drinke thereof with good white wine. Stomacke paine, stampe the greene leaues with olde greace well purified, and apply it. Wormes, put in a Suppositor of Peach kernels and Wormewood, or seethe the leaues of both in water, and wash therewith. Stitch or winde in the body, drye the leaues in the forepart of the yeere in the shadowe, and drinke the powder of them with a little Ale when neede is. Eares dull noyse Feuer hote tertian Fluxes Glandules Head ach Haire to growe Horcenesse Iaundies Kernels Liuer stopt Stone Strangury Tetters Throte kernels rough Voyce bad Vrin stopt Whelks Winde Wormes PEase: their broth is good against the Iaundies and dropsie, it may be vsed in all inward greefes without perill. The same sodden in water and lee, helpeth spreading sores of the head, the spots of the face, and griefes of the skinne. The same decoction mixt with hony and barley meale, cureth spreading sores that be hard to cure. The same sodden in water with Orobus and applied, helpeth all swellings and ache, so doe beanes. In the newe of the Moone, take for euery wart a Pease, and touch the warts therewith, and binde them in a cloute, and cast it behinde thee. Heart burning, eate vi. or vii. Peason or moe. Vomiting of cold moyst humors, eate the broth of gray Peason. Pease broth is good to take purgations withall to cleanse a rawe stomacke, whether they be gray or white vnsalted. The potage of great Peason are good for the strangury: and to take Sene withall morne and euen for the ague, And Rubarbe for the Iaundies. Spots or steynes in clothes, white or other colour, seethe Peason in water, and steepe the cloth in the water, and wash it with riuer water and drye it. Aches Bleeding Clothes steyned Dropsie Face deformed Feuer Heart burning Headsores Iaundies Nosebleeding Purging Skin griefes Sores Strangury Swellings Vomiting Warts Pease Earthnut. PEase Earthnut: boyle the rootes, and eate them as Persnips or Turnips to stop the flux boyled in wine and drunke, and so it stoppeth the termes and all issues of blood. Cast the powder of them on sores and wounds to stop the blood. Stampe the roote, and steepe it in an earthen vessell, and stirre it, and with a feather gather that which swimmeth aloft, and drye it, and drinke fifteene graines of it to purge both wayes without peril. PEniwort, or wall Peniwort, is good against all inflammations and hote tumors, S. Antonies fire, and kibed heeles being applied. Eate the leaues and rootes to breake the stone, prouoke vrine, and helpe the dropsie. The iuice of with wine applied or put in, looseth the stopping of the priuities. It is good for wens. The leaues and rootes taken in meates or honied wine, is good for the stone, to prouoke vrine, and helpe the dropsie, but especially with Oximel. Inflammation Kibes Priuities stopt S. Antonies fire Stomacke hote Stone PEllitorie, or Magistrantia of Spaine, drinke it with wine against all poyson, corrupt aire and infection of the plague. Stampe the rootes it selfe, or with the leaues, and apply it to carbuncles, plague sores, botches, apost. and swellings. Drinke the roote with wine against the rigorous fits of old feuers, and the dropsie, to prouoke sweate, to comfort the stomacke, and to cause appetite and digestion, to dissolue windinesse of the belly flanks, to heale brusings burstings, and to dissolue congealed blood in the body. Stampe the rootes leaues, and apply it to bitings of mad dogs, and venemous beasts, and stingings. The wilde called herbe Gerard, stampt and applied, is good for the goute, and cureth the Emerods being bathed with ye decoction thereof. Chewe the roote of Pellitory a good while, and holde it in thymouth to clense the head and braine, and to helpe the aking Mixe powder of ye roote with milke of Wartwort, or Spourge, and Galbanum, and apply a litle of it to any aking or rotten teeth, and breake them, and to plucke them out. It expelleth winde mightely from the stomacke, guts and mother, and is good for the gnawing stomacke, the chollike, and to prouoke the termes and vrine. seethe the roote in tarte wine, and bathe them therewith. Barrennesse of colde cause, and for the strangling of the mother, and for the colde diseases, as the palsie, the falling sicknesse, and nummednesse, drinke the roote with wine. Feuer quarten, drinke halfe a spoonefull of the powder of it before the fit. It causeth a sweete breath, strengtheneth all the senses or wits, it is good against the plague, and all infectious diseases, poyson, venemous bitings, shortnesse of breath, obstructions, the dropsie, and the griefes of the milt. The herbe, iuice, powder or water, is good against all colde griefes of the feuers, and of the stomacke, and all venom and poyson, being taken moderately as the cause requireth. Seethe it in wine, and drinke it morne and euen to helpe the colde lungs, shortnesse of breath, the moyst and cold cough, to expell vrine, and the stones of the kidneis, the flowers, seconds, and dead birth, to mitigate the sciatica, and colde griefes, and colde aches, to prouoke sweate, to driue out the dropsie, to ingender naturall seede, and it may be vsed for Lacerpitium. It is much of like nature to Angelica and Louage. The rootes or iuice applied, taketh away swellings, hardnesse, and gatherings of humors. Drinke powder of the roote with wine or ale against the palsie, the crampe, the falling sicknesse, (See Angelica, Louage, Piretrum, Ptarum. Take one ounce of powder of the roote with white wine hote fasting, to voide the chollike and paine of the side. Seethe it with figs in vineger or wine, and gargarise therewith to clense the braine. Palsie and goute, stampe it and seethe it in wine, and apply it: but if it be greene, stampe it soke it fifteene dayes in wine, then boyle it well, put thereto oyle and waxe, it is the best oyntment for the griefs aforesaid. Dropsie, seethe it in wine wt Hysope and vse it. of wormes, apply the powder with hony. Cough, chewe it. dayes. in vineger, then braye it and keepe it to thy vse, and when neede is, couer the other teeth with waxe, and couer the aking teeth with the medicin, and within one houre plucke it out with thy finger, and holde it in thy mouth. The roote taken with hony, is good against the falling euill, the apoplexia, the long, old cold diseases of the head braine. Seeth it in vineger, hold it in thy mouth for ye Sweate to cause, boyle it in oyle, and anoint therewith: it is excellent for members that are colde, benummed, foundred, or striken with the palsie. The seede or roote sodden in wine and drunke, driueth downe by vrine and seege, colde tough humors: it is generally good for all diseases that come of colde causes. Stampe the leaues and flowers, and apply it to bruises to disperse the congeled blood. Steepe the rootes in vineger, and make them into pilles, and hold them in the mouth to purge ye braine, and to cease ye Seethe the roote or iuice in oyle, and anoint the body well with it to put away the feuer, colde, tertian quarten, and it is good for the colde and swolne stomacke. Ptermaca chewed and holden in the mouth, cleanseth the braine as strongly as Bartrum, and is good for the is good in sallads, as Taragon or Rocket. Stampe it and apply it to draw away swellings, and olde hard lumps, and to bruises. Ache of the head and teethe, chewe Piretrum iii. or iiii. times a day iii. dayes. For the palsie, choller, griefes of the stomacke, womans griefes, ache of the sides, backe and reines, the lunacie, and all other sickenesses, drinke iii. spoonefull of the fine powder of it with Mulse, or temper it with hony or Mulse, and drinke ii. cyathes. Scabs and breaking out, seethe it in water till the water be clammy and yellowe, and wash therewith. PEniroyall: gather it when it beareth flowres, and so it may be kept ii. yeeres. Seeth it in water, and wash the itche therewith to cure it speedely. Stampe it with hony salt, and apply it to the palsie and broken members. Breath strait, bruise it and eate it with hony. Seethe it with twise so much wine, and drinke it against griping of the bowels. Liuer lungs, drinke powder of it two nights with wine to bedward. Stomacke rawe and casting, take powder of the seede or hearbe. If any man by bleeding be bereft of mind, apply it to his nostrels with vineger to restore him. Stampe it temper it with Saffron, and anoint euill vlcers of the body, nayles, or fingers, to heale them. Drinke it warme with wine to helpe the dropping of the bladder, and also boyle it with wine and oyle, and apply it to the belly for the same purpose. Stampe it and seethe it in wine and apply it twise or thrise to the nostrels to helpe the reume, and distilling of the head. Seethe it in wine with dry figs, and drinke it for the drye cough comming of clammy and watrish humors. Seethe it in wine, and drinke it to prouoke the termes, and to bring foorth the seconds and dead fruite, to prouoke vrine and breake the stone, especially of ye kidneis. Take it with hony to cleanse the lungs and breast of all grosse and thicke humors. Take it with hony and Aloes to purge melancholy, and for the crampe drawing together of the sinowes. Take it with water and vineger to asswage the disposition to vomite, and for the paine of the stomacke. Take it in wine against the bitings of venemous beastes. If any be constrained to drinke stinking or salt water, let them put Peniroyall or the powder thereof into it, and it shall not hurt them. Head paine and giddy, apply a garland of it round about the head. Stampe it with vineger and smell to it against swooning and faintnesse to quicken the senses. Rub the gummes with the powder or ashes of it to strengthen them. Stampe it and rub the sciatica and paine of the goute therewith till it waxe red. Mixe it with vineger and hony, and apply it to the crampe and the griefe of the milt. Sit in the decoction of it for the windinesse, hardnesse, and stopping of the matrix, or sit ouer the fume of the same decoction in a Stew or Bath. The same is good also against itche, maundge or skabbe to braunche lapt amongst wooll and smelled vnto, or layde amongst clothes of the bed, cureth the feuer tertian. Make an Electuarie of it with Sugar Rosat, and vse it in the plague time fasting, as much as a Chestnut at once. Seethe it in white wine, and drinke it morning and euening to driue downe the dead birth, flowers, and seconds, and to stop the whites. Seeth it in vineger and hony to stop the termes, and for lothing and vomiting. Seethe it in wine with Hony and Aloes to purge choller and flegme about the lungs, to cease inward gripings, to comfort the matrix, and against venemous bitings. And gargarise therewith against the Squincy and vlcers of the mouth. Vse the water or iuice of it to make the eyes cleare. Apply it to the or goute, till it waxe red to cease the paine. Stampe it with vineger, and apply it to the nose and mouth of them that swoone, or be sleepie, or haue the lethargie, to bring their senses againe. Stampe it with vineger and Salt, and rubbe the Crampe therewith. Wash aches with the broth of it to auoide them. Seethe it with hony and Aloes, and drinke it to cleanse the liuer and purge the blood most excellently. Put the iuice with vineger into the nose against the frensie and lunacie. Drinke the iuice with warme wine to prouoke the flowers and seconds, and to helpe the vlcers of the mouth. To stop vomiting, drinke it with wine or warme water. Head whirling, drinke powder of it with the water thereof. Hoarsenesse, chap a handfull small, and seethe it in a pint of vineger, till the third part be wasted, then streine it and take a spoonefull of it morning and euening. Sweate to cause, sit ouer the decoction of it that it may strike vp into thee. Head turning and dasling, seethe it and applye it to the temples, and powre Baulme into the eares ii. or iii. times. Speeche lost suddenly, stampe it and drinke it with vineger, and also apply it to the nostrels. Breast flegme, seethe it in water with a little salt, and drinke it. Appetite lost, seethe it with as much Cummin and some Pepper in Ale, and drinke it at euen hote, and at morne colde. For euils at the heart, seeth it with Tussilago and a little salt in water, and drinke it fasting dayly. Liuer griefe, anoint the side with the iuice of it. Backe ache, stampe it with vineger and oyle Oliue, and apply it. Ache in the body, stampe it and apply it to the nauell. Belly ache, drinke the iuice of it and of Smallache. Wormes to kill, seethe it with Tansy and Camomile, of eache like much in a pint of Malmesey to the one halfe, and streine it and drinke it. Pockes, drinke the iuice of it and of yong Tansy. Milt griefes and swelling, seeth it with salt, and apply it. Flowers to cause, seethe it in wine and drinke it. heate the powder of it without any liquour in a skillet, and apply it. For cold stoppings in the head, the cough and reume, seethe it with figs in vineger, and take a good spoonefull of it, and gargarise therewith iii. or iiii. times. Seethe it in wine and drinke it for the griefes of the stomacke and guts, and the winde thereof. Mixe the powder thereof with hony, and make it into an Electuarie thereof, and vse it for the cough flegme of the breast, or boyle the hearbe with hony in wine or water, and drinke it. For blacke choller, boyle the iuice with wine, and drinke it and be whole. Cough and to prouoke vrine, boyle it in wine and drinke it luke warme. Belly griefes, stampe it with Cummin and water, and apply it to the nauell, and be whole. Liuer griefes, stampe it and streine it with water and vineger, and drinke it and be whole. Legs ache, stampe it with as much Eldren leaues, and apply it. Feuer tertian, lap the branches in a good locke of wooll, and smell to it before the fit come. Dead childe to auoide, stampe it and streine it with old wine and drinke it. Crampe, drinke the iuice with vineger fasting to auoide it. Speech lost, stampe it and drinke it with white vineger hote. Burne it when it flowreth where fleaes be to destroy them. That no shall come by heate of the sunne put it into eache eare. Cattell infected Flowers and seconds to cause, distill it with white wine, and drinke thereof iiii. ounces fasting, and also if neede be, put thereto a little of the iuice of Leckes. For the superfluous moysture of the vuula and gums, seeth it in vineger and dry figs, and gargarise therewith often. and lightnesse of the braine, seeth it in vineger and drinke it, and smell to it, and apply thereof to the head all night, or drinke the iuice of it with water, and eate nothing till noone. Bladder griefes Blood to cleanse Bones broken Breast to cleanse PEony, the roote endureth tenne yeeres, it comforteth and cherisheth the body, prouoketh vrine, and purgeth the liuer and kidneis. The roote boyled in wine and drunke, purgeth the blood, and is good for women in childe bed to purge their seconds and termes without harme, as much as an Almond is to be taken at once. The roote boyled in wine, doeth helpe the gripings of the belly, the shedding of the gall, and the paine of the kidneis and bladder, comming by stopping of the vrine. The smoke of the little braunches of the roote receiued into the nose, putteth away the Kings euill. The roote hanged about the necke, helpeth the falling sickenesse, especially the roote of the male Peony. The roote of the female boyled in wine and drunke, doeth purge women after childe birth, and so doeth the seedes of it: and in other matters, the rootes of both be of like propertie. The fresh roote worne about the necke withstandeth the vapours ascending into the head, and strengtheneth the braine: this doeth the male which beareth leaues like the leaues of a Walnut tree, and a white roote of a finger bignesse a span long. The roote is to be gathered in ye wane of the Moone, and when she is vnder the earth, and the seedes doe especially prouoke termes, and send out the dead yongling, and the seedes drunke in wine, doe helpe a hard deliuerie of a woman in trauell. of eache like much by waight, and taken euery morning and euening, doth expell poyson, and loosen the belly gently. Ten or twelue of the seedes drunke in olde wine, doe stay the superfluous course of the termes. And fifteene of the blacke seedes drunke either in water or hony, or in wine, doe helpe the nightmare, the strangling of the secrets, and paines of the matrix. Powder of the seedes giuen in meate and drinke to children, driueth foorth ye stone that beginneth to breede in them. Seeth the roote in wine and drinke it with powder of the roote to helpe the falling sickenesse. Drinke powder of the roote with white wine to ease the paine of the reines and bladder. The powder of the roote as much as a Beane drunke with wine, cleanseth the matrix after childebirth, and expelleth the flowers, the stone of the kidneis and bladder, and is good for the Iaundies, and the ache of the belly. The water distilled of the rootes and flowers, strengtheneth the heart, and helpeth the falling sickenesse in children, being taken two or three spoonefull at once. The roote and seedes hanged about the necke of children, is good against the falling sickenesse, and the haunting of the Fairies and Goblins. The iuice or powder drunke, is good against the stopping of the gall, liuer, and kidneis. And sodden with olde red wine and drunke, it stoppeth the And the blacke graines sodden in red wine, do strengthen the matrix that aboundeth with fluxe of blood. The roote sodden in wine and drunke, purgeth the belly, voydeth the chollike, cleanseth the guts, and defendeth against frensies and passions of the braine, the strangury, and bitings of Serpents, but there must bee taken at once but foure drammes. Drinke the powder with white Wine and Saffron for the yellowe Iaundies, it is a soueraigne medicine. Drinke fifteene or sixteene of the blacke seedes in wine or mede against the strangling of the mother, the and melancholie dreames. Drinke the powder with Sage, Rosemary, and Margerome in Hydromell, or meates for the falling sickenesse. The red seedes eaten, helpe the gnawing of the mouth of the stomacke. Dropsie, put the seedes of Peony, Anise, and Fenell into thy drinke. wine of the decoction of Peony, or eate euery morning and euening fiue graines of Peony pilled. Vse to drinke powder of the seedes with wine to restore the wittes, and comfort the senses. Weare the seedes about thee, that no euill spirites do hinder thee. Drinke powder of tenne or twelue seedes with Wine to auoide the nightmare. Vse powder of the roote with Sugar for the falling euill, or drinke the iuice three seuerall times. Flowers stopt, drinke the powder or decoction of the roote. Deliuerance to cause, stampe the blacke seedes with oyle, and anoynt the loynes and priuie partes therewith. Seethe the rootes with Castory in Wine to helpe the Palsie and the Stone. Cast the powder of it on Cotton, and put it into the fundament, and also drinke thereof with wine against costiuenesse. Falling sickenesse, eate it or drinke it with wine, and hang the roote about the necke fifteene dayes. Drinke the powder with water, hony, and powder of Coriander, to helpe the griefes of the stomacke, milt, and grauell in the reines. Let women seethe it in white wine, and drinke it against many diseases, to helpe the stone, the paine of the matrix. Seconds, drinke powder of fifteene of the blacke seedes at once. To cause a woman to haue throwes in labour, let her take foure or sixe of the seedes of Peony. The roote gathered on the Sunday in the houre of {Sun} in the moone increasing, and borne on them that haue the falling sicknesse, cureth them, or hang the roote of male Peony about a boyes necke for the same purpose: or vse the first seedes that are rounde and blacke, especially taken with Oximell, or with syrupe of Stecados, and a little Nutmeg. For griefes, swelling, and windinesse of the matrix, drinke one dramme of the powder of the rootes in broth, especially of the flowers of Camomile. For the falling euill, feare mad, and witlesse, drinke Peony with Wine, Ale, or water: Or vse powder of it with all thy drinkes and brothes. PEpper is good in sauses to giue a good taste to meates, to prouoke appetite and helpe digestion. With the tender leaues of Bay, or with Cummin, it prouoketh vrine, and expelleth windinesse, and paine of the belly. It is good against poyson and venemous bitings, and therefore vsed in Treacles and preseruatiues. The same drunke before the fit, or laide to, or anointed outwardly with oyle, is good against the shakings of Feuers. The same licked in with hony, is good for the cough comming of cold cause, and all colde griefes of the breast or lungs. Apply it with hony to the Squincy to waste the swelling and tumour. Apply it with pitch to dissolue the Kings euill, kernels, wens, hard cold swelling, and to drawe foorth prickes, shards, and splents. Long Pepper is good in collyries, and eye medicines for the griefes of the eyes. With Niter, or naturall salt Peter, it skowreth away morphues, and such like foulenesse of the skinne. of fine powder of Pepper with a pint of Aqua composita, and a beastes gall to the one halfe, and apply plasters thereof hote to the sciatica, ache, goute, or other paine iiii. or v. times if neede be at euery twelue houres ende. Stampe it with good wine, and holde it hote in thy mouth till it be colde, and then spit it out, and it will kill wormes in the teethe. Dropsie, drinke Pepper and Fenell seede continually with wine to cure the swelling of it. Flux to stop, grate hard cheese and mixe it with a portion of Pepper and drinke it with red wine sodden together with a fewe crummes of white bread. Matrix suffoc. eate nine graines of Pepper, it is the best medicin. Mouth griefes, holde powder of Pepper with white wine in thy mouth. Sciatica, stampe Onions with oyle de Bay, and put powder of Pepper, of Euphorbium, and apply it to the place. Sweate to cause, drinke twentie graines of Pepper wt one handfull of Rue in white wine. Eyes hawe, put in powder of burnt Pepper with the marow of a Goose wing. For the host, seethe Sage, Rue, Cummin, with hony Pepper, and take thereof dayly. Cough, seethe Senuy and white Pepper in good wine and drinke it. Canker and fester, mixe powder of Pepper, and of mans doung burned, and vse it as often as neede is. make caudels of Vine leaues, Pepper, and hard Egges, and vse them. Eyes pearle, mixe fine powder of Pepper and Ginger with the gall of an Eele clarified Hony, and it will kill it. and swelling of the gummes, seethe powder of Pepper Ginger of eache like much in Ale, and applye it in a litle bagge dipt in aqua vitae. Winde chollike and flegme, boyle powder of the three kindes of Pepper with Rose water and Sugar in a porenger till it bee thicke, and eate thereof to bedward, or when the fitte commeth. Goute, plaster it to the greefe of the ioyntes or synowes. Scrophules in Infants, mixe the powder with hard pitche, and applye it to disperse them. seethe three spoonefull of the powder in a pinte of good white Wine to the one halfe, and gargarise therewith often hote one spoonefull at once. Stomacke colde, take a reare Egge with grosse Pepper fasting. (See Baye. Mixe as much as will fill vp the shell of an Egge with the yolke, and burne it and mixe the powder of it with Wheate meale, and make little fritters and bake them and eate them first and last to helpe the bloody fluxe. Stomacke griefes, drinke Pepper with wine hote, and eate Butter after supper. Palsie, mixe powder of Pepper three ounces, and of Senuie seede two ounces, with Swines grease a little salted and anoint. Seethe it with Figges in Wine, and drinke it to cleanse the spirituall members from tough humors, and for the pose comming of colde, and for the same eate Figges with powder of Pepper. The powder with meates comforteth the stomacke, and helpeth digestion, and so doeth long Pepper eaten with rosted Apples. Vuula fallen, fill an Akorne shell full of powder of Pepper, and burne Alome, and apply it. Mixe powder of Pepper with the marowe of a Goosewing, and put it in a cloute and burne it, and put thereof vpon the hawe in the Eye to auoide it. White Pepper helpeth the stomacke, the cough, the winde, the chollike, withstandeth the causes of colde Feuers, and easeth the shaking thereof. Diatrion Piperion may be taken at any time of the day for a colde and windie stomacke: for lacke thereof, take a fewe graines of blacke Pepper grosly beaten, with a draught of Ale fasting, or a little of the powder of any of them with meate: for nothing is better against winde and flegme then Pepper. Roste powder of Pepper in a great Onion, and worke them well together, and keepe it in a boxe, and anoint the goute therewith against the fire. Matrixe suffocated, eate nine cornes of Pepper, and after smell to stinking things at the nose. Bloody fluxe, make caudels of Vine leaues, hard egs, and Pepper, and vse them. Emerods, burne olde shooes, and mixe the powder thereof with powder of Pepper, Hony, and oyle Oliue, or oyle of Creame sodden, and apply it iii. dayes hote. Face seeming leaprous, mixe quicke siluer mortified with Bores grease blacke Pepper, and anoint therewith, keepe the face from wind iiii. or v. dayes. Seethe hony, and clarifie it, and put thereto powder of Pepper, and seeth it till it be blacke, and lay thereof vpon halfe a Sage leafe, and apply it to the teethe that ake. Drinke cornes of Pepper with warme water to voide the quarten and intermissiue feuers. Diatrion is very good against hoarsenesse and stopping of the lungs and colde reumes. Vse the powder in oyntments against shaking feuers that come by fits. It is good against venemous bitings, and expelleth the birth being drunke or often eaten. It is vsed in Lohocks and Syrupes for the cough and paine of the breast. It is good to be vsed inward outwarde for the apostume of ye milt, and being much vsed it expelleth vrine. Feuers, drinke halfe a pint of thine owne vrine with one peniworth of Pepper bruised one houre before the fit, and couer thee well to sweate. Chollike, drinke powder of long Pepper and Fiueleafe rootes with good ale. Ringwormes, apply fine powder of Pepper with blacke sope. PErwinkle sodden in wine and drunke, stoppeth the laske, the bloody fluxe, termes, spitting blood all other issues of blood. Mixe it with milke and oyle of Roses, and put it into the Matrixe as a suppositer to take away all paines thereof. Chew it to helpe the toothach, and all venemous bitings or stingings being applyed. Bruise it and put it into the Nose to stop the bleeding. Seeth it in wine and drinke it against all torments and fluxes of the body. Put the iuice into the eares to cease their ach. Put the herbe into troubled wine that hath lost the colour, fifteene dayes to restore the colour againe and the cleerenesse. Nose bleeding, hold it in thy mouth betweene thy teeth, or lay a lease vnder thy tongue. Pissing blood, drinke the iuice of it and of Planten. Nose bleeding, holde it betweene thy teeth and binde the pulses of thy armes and legs, and thou shalt not bleede while it is there. Bloody fluxe Eates ach Flowers to stop Matrixe paine Nose bleeding PImpernell boyled in wine and drunke, is singular good against all venemous bitings, obstructions of the Liuer, and payne of the kidneys. The iuice put into the Nose, cleanseth the head, and helpeth the toothach being put into the Nose on the contrary side to the griefe. Apply Pimpernell to corrupt and festered sores and to fretting sores, and to cleanse and heale them, and to pricks and splents to drawe them out, and to the inflammation of the eyes. The iuice mixt with Hony and straken often, or put into the eyes, taketh away the dimnesse of sight. Seeth it in wine and drinke it against all venemous bitings, and also wash the wound therewith. Drinke a draught of it, and couer thee well to sweat, to expell the plague or any poyson, to driue out the dropsie, to open the liuer, to purge the kidneys, and expell the stone. Apply the iuice or water to venemous wounds, stingings or bitings, to mitigate the ache, and to drawe out the venome and stings. It healeth painefull sores that creepe in the flesh, and the diseases that come of reume. The iuice mixt with pure Hony, taketh away the mistinesse and rednesse, and spots of the eyes, and cleanseth the sight. Eyes web, mixe the iuice with Goose grease, and put a drop into the eyes. Speech lost, holde the iuice of it and Sage vnder thy tongue. Plague, drinke powder of Pimpernell, Betony, Fiue leafe, Sage and scabious, with ale or beere warme fasting a weeke. Eyes web pearle, put in the iuice wt the marow of a Goose wing. Apost. or Byle to breake, stampe it wt Holyoke Brocks grease and apply it. Biting of an Addar, drinke the iuice of that with the red flower. Nose bleeding, stampe it and put it into the Nose. Feuer continuall, drinke it with warme water, it helpeth also the feuer tertian. Fistulaes and hollowe vlcers, put in the iuice, and apply the herbe. If the Fistula bee inward, drinke it: if outward, put in the iuice. Mixe powder thereof with the distilled water and some suger made into an electuary, and take thereof two ounces dadly, for the Ptisicke of the Lungs. in the Plague time to defend thee, (See Aloes, Dog Fennell, Lunarie. Feuer, binde it to the Pulses, (See Egrimonie, Houndstong Face sause flegme, anoynt with the iuice mixt with Pepper and Ginger. Pimpernell destroyeth venome, and healeth apostumes and sores of the eyes. For the griefs of the bladder, and to expell vrine and the stone, drinke the iuice of Pimpernell, Fennell, Parsley and Smallach with water. Wounds to heale, drinke the iuice of Sanicle, Pimpernell and Bugle with ale morne and euen. Pyles to heale, drinke the iuice of Pimpernell often, and be whole. For wasting of nature, drinke the iuice with suger, (See Bugle. Emerods Face sause flegme Feuers continuall tertian Fistula Heart cardiake stitch Head broken to cleanse Kidneys griefe Liuer stopt Speech lost Stingings Stone Sweat to cause Teeth ache Venom PIne tree: The scales of the Pine apple with the barke of the Pine tree, doe stoppe the laske, the bloody fluxe, and prouoke Vrine, and so doth the broth of the same drunke. The same is good also against all skorchings and burnings with fire, being stampt with Litarge of siluer and Frankincense, if there be some Coprose put to it, then it will cleanse and heale consuming or fretting sores. The leaues heale greene wounds, and boyled in vineger, they swage the tooth ach. The kernels in the Nuts are good for the lungs, they cleanse the breast, and cause easie spitting, they nourish well and breede good blood, and are good for the cough, and for them that begin to dry and consume away howsoeuer they be taken. This fruite also doth vnstop the liuer, mitigateth the sharpenesse of the vrine, and is good for the grauell and stone. The vertues of the Rosin and Pitch, shall bee declared hereafter. The barke both of the Pine tree and Pitch tree in powder sprinkled vpon chafing or gauling, and bare places, and burnings, with Litarge and fine powder of Frankincence, doth cure them. The same receiued in a Treat or Cerot of Mirtles, bring sores in tender bodies to a skin, and stoppeth such as runne farre abroad, being laid too with Coprose. Being taken in water or Mede one dram, they are good for the diseases of the liuer. The kernels by themselues or with Hony, are good for the cough and griefs of the breast. The kernels drunke with Malmesie, and the seed of a Cucumber prouoke vrine, and taketh away the sharpenesse thereof. And taken with the iuice of Pursten, they swage the gnawing of the mouth of the stomacke. They take away the weakenesse of the body, and hold downe the corruption of humors. But the whole Nuts newely taken from the trees, bruised and sodden in Malmesie, are good for the olde cough and for a consumption, three Cyaths of the broth that they are sodden in, being drunke euery day. The Nuts being cleansed and eaten or drunke with the decoction of Reasins or the seedes of Cucumbers, prouoke vrin, and helpeth the sharpenesse of the kidneys and bladder, and the gnawing of the stomake. The middle barke of the tree drunke, stoppeth the fluxe, and prouoketh vrin. One dram of the leaues drunke wt Honied water, is good for the griefs of the liuer. The powder of the barke or leaues, helpeth the chafings and gaulings, and The leaues stamped, are good for inflammations, sodden with vineger, they are good for the tooth ach. Stampe the sound or fresh kernels and seeth them with wine and clarified Hony to the forme of Hony, and vse to take thereof for the Ptisick. Dippe a Pine apple without kernels in Skamony, and burne it, and sit ouer it in a close stoole, to helpe both the fluxe and the Tenasmus. Belly wringing, seeth the rinde of the tree in wine drinke it. Bloody fluxe, lap a Pine apple in Pitch, and lay it on hote coles, and take vp the fume thereof. PItch tree: The fruite, leaues, kernels, nuts and barke, are almost of the same nature that the like are of the Pine tree. The Rosins both of the Pine tree and Pitch tree, doe cleanse and heale newe wounds, and is therefore vsed in oyntments and plasters for wounds: it softeneth hard swellings, and is good for bruises being applied in oiles or ointments agreeable. Haires to auoyd, shaue them off, and apply a plaster of the driest Pitch on Lether, that they grow no more. Stone or drie Pitch, hath the vertues of Tarre or liquid Pitch, but not so strong: but is better and apter to glew wounds together. Senowes shrunke, melt Pitch waxe with Weathers grease, and apply it. Sciatica, anoynt it with oyle of Turpentine Aqua vite, and apply Ceareclothes of Pitch. Crampe, apply ship Pitch with sal Armoniak, it helpeth the Gout in like sort. Necke and throte, Pustules and scrophules, melt it with Hogs grease, and put thereto some quicke brimstone and wheate branne, and apply it. Swellings or Apostumes, stampe Cresses with Pitch, and apply it. Put powder of Pitch into a sore, to ingender flesh. Lethargie, mixe ashes of thine owne haire with vineger and a little Pitch, and apply it to the Nostrels. Seeth a good piece of stone Pitch in a quart of white wine with Aniseedes, Parsly seedes and suger to the one halfe, and drinke thereof morne and euen, to expell the vrin, (See Walnuts. Head skald, seeth Pitch and waxe, and lay them on a cloth, and apply it as hote as may be suffered nine dayes, and doe so till it be whole. Knees and senowes griefes, mixe Pitch and waxe with grease and apply it, it helpeth also shrunke synowes. Belly windy, boyle Pitch with Hony and Butter, and anoynt. Scrophules, mixe powder of Pepper with stone Pitch, apply it. For a new Sciatica, mixe powder of Pitch with Tarre, oyle Oliue vnwrought waxe, and streine it keepe it in rolles or in a boxe, and apply thereof vpon Lether or Linnen. Belly windy Bruises Crampe Flesh to grow Fundament fallen Head skald Haires to voyd Kernels Kings euill Knees ach Lethargie Necke scrophuls Synowes griefs PLane tree: the fruite thereof drunke with wine, helpeth venemous bitings. Teeth ach, seeth the barke in vineger, and vse it. Stampe the tender leaues, apply them to inflammations, swellings, and running eyes. Vomit to stop, seeth the leaues in vineger, and drinke it. The horinesse that cleaueth to the leaues, is ill for the eyes. PLanten: Ach, apply the leaues stampt with a little salt, (See in their proper places, Gout &c.) Apostume, apply the iuice or hearbe stamped. Belly wormes, drinke a spoonefull of the iuice, (See Wormes. To auoyd Biles, stampe it with Egrimony Goose grease, anoint. Bitings venemous, drinke it with wine: or drinke the iuice, and apply the substance, and hang the roote about thy necke: or apply the iuice or water: or drinke small Planten with wine. Bladder griefes, seeth the roote by it selfe or with the seeds in white wine, and drinke it to open the passages of the liuer and kidneys being stopt, and for the Iaundies and exulcerations of the bladder and kidneys, griefes of the head, stones, the Emerods and the Gomer passion. Bladder griefs generall, cut the leaues neere the ground and roote, and seeth them in water, and drinke halfe a pinte morne and euen foure or fiue dayes. The rootes and leaues with good swete wine, are good against the sores blisters of the kidneys and bladder. Blood to stop, drinke a little Cresse seede with the iuice when a veine is broken inwardly: or drinke it also, apply it with bol armoniak and sanguis draconis, the white of an egge barly meale: or stampe water Planten, and apply it: or drinke the iuice of Planten. Bloody fluxe, drinke the decoction of the leaues to swage it and all other fluxes of the belly: or drinke the iuice: or seeth the leaues with Holyoke roote in water, and drinke it against the grieuous bloody fluxe: or stampe it with Yarowe and streine it with red wine, and drinke a good draught first and last foure or fiue dayes, to stoppe the bloody fluxe: or drinke the seedes with red wine: or seeth the rootes therein and drinke it: or eate the hearbe with salt and vineger: or vse it in Glisters. Breast griefes, as Ptisike and cough, frie the iuice with Parietarie, Isope and swines greace of a barrowe hog, and streine it and anoynt the breast therewith to haue winde at will. Breast and heart cleansing from rotten humors, take a spoonefull of the iuice with Hony. Burnings, Inflammations, and the holy fire, apply the iuice or water with Housleeke, or anoynt with the iuice of Planten.
