Catharre and falling downe of Reume, the Cough, Ptisik, and Consumption of the Lungs, and to comfort the stomacke, eate the leaues with meate or otherwise, (See Breast, Breath. Dropsie, fill a pot almost full of the iuice, and doe ashes on the top with a cloth, seeth it to the one halfe, and drinke thereof fasting dayly, for the Dropsie, Timpany, and Iaundies. Eares dull, put in the iuice with a tent, it taketh away the paine also of the eares. Emerods, apply the herbe, or vse the herbe inwardly or outwardly. Face blaines, stampe the rootes of Planten and Burres with salt ana, and vineger, and anoynt therewith at night. Face pimples and ringwormes, stampe the rootes with salt and vineger, and wash therewith. Falling euill, drink the leaues, roots or buds of water Planten. Feete surbated, sore and swollen with trauell, anoynt with Planten iuice, or stampe it with vineger, and apply it. Fellon, drinke the iuice of Planten and Morell, and apply the herbes, apply the iuice of Planten and Celondine. Feuers, stampe three rootes and streine them with water, and drinke it. The roots taken with wine and water three at once, cure the tertian, and foure the quarten. The leaues and rootes sodden in faire water, or Borage water, and drunke with suger, doe cure the tertian and quarten Feuers. Feuer quarten, drinke the iuice with Honied water, two houres before the fit, and it will haue a wonderfull effect. Drinke the iuice of Ribwurt two houres before the fit. Fistula, vse the iuice and herbe inward and outward, or the water: the herbe stamped and applied, doeth Flowers to stop, vse the decoction of it, drinke the iuice with Lapis Hematites. Gums griefes and kanker, vse the iuice with vineger, Hony and Alome: vse the iuice, water, or decoction thereof. Gout and all aches, and swellings of the synowes, stampe the leaues with a little salt and apply them. Gout in the feete, drinke it with vineger, bruise it and apply it to any Goute. Hardnesse of all sorts, stampe it with swines grease, and apply it. Heart griefes, drinke a spoonefull of the iuice with Hony, to expell it. Headach, vse Planten, apply the iuice or water with linnen. Head megrem, stampe ribwort, red Fennell and Betony with womans milke and apply it: and as the griefe remoueth, follow it therewith. Stampe Planten, and binde it to the necke to auoyd headach. Boyle it with Fenigrek in milke, and apply it in a cloth. Iaundies, take the iuice of Planten, Wormewood and Smallach with suger: or the iuice of Planten and Wormewood ana with suger, (See Dropsie. Drinke the iuice of Planten and Letuce with vineger, and also apply it to the right side, (See bladder.) Kankers, vse Planten inward and outward: or the iuice or water. Stampe Planten and apply it, and also drinke the iuice thereof. Seethe the rootes and leaues with good sweete wine and drinke: vse the rootes by themselues with the seedes in like sort. Mad dogs biting, apply the iuice or water, or leaues, and drinke thereof. Megreme (See head ach.) Morphue white, drinke the iuice or infusion thereof. Vse the iuice or decoction of the roots: for the Vuula, chew Planten. Nolimetangere, mixe salgem with the iuice, and make it somewhat thicke and apply it, and bruise the leaues, and wring out the iuice a little, and apply them and whole leaues vpon them. Nose bleeding, stampe Planten, Ribwort and Housleeke with Barley meale and apply it about the necke and on the same side that bleedeth, or drinke the iuice with vineger, or the iuice alone. Pocks, or swine Pocks, hang the roote about thy necke. eate the leaues with meate or otherwayes, or vse the herbe, seede or powder inward. Rankling, drinke it and also apply it with bol armoniak, barley meale, and whites of Egges. Saint Anthonies fire, apply it with Cimolea and white lead. Senowes griefes, stampe the leaues with a litle salt, and apply it. Serpents biting, drinke Planten with wine, drinke the iuice and apply the substance. Side ach, seethe the lesser kinde of Planten, and apply it hote, or bruise the leaues, and apply them. Put as much mouse dung as will lie on a groat, to halfe a glasse full of the iuice, and drinke it first and last with suger, as long as neede is: drinke the iuice, or drinke the seede with wine. Squincie and griefes of the throte, vse the iuice inward and outward. Swellings, vse Planten: stampe the leaues with salt, and apply them: or with olde greace. Teeth ach, vse the iuice or decoction of the leaues. Seeth the roote and rub often therewith, and chew it. Throte wenne, stampe the leaues with salt, and apply it, (See swellings.) Wormes, seethe good store of Planten seedes in Malmesie or ale, to the one halfe, and drinke it fasting daily. Wounds generall, vse Planten of all sorts, (See bleeding, rankling,) apply the iuice of Planten and Smallach with wheate flower. Yard sores and chafings, seethe the iuice of Planten with a little Hony, and anoynt. PLum tree (See Damson, Sloe, Acatia. for the leprie Impetigo, and Serpigo dissolue the gum in vineger anoint therewith. Ringworme, boyle the sap in vineger, and streine it and anoynt therewith. Swelling of blood letting, stampe the leaues of a white Plum tree with water, and apply them. POlipody: The roote openeth the belly, and purgeth Melancholy grosse and flegmatike humors, and is good for the chollike and griping in the belly, the hardnesse and stopping of the milt and quarten feuers, especially with Epithymum. It must bee boyled in broth of Mutton or Capon, or the decoction of Mallowes or Beetes, and a little Annise, and then drunke: or the powder may be drunke with Mede. Nose Polip, put in the powder to take it away. That which groweth at the foote of the Oke is best. The roote of that of the Oke or Willow sodden with a Henne with some Anniseedes and Ginger, the broth drunke warme, purgeth choller melancholly: some vse Beetes, and some Mallowes therewith. dram or more of the powder drunk wt Honied water three or foure houres before other things, doth the like. The same root is good for swine again ye murren. Deliuerance to cause whether the childe be quicke or dead, stampe it and apply it to her feete that is in trauell. Seeth it with a Hen, or with fish, or with Beets, or Mallowes, to make a purgation to purge grosse humors from the ioynts: it is good for all griefes that come of melancholy, as the quarten, if it be taken with Mede, Dodder of time and salt Indian. All maner of wayes it is good for the Chollike and hardnesse of the milt. If it be taken with Mede or barly water, or the broth of Reasins, or of Cockes or Hennes, or sodden with whey, it will not mooue the stomake to vomiting: it is good to take it with well sauouring spices or seeds, as Aniseed, Carawayseed, Fennell seed, Ginger and such like, that comfort the naturall power of the stomacke: it will bide long seething, it may be taken fro~ two drams to sixe drams: an ounce and a halfe of our English Polipody, will scarce purge. Some take powder of the drie roote, at the least one dram for a purgation. The roote sodden in wine and sweetened with Suger or Hony, and drunke certaine dayes, is good against the quarten, the Cough, shortnesse of winde, melancholly and heauie dreames, &c. Belly bound, seeth it with as much Mallowes, drinke the broth: or seeth it in water, make pottage therewith: or steepe it in wine, drinke it. Seeth i. handfull in red wine from a gallon to a quart, with ii. spoones full of clarified Hony, drinke one spoonefull morne euen. Stuf an olde fat Hen or Cocke with it Hony, Butter, or fresh grease, seeth it well and drink ye broth hote, drink white wine no other drink after it, till thou beest soluble. Fundament fig, stamp it wt Yarow drink it wt ale. Pricks, apply it wt swines grease. Kings euill, take as much powder of it as will lie on a groate, with Hony or wine one and twenty dayes, beginning at the quarter decreasing, keepe good order of diet, and be whole. Ptisike and euill colour in the face, distill it in September, and drinke three or foure drams in the morning. Chollike, seeth it with an old cocke, and drinke the broth. To preserue health, and for the quotidian Iliak passion, stampe halfe a dram or a dram with Prunes and violets, or Aniseeds in Fenel water, and streine it and drinke it morne and euen: or seeth it with Fenell seed in water, and make therewith a chicken broth with sweete spices, and eate it: or stampe it and boyle it in wine, and after put more wine to it, and so make it a drinke with sweete spices, and vse it. Cough Colour ill Dead childe Deliuerance Dreames ill Feuer quart. quotid Fundament fig Hogs murren Health to keepe Iliak pas. Ioynts out POmegranate: The iuice is very good for a hote and weake stomacke, as the iuice of Oringes or Cytrons, and for all hote agewes and inflammations of the liuer and blood, especially the sower Pomegranates, and next vnto them, such as be of a winish taste: for the sweete are not very meete to be vsed in agewes. The blossoms both of the tame and wilde Pomgranat trees, as also the rynde or shell in powder eaten, or boiled in wine drunke, are good for the bloody fluxe, and the inordinate course of the mother, not onely as is aforesaid, but also to sit or bathe in the decoction thereof. The same barke or blossomes, stoppe the blood of greene wounds, being applied in any sort. The same barke killeth wormes, and is a good remedie against the corruption in the stomake or bowels, being washed wt the broth or decoction therof. Vse the barke and flowers in plasters, against bruising and ruptures. The seedes dried in the sunne haue like vertues as the flowers: it stoppeth the laske and all issues of blood, being taken in the same maner. The same mixt with Hony helpeth al the sores of the mouth, priuities fundament. They that eate three flowers of the tame Pomegranate, shall be preserued one yeere from dropping and bleared eyes. The iuice and kernels are good in hote griefes and burning feuers to quench thirst and heate of the stomacke: and so is the syrope of the iuice of it. The kernels of the sower Pomgranats dried in the sunne, helpe all maner of fluxes, both of the belly and Matrixe. And drunke with rawe water, they helpe the spitting of blood: and so doe the flowers or rindes thereof. The rinde sodden in wine drunke, killeth wormes: and the powder of the rinde or flowers drunke or taken fasting, is good for the cold cough and the reume. The iuice of the kernels mixt with Hony and sodden, is good for painefull sores of the mouth, yard fundament, and for the loosenesse of the skin about the nailes, and for swellings and knots in any part of the body, for ach of the eares and griefes of the nostrels, especially the kernels of the sower Pomgranats. The rinde of Pomgranats powdred and mixt with Hony and anointed, sistit fluxum vrinae aureae. The powder of the flowers in plasters, driueth backe the hernyes and swelling of the Cods, especially if some gaules be put thereto. The wine of Pomgranats is good to comfort the stomacke after meate. The flowers of wilde Pomgranates stop fluxes, being vsed in drinks and Glisters. The kernels of the sower Pomgranat dried in the sunne, and either sprinkled on meate or sodden therewith, stop the belly stomacke that is loose. The sower Pomgranat is good for the heart burning and the swooning that commeth by choller, the inflammation of the liuer, and to cause appetite. The syrope is good for women with with childe, and the heate of the stomacke liuer. The iuice of the sweete Pomgranat is good for the stomake, but in hote feuers the sower is better. They are very comfortable restoratiue in long sickenesses, consumptions and fluxes. The powder of the rinde drunke with red wine and Cinamome, helpeth any laske or fluxe. The whole Pomgranat lose with clay into an earthen pot, and dried in an Ouen, helpeth the bloody fluxe and torments of the belly, one dram a halfe drunke with wine. Powder of the kernels of sower Pomgranats, one ounce, with one dram of Frankincense thereof drunke with Rose water, stoppeth the whites in women. Eyes itch, heat and running, take vp the fume of the decoction of the flowers. Teeth ach, wash with the decoction of the flowers, put powder of the same into the tooth. Belching yexing, to restore appetite, stampe a Pomgranat whole with the rinde, and boyle it with a quart of Hony till it be thicke, and take a little of it fasting with cold water. Wormes, seeth the rinde with the root of an Ash in wine, and drinke it fasting, it helpeth also the Tenasmus: or drinke Acatia with water of the decoction of Pomegranates. Heart faint of hote cause, make pottage of the kernels barly meale, vse to eate thereof. Thirst to void, sup the iuice of it, (See Almonds for the bloody fluxe.) Eyes pin and web, put in the iuice of a sowre Pomegranate two or three times to heale it. The same cureth sauseflegme, rednesse such like in the face, and also the morphue. Fluxe red or yelow, vse ye syrope of Pomgranats wt Mint water. Wild fire, mixe powder of the vtter rinde wt vineger, anoint therewith. Blood to stop Bursten Cods swollen Conceiued Consumption Cough Eares ach Eyes griefs POmpons, (See Mellons. make little balles or trochiskes of the iuice of the inner part, and Beane flowre, drie them in the shadowe, and wash therewith in a Bane, to auoyde all filth and spots from the skin when you begin to sweate, being broken and mixt with water. Poplar POplar white: Boyle the barke in wine to prouoke vrine, and helpe the strangurie and the Sciatica. Eares paine and vlcers, drop in the iuice of the leaues. The leaues yong buds of blacke Poplar, stampt applied, swageth the paine of the gout in the hands or feete. The oyntment that is made of the buds, is good against all inflammations, all bruisings swellings, being applied. The iuice of the barke sodden in red wine, helpeth the bloody fluxe and the Sciatica. The leaues of blacke Poplar applied with vineger, are good for the gout. The rosen that commeth out of Poplar, is often mixed with softning suppling in Plasters. An ounce of the barke of white Poplar, is good against the sciatica, being drunke, and likewise for the strangury. The round pilles which come forth at ye budding time, broken applyed with Hony, heale the dulnesse of the sight. The katlins or taklets of Poplar, come forth about ye end of March April, then the buds therof must be gathered to make vnguentum Populeon. Poplar is good in baths against most diseases of the body. Lust to voyd, drinke or eate ye flowers of the tree. Anoint the stomacke or belly therewith to stop either vomite or laske. Feuer pestilentiall, anoint the spine of the backe, and the plants of the hands and feete therewith, and oyle of Roses, and also the region of the liuer. Burning and skalding, mixe it with yolkes of egges and apply it, or mixe it with whites of egges, and oyle of Roses, and vse it. Frensie, shaue the head anoint it with it, and apply a whelpe or cockrell slit through the middest of the backe. Strangury, anoint with it, and weare a plate of lead prickt full of holes to the reines. Yarde paine and chafed, mixe it with oyle of Roses or of Violets, and of Poppy, and the white of an Egge and vse it. Fistula, searche it, and put in a tent that will fill it, anointed with Populeon, and the sore also, but dip the tent point in this powder: take greene Coprose two ounces, burne it in a crusible, and put thereto Mercurie sublimate one ounce, and grinde them very fine, and so dresse it two dayes together with this powder once in houres, and then other two dayes with Populeon onely, and when it is cleane, heale it vp with incarnatiues &c. Itch and skabbe, mortifie Quicksiluer with fasting spittle, and mixe it with twise so much Populeon, and anoint the plants of the hands, and feete therewith morne and euen. Bathing Bruses Burnings Eares griefes Eyes griefes Falling euill Feete goute Hands goute Inflammation Itche Liuer chafte Lust to voide Pissing bed Plague Reines running Sciatica POppie: white Poppie seedes gathered when they be ripe, may be kept fiue yeeres, they prouoke sleepe, and swage paine. Bruse the seedes with womans milke and the white of an Eg, and apply it hote to the temples and forehead to prouoke sleepe. The seede or hearbe bruised with oyle of Roses, and applied, draweth out the great heate of vlcers comming of a bruise, and applied to the hote liuer, it doth helpe it much. Anoint the backe with powder of the seedes, and oyle Oliue, to asswage the ache of the ioynts, and to strengthen them. The iuice with oyle of Roses helpeth the hote goute of the feete, and the ache thereof. Powder of the seedes with oyle of Violets anointed on the backe bone, doth helpe the burning of the Feuer, and heate of the liuer. Any kinde of Poppie, or the iuice or water thereof applied to the forehead and temples, prouoketh sleepe, and helpeth the frensie. Put the iuice of the hearbe with a tent into the nose to prouoke sleepe: and into the naturall place to stop the termes: apply it to any paine to mitigate the same. Seethe heads and leaues in water, and bathe the head therewith to prouoke sleepe. The broth is good to be drunke against too much want of sleepe. The heads broken with parched Barley meale, are good to be applied to inflammations both chollerike and others. The greene heads must be brayed and fashioned into little cakes, and dryed to serue in time of neede. The whole heads are sodden alone in water to the one halfe, and then streyned and sodden with hony to the thicknesse of an Electuarie, which is good for ye cough, the cathar that falleth into the pipes, for the running of ye belly, but it will be much better if Hypoquistida or Acatia be put to it. Drinke the seedes of blacke Poppie broken in wine against the fluxe, all issues of women. The seede of Garden Poppie is good to be mixt with bread to season it, but ye white is better then the blacke. The vse of Poppie is very good of the much spitting and coughing of raw matter from the breast, by distilling of reume from the head. The seede of blacke Poppie taken by it selfe or with wine, helpeth the cough and falling downe of reume, the flowing of womens sickenesse and termes, and paines of the small guts: the same doeth the iuice thereof. Powder of white Poppie seede giuen to children in milke or possite drinke, or an alebrew, or rather with a Caudell of Almonds and hempe seede, causeth them to sleepe. Stampe white Poppie Henbane seede with the white of an Egge, and apply it to the forehead to prouoke sleepe in the frensie. Stampe the leaues of white Poppie and red Nettles with a little Beane floure, and binde it to the forehead to prouoke sleepe. Wash thy face with hote water of the decoction of Poppie, and thou shalt either sleepe, or dye out of hand. The iuice of Poppie with oyle of Roses prouoketh sleepe. Stampe the heads of greene Poppie with oyle of Roses and Rose water, and apply it to the forehead and temples for and to prouoke sleepe. The seedes in an Electuarie are good for the cough and hoarsenesse. The decoction of the leaues and heads in water drunke, causeth sleepe, and so it doeth if the head and hands be washed therewith. The seede of blacke Poppie drunke in Wine, stoppeth the fluxe and termes. And being mixt with water and applied to the temples causeth sleepe. plaster made of the greene heads before they be ripe, and parched Barley meale is good for the holy fire, and hote tumours. Sleepe to cause, stampe the seedes with womans milke, and apply it to the forehead and temples, or anoint with the iuice and womans milke, or applye the iuice of Poppie, Houseleeke, and Nightshade, with the seedes of Poppie, and the white of an Egge in a sharpe Feuer. Or seethe the toppes of blacke Poppie in milke and drinke it, or stampe them with water, and apply it blood warme to the forehead, temples, and pulses. Seeth crownes of Poppie heads in milke and drinke it. Feuers caused of hote meates, vse Opij Zaccarum with milke of Poppie seede. Costiuenesse and stampe the seedes and streine it with water, and drinke thereof, especially at night, and apply it to thy forehead. Feuer of hote blood, drinke water wherein the leaues of Fleawort haue beene sodden with a litle milke of Poppy seede. Sleepe to cause, stampe the seedes of Lettuse and white Poppy, with womans Scrophules, seede wilde Poppy, quicke Brimstone, Doues doung, and Linseede with pure wine, being first stamped, and apply it to all Scrophules. The branches of wilde Poppy and vnripe Figges, drawe broken bones out of vlcers. Sleepe to cause, apply a plaster of the seedes with womans milke, and the white of an Egge to the temples. For a hote impostume and chafing of the liuer, stampe the seedes or hearbe of white Poppy, with oyle of Roses, and apply it. For drynesse in a feuer hectike, stampe the seedes with oyle of Violets, and anoint the small of the backe therewith. Sleepe to cause, stampe the seedes of Poppy and Henbane, with the white of an Egge, and apply it to the forehead. For great griefe in the body, boyle the leaues with Fiueleafe, and Peniroyall, of eache like much in wine, and foment therewith. apply the seedes with gumme Arabike and womans milke to the temples. Bones broken, seethe Figs and Poppy sodden in water and apply it. Fluxe to stop, make drinke of the seedes of Lettuse and white Poppy and vse it. Sleepe to cause, drinke a spoonefull of syrupe of Poppy, or anoint the temples with oyle of Poppy. Sleepe to cause, take one spoonefull of white Poppy seede with a little possiteale made with Violets, Strawberie leaues, and Fiueleafe, and drinke it warme when neede is. ounces of white Poppy seede, but not ye ripest, steepe them in a pottel of raine water houres, seethe it till the better halfe be wasted, streine it, and to euery pint put one pound of Sugar, seethe it and skomme it, and keepe it in a close glasse, and take one spoonefull when neede is to prouoke sleepe. PRiuet: the leaues doe cure swellings, vlcers, and apost. of the mouth, and sores, pustules, and blisters of the throte being washed or gargled with the decoction or iuice. Straw powder of the leaues on hote vlcers and festring consuming sores, or bruise the fruite and apply it to the same effect. The oyle heateth and softneth sinowes being mixt with things that be of hote nature. The water of the leaues and tendrels or flowers distilled in May or Iune, helpeth the exulceration of the mouth, hote inflammations, carbuncles, vlcers of the priuie partes and burnings with fire. Priuities sores Sinowes griefes Skalding Skinne off Sores Swellings Throte sores PVrslaine eaten greene, helpeth a hote stomacke, the swelling of the mouth of the stomacke. Stomacke hote, bruise it with Barley meale, and apply it. Flowers to stop, eate it to stay them without harme. and heate of the eyes, apply it with Barley flowre. Feuer burning, drinke the iuice, which also killeth wormes, and helpeth spitting of blood. Belly bound, seethe it in water with Prunes, and drinke the broth. Warts, anoint with the iuice to plucke them vp by the rootes. The eating of it rawe, breedeth clammy humors in the stomacke. Eate it to stop fluxes, to quench burning choller, to extinguish lust, to helpe the reines and bladder, to kill rounde wormes, to comfort the matrix, to stay the abundance of termes. It may be preserued with salt, and then it is good with rosted meates. The roote hanged with a threed about thy necke, helpeth the falling of the vuula. It quencheth the fretting and exulcerations of the kidneis and bladder, and outragious lust. It is good in eye medicins, And in glisters for the fluxe, and ye gnawing and fretting of the matrix. Head ache of heate, anoint with the iuice oyle. Head plouks and blaines, rub it with the iuice wine. Drinke it and apply it against all poyson and venome, and to withstand vnholsome water. Chewe it with hony apply it to sores to heale them. Chewe it raw for the sores of the mouth, swellings of ye gums, and the tooth ache, and to fasten loose teeth. Apply it to the ache of the necke with as much of a gall and Linseede. The seede sodden with hony, is good against shortnes of breath. With oyle parched Barley, it swageth ache of wounds, it softneth ye hardnes of the sinowes, it driueth away vncleane dreames of venery, minisheth seede, it hurteth ye eyesight. The iuice, water, seede, or any part of it is good for all inward heates of ye stomacke, liuer, and kidneis. The water stoppeth the bloody fluxe other fluxes, and is good for the frensie, the inflammation, ache, or running of the eyes and eares, all infla~mations of the belly, the termes, Emerods, spitting of blood, the cough shortnes of breath. The seede, herbe, or water vsed, stoppeth ye running of the reines, abateth lust, cooleth the blood. The herbe or seede stamped with flowers of parched Barley, and applied to the forehead temples, appeaseth co~ming of heate, helpeth the frensie, the inflammation of the eyes, their rednes: it helpeth the holy fire, the shingles, ringwormes, tetters. Mixe ye iuice with oyle of Roses or of Violets, apply it to ye temples wt stuphes of Hempe to prouoke sleep. Mixe the iuice with oile of waxe, apply it to the swelling of the yard. It stoppeth all issues of blood, the iuice being drunke and the herbe boyled eaten. The iuice powred on ye head with oyle and vineger of Roses, swageth ye hote comming by heate of the sunne. The iuice throwne vp into the matrix helpeth the burning inflammations, exulcerations, gnawings and frettings in the same. And put in by glister, it helpeth ye fluxe of ye guts and exulceration of the bowels. Purslaine cooleth all things that are too hote, defendeth wounds fro~ inflammation. Wild Pursten may be vsed to all purposes in stead of it: it groweth in gardens, alleys and rockes, &c. Purslaine preserued in salt or brine, heateth purgeth the stomacke: dip a cloth in the iuice of Purslaine, Gourde, or Cucumber, and apply it to the head against ye frensie with vineger round about the head. Purslaine will not suffer choller to ingender in the stomacke. Matrix swolne, drinke Purslaine and apply it, or bathe it with the decoction of it. Nauell out Poyson Reines running Ringworme Senowes hard Shingles Sleepe to cause QVince: The Quince stoppeth the laske or common fluxe, the and all other fluxes of blood, spitting blood, especially when it is rawe: for when it is either boyled or rosted, it stoppeth not so much, but it is then fitter to be eaten, and more pleasant to the taste. Women with childe that eate Quinces often in meate or otherwise, shall bring foorth wise children of good vnderstanding. The Codenac, or Marmalad made with hony as it was wont to be, with sugar as they vse to make it now a dayes, is very good to strengthen the stomacke, and to keepe the meate therein till it be perfectly digested. Being taken before meate, it stoppeth the laske, and after meate it looseth the belly, and closeth vp the mouth of the stomacke so fast, that no vapours can ascend vp into the braine, and cureth headache, that The decoction or broth of Quinces hath ye like vertue, stoppeth the belly, al fluxes of blood, and the violent issues of the termes. With ye same it is good to bathe the loose fundament falling downe of ye matrix, to make them to returne into their naturall places. They are also good in plasters to stop the fluxe vomiting, for al hote swellings inflammations of the breast other places. The downe that groweth vpon Quinces sodden in wine applied, healeth carbuncles. The oile of Quinces staieth vomitings, gripings in ye belly or stomack with ye casting vp of blood, if ye stomack be anointed therewith. The flowers of the Quince tree doe stop fluxes, spitting blood and the flowers, haue the same vertues that Quinces themselues haue. If the stomacke be very hote and moist, or the belly laxatiue, Quinces are best to be eaten before meate, being rosted or eaten colde, the tarter that they be, ye better they are. But the custome of taking of Quinces in meates hurteth ye sinowes, but by way of medicin they be excellent. And the cores taken out and preserued in hony or kept in their mussilage, they may long continue to ye vse of rosting or baking: for they be perilous to the stomacke being eaten rawe, but preserued, they doe mightely preuaile against drunkennesse. If he that hath drunke well eate a Quince rosted or otherwayes ordered, the drinke shall not annoye his braine much. Quinces well rosted or baked, are of good nourishment, and are good for the stomacke, and take away belching, vomiting, and lothing, especially taken after meate. The syrupes and Electuaries made of Quinces with spices, are very profitable for many griefes. The iuice of a rawe Quince is very good for them whose winde is stopt, and cannot holde their meate. Quinces preserued whole in hony, are very good to be vsed of them that haue the bloody fluxe. Rawe Quinces applied in plasters are good to stop the fluxe and vomiting, the heate of the stomacke, and inflammation of the breast and liuer. The decoction of the leaues is good against the falling downe of the matrix and fundament. The seede steeped in is good against thicke and grosse humors, in burnings with fire. they make a man pisse well, but when they are rosted, they are counted to be gentler. The iuice of rawe Quinces is good for them that are short winded. The broth of them is good to bathe the mother in that falleth downe. They that are sodden in hony, are more pleasant for the stomacke. They are good raw in plasters to stop the belly, for the inflammation of the stomacke and paps, for vomiting, hardnesse of the milt, and swelling about the fundament. You may make wine of them, by stamping and streyning them, but it will not last, except you put to euery xv. quartes one quart of hony, for without hony it will turne to vergis. The wine so made is good for all the things aforesaid. The oyle of Quinces is made of the smallest, roundest, and best smelling Quinces. The flowres both greene and drie, are good in emplasters for all things that neede binding, and for inflammations, vomiting of blood. And they are also good against the flixe, and to stop the termes. eate rosted Quinces after meales when the ache commeth of vapours. Vomit to stop, steepe the kernels in water and drinke it, or binde the leaues vnto thy wristes. They may be gathered in August, and kept all the yeere. Fluxe, seethe Quinces after they be pared and cored with Oke apples Cinamom, and sugar it and take thereof iii. nights. To make Marmalad of Quinces, take Quinces xvi. pound, core them, seethe them, and stampe them in a stone morter, then clarifie tenne pound of hony with the gleyre of an Eg, or white well beaten, and seeth all till it be stiffe, then lay it on a marble stone, and cut it of what fashion you will. plaster of Quinces is restrictiue and good for the bloody flixe. Tong sharpe and drie, put the seedes of Quinces, and Psilium, or one of them into a cloth, steepe it in water, and wash therewith. Stamp Barley meale with halfe as much Quince kernels with vineger, and apply it to burnings or inflammations of the goute. Mixe the pap of sodden Quinces eight ounces, with powder of Sugar foure ounces, vineger sixe spoonefull or more, Ginger halfe an ounce, white Pepper one dramme, seethe it to the height of a Conserue, and take thereof before and after meate to comfort the stomacke. RAdi&sh eaten at supper doeth well digest meate, heateth the stomacke, causeth a stinking breath, if any sleepe by and by after the eating of it. Canker in olde vlcers, anoint with the iuice of the roote, or vse the powder of it. Boyle the iuice with hony, and mixe it with a little vineger, and streine it and drinke it, to helpe the quarten Feuer and the stopping of the milt. Stampe the roote and apply it to the water betweene the skinne and flesh, and to the hardnesse of the milt. Kings euill, drinke the iuice of the roote with the lyanor of Reasins. And with hony to void the cough, stopping the breast, and shortnesse of breath. Bruise the rootes, and steepe them two or three dayes in vineger, then put thereto a third part of hony, and streine it and drinke of this Oximell to helpe the feuer quotidian and quarten, except the same come of salt flegme. For colde and vndigested humors in the stomacke, steepe the rindes of the rootes in vineger and hony mixt together, and eate dayly a good quantity thereof, drinke after it a draught of warme water, put thy finger or a feather dipt in sallet oyle into thy throte to procure vomite at any time, but the best time is in the morning. For hardnesse of the liuer and milt, seethe the hearbe alone in oyle and wine, and apply it plaster wise hote, and likewise for the strangury to the bottome of the belly and roote of the priuitie. Distill water of Radish in September, and drinke iii. or iiii. ounces of the water morne and euen for the stone, to prouoke vrine, to cleanse the reines and bladder, and testicles, and for the Kings euill, to kill wormes and helpe digestion, and to cleanse the stomacke from humors that let digestion, to open all obstructions of the intralles and veines, and to cause a cleare voyce. Gargle therewith in the throte, and holde thereof in thy mouth to helpe the swelling in the throte, and vlcers in the gummes. Drinke thereof also iiii. ounces morning and euening three or foure weekes together, and forbeare much other drinking to helpe the water betweene the skinne and the flesh. Stampe earth wormes, and put thereto the iuice of Radish rootes, and quench therein any knife, sworde, or other toole to make it cut Iron as it were Lead. Boyle iiii. pound of the outward rindes of Radish with viii. pound of hony to the one halfe, then put thereto powder of Cinamom, Cloues, Mace, Nutmegs, and blacke Pepper, of eache halfe an ounce, and keepe it in a close vessell, and take thereof halfe an ounce euery morning fasting to be free from the chollike and iliake. Mixe the iuice of the rootes with white wine and Turpentine burned or dryed in the sunne, and drinke it to driue out ye stone. The yong stemes and tender crops and buds, may be boyled and eaten with oyle and vineger, and they nourish better then the rootes, though their nourishment be but little. The barke of the roote taken before meate with Oximell stirreth vomiting, purgeth tough humours, and quickeneth the wit and vnderstanding. The decoction or broth of Radish drunke, prouoketh vrine, breaketh the stone, and driueth it out, ripeth grosse flegme, cleanseth the breast and stomacke, and helpeth the olde cough. Radish is good for the Dropsie, the griefes of the liuer, and stopping of the reines. And eaten with Mustard, it is good against ye Lethargie, drousinesse, and forgetfulnesse. It is good also for them that are sicke with eating of Todestooles or Mushroomes or Henbane, or other venome, and for the chollike and griping paine in the bellie: it prouoketh termes, and causeth abundance of milke. The roote stamped very small with vineger applied, cureth the hardnesse of the milt. The same with hony helpeth fretting, festering, and consuming sores, and is good against skuruinesse and skales of the head, and restoreth haire. The same with Darnel meale taketh away blewe spots of bruises and all blemishes, and frecles of the face. The seede causeth vomit vehemently, and prouoketh vrine, and being drunke with hony and vineger, it killeth and expelleth wormes. The same taken with vineger wasteth the milt, slaketh the hardnes thereof. The same sodden in honied vineger often gargarised hote, is good against the Squincy. The wild or water Radish hath the same vertues, but stronger, and is singular good to prouoke vrine. Radish laide to with vineger, doeth mightely skowre away gangrenes, or extreame hote sores. Radish sodden with water and tempered with hony, is good against the olde cough, and cleanseth the breast and lungs being vsed certaine dayes. The barke of the roote stamped and taken with hony and vineger, prouoketh vomite, and so doeth the seede taken with warme water. Radish stamped finely with hony, taketh away all blacke spots of bruises, the spots and pimples of the face, restoreth haire, and is good against all venemous bitings and stingings. And the same applied to the nauell of a woman, taketh away ye torments of her belly. The great wilde Raysart is much of like nature to Radish. The yong plants of Radish with vineger at the beginning of meales, is good sause to loosen the belly. But it is best to seethe Radish, and put vineger, sugar, and good sweete oyle to it, and not to eate it rawe. Radish sodden in wine and drunke morne and euen, breaketh and expelleth the stone, openeth the gall, diminisheth the splene, and moueth venus. Drop the iuice warme into the eare to helpe any paine therein. The ashes of burned Radish doeth cleanse and drie vlcers. Stampe two ounces of the roote, or three drams of the seedes, put thereto honied water or barley water or whey, and streine it and drinke it to prouoke vomite, and cleanse ye stomacke: it may be giuen to any of any age or kinde. Radish is vnholsome for them that haue paine of the goute or ache of the ioynts. grease, and applye it to botches and apostumes, and to helpe them. Eares dull, seethe the seedes of Radish, Stauesacre, and Wormewood, and streine it and put it into the eare with a tent. Flegme to voide, put the roote with Oximell into warme water, and drinke a good deale, and put thy finger into thy mouth to prouoke vomite. Eate the rootes for the Iaundies, hauing first drunke Oximell squillitike. The iuice drunke is a good preseruatiue against death drunke with wine. For flegme or reume, stampe the roots with Figges and a little Honie, and boyle it into an Electuarie, and vse it to cleanse the stomacke of flegme. Seethe one handfull of the rootes with foure ounces of Saxifrage in wine to the third part, then put in a litle Hony and drinke it warme at euen for the stone. Stampe the rootes, and apply them to the belly to kill wormes and expell them. Vrine to cause, seethe as much horse Radish as two egs sliced thinne in a pint of water, with as much hony as the roote, and when it is well sodden drinke thereof. Or slice as much as both the fistes, and stampe it and put thereto thrise as much course branne, seethe it in a pottell of water till the water be consumed, and lie vpon it, thy belly downewards, as hote as thou canst suffer. Stone and stopping of the vrine, slice ii. pound of the roote of wilde or horse Radish, stampe them and seeth them in a linnen bag in a pot of water, and put to it sixe buckets of other water, and sit therein vp to the middle, and apply the bag vnto the place, and drinke the distilled water of the same hearbe at morne, noone, and euen, especially with powder of the kidneis of a Hare two drams. Or cut the saide roote checkerwise as dice foure ounces, powre thereon a quart of the best wine that can be got, and let it stand Ptisike, drie the roote of Radish, and make it into fine powder, and vse it in meates, brothes, sawses, and drinkes. Canker, apply the iuice of Radish, and Elecampana, with wheate flowre, and the white of an Egge. Canker wormes, apply the leaues stamped with blacke nesh sope. Stone to breake, steepe the sliced rootes in white wine one night, then streine it and drinke it. Head pushes, and sores, stampe Radish with Hogs grease, and anoint therewith. Falling euill, stampe it and apply it to the braine. fill it with a peece of the roote, or rub the teeth and gummes therewith. put in the rinde of Woodbine and the scraping of Radish. Feuer tertian, stampe the roote with wheate branne, and apply it betweene the nauell and the share. Scrophules, vse to take Radish any way in meate or drinke. The oyle of the seedes with the iuice of Broome killeth lice. Anoint thy hand with the iuice of the roote, and no serpent will hurt thee when thou handlest her. Face bruised or hurt, anoint with hony and the iuice of the rinde of the roote. Skin spots, distill Radish in a Limbek, and wash therewith. Fretting sores, mixe well the oyle of Radish with salt, and apply it. Bruises and spots, anoint with the iuice or with hony wherein the seedes be dissolued. Eyes dull, gather the rootes in an euening, slice them and lay the cut side downewards in a chafindish, and let it stand all night in the ayre, and gather the water, and drop it into the eyes. Radish is good against all choking of mushroomes and poyson, or venome. Reines ache, cut the rootes in small gobbits, and steepe them all night in Malmesey, and drinke it first and last nine dayes. Pare the rootes, and put them in dishes with vnpured hony, and let them stand all night, and in the morning eate nine gobbits or slices fasting, the next day eight, the next day seuen, and so to one, to breake the stone. Biting of a mad dog, pare the roote and seethe it in wine, and stampe it, and applie it, for it will holde the hole open, and drawe out the venome, if you stampe the leaues therewith, and apply it, it will doe better. Stomacke to cleanse, seethe Elecampana, and Radish of eache halfe a handfull in a quart of water with a pint of Hony, and a farthingwoorth of bruised Licoras, and drinke thereof first and last. Flegme to voide, seethe Radish in Ale, and eate it. Flowers stopt Gall stopt Gangrene Goute Head skales sores Haire to restore RApe and Turnep: The Turnep taken in meate nourisheth meetely well being moderatly taken and well digested, but taken too much, it ingendreth much windinesse and superfluitie of humors, especially eaten raw: for then it hurteth the stomake, and causeth windy griping torment in the small guts. The same boyled in milke applied, swageth the paine of the gout. Oyle of Roses put into a Turnep, and rosted in the Embers, healeth kibed heeles. The broth of Rapes is good for the same purpose being washed and bathed therein sokingly, and so is the Nauew or Turnep it selfe being either baked or rosted and applyed. The scrops and yong springs of Turnips eaten, prouoke vrine, and are good for the stone. The seedes of Turneps or Rapes, withstand all poyson, and are therefore put into Treacles and medicines against poyson, and to swage ache: and so is the oyle of the seede. and taken raw, it expelleth wormes. The roote prepared and vsed as is aforesaid, stirreth vp Venus, and so doth the seeds being drunke. The seedes are also put into medicines that are made to beautifie the face, and all the body. Rapes haue also a marueilous propertie to cleanse the sight. Rapes sodden and applied hote, helpe the ach of the Gout, and healeth kibes: especially some oyle of Roses and waxe being rosted therein. Wilde Rapes are put into medicines to cleanse the skinne, as with Lupines, Beane meale, &c. There is great plentie of it made in Marsh land, neere to Linne, very profitable in our common wealth. The oyle drunke, is a present remedy against poyson deadly drinkes. The Rape laid vp in brine, nourish lesse, but causeth appetite to meate. It is good that Rapes be twise sodden before they be eaten, then they nourish sufficiently, prouoke vrin, ingender seede, and swage the roughnesse of the breast and throte. If they be eaten with salt and vineger, they cause appetite. Rapes are good for white flawes and such like diseases of the nailes. Seeth Raphanus or Rape in oyle and anoynt thy head therewith for the Frensie, and thou shalt either sleepe or die. Head ach of murre, seeth Rapes in a pot, and holde thy nose ouer it. lately come, roste a Rape root till it be blacke, and pare it, and eate it as hote as may be suffered, and drinke a draught of hote water after it, and wet a cloth in cold water, and wring it, and binde it about thy necke, a warme cloth on it morne euen. Lamenesse, eate yong Hogs feete sodden with Rapes and Buglosse. Cough and other griefes of the chest, seeth Rape in a pot, and hold thy mouth and face ouer it, till thy face sweat, and keepe thee warme after it. Gout and paine of the ioynts, vse water of the decoction of Rapes. Matrixe windy, mixe the iuice of Mullin and Rapes with Barley meale, and apply it. Matrixe swollen, and windy, seethe Rape seede in water, and foment the place therewith. Skorching with fire, stampe Rapes with their root, and distill them in a Limbecke, and wash therewith often. RAspis are of the same vertue that co~mon Brier or Bramble is of: and moreouer, the flower stampt with Hony applied, is good for the inflammation of the eyes and the shingles. It is good to be giuen with water to them that haue weake stomaks. It were good to keepe some of the iuice of Raspis berries in some wooden vessell, and to make it as it were Raspis wine, which is good for many purposes, both for a weake stomake and the flixe, and diuers diseases of the Gums, Teeth, Vuula, Pallat, and other The leaues and tender springs, fruite and roote, are not much vnlike in vertue, to the like parts of Briers. REd rattle sodden in wine and drunke, stoppeth the termes and all other issues of blood. Prickes, stampe the roote small and apply it with vineger, it swageth the paine of the ioynts that are out. The greene tender leaues finely stampt and applied, doe heale cholorike inflammations or wilde fire, and hote swellings and impostumes. If the downe thereof happen to get into the eares, it causeth such deafenesse as can hardly be cured. The roote applied with vineger, swageth paine of the Reines or Loines. The ashes of the barke with vineger healeth the falling of the haire. Tongue hurt, seethe it with Hony, vse it, (See pricks in Elecampana. Stampe the rootes with Hony and apply it to pricks. And with earth wormes to the ach of the ioynts and shrinking of the synnowes. Backe ach Haire falling Inflammation Ioynts ach Ioynt out Loines ach Pricks REasins and Vine: Vine leaues, branches and tendrels stampt and the iuice drunke, is good for them that vomite or spit blood, and the bloody fluxe, and women with childe giuen to vomiting, and so doe the branches and clasping tendrels by The same clasping tendrels stampt with parched barley meale, are good for the headach, comming of heate, and for hote vlcers of the stomake being applyed. The ashes of the drie boughes or cuttings, applied with vineger, doe cure the excressence and swellings of the Fundament, being first clarified and pared. The same dissolued in oyle of Roses and vineger, is good for the bitings of serpents, members out of ioynt, inflammations or heate of the milt. Greene grapes ingender winde in the stomacke, belly, and doe loosen the belly. The dried Raisins are good against the Cough and all diseases of the lungs, kidneys and bladder, and the stopping and weakenesse of the Liuer, to open and strengthen it. The broth of Raisin kernels, is good for the bloody fluxe and the laske, being altogether powred in by Glister. bath of the decoction of the sayd kernels, stoppeth the flowers being bathed therewith. The fame kernels made into fine powder and applyed with falt, doe swage and consume hard swellings, and the swellings of the brests. White grapes are better then blacke, and wholsomer after three or foure dayes gathering, then when they are new gathered: if they be sweete, they partly nourish and warme the body. Raisins of the sonne be very wholsome, and doe comfort digestion: but the stones and rindes would be refused, and then they be good for the milt and liuer: so bee Assigants: but the small Raisins be hurtfull to the milt. Reisins bee of the nature of Figs. The sweete are best for the stomacke, and yeeld good nourishment. The iuice or water of the leaues or tendrels of the Vine, are good for spitting of blood, the griefes of the stomacke, and the longing of women with childe. The liquor that droppeth out of the wood yeerely, is good for the stone being drunke. The gum dropped into their eyes, is good against their mistinesse and webs, it healeth pushes, skabs, leprie, skurfe and such like, being rubbed on with And the sayd gum layde too continually with oyle, continually wasteth away haire. The pulp of Raisins eaten, is good for the roughnesse of the throte, the Cough, and griefes of the kidneys and bladder. And eaten with their stones, they are good for the bloody fluxe. And taken in meate with Barley meale and an egge If they be laid too with Rue, and without their stones they heale red and angry night plowks and sores that haue matter in them like Hony, carbuncles, rottennesse about the ioynts, and gangrenes. The same layde too with the iuice of Panik, are good for the Gout, and layd to loose Nailes, they make them come off. Raisins eaten before meales, strengthen the stomacke, prouoke appetite, and comfort weake bodies. And without kernels they open the liuer and breast: but eaten with their kernels, they binde: without their kernels, they concoct rawe humors, and withstand putrifaction, and are good for the griefes of the chest, throte, kidneyes and bladder, and soften the belly being taken fasting. And so chewed with fine Rubarbe, they take away crudyty and rawnesse of the stomacke. Ringwormes and Tetters, rub them with the gumme, but first rub them with Asponge dipt in warme wine, and applied to the left Pap, is good against the Frensie. Teeth ach of hote cause, gargarise with water of the decoction of Raisins: it helpeth also the stopping of the throte. Small Raisins eaten with meate, voydeth belching, and stoppeth the fluxe. Teeth ach of heate, gargarise with the decoction of Raisins. Eate two drams of great Raisins fasting the stones taken out, to preserue youth, helpe digestion, diminish flegme, comfort the liuer and stomacke, and increase blood, and make it thicke, and after meate they strengthen and moysten the belly. Ach, stampe Raisins of the sunne, the stones taken out, and apply it to any ach or griefe, (See Figs, Goose heyrif. Fellon in any place, bruise spanish Raisins and apply them. Raisins eaten or boyled in wine, are good for the colde cough, and for a colde stomacke, and the Raisins so sodden, are good for cold Apostumes. Stampe well the kernels of grapes, and binde them in a cloth, and steepe them in raine water or spring water, foure and twenty houres, and drinke a good draught of it morne and euen, against the loosenesse of ye belly. Vomiting to stop, for drinesse of the stomacke, and obstruction of the Burne sower Grapes on a tyle, and put the fine powder thereof into the eyes that are red and running, (See Mulbery. Blood to stop, apply the ashes of a vine with a mans vrine, (See Nettle. Feuer tertain, take the iuice of sower Grapes two mornings, or steepe vine leaues in wine, and drinke it three or foure times, for the feuer tertian, or quarten. The gumme drunke with white wine, expelleth the stone in the reines. Rub Lepries, Ringwormes and Tetters therewith, and salt peter, to cure them. Stampe greene Grapes with some vineger, and make litle loaues, and drie them in the sunne, and steepe them in wine, and it will be vineger. The water that falleth from vines after they be cut, killeth wartes being often washed therewith. Chollike and stone, steepe the newe ashes of the branches all night in white or renish wine, and drinke it in the mornings. Mixe the ashes of the wood with vineger, and apply it to the Emerods. For infection of the skinne, boyle the rootes with Fitches and Fenigreke, and wash therewith. Deliuerance to cause, drinke foure ounces of the iuice or decoction of the leaues sodden in white wine. Warts or hard knobs, burne the wood, and gather the water or sap thereof at the ende, and rub them therewith. Iliaca passio, drinke the iuice of the leaues or buds. Fellon Feuer quarten tertian Flowers to stop Fluxe Frensie Fundament griefs Gangren Gout Head ach Haire to voyd Iliak pas. Ioynts out Kidneys griefs REstharrow, Cammok, or Petywhin: The barke of the root with Hony prouoketh vrin, breaketh ye stone. The broth or decoction thereof sodden in wine drunk, hath the same vertue. The same boyled in Hony and vineger drunke, is good for the falling euill. And boyled in water and vineger, and holden in the mouth while it is warme, helpeth the tooth ach. The tender springs and crops before they bring forth leaues, preserued in brine or salt, and sometimes eaten in sallads, are good for the grauell and stone. The barke of the roote drunke with wine, prouoketh vrine, breaketh the stone, and helpeth the Emerods and fig in the fundament. Seethe the leaues in water, and bathe the legs therewith vp to the knees, to stop the fluxe. Emerods Falling euill Fig in the Fundament Fluxe Fundament griefs Grauell Stone Vsed with milke, it causeth a good colour, increaseth naturall seed: it must be steeped a night in water before it be sodden. The flower or meale thereof in drinke or glister, stoppeth ye bloody flixe. Rice may be eaten as a restoratiue, with Almon milke, and so it comforteth nature. Rice potage made with good milke, seasoned with suger Cinamome, is of easie digestion restoratiue. If the milke haue hote stones quenched therein first, it is good to stop any fluxe, especially thus: Take a good handful of oken barke, boyle it in a gallon of running water to the one halfe or more, then streine it coole it, then beate halfe a pound of Iorden Almonds huske and all, and streine them with that water, and so with Rice make potage, vse it for ye flixe. If blanched Almonds be stamped with Rose water streined into Rice broth, potage or milke: it is also very good for ye flixe. Feuer flegmatike, purge the body, and then vse Rice potage. Face blaines, pimples spots, seeth Rice in running water, and wash therewith. Bloody fluxe, make it into fine flower, and mixe it with yolks of egs, and frye them with sweete butter, and eate them morne and euen. Colour bad Digestion Feuers flegmatike Fluxes Liuer cold Seede to cause Rye. RYe meale put into a little bag laid vpon the head, cureth the olde paine of the head, and drieth the braine. The leuin thereof draweth forth thornes and pricks, it ripeth all swellings and apostumes better then leuin of wheate meale. Rye bread with butter is of the like vertue, but not so strong as ye leuin. Rye bread is heauie and hard to digest, good and strong for labouring men. The yong blades distilled are good for the stone, and for any great heate in any part of the body. Teeth yelow, mixe Rye meale, salt and Hony, of ech like much, and rub them therewith two or three times a day, then wash them with water. Mouth kanker and stinke, bake a cake of sower Rye dough, with good store of salt and Pepper, and make it into powder, with powder of a Harts horne, and a Pill of cleane leekes, and apply it all night. Wounds to heale, seeth swines greace with Hony and Rye meale, and a little iuice of wilde Nep, called Bryony, and vse it to cleanse heale it fast. Kanker, seeth Sloe thorne barke in water, till it be thicke and blacke, and put Hony to it, and temper it with Rye flower, apply it. Strangury, anoynt thy yard with Populeon, and apply Rye meale on the yard. Dropsie, bake cakes of Rye meale, and the iuice of Lilly roots, and bake them vnder a of earth, and apply them hote to the belly one after another: or take sage and Rye meale of ech like much, mixe them finely with a little salt, and bake them finely together, and cut it into gobbits, and put it into a pot of ale, drinke the ale, and eate the cake, especially first and last. Sciatica, apply Rye flower with vineger: if it be the hote gout, the paine will mitigate, or els it is the cold gout. Skabs, mixe the iuice of smallach with Rye meale, sewet, waxe and brimstone, and anoynt, and the third day bath thee. Wounds ache, mixe the iuice of smallach with Hony, swines grease Rye meale, and apply it. Belly grinding, bake a cake of Rye flower well sowred, and heate the inside of it being cut through the midst, and anoint it with Hony, cast thereon powder of Cummin, apply it as hote as may be suffred, as often as need is. Cods swollen, boyle Rye flowre with the iuice of wall wurt, Hony vineger till it be thicke, apply it. Gout in the bones, make tostes of Rye bread, steepe them in vineger, after in Hony, apply it iii. dayes, and lay on it a wurt leafe. Kanker fester, burne a dogs head to powder, and mixe it with Rye meale, the iuice of Louage and Hony, and apply it with tents of linnen till it be whole. Fester, burne Hempe seede Rye to powder, and mixe it with Hony and the iuice of smallach, and apply it: or kneade a cake of Rye flower with Hony, and bake it hard, and apply it till it waxe nesh, and then apply newe as often as neede is. Rume Sciatica Skabs Spitting blood Stone Strangury Swellings Teeth foule Wounds Feuer quarten, drinke the iuice two houres before the fit. Feuer tertian, drinke the iuice two houres before the fit. Feuer quarten, drinke the iuice with warme water Hony. Swellings generall, stampe it when it is new gathered, with cleere greace, apply it. Fester colde, make a cake of Rye flower, whites of egs, and iuice of Ribwurt, apply therof often. Kanker, mixe it with Hony Rye meale, apply it warme, likewise to ye marmol. Wounds of all sorts, new or old, vse the iuice or powder of it. tertian Fluxe great Kanker Matrixe Fluxe Palsie Speech lost Swellings Wilde fire Wounds generall Rocket. ROcket is a good sallat herbe to be eaten with Letuse, Purslen and other like colde herbes, and so they will not hurt the stomacke with their coldnesse: but eaten alone, it heateth too much, and causeth headach. The vse thereof mooueth venus, especially the seed: also it prouoketh vrin, causeth digestion. The seede is good against venemous bitings, and applyed with Hony, it taketh away lentils, freckles, and other deformities of the face. And with the gaul of an oxe, it taketh away blewe markes and skarres. He that taketh the seeds before he be beaten or whipt, shall be so hardened, that he shall easily indure the paine. The roote boyled in water applyed, draweth foorth shords, splinters, and broken bones. The seed driueth all kinde of little worms out of the body. With Hony it healeth all the deformities of the face. For griefe comming of Ruptures, fractures or vnplacing of ioynts, boyle the roots it water and stampe them, and apply them. Blacke spots or bruises, grinde the seedes with an oxe gaul, of ech like much, and apply it or anoynt. ROs solis: Bruise it with salt, and apply it on the bare skinne, to make blisters holes, euen as Cantarides doth. The distilled water of it, is singular good against consumptions, straitnesse of breath, vlcerations of the Lungs. If it be put into a glasse wherein is poyson, it will make it flie out, or make the glasse flie in pieces, and being heated in a cup of wine with poyson, it will make it flie out. Carry it about thee, to bee free from the daunger of thine enemies, and to haue them Apply it to a womans belly, to cause speedy deliuerance, though the childe be dead and rotten. And being caried and also eaten of euery day, it preserueth from the falling euill. Drinke the iuice therof against the Apoplexia drawing of ye mouth awry, to haue speedy helpe. Hang it about the necke of them that be demoniak. Hold it to the mouth, to staunch bleeding at the nose. Drinke the iuice with wine to auoyde wearinesse by trauell, and to heale wounds, drinke it in wine or ale ten dayes, also wash the wounds therewith, and apply it with a cloth dipt therein. To make Rosa solis, Take aqua vite one pinte, the flowers of Roses solis, one gallon, a piece of Angel gold, Rosemary flowers, or the herbe it selfe, and a quantitie of fine suger: distill them in a stillatory, and take thereof one spoonefull at once by it selfe. Apoplexia Blister to make Breath streit Consumption Dead childe Deliuerance Demoniak Distilling Enemies Falling euill Lungs griefs Mad Mouth awrye Nose bleeding Poyson Teeth ach Wearinesse Witchcraft Wounds Rose. ROse: Red Roses must be clipped off, when they be not full ripe, and dried in the sonne: Rosed Hony eaten, doth comfort the blood and the stomacke. The iuice sodden with wine, taketh away the paine of the head, and helpeth the eies the gums, being washed therewith, the toothach. Bruse the leaues, and apply them to drawe out the heate. Rub the gummes and teeth with powder of the seedes, to helpe the tooth ach. Seeth the heads wherein the seedes hee, and drinke the broth, to loosen the belly, and for spitting blood. Mixe Roses with suger and Hony, and eate it to drie vp the euill humors of the stomacke. Seethe the leaues in wine, and drinke it for the griefes The fresh newe leaues with Hony, doe aptly purge the body. speciall laxatiue: Take the iuice of Roses two ounces, mixe it with whey of Cowes milke a little spikenard: or take syrope of Roses made of fresh Roses, to purge the belly. The Rose leaues wrought together with suger and Hony, doth both comfort purge the belly. Steepe Rose leaues one night in vineger, anoint hote members places therewith, and also apply it to a hote stomacke, to qualifie the burning heate of it. Drinke the iuice of Roses with sweete conduit water, to loosen the body, to purge the blood, especially from choller, and to put away the kings euill. The Rosed Hony doth both comfort expell melancholy flegmatike matter, and taken with water wherein Fennell seedes haue bene sodden, and a little salt put thereto, doth purge the better. Clip the Rose leaues from the whites, boyle them in oyle of Oliues, sunne it in a glasse fiftie dayes: and this is the best oyle. Apply thereof to the liuer, to helpe the heate thereof, and the temples for the ach beating paine of the head, and to coole it. Vse Rose leaues in meate, for the heate of the stomake liuer. Mixe powder of Roses with vineger the white of an egge, apply it to ye temples, to take away the paine of the eyes, to restraine ye humors the shedding of blood into the veines of the eyes. Suger Roset is good for ye bloody fluxe, the cholerike vomitings, the faintnesse of the body, the cardiak passion. Gather the deaw that fallethon Rose leaues, and droppe it on the nether lid of the eye, to amend the blearednesse. Boyle drie Rose leaues in wine drinke it to amend the paine of the head, eyes, eares, and gums: and take the same in a glister, to amend the corruption of the bowels matrixe. Water of red Roses drunke, doth strengthen and coole the braine, heart, stomake and all inward parts, it strengtheneth the spirits naturall heate, and preserueth from rottennesse. To cleanse, drie and strengthen the sight of eyes, Take red Rose water one ounce, white wine a little, tutia one dram, aloes epatica and sugar candy, of ech twenty graines: mixe them together, drop it into the eyes. Drop Rose water with a litle suger into the eyes, for the exulceration of them, comming of heate. Drinke three ounces of the water fasting, to comfort the head. drinke sixe ounces, to take away the giddinesse of the head, and to strengthen the liuer. Smell to Rose water in time of the frensie, to prouoke sleepe. The iuice or infusion of the reddest Roses, or the decoction of them looseneth the belly gently without danger, and purgeth choller, and openeth the stopping of the liuer, and strengtheneth it, and is good for hote feuers and the Iaundies, the shaking, beating and trembling of the heart, discharging all euill corrupt humors in and about the veines of the heart, and is good to bee laid to the inflammation of the eyes and all other hote infirmities, especially S. Anthonies fire, or wilde fire. Stampe Roses small, and apply them to hote inflammations and swellings of the Paps and outragious heate of the midrife and stomacke, and also the shingles, S. Anthonies fire and Tetter. Boyle dried Roses in wine, and drinke it for the paine of the eyes, eares, and head, hawes, gummes, bladder, right gut and mother, either powred in by Glister, or anoynted. The yelow in the midst of the Rose, stoppeth the superfluous course of the flowers, and all other issues of blood, but especially the whites. The fruite eaten, stoppeth the laske all other issues of blood. The wilde Rose punned with Bores grease, is very excellent good for the Alopetias or red skall, or falling of the haire. The rough spongious ball of the wilde Rose bush, is of great vertue against the stone and strangury, bringing forth grauell and prouoking vrine. Anoynt the head with oyle of Roses and vineger, for the frensie. Drinke the hard seeds that are in the heads of Roses made into powder, with wine, to breake the stone. The red fruit of Roses with all his substance, stamped, streined, and dried, and made into powder, is excellent good for the running of the reines, and for the flowers both white and red, and so doe the red heads taken before they bee ripe or waxe soft, being kept drie and sodden in wine and drunke, which also healeth the bloody fluxe spitting of blood excellently well being well streined. Take i. ounce of the iuice of Roses, with two or three ounces of whey, and a little spikenard, to purge the body: or steepe the Rose leaues in whey, and presse it out with Hony, to purge without any griefe. The syrope of the iuice of Roses, and of Roses themselues, doth also purge gently. Roses condited with Hony, scowre, purge, and strengthen: but condited with suger, they skowre lesse: but strengthen more. Vineger of Roses staunch all inflammations hote burnings, and cutteth and skowreth, and strengtheneth. Roses, especially fresh, can abide no seething, for then their purging vertue is taken away by the fire. The iuice by seething measurably, is made more fine, and skowreth more mightily. The iuice of Roses is giuen from one ounce to two ounces. Seethe dried Roses in wine, and wash the head therewith for the headach, and likewise the eyes and eares for their paine. Vse the oyle in lynaments to coole hote burning vlcers and inflammations, and to any stripe or bruise. Vnguentum Rosarum extinguisheth the heate of the backe and reines, and procureth sleepe. Fewe cordials can want the helpe of Roses, or Rose water. The little yelowe tufts within the Roses in powder, stauncheth blood, kill wormes, and the kanker in the mouth, and Polyp in the Nose. The dried leaues of red Roses sodden in wine and applyed, is good for the head ach, and for the ach of the eares, eyes, gummes, fundament and matrixe, being vsed warme, they helpe all inflammations of the intrals, the griefes of the stomacke, and the holy fire: and so doth the vineger and oyle of Roses. The oyle is excellent good in the plague time against the burning Pushes. The water, oyle, or vineger, are good against all hote and cholerike griefes and for headach, &c. The Rose is chiefe of all flowers. Roses shreaded small and sodden in clarified Hony, doeth comfort, cleanse and dissolue, and digest flegmatike and thicke humors, and with colde water it stoppeth, and with hote water saxeth. Sugar and Roses incorporated together, doth comfort, binde, helpeth the bloody flixe, swooning, cholerike vomiting, and the Cardiake passion. Oyle of Roses helpeth the heate of the Liuer, headach, hote fierce agewes, and causeth sleepe. Rose water taketh away webs and foule specks of the face, and maketh the skinne subtill and thinne. The decoction of dried Roses in raine water, stoppeth all fluxes that come of colde causes. Their powder stoppeth bleeding at the Nose, and is good for the gummes and loose teeth. the white of an egge, healeth the sore ach of the eyes, and stoppeth the humor of blood that runneth into the veines of the eyes the swelling and falling downe of the matrixe. The conserue of Roses doth coole comfort the principall parts of the body, as the head, heart, stomake, liuer, milt reines, and is thus made: Take the buds of red Roses before they be ready to spread, cut away the white part, stampe them small in a stone morter, with a woodden pestell, put thereto thrise so much suger by little litle, keepe it in a close gally pot, set it in the sonne for a season, so do al other conserues. The water of the said leaues drunke by it selfe, or with suger, or with wine, is good for all the aforesaid purposes. The best way of distilling of Roses or any other thing, is in a stillatory of glasse set ouer a pot of boyling water, which is called Balneum Mariae: for those that be distilled in mettall, haue some smatch of the mettall, and are not so wholesom. The iuice of Roses is kept in a glasse, with oyle powred on it, when it shalbe occupied, the oyle is to be taken away with bombase or cotton dipt in it, it loosneth the belly, comforteth strengtheneth the stomake, and cooleth the liuer. Steepe Rose cakes in wine warme, and apply them to mitigate any ach. Roses dried in the sunne a little, may be kept three yeeres. For madnesse and heate of the head, stampe Housleeke and Roses with womans milke, and apply it to the forehead temples. Faintnesse and heate in the night, dip a cloth in Rose water, and halfe as much vineger, and hold it in thy hands, apply it to thy wrists and soles of thy feete. Eyes swollen, seeth Frankincense Roses in white wine, and wash therewith often. Nose bleeding, apply Rose water all about thy head necke with linnen clothes colde. Pricke to draw out, stampe the roote of red Rose tree, and apply it with linnen cloth. Head ach, stampe a piece of a Rose cake with oyle, and heate it on a tyle, and apply it to the nape of the necke, to bedward. Stomacke feuers, and all hote euils therein, vse conserue of Roses. Heart weake, drinke Rose water with suger, powder of pearle three or foure dayes: or drinke the water only, and cast thereof in thy face. Swooning, take powder of Roses with a reare Eg. Consumption, make a confection with the flowers of Borage Roses, with Aromaticall spices, and vse it. Eyes bruised and rupture of the tunicles, seethe red Roses in water, and apply them. Matrix with congealed blood, seethe red Roses in red wine in sommer, but in winter take the rootes of the tree, seethe it in water with Bursa Pastoris, and apply it often hote in a cloth. Put yong buds of Roses when they beginne to open into a reede as it groweth, and let it growe still, and so the Roses may be kept till you neede to occupie them, and then take it out, and put it into lukewarme water, it will be fresh as in May. Flowers to stop, mixe hony with red Rose leaues, the iuice of Planten and wheate flowre, and apply it plasterwise to the shares. Eyes inflamed, beate the white of an Egge with and vse it. Syrupe of Roses, take three pintes, Sugar, two pound, boyle them with a gentle fire till it rope, and keepe it in a glasse with some Sallet oyle powred on it. It slaketh thirst and drought in hote feuers, and comforeth the heart, stomacke and liuer, and suffereth no corruption to remaine in the heart. For a winde or chollike in the belly, toste a at the fire, and sprinckle it with vineger, and apply it as hote as may be suffered. Sleepe to cause, mixe oyle of Roses and of eache one ounce in red vineger halfe an ounce, and anoint therewith and apply it. anoint with the iuice of Roses and hony of eache like much. Belly loose, boyle with Cloues and Masticke in a double vessell, and drinke thereof, or vse powder of Roses. Feuer ephemera, drinke newe and anoint the pulses with oyle of Roses. Ache, or bruise or swelling, mixe crummes of sowre bread with vineger and Rose leaues, and apply it to heale it. and heate, steepe red Sanders and in one night, wash therewith. To keepe Roses all the yeere, gather them with a knife at euen, when they are halfe blowen, and set them in the ayre abroade all night, and in the morning put them into a earthen vessel well leaded, and stop it well, and couer it with drie sande, or put them into a reede as it groweth. Vnguentum Rosarum, take oyle of Roses iiii. ounces, white waxe one ounce, melt them together ouer seething water, and chafe them well together with Rose water and a litle white vineger, and vse it. Stampe Roses with Rue bitter Almonds with vineger, and rub the therewith that commeth of too much drinking. Tetters, wash in the mornings with Parsley water, and at night with Rose water. Matrix sores or rent, stampe dryed Rose leaues, and wash them with wine, and anoint a suppositorie therewith made of hares haires, and put it in, and wash it with a sharpe lotion. Bruses and cuts about the eyes, mixe powder of saffron halfe a dram, with oyle of Roses one ounce, and the yolke of an Eg, and apply it. Fundament chops, mixe oyle of Roses with Vermilion, and anoint. Nostrels stinke, boyle Roses with hony in wine, and put them in. Drinke oyle of Roses to moysten the belly, and coole the heate of the stomacke. Apply Rose oyle with vineger to all hote aches of the head, or else where, and to all outward heates. Drop the oyle into the eare for the ache and hote apostumes thereof. Wounds to heale, wash them well, and put in the oyle hote as may be suffered morne and euen iiii. dayes, and when it is well cleansed, apply a plaster of Melrosate, to heale it vp, (See Celondine. Digestion to cause, seethe a Rose cake in vergis, and apply it to the stomack in a bag of linen. Flux white, seeth red Roses in water, and wash the belly therewith. Tong wheales or bladders, seeth Roses and Violets in Rose water, and wash therewith. Whelks white or red, anoint them wt oile of Roses. Head ache, mixe vineger, the gleire of an eg of each like much, apply it with flaxe heards. Seeth it wt cloues mastike, and vse it against fluxes feeblenes of vertue. is good for swooning the cardiacke passion, for sore eyes oyntments for ye face, takes away ye wens superfluities. For chollerike fluxes, seethe them in raine water, drinke it, or apply a plaster of powder of Roses, vineger, and the white of an Eg to the pit of the stomacke. Or take the powder of Roses with a rere egge. To make oyle of Roses, seeth li. and a halfe of Roses in a double vessell till the thirde part bee wasted, and streine it and vse it. Some put Rose water in a glasse, and put Roses thereto with their dewe, and boile them in a double vessell, and sonne it, and this is the best way. Head scaulde mixe oyle of Roses Linseed and Oliues of eche like much, with powder of Lytarge, and apply it. Face salsflegme, eate powder of red Roses or drinke the water thereof. Swellings of great heate, beate the white and yolke of an egge (the strening put out) with oyle of Roses, and apply it with flaxe hards. Oyle of Roses, gather the brodest Roses in the morning before the dewe bee off of them pound, clip them small, and put thereto one pounde of the greenest oyle Oliue in a glasse fast stopt with lether, and hang it in the Sunne tenne or twelue dayes, then streine it and let it rest houres, then powre out the water, and put the oyle in a glasse, and euery ninth day stirre it in the morning. But if you would make it colde, then hang it in water so long as it shoulde haue bene sunned. The yellowe in the midst of Roses stoppeth the whites. But if it be for a Lord, put myrre thereto, anoynt therewith to heale it easily. Suger rosat, dissolue suger in Rose and seeth it well and cast it on a marble stone till it be colde and hard, then cut it in great pieces and keepe it. The like may be done with Violets, Borage, Buglosse, Rosemary flowers, &c. To take away heat of the face, beat the whites of egs, two spoones ful of sallet oyle, two spoones full of Rose water together, and anoynt therewith. It quencheth thirst in hote feuers, and the heat of the heart liuer, it resisteth corruption of ill humors, preserueth health. Conserue of Roses, stamp them with thrise so much suger. Mel Rosarum, seeth the iuice of Roses with as much hony. It co~forteth the stomacke, doth digest purge flegme in the stomack or veines. Manus Christi, melt suger in Rose water halfe a pound, seeth it til a suger be hard, then put in powder of pearles or precious stones, and lay it on a marble anointed with oyle of Roses or of Violets, or and vse it. Vnguentum Galeni, take white waxe one pound, oyle of Roses three pound, melt them together, and wash it well and often in colde water till it be white, but rather with vineger which is better. Mell Rosarum is made of seuen pound of hony, and one pound of Roses boyled meanely together, till it haue a sweete odour and red colour: it doeth comfort and cleanse, and may be giuen in sommer or winter after it is three dayes olde: for colde humors, take it with water that Fenell seede and three graines of Mastike haue beene sodden in. Sugar Rosat, stampe one pound of newe gathered Roses with foure pound of Sugar, and sunne it in a glasse thirtie dayes, it may be kept three yeeres. Fluxe to stop, eate one dram of Sugar Rosat with as much Mastike, and then drinke sodden with Mastike and Cloues. Oyle of Roses, fill a glasse with oyle and Roses, and boyle it in a vessell of water, or stampe ye Roses, and sunne it with the oyle foure dayes: it helpeth the chafing of the liuer and hote ache of the head, there must be two pound of Roses, three pound of oyle. Vineger of Roses, gather them before they be full blowen in dry weather, lay them on a boarde halfe a day, then put them into vineger close stopt houres, then stampe them and set them in glasses in the sunne all sommer, then streine it and vse it: if it be renewed with Roses euery tenth day it is the better, it may be made with wine either white, red, or claret. Conserue of Roses or other flowers, gather them before they spread, cut the red part from the white, grinde ye red in a stone morter, with a woodden pestell with thrise the weight of sugar, keepe it close stopt, it comforteth the stomacke, heart, and all the bowels, and is good against blacke choller and melancholy. Conserue of white Roses doeth loosen the belly more then red: doe so with all conserues of flowers. White Rose Wilde fire Wilde rose Whelkes Windinesse Wormes Wounds the seede with the flowre, or either of them drunke, are good against the stinking of scorpions. The seede, flowres, and whole hearbe of wilde Campians both red and white, are very good to the same effect. Drinke two drams of the seede to purge downe hote chollerike humors. RVbarbe: the roote is good against the windinesse, wambling, and weakenesse of the stomacke, and all paine thereof, and it is good against crampes, the griefes of the liuer and milt, gnawing and griping of the belly, kidneis, and bladder, the ache of the breastes and mother, the sciatica, spitting of blood, sobbing, hickit, the and laske, the fittes of Feuers, all stingings and venemous bitings, one dramme, taken in a Feuer with Hydromell for the same purposes: and with Syrupus Acetosus, against the griefes of the liuer and milt. With honied wine against the griefes of the breast. And drye without moysture, for the weakenesse and loosenesse of the stomacke. Rubarbe may be taken to purge one dramme with wheye, or any cooling drinke or potion to helpe hote Feuers, obstructions of the liuer and milt, the Iaundies, all issues of blood, inward burstings and bruises, crampes, and shrinkings of the synowes. Being tosted and dryed at the fyre, and drunke with the iuice of Planten or thicke red wine, it cureth the and all laskes. Eate one scruple of Rubarbe tosted at the fyre fasting euery morning, against spitting of blood. Rubarbe purgeth choller and flegme from the stomacke and liuer, cleanseth the blood, taketh away obstructions and griefes comming thereof, as the Iaundies, the Dropsie, swelling of the milt, rotten Feuers, and pritching in the sides. The oyle of Rubarbe is good for bruises, and ache, and shrinking of the synowes. Rubarbe may be preserued in good Hony, or in Fleawoort, or in Turpentine and Waxe, or in Waxe alone, or in Millit, or Hyrsse, or in Flaxe seede. It may bee taken with the pap of an Apple or Warden. Fluxe red, mixe Rubarbe and Sumache with the iuice of Planten, and drinke it. Take Rubarbe with as much Scamony with Ale or white Wine to purge the body. Liuer corrupt, stampe Liuerwoort, and seethe it in good strong Ale with some Rubarbe, and vse to drinke thereof. Life and health to preserue, vse to eate Rubarbe dayly.
