Bursten Cholicke Choller Crampe Dropsie Feuers Flegme Flowers to stop Fluxes RVe or herbegrace, both the leaues and seedes serue in medicine. The seedes are gotten in haruest, and may bee kept fiue yeeres, the dried leaues may bee kept one yeere. Eate of the herbe to mend the sight, and to put away winde, but it dulleth the veneriall act. Eate the leaues with dry figs and walnuts, as the surest remedie against deadly poison, if it be taken in time: or take Rue one ounce, Figs halfe an ounce, Iuniper berries halfe an ounce, Walnuts two ounces, Vineger foure ounces, mixe them all together, and swallow downe a little fasting, to bee free from poison and pestilent aire that day. Seeth Rue with figs in wine, to the one halfe, and drinke it: it doeth mightily helpe the dropsie, the paines of the brests, sides and loines, the Cough and griefs of the lungs, liuer and kidneis, so that thou haue no ague. Seeth Rue in oyle, and take it in a glister against the paine of the matrix and fundament. Stampe Rue with oyle, and apply it to the fundament or matrix against the strangling thereof, and the swelling of the great gut. Seethe Rue, Hysope, and Aniseedes in wine, and drinke it, and also foment therewith the grieued place to put away gripings. Stampe it with oyle and apply it to the nauell to kill wormes, Eate it after Garlike and Onions, to put away their smell. Seethe it in oyle, and anoint the body therewith before the comming of the fit, or else take it in glisterwayes to auoide the ague, put thereof into the eares to kill the wormes therein. Seeth it with Myrrhe in wine, and drinke it to put away the water betweene the skinne and the flesh. Mixe the iuice with oyle of Roses and vineger, and anoint the head therewith for the beating paine thereof. Seethe it in Fumiterie water, and giue it children to drinke for the small pockes. If children hauing the measels be not already blinded with them, hang the roote of Rue and Scabious about their neckes to defend them. Mixe Rue with oyle of Roses, vineger, and ceruse into an oyntment to heale all skabs, holy fire, running sores, and hote blisters. Apply Rue with Garlike, Salt, and Walnuts to the biting of a mad dog, or adder, to heale it. Eyes dull, steepe it in thy wine, or other drinke. Mixe Rue with and apply it to bleare and bloodshotten eyes, to cleanse and heale them merueilously. seethe it in wine, and apply it, or burne the stalke a little, and put it into the hollowe tooth. Stomacke colde, and for the palsie, seethe it with Castory, and drinke it. For stopping of the liuer and milt, and streitnesse in making water, seethe Rue and Fenell rootes in wine, drinke it, or powder of Fenell rootes with the iuice of Rue. Bloody fluxe, and straitnes of vrine, seethe it in wine and oyle, and apply it to the roote of the yarde. Teeming women may not eate Rue for hindering their conception. Anoint thee with the iuice of Rue, and cary the hearbe about thee, no venemous thing shall bite or sting thee. Plant Rue neare Sage, and Todes will not sit vnder the Sage, where they delight to be. Sprinckle water with Rue about the house to expel flies gnats. Sprinckle Pultrie with the iuice, and the Wesels such like vermine will not come at them. Weede not Rue with bare hands while the dewe is on it, for it causeth dangerous blisters and sores, itche, and swelling, the remedie is to anoint them with Salet oyle, or the Rue eaten greene, quencheth lust in men, and prouoketh lust in women, and sharpeneth the sight and wit. The water of the decoction thereof killeth fleaes being sprinckled. Eate Rue figs with sweete Almonds in the morning to withstand poyson. Eate two dry Walnuts, ii. figs, i. graine of salt, and xx. leaues of Rue to preserue thee both from poyson and pestilence. Seethe Rue and Dill seede in wine, and drinke it against the torments of ye intrals: the water doth the like, so doeth the oyle thereof in glisters. Seeth it in raine water, and drinke it to stop the white fluxe. Seeth Rue and figs in wine, and drinke thereof, and also anoint therewith for the dropsie. Stampe Rue with Bay leaues, and apply it to the swollen priuities both of men and women. Put the iuice into the eares to cease their ache. Mixe the iuice with alome, salt peter and hony, and anoint all breaking out, whelkes, pushes, scabs, and tumours. Anoint the head with oyle of the seedes of Rue, to cause a good memorie when it is weakened by humiditie or colde. Seethe Rue with dryed Dyll, and drinke it for the gnawing in the belly, the ache in the sides and breast, pursinesse and shortnesse of breath, coughes, inflammations of the lungs, the sciatica, and paine of the ioynts, and colde that commeth by fittes and courses. Stampe it with hony, and put it vp a good way into the matrixe against the suffocation of the mother. Apply it with hony to aches, and with Figs to the dropsie, and also drinke it for the same, or seethe it in wine to the one halfe, and rub it on for the same purpose. With flowre of parched Barley, it swageth the ache of the eyes, with Rose oyle and vineger it helpeth Bruise it, and put it into the nose against the bursting out of blood there. Rub the white morphue with Rue, Salt, Niter, Wine and Pepper to heale it. Apply it with Hony and Alome to heale the skuruie euill. Heate the iuice in the rinde of a Pomegranate, and powre it into the eares for their ache. With the iuice of Fenell hony, it helpeth dull hearing. Apply it with vineger, Rose oyle, and to hote chollerike running sores, and inflammations, tetters running sores to heale them, running sores in the head. Drinke ye parched seedes of Rue vii. dayes against pissing in Rue is good for ye windy watry dropsie, for them yt haue drunke Opiu~, or ye poyson called Aconitu~, and for ye chollike being also taken in a glister beneath. Seeth it in oyle, bathe ye bladder therewith against ye stopping of water, being also taken in a glister, also drunke. It is good for the Lethargie forgetfulnesse, for the goute or paine of the knees of watrish humors: it strengtheneth the guts, but it is not good for the chollerike folkes, nor for women with childe. Boyle it in water and drinke it to prouoke vrine termes, and to stop the laske. Stampe it and eate it, or drinke it with wine, against all poyson and venemous bitings, todestooles, mushroomes. The iuice is good for the same purpose, and against bitings or stingings of serpents, scorpions, bees, horners, and waspes, with wine, or stampe the leaues and apply them. Put the iuice with cleare hony into the eyes to cleare the sight. Stampe Rue with oyle of Roses, and apply it somewhat thicke to the crowne of thy head when thou art sicke: if thou sneesest within vi. houres after, thou shalt escape, or els not. Take blacke sope and aqua vitae, of eache one pound, sallet oyle halfe a pound, the iuice of Rue a quarter of a pound, seethe them with a gentle fire, and stir them till it be somewhat thicke, and apply it plasterwise vpon lether to the sciatica, three dayes and nights, and then apply newe if neede be, and be whole. Seeth Rue and Rosemary of eache two handful with Malmesey and common oyle, of eache a quart halfe an houre, and bathe therewith any lame member, halfe an houre euery night when thou goest to bed three weekes together, and then lay thereto the woolly side of a lambes skin, be whole. Put the iuice of Rue of red Docks into ye nose to cleanse ye braine. Stamp Rue, red Fenell, Wormewood, streine them with small white wine, drop it into the eyes when thou goest to bed to expell the superfluous blood, and to cleare them. Put the iuice of Rue with aqua vitae into thy eare, and binde thy head hard with a cloth, and lie downe with that eare to take away the paine, and to drawe out the humor that causeth the paine. Chewe Rue, and put it into hollowe teethe to take away their paine. Let women drinke ye iuice of Rue wt wine to purge them after their deliuera~ce and to expell the secondines, the dead childe, and vnnaturall birth. Rue eaten a certaine space, drieth vp naturall seede in man, Rue boyled in wine to the one halfe and drunke, is good for such as are falling into the dropsie. Eate it rawe, or candited otherwayes with salt or in meates, to cleare and sharpen the sight, so doeth the iuice put into the eyes with hony, and the iuice of Fenell, or by it selfe. The leaues stampt with Barlye meale, swageth the paine of the eyes. Mixe the iuice with oyle of Roses, or of Bayes, and hony, and vse it against the sounding or noyse in the eare, being dropt in warme. Stampe the leaues with oyle of Roses and vineger, and apply it to the Stampe it with Baye leaues to cure the swelling of the genitors. Mixe Rue with Pepper, Niter, and wine, to voide all spottes of the face and skinne. Mixe it with Hony and Alome to cure the foule skab and tetter. Stampe the leaues with swines grease, to cure the ruggednesse of the skinne, the skurfe of the head, the Kings euill, or hard swellings about the throte. Mixe Rue with hony to mitigate the paines of the ioynts, and with Figs to voide the swelling of the dropsie. Smell to the iuice with vineger to quicken thee in the Lethargie and drousinesse. Mixe powder of the roote with hony, to dissolue congealed blood and blacke bruises, being well rubbed therewith. Seeth Rue in oyle, or else steepe it long therein, and vse it to warme and chafe all cold members being anointed therewith. And anoint the region of the bladder to prouoke vrine, And the swelling and hardnesse of the spleene being anointed therewith. And in glisters it driueth out windie gripings of the guts. Stampe the leaues and apply them outwardly to the nose, to staunche the bleeding of it. Mixe powder of the seedes with fresh clarified butter and pitche melted together, and drinke it for inwarde bruises. Make powder of the seedes and of long Pepper, and sweete Calamus, and seethe it in white wine, and drinke it warme for the winde in the small guttes. stampe Rue, Wormewood, and Sage, ana one handfull with Barowes grease, and frye it and apply it, or straine it and anoint. Chollike, boyle Rue in Oyle or Butter, and receiue it in by glister, or eate Rue often, or vse the decoction thereof, especially with some Camamile. deliuerance of a dead childe, drinke Betony, Rue, and Hysope in hote water. Eares griefes, put in the iuice of Rue, or punne Eeles blood, with the iuice of Rue, and put it in. Falling euil, put the iuice of Rue into his nose, and he will rise straightwayes. Feuer quarten, stampe Rue, Sage and Tansy, of eache like much with wine, drinke it morne and euen. Goute, stampe Nep, Rue, Amydum, and powder of Pepper, Euphorbium, and apply it warme, or stampe one handfull of Rue with a great deale of salt, and put hony or mustard thereto, and stirre it well till it boyle, and apply it in a cloth. Headache, stampe Rue with hony and salt, and apply it, or seethe Rue and Fenell in water, and wash thy head therewith. For the hote euill, drinke the iuice of Rue with stale ale. Knees swolne, stampe Rue with hony and salt, and apply it. Lethargie, boyle Castory in water with the iuice of Rue and white vineger, and make it an oyntment, and rub the hinder part of the head well therewith, and fret it well in. For alienation of the minde or madnesse, drinke the seedes of Rue with vineger, and put the iuice of Rue into thy nostrels. Nostrels stinke, put in the iuice of Rue Mints, it doeth also helpe the braine. Noli me tangere, incorporate Myrrhe with the iuice of Rue, and anoint therewith. Reines ache, stampe Rue with salt and hony, and apply it often. Sciatica, stampe Rue and Nep of each like much, with a little Amidum, and the yolke of an Eg, and put thereto powder of Pepper, and of Euphorbium, apply it. Shingles, mixe Rue mints with oyle and vineger, and anoint to helpe it the same day. Speech to cause, put ye iuice of Rue into thy nose. Spiders biting, or crept into the body, drinke Rue with thine owne vrine, it helpeth all stingings of serpents. Stomacke griefes, drinke the iuice of Rue and Sage twise a day. Knees ache and swelling, apply Rue and Mints with salt often. Wormes, drinke Laurell, Rue, and Stonecrop with Ale or Wine. Eeares deafe, seethe Rue in vineger, and receiue vp the fume thereof. Pockes Measels in children, seethe Fumiterie and Rue in water drinke it. For vnkind heate in ye stomacke, eate Rue euery morning. Cods swolne, stampe Rue Wormewood with hony, apply it rawe, after wash it wt vineger. Oile of Rue, cut ye leaues small, put them in oile dayes, then seeth it to ye third part, streine it vse it. Eies watring, drop in the iuice with hony. Eares dul, boile Rue long in water, streine it drop it in, dip therein a tent, cast on it powder of Castory, and Piretrum, put it in warme, lie vp therewith houres, and be whole, or put in the iuice with Eeles grease, or drop in the iuice Speech lost, mixe the iuice with powder of Castori Piretrum, blacke Pepper, and Euphorbium, and holde little pellits thereof vnder thy tongue. Cough, seeth wormewood two handfull, Rue one handfull in good wine, drinke it. Reines ach, drinke powder of ye seedes with water hony. Goute paine, seethe the iuice with white hony, then put thereto the white of two Egs, streine it, anoint therewith. Goute to soften, stampe Rue, red Brier crops, and Broome flowres, of eache like much with Gilts grease, and boyle them well together and streine it, and anoint therewith. For ache and swelling in the knees, stampe Rue Louage with hony, and apply it. Skabs generall, anoint with the iuice of Rue, Celondine, Centory, wormewood. Wormes, stampe Wormewood, Arsmart, Rue, and frye them with butter or grease, and apply them, or drinke the iuice of Centory, Rue, and Wormewood with milke. For biting or stinking of an adder, stampe Rue with oyle, and apply it to the wound. Vomit to stop, mixe Mastike, Cummin, and Bayes with the iuice of Rue, and apply it, (See Garlike. Cods swolne, stampe Rue and apply it to haue present helpe. To heale a sore legge, stampe Rue and Sage very finely with the yolke of an Eg newe laid, and as much blacke sope as ye yolke, apply it: proued. Wormes crept into the body, drinke the iuice of Rue. To be deliuered of a dead childe, drinke water of Rue, with powder of two Date stones. heate Rue and Sage betweene two tyles or brickes, and apply it warme to thy temples, See in Planten, Mints. If thou wouldest rise quickely, put the iuice or powder of Rue into thy nose. Heart griefes, stampe Rue with Beane flowre and Ginger, and put it into a glasse Nose stinke, put in the iuice of blacke Mints and Rue into thy nose. Stitche, stampe Rue, Sage, and Wormewood, of eache a handfull, seethe them in ale till it be thicke, and apply it hote in bags one after another. of much drinking, stampe Rue Roses with vineger, and bitter Almonds, and anoint therewith, or rub thy temples therewith, and thy forehead. Head skurfe, seethe a handfull of Rue, and halfe an ounce of quicke Brimstone in good olde wine, and wash thy head therewith, being first washt with water, (See Fenell. Pissing blood, drinke powder of Rue with ale. Stinging, drinke Rue with thine owne vrine. Eyes dull, put in the iuice with scommed hony, (See Cummin. Eyes teares, put in the iuice with vineger and hony. Eyes blood, seethe it in wine to the third part, and drop it in. seethe it in wine, and apply it to the gummes. Squincy and losse of speache, seethe it in vineger, and then put thereto light Wheate Branne, and seethe it to a pulse, and suppe thereof. Fundament riftes and sores, stampe the stalkes with ordure of a man, and the yolke of an Egge, and apply it. Mother suffocate, seethe Rue, and stampe it with Hennes grease, and Goose grease, and apply it to the nauell and share, or seethe it and stampe it, and put it in as a pessarie, or take vp the fume thereof. Goute, seethe Rue and Sage with oyle, and stampe it and apply it hote. Or stampe it with Salt and Hony, and apply it. Seeth ix. handfull of Rue in sufficient wine, and drinke it before the fittes of any Feuer one houre. Apostume to breake, stampe Rue with Nuts, and apply it. put the iuice warme into the nose, or with as much white wine to purge the head. For stopping of the liuer and milt, the strangurie and fluxe, seeth Rue in wine with Fenell rootes, or powder of Rue with the iuice of Fenell and drinke it warme. Ache and fretting, stampe Rue with powder of Cummin, and applye it. Eyes dull, distill it with Roses, and put thereof into the eyes. An oyntment for the eyes, stampe Rue with as much Fenell by waight, and mixe them with Hony and Eyebright, and anoint the eyes therewith. Grinde Rue, Cummin, and Pepper, of eache like much by waight with Vineger and Hony, and vse it for the ache in the breast and in the reines. seethe Bay leaues and beries with Rue and Heyhoue in wine and water, and anoint therewith, or with Rue and vineger. Breath stinking, drinke the iuice of Rue with vineger morne euen, and put the iuice of Rue and blacke Mints, of eache like much into the nose. Eyes cleansing, stampe Rue and streine it with wine, and drinke it dayly, and also vse it in meates. Ache, stampe Rue as much Louage with hony, and apply it to voide the ache and swelling in the knee or else where. Palsie, boile Rue, Pellitory, Sage, Cammamile, Mustardseedes, and salt in oyle to ye one halfe, and anoint therewith, it will restore speach. Dropsie, seeth Rue Figs in wine and apply it often about the belly. Impost. to breake, drinke the iuice of Rue Scabious with powder of Coral a good draught, or drinke the iuice of Rue often wt wine. Venom of all sorts drinke ye iuice of Rue wt thine owne vrine, or with fasting spittle and vrine. Biting of an adder or dog, drinke Dragons, Rue Betony. Biting of a man, stampe Rue garlike wt hony, and flowre, apply it. Wormes crept into ye body, drinke Arnament Rue with thine owne vrine, or with fasting spittle vrine. Biting of an adder, seeth Rue, Fenel Betony in butter and drink it. Speaking in sleepe, drinke ye seedes of Rue wt vineger, put ye leaues into thy nose. Biting of a mad dog, stampe Rue with hony salt, apply it. and Rue with vineger, and drinke it hote. soueraigne medicine for aches, bruises or wounds of the legs, stampe Rue, Parsly, and Housleeke, of ech like much, and put thereto good store of whites of egs, and apply it without seething. Cough, seeth Rue, Centorie and Wormewood with good ale and Hony to the one halfe, and streine it drinke it: vse some Gentian therewith, if you can haue it. Rue is good for the stomake, it represseth lust, killeth the kanker, and prouoketh termes. Seeth Rue with water, and a fourth part of vineger, and drinke it for the fretting in the belly. Rue helpeth the griefes of the lungs, breasts and ribs, and the sciatica. Dropsie, seeth it in drinke, and anoynt with the iuice. Seeth it with the iuice of Fennell, and as much Hony as Rue, and vse it for the dropsie. Headach, mixe the iuice with oyle of Roses and vineger, and anoynt the forehead therewith. Hicket, stampe Rue, sage and wormewood, of ech like much, and seeth them with vineger and May butter, and apply a plaster thereof to thy breast, and let it lie foure and twentie houres, and doe so thrise: if you haue no May butter, take fresh butter without salt. To heale a kanker after it is cleansed, stampe Rue, and boyle it with Hony, and apply it. Headach, stampe Rue Iuy, with vineger and oyle Oliue, and apply it. Tongue palsie, boyle Rue with powder of mustard seed salt in oyle to the one halfe, and anoint the tongue therewith For swelling of the Knee, or hurt with a knife, stampe Rue with Hony and salt, and apply it till it be whole. Eares deafe, put in the iuice of Rue and sage. Stitch, clarifie a quart of ale, and put thereto sage and Rue, of ech halfe a handfull, and boyle them well, then take out the hearbes, and make it hote of Pepper, and put thereto a spoonefull of red saunders, and brew them well together out of one pot into another, and drinke it as hote as may bee suffered. Greene sickenesse, stampe Rue one handfull, red sage two hands full, and streine out the iuice, and put it to a pinte of hote Hony well clarified, and put thereto a great spoonefull of grosse Pepper, and stirre them well together, and giue thereof one spoonefull a halfe blood warme, morne and euen, and let her eate foure or fiue times euery day sixe or seuen Raisins of the sunne at a time, this will cure it, though it appeare not at the first: if the patient mend not at the ende of ten weekes, giue her this receipt againe. Belly ach, stampe Rue with stale ale, and drinke three spoonesful at once: or stampe Rue with salt, and drinke it with ale or water, and be whole. Vrine to cause, stampe Rue, Parsly and Gromell, and temper them with white wine, and drinke thereof, and be whole. Headach, seeth Rue and Fennell in water, and wash thy head therewith, and apply the hearbes plaster wise. Wormes to kill and expell, stampe Rue with thine owne vrine, and drinke it. Ach from the girdle downeward to vnder the feete, stampe Rue with blacke Sope, and a red Onion, of ech like much, and apply it. Teeth ach, stampe Rue seedes and seeth them with wine, and apply it. Belly ach, stampe one handfull, and seeth it in oyle and butter, and apply it in with a Glister. Breast to cleanse, seeth it in vineger, drinke it with suger. Gout, seeth sage and Rue in oyle, and stampe it, and apply it, to take away the paine by and by, and keepe thy body soluble. Headach, put the iuice into thy Nose. For the plague, and for wormes, take euery morning a top of Rue, a Garlike head, or halfe a quarter of a walnut, and one corne of salt thirtie dayes together, and be merrie. preseruatiue in the plague time, eate euery morning three little branches of Rue, a walnut, and a fig. Cods swollen, stampe Rue and apply it. If one haue taken Todestooles, let him drink Rue or Organy with Hony, or Organy with Hony and treacle, or mithrydate, with strong vineger, or oximell squillitike, or aqua vite, or eate raw garlike. Eare betle or wig, put in the iuice of Rue with aqua composita, lie downe therewith, and binde a cloth fast about thy head. Mithridates medicine against the plague, mixe twenty leaues of Rue with two figs, two wall nuts, and a little salt, be sure for that day. Skurfe to voyd, seeth a good handfull, with halfe an ounce of quicke brimstone in good old wine, wash thy head therewith, being first washt with warme water. Eate the leaues wt vineger, to preserue thee from the plague. Hicket, stampe it dissolue it in white wine, and drinke it. Vomiting in children, drinke powder of Rue, and halfe as much incense with wine, or syrope of Roses. Vuula fallen, boyle powder of Rue and Colyander seede in water of Mints, and hold therof cold in thy mouth. Ioynts griefes, stampe pulp of Reisins with greene Rue, and apply it. Blacknesse of wounds or sores, anoint wt the iuice of Rue Hony. Matrixe suffoc. stampe Rue with Hony, and dip woll therein, put it into the fundament. Stomacke belching, and winde in the body, distill the leaues in the midst of May, drinke three ounces of the water morne and euen. Chollike, drinke the iuce with the fat of a Peacocke and Hony, of ech like much with wine. Burning by occasion of cold, boyle the leaues of Rue in oyle, and anoynt. Falling euill, mixe halfe an ounce of the iuice, with i. dram of Castory, and put thereof into the Nose with wooll, when the party is fallen. Stomacke ach swelling, and the belly likewise, seeth Rue and Mints in sweete milke, and drinke it. Ach and Gout of the feete, stampe it greene with oyle, and anoint therewith against fire often. Side and breast ach, seeth it in wine, and drinke it. Eyes dull, put in the iuice of Rue and wormewood. Nost bleeding, burne it and blow it in. To kill lice fleaes, wash the place with the iuice, they will soone die. Eyes bloody, seeth Cummin in white wine, put thereto the iuice of Rue, and apply it. Belly ach, drinke the iuice with wine or ale: or eate the crops of it, or boyle it in wine, and apply it. Emerods, stampe it with louage, of ech like much, frye them with Hony, apply them. Senowes or veines bruised or hurt, or shrunke, boyle it with waxe oyle Oliue, and anoint therewith, and also apply it with wooll, (See Cummin. Breast stopt with much fatnesse, stampe a good quantitie, and seeth it long in vineger, and drinke thereof morne and euen. Eares wormes, put in the iuice of Rue, Sothernwood, wormewood, of ech like much fiue nights, and lay the substance on the eare. Belly swollen, stampe Rue and drinke it often with wine or ale. Head giddy, and turning, stampe it with vineger, and anoint. Flowers to cause, stampe it with as much Mugwort, with oyle de Baye, and put it in as a Pessary: prooued. For poyson drunke, or any venemous biting, drinke one dramme of the seedes Eyes dull, make an oyntment of the iuice of Rue and Fennell with Hony, and anoynt therewith, or eate them, and let thy breath goe into thine eyes. Fleaes to auoyd, seeth it in water, sprinkle the house with it. Ach, heate Rue and sage on a hote tyle, and apply it hote, (See Elecampana, Gentian, Betony, Figs. Belly wormes, stampe it with salt and streine it with ale and drinke it. Hands itch and wormes, wash them with the iuice of Rue, water and salt. Belly ach, eate it with Tansy, Sothernewood and salt, (See Mallowes, Mints, Rosemary. Belly swollen, drinke the iuice with wine or ale, (See Betony, Cummin. Seede to abate Senowes griefes shrunke Seconds Sickenesse generall Sides griefe RVsh: The seede of the common Rush parched and steeped in wine, stoppeth the laske and the termes, and prouoketh vrine, but being taken too much at once, it causeth headach. Oxen sicke, seethe the rootes in water, and giue it them to drinke. Flowers to stop Fluxe to stop Oxen sicke Sleepe to cause Vrine to cause Rosemarie. RO&semarie: Ach, seeth the flowers and leaues in water, and bathe therein. Appetite to cause, distill it with the flowers thereof, and vse the water in thy sawses with powder of Cloues and Cubebs. Seeth the leaues in water, and drinke it with thy wine. Seeth the leaues in water, and when it is colde, put as much white wine to it, and make sops therein, and eate them, it helpeth feeblenesse, and vnkinde sweats. Belly ach, boyle the hearbe with Pellitorie in wine, and drinke it. Seeth it with the flowers in wine, and drinke it morne and euen. Belly bound, seeth it with Pellitorie in wine, drink it. Bitings venemous, seeth it with pellitorie in wine, and drinke it. Blood to comfort, vse the decoction with the flowers, or vse them with rere Egges. Braine to comfort, seethe it in wine, and drinke it. Seeth it in wine with a fewe Cloues, and then drinke it, (See Stomacke. Breast cleansing, seethe it in water, and drinke it, for all the griefes of the breast, breath and lungs. Grinde Rosemarie leaues finely, and drinke it before the fit, for the feuer quarten. For itch and skab, drinke the iuice with water or wine nine dayes, and be whole. For the web and dulnesse of sight, anoint with the iuice and Hony. To bring the flowers, and comfort the thing conceiued, vse fomentation therwith, and also put it into the Matrixe. For tooth ach, rub them with the root, or apply the iuice. Sores colde, seeth the flowers and leaues with common oyle, and anoynt therewith. Seeth Rosemarie with white wine, and drinke it, for the feeblenesse of the braine and stomacke: or seethe it with white wine and Masticke, and Time, and vse it for the stomacke. For the Strangury, and stopping of the vrine, stampe the leaues and flowers in white wine, and apply it to the shares. The iuice, flowers, leaues, or rinde drunke in water or wine, cleanseth the stomacke from corruption, and keepeth the body in Make a Pasty of the flowers leaues with Graines and Pepper, and breake it into a gallon of new ale, and after it is three dayes olde, drinke thereof at euen hote, and at morne colde, to helpe the cough and hoarsenesse, Chollike, and Iliake. Vse the same drinke with Sage, Vineger, Cloues, Galingale, Graines, long Pepper and Setwall: it helpeth the Yexing. Rosemary helpeth all colde diseases in the body, the body being first purged, drinke the decoction of the flowers in wine or water first and last. Seethe it in white wine, and wash the face therewith, to make it whole, cleere, faire, and ruddie. Carry powder of the flower about thee, to make thee merry, glad, gracious, and welbeloued of all men. Keepe a cole of the tree in a linnen cloth, and rub thy teeth therewith, to auoyde all wormes and filth. For the colde, pose, and stopping of the head, take vp the fume of the barke, at the mouth and nose. Seethe the roote in vineger or wine, and let a thiefe wash his feete therein, and he shall neither rob, steale, feare, nor fright any man. Eate the flowers with bread and Hony fasting, against the falling sickenesse. Lay the flowers on thy bed, to keepe thee from all euill dreames. Seethe much Rosemary, and bathe therein, to make thee lusty, liuely, ioyfull, likeing, and yongly. Seeth it in milke with Sage, Margerom, Auens, Eyebright and Honie, and when you are bathed, anoynt your face and body therewith, to comfort the veines, sight, minde and heart, and for many other griefes. Distill it when it flowreth, and vse it in the sawse with cubebs in powder, to cause appetite. Stampe the leaues and apply them to a kanker, to destroy it for euer. Make a spoone of the wood, to giue thy broth a fine taste, and thy body health. Anoynt any venom, or poyson, or stinging, with Rosmary, to auoyde it, or to preserue the place from hurt thereby. For the colde cough, and the pose, Seeth it in water, and take vp the fume at thy nose, and wash thy head and mouth therewith. To prouoke appetite, and auoyde loathing, seethe the leaues in water, and drinke it with thy wine. For any sore or ach, seethe the flowes and leaues Burne it and the smoke thereof will driue adders out of their holes, or kill them. For griefe and heate of the stomacke, seethe the leaues in Well water, and drinke it colde with a litle of a Pomegranate: it so taketh away thirst. For the breath, and to open the pipes and cleanse them, burne the wood and take vp the fume. The flowres laid among clothes, keepeth them from mothes. For the cough and pose, seethe the leaues in water, and drinke it, or make a syrrop thereof and vse it. For the cardiake and swelling at the heart, make a drinke thereof with Rose water, or white wine: or else a syrroppe with Rose water or white wine, with the iuice of Parsneps, sugar, and the bone of a Stags heart, and vse thereof. To comfort the heart, seethe Rosemarie, and the flowres with and drinke it. Skinne cleansing, seethe the flowres with white wine, and washe therewith, and drinke thereof. Feuer: seethe yssop, sage, Rosemarie, and the rootes of Polipodie ana three ounces in a pottell of ale or beere to the one halfe: then streine it, and drinke a litle before thy fitte as often as neede is. Itche: Seethe halfe a pinte of white vineger with Rosemarie and Celondine ana one handfull, streyne it, and while it is hote, put in some white coprosse and vse to washe therewith. Mouth kanker: Seethe a sprigge of Rosemarie in halfe a pinte of ale, and scumme it, and put in as much Alume as a nutte, honie one spoonfull, and two spoonefull of Honiesuckle water, and vse it. Face to bee faire, and breath to bee sweete, seethe the flowres in white wine, and wash therewith, and drinke thereof. Emerods to heale, apply a plaster of ye leaues, the same helpeth the swelling of the fundament. Feuer quarten, and Intermissiue, drinke the iuice before the fit and be whole: or drinke the decoction of Rosemary, Sage and Lauender before thy fitte. To cleanse comfort the braine: seethe it in white wine, and receiue vp the fume thereof at thy nose and mouth, and hold a cloth ouer thy head. Haire to growe, anoynt with the iuice of Rosemarie, and let it drie in of it selfe. Iaundies: seethe Rosemarie in clarified Ale, and streyne it, and put in yellowe turmericke, saffron and sugar, and drinke thereof morne and euen. Sores: receiue Rosemarie stript from the stalkes, seethe it in running water to the one halfe, and then streyne it, and put in allume at your discretion, and vse it after it is sodden a little more, and washe therewith: and when you will heale it vp, put in English honie, and vse it dayly: prooued. Kings euill: Steepe it with Harts tongue a night in wine, and drinke thereof to put it away. The iuice of the roote and hearbe mixed with honie, and drunke, helpeth the dulnesse of sight, and purgeth grossenesse of humours. Vlcers harde: the roote bruised and mixed with honie, and applied, softeneth them speedily. The roote boyled with Pellitorie in wine, and drunke, softeneth the bellie, helpeth the payne thereof, and helpeth the bytings of venemous beastes and wormes. And in the same maner tempered with Mugwort, it prouoketh vrine and the menstrues. The flowers tyed in a faire linnen cloth, and sodden in wine and drunke morne and euen, auoydeth many griefes of the bodie, but especially of the pappes. The powder of the flowers drunke in warme wine, maketh the minde merrie, comforteth nature and blood, and preserueth manie from diseases, which otherwise woulde come. The smoke of the barke stoppeth the rewme, if the head bee holden ouer it. Appetite to cause: boyle it in water, and drinke it alone, or with Wine. The powder of the flowers eaten with reare potcht egges doeth greatly strengthen nature, and amendeth the blood. Drinke a good draught of wine made of Rosemarie morne and euen to cleanse the blood, and prouoke appetite, to expell all inner humours, and to helpe a great weakenesse. Boyle Rosemarie with wilde Peniroyall or Mints, in wine and oyle oliue, and anoynt therewith to cause sweate, and helpe the dropsie. Boyle it in wine with Rue and a litle pepper, and drinke it to helpe the falling sicknesse. Boyle it in wine with Pellitorie, and some gargle therewith to helpe the greatnesse of the Vuula. Seethe it with the flowers in wine, and drinke it morne and euen three houres before and after meate to helpe the Kinges euill, the harde fetching of breath, to open the pipes of the lungs, to cause easie spitting forth, to helpe digestion, to cease the gripings of the bodie, and to clense the blood. Fluxe to stoppe, Boyle the flowers in the strongest vineger, and binde it to thy Nauill. The decoction of Rosemarie helpeth the Iaundies, prouoketh vrine and menstrues. Rosemarie helpeth the Cough beeing taken with pepper and honie. The greene leaues of Rosemarie beeing bruised and applyed doe stoppe the Emerodes. Drinke wine of Rosemarie morne and euen three or foure houres before meate to stoppe the whites, and to heale the gnawing of the secrete partes, the Iaundies, shortnesse of breath, and to open the pipes of the Lunges, to helpe digestion, to resist poyson, to purge the blood, and auoyde stinking sweate, and couer thee well, and lie still: the like doeth the hearbe with the flowers sodden in wine. The water drunke, restoreth the speech, and serueth almost for all the diseases aforesaid. Rosemarie in drinke, or applied, taketh away swooning, trembling, swimming of the head, cleareth the colour of the face beeyng washed therewith, and cleareth the thinne filmes that couer the eyes. The decoction thereof with Dittander, or the water cleanseth and healeth rotten sores and woundes, as creeping sores, and Fistulaes, &c. Seethe Rosemarie in water and drinke it before exercise, and enter into a bathe, and drinke vnwatered wine after it to heale the Iaundies. The seedes thereof drunke in Wine, helpeth the falling sickenesse, and payne in the breastes. For the griefes of the stomacke: eate thereof daylie with bread and salte fasting. To cleanse and comfort the stomacke, and to make a sweete breath: take Rosemarie with the flowers, or without the flowers a handfull or more, Seethe it in good white wine a good space, and drinke it with a little Cinamome. To comfort the stomacke, seethe a good handfull with a quarte of Wine, and a fewe cloaues therewith, vntill it bee readie to burne, and vse often to drinke thereof. Stampe thereof and streyne it with Wine, and drinke thereof to open the obstructions of the Liuer and milte, it preserueth and keepeth health, beyng taken a weeke together at the Spring and fall of the leafe. An Electuarie to comfort the stomacke and braine, and to make a sweete breath: Take Sage two drammes, Rosemarie flowres one ounce and a halfe, of Cloues fiue ounces, Cinamom one ounce and a halfe, Nutmegs a scruple: Stampe them well with honie or sugar, make an Electuarie thereof, and take halfe a spoonefull in the morning, and drinke a little redde wine boyled with a little Sage after it, and vse the same daylie vntill you haue your purpose. An oyntment for the stomacke against the Cough: stampe three handfulles of Rosemarie striped downewardes, and boyle it with foure ounces of Capons greace till it bee greene, and the stronger it is, the better it is: then streyne it and put thereto halfe an ounce of fine powder of Maces, and vse it to the mouth of the stomacke warme. The ashes of Rosemarie doeth fasten loose teeth, and beautifieth them beeing rubbed therewith. Headache: Seethe Willowe toppes with a little Rosemarie in vineger, vntill the thirde part bee wasted, and washe the head therewith. Eyes to bee cleere: stampe Rosemarie one handfull, Balme one great handfull, streyne them with a quarte of ale, and drinke thereof morne and euen to consume the vapours that hurt the brayne and sight. Braine cleansing, and Nose stinking: chewe good store of Rosemarie leaues halfe an houre together before dinner and supper, and holde downe thy head. Headache: Seethe balme and Rosemarie ana one handfull, greene or drie in a quarte of milke as it commeth from the Cowe, and drinke it hote with powder of Nutmegges. To preserue from sweat: steep balme, Rosemarie and burrage in ale or beere twelue houres or more, and drinke thereof morne and euen. Heart to comfort, and to open the pipes, and to expell melancholie: vse conserue of Rosemarie flowres, put the flowres into a linnen cloth, and boyle them in faire water to the one halfe, and coole it and drinke against all euils of the bodie. To bee merrie and ioyfull, binde the flowres to thy right arme. To withstand all euill swellings of the bodie, eate the flowres with honie fasting. For the Ptisicke, boyle the flowres in Goates milke, and let it stand all night faire couered vnder the ayre, and drinke thereof. To keepe the face from breaking out: Seethe the leaues with white wine, and washe therewith. To auoyde euill dreames, put the leaues vnder the beds head. and vnkinde sweates, boyle the leaues in water, and when it is colde, put thereto as much white wine and make soppes therein, and eate them. Fluxe to stoppe, boyle the leaues in strong vineger, and applye them to thy wombe. Legges swollen with the Goute, boyle the leaues in water and applye them. To bee deliuered from all euils, boyle the leaues in strong vineger, and applie them to thy stomacke. For the Cough, Boyle the leaues in white wine, and drinke thereof. Youth to preserue, make a boxe of the wood, and smell to it. To withstande the danger of Serpents, put thereof in thy doores, or within thy house. To withstande poyson, make a barrell of the wood, and drinke all thy drinke out of it, and no poyson shall hurt thee. For losse of good smelling, and for one that cannot drawe his breath, Make fire of the wood and drawe in thy breath therewith. Feuers of all sortes: Drinke the iuice of Rosemarie, Sage, Mustarde, Vineger, and Triacle, ana like much before thy fittes thrise. Seethe Rosemarie and Rue, ana like much two handfulles in common Oyle and Malmesey, of eche a quarte, halfe an houre, and chafe any lame member well with a hote cloth, and then wash it therewith halfe an houre, and apply the woollie side of a Lambeskinne, and doe so three weekes at the least to bedwarde, and bee whole. Fundament swollen: Stampe Rosemarie and applye it warme in a cloth. For the Chollicke and paine in the side, Seethe one handfull in water, and temper your wine therewith, and none other water. Face spottes: Fill a glasse with the flowers and burie, halfe in sande, beeing stopped with newe waxe, and couer the vpper part, and let it rest so thirtie dayes: then streyne it, and keepe the water as a thing precious for this purpose. To preserue from the Gowte, Seethe the roots well in vineger, and washe therewith. Head colde: take vp the fume of the barke at the Nose. Madnesse and foolishnesse: Boyle the leaues and flowers in water, and bathe therein. Thirst great: seethe the leaues in water, and drinke it with wine of Pomegranates. Ptisicke: Boyle the flowers in Goates milke, and let it stande all night in the open aire, and drinke it. Toothach: chewe the roote, or hold the iuice in the mouth. Feuer quarten: stampe the flowers and leaues, take them before thy fits. Flowres to cause, seethe it in white wine, and drinke it, and apply pure honie and womans milke to the matrix as hote as may bee suffered. For all griefes, Seethe the flowers in water in a bagge to the one halfe, and drink it. Milke to cause, seeth it in broths and drinkes, and vse it. Stitch: seethe it with sage Rue, ana one handfull in white wine, and drinke it. Foolishnesse Fundament swolne Gnawing Gowte Griefes generall Heart to comfort Lamenesse Liuer stopt Lust to cause Madnesse Melancholie Megrim Memorie to comfort Menstrues Milke to cause Milt stopt Mirth to cause Rhewme Sinews Serpents to withstand Skinne to clense Smell lost Sores Sores colde Sores rotten Speech lost Spitting hard Stinging Stitch Stomacke to clense Sweat to cause Sweat stinking Sweat to withstand Swelling to withstand Swooning Teethach Trembling Vaines to comfort Venom Vlcers hard Vrine to prouoke Vuula great Weaknesse to helpe Whites to stop Wormes Yexing Youth to preserue Saffron. SAffron is good in medicines against the diseases of the breast, lungs, liuer and bladder. And in meates it is good for the stomack, and causeth good digestion. Sodden in wine and drunke, it preserueth from drunkennesse, and prouoketh lust. And taken in sweete wine, it causeth one to be long winded, and easie. Mixe it with womans milke, and apply it to the eyes to preserue them from the falling downe of humours, and from the small pocks and mesels, and to stop the fluxe of blood of the same, or bloodshooting. It is good also to be laid vpon inflammations, cholericke impostumes, and wilde fire: and is good to bee mixed with all medicines for the eares, to mollifie all hardnesse, and to ripen all rawe swellings. The root drunke in wine, prouoketh vrine that is stopped, and commeth forth by drops, and expelleth the grauell and stone. If a woman anoynt the corners of her eyes with oyntment of Saffron, and that her spittle doe afterwardes sauour therof, she is not barren. For the pocks in the eyes, to preserue the sight: steepe Saffron in a sawser full of faire water, and when it is yellow, drop thereof into the eyes. Mixe three drams of Saffron, and one dram of Opium with the yolks of foure new laid egs, and apply it to griefes of the Gowte to asswage it. Mixe fine powder of English Saffron with fine black sope, and apply it to the nauell with a piece of lether to expel the vrine within one houre. Drinke fine powder of half a peniworth of Saffron, with a spoonful of Malmsey often to help the chollicke. Smell to Saffron in the frensie to prouoke sleepe: and vse it also in meats to prouoke sleepe. Apply Opium, Saffron and Mandrag. to thy head to prouoke sleepe. For turning and dasling in the head: take Opium and Saffron, of eche a dram, of roses drams, apply the same as a plaister with vineger. Saffron strengtheneth the heart and intrals beeing taken with measure, so it is profitable for the stomack, and helpeth digestion. It purgeth the blood, withstandeth poison, is good against the plague. Some rost it in an egshel with triacle, mustard, other spices, and make it into an Electuary to bee taken to driue out the plague and inward poyson. Vse Saffron in meates and drinks to prouoke vrine, helpe the Iaundies, and driue downe the termes, but especially the roote thereof with Malmesey or Muscadell. Saffron is good for the vlceration of the stomacke, breast and kidneys, the inflammation of the liuer, lungs and bladder. Saffron is good for the palsie members, and all hardnes of the sinews: and therefore is Oxycroceum made thereof for all the aforesayde. Saffron, with womans milke anoynted, stoppeth the running of the eyes. Put powder of Saffron with oyle of bitter Almonds into deaf eares to helpe the hearing. graines of Mythridatum, keep it in a close glasse, and take thereof in ye morning Many goodly medicines be made of Saffron, as Diacucurma against the Iaundies, and it is put into many antidotes and plasters, as Oxycroceum, &c. and with ointments against the palsie and gowte. Saffron, Opium, milk and Rose water tempered together, doth make a goodly medicine against the paine of the feete. Stampe Saffron with beete leaues, and apply it to the forehead to prouoke sleepe. Saffron is good against all manner of swellings in the breast, wind in the bellie and guttes, and stopping of the mouth of the Matrix, eyther in oyntment or drinke. It is a good cordiall to be vsed in meats of melancholy persons, to make them merie and glad: it causeth a good colour in them that vse it. Saffron, with the white of an egge driueth away all inflammations, but especially of the eyes. It helpeth the suffocation of the mother, it is excellent good for the exulceration and going off of the skin of the stomacke, lungs, liuer, breast, kidneys and bladder: it is also good for the Cough and the Plurisie. It is good for weake braynes that cannot well beare drinke. It healeth flegmatike diseases, and the drousinesse of the Letargie. It is not good to take of it too much at once, but vsed moderatly, it profiteth much. Warme honie, and Cowes milke, of eche halfe a pinte, with sixe graines of wheate flower, and two penie weight of beaten Saffron, and applye it to the stitche of the side to haue present helpe. For a great payne and stitche in the side: Seethe halfe a pounde of milke, with two ounces of honie, one ounce of Wheate flower, and one penie waight of Saffron, and applie it. Chollicke: Make powder of Saffron, the roote of Fiue leafe, and long pepper, and drinke them with ale hote. Dropsie: stampe goose dung and Saffron, and streine it and drinke it first and last. Mixe Saffron with horse greace, and anoynt the hote Gowte therewith. Drinke whole Saffron sodden in Wine, to preserue from death, and to driue away sicknesse at the beginning. Swellings: seethe Cummin, Oatemeale, and Saffron in sweete milke, and applie it to all swellings. to cause, Drinke powder of dried salt with Saffron, a good quantitie with white wine. Headache of flegme, to drie the moysture of the brayne, and to warme the stomacke, take aqua vitae sixe drammes, buglosse water foure drammes, beaten Saffron and Cinamome, of eche one penie waight, steepe them together foure and twentie houres, and drinke it. Drinke a penie weight of beaten Saffron with strong drinke fasting, to comfort the braine and stomacke, and to stop vomiting. Heart feeble, and emptinesse, vse hote Saffron in thy drinke, especially with aqua vitae, and euery day about two a clocke after noone, put to the yolke of a reare roasted egge, a litle Saffron and salt, and suppe it of to comfort the heart and the whole bodie. To strengthen the heart, and al the whole bodie members, quench fine gold nine times in the best aqua vitae, put thereto Saffron one dram, and Cinamom two drams in powder, and let it stand foure daies in a close vessel, and shake it often: then drinke half an full euery day with as much good wine morne and euen. To refresh the body, stew an old henne with a goblet of wine, and a dram of beaten Saffron in a pottell pot in a vessell of seething water, and vse it. Iaundies, drink powder of Columbine seeds, and Saffron, of eche a penie weight with wine, water and vineger, of ech one full, and drinke it first and last. Eyes hurt, grinde Saffron with womans milke, and apply it. Host of the lungs, drinke Saffron sugar with the iuice of coleworts, (See in Coleworts. Liuer chafed, stampe marigoldes with Saffron, and drink it with wine morn euen. Flowers to cause, (See in Germander. Belly bound, mixe as much May butter as a walnut with Saffron, and anoint the bellie therewith, and apply it to the nauel. Flowers to stop, drink powder of coliander, sanders, Saffron with red wine in the morning. Iaundies, (See in Rosemary, Milt griefs, (See in Harts tong. Saffron in all meates prouoketh sleepe. Iaundies, dissolue Saffron in water, and drink it to heale it by and by, or apply Saffron to the nauil. Saffron in powder with Malmesey morn and euen, or with sallet oyle, triacle, and malmesey, of ech a halfpeny worth. Chollick, drink a halfpeny woorth with a spoonefull of malmesey in powder, (See Bayes, Garlick. Ptisick, dissolue Saffron one scruple, musk halfe a grain in good wine, and drink it. Apost. to ripen, mixe the yellow part of cocks dung with the yolke of an egge, and a litle Saffron, and apply it. Plurisie, and Ptisick, take gum Armoniack, a dram and a halfe, Saffron halfe a dram, make it into fifteene pilles, with Oximel squillitike, and take euery morning one. houres, then heate it, and cleanse it, and vse it. Saffron causeth a good colour, resolueth apostumes, is good to be anointed on the shingles, but it causeth headach, and hurteth the head: it causeth an easie breath, and comforteth the heart and stomacke, and is good for the milt, and prouoketh lust and vrine: a certain woman drunke two drams in her trauel, and had speedie deliuerance. Goute, mixe Saffron with yolks of egges, rosewater, and oyle, and anoynt therwith cold with a feather. Eies dim and dropping, drop it into the eyes with rosewater womans milke. Mixe it with rosewater, womans milk, and Opium to take away the paine of the feete. Stampe it with beet leaues and apply it to the forehead, to cause sleep. Saffron is good against all swelling in the brest, wind in the belly, and guts, and stopping of the mouth of the matrix in oyntment or in drinke. It is a good cordiall, and helpeth them that are melancholie, and reioyceth the heart. Iaundies black, greene, or yellow, make fine powder of Iuory foure drams, turpen+tine sixe drams, Saffron foure peny weight, and drink therof with stale ale morne and euen: but for the black Iaundies, purge melancholy first. Chollick, stamp Saffron and thyme, and streine it and drinke it with good ale to haue present helpe. Rising vnder the stomacke, seethe powder of long pepper, graines, Saffron, ginger, anniseeds, lycoras, and sugar in good ale, till it be thicke, and drinke it, and be whole. SAgapenum, or Serapinum: drinke one dram to purge tough and slimie humours, and all grosse flegme and choller. It is also good against all olde and colde diseases that are hard to cure, it purgeth the braine, and is good against all griefes of the head, the Apoplexia and falling sicknesse, cramps, palsies, shrinkings of the sinewes, taken in the same sort, and for shortnes of breath, the cold, and cold cough, paine in the side and breast, and cleanseth the breast of all cold humours: it cureth the hardnesse, stoppings and windinesse of the milt, being also applied outwardly in oyntment or plaster: and is good against the shaking off old and cold feuers drinke it with honied water to prouoke termes, and to expell the dead birth. Drinke it with wine against all venemous bitings and stingings. Soke it in vineger to scatter and dissolue all harde, old and colde swellings, tumours, botches, hard lumpes, &c. about the ioyntes. Mixe it with all oyntments and plasters that are made to mollifie and soften. It cleareth the sight, and at the beginning it taketh away the haw or web, and all spots or blots in the eyes, being dropped in with the iuice of rue, and for their bloodshooting dimnesse, comming by grosse humours. It is a precious gumme, the best shineth through darke in colour yellow without and white within. Apoplexia Apostumes Bytings venimous Braine griefes Breast griefes Breath short Botch Colde Cough Crampe Dead childe Eyes griefes Falling euill Feuers colde Flowers stopt Hardnesse SAge sodden in wine and drunke, stayeth excessiue Fluxes, and the termes staying, it draweth them downe, but too much running, it stayeth them. Seethe it with wormwood, and drink it to stop the bloody fluxe. Vrin and termes stopt, seeth the leaues and stalkes together drink it. Palsie: seeth it in wine drinke it, or apply it. Seeth it in water, and drinke it for the gout falling sicknes, and especially for the dropping of the vrine, being both drunke applied to the bellie, foment with the decoction of it, for the strangurie, bloody fluxe, and to clense the matrix. Boile it in wine with mullin, and sit ouer it hote in a close stoole, to send vp the fundament that is fallen: Seeth the leaues stalks in wine, and wash ye itch of the priuities therwith, sit ouer the hot broth for the itch of the fundament. Mixe the iuice with hony, and wash filthy wounds therwith to clense the~. ounces of the water morn euen to amend ye griefes of the liuer, to auoid the cough, to send down the dead yongling. Drink it with wine to procure appetite, to strengthen the stomack womens natural places. Drink it by it self for the pain in the sides, the shaking of the hands the palsie: and also bath them in the same water. ounces of it morn euen to break any inward impost. to comfort the brain, to take away ye distillings of the head, to comfort a hot liuer, put away the frensy. Mix ye same water with peacoks dung to stay the fresh bleeding of wounds, being bound about with mosse cotton. Eat iii. leaues of Sage in the morning to be free that day from al euil aire. Seeth Sage in wine drink it for the health of the whole body, to expell poison, the cough, the plurisie, to warm the liuer matrix, and to driue out the stone menstrews. Vse the decoction of it to clense the intrals to help the bloody fluxe. Vse pouder of it as a sawse wt meats, it is better then al strange spices aromatikes. Seeth Sage in water, wash thy head therwith to make thy haire black, to heale the skurf, vlcers, venemous bitings. Sit in the decoction of it to help the strangury, to prouoke vrin, take away the pain in the bloody flixe other diseases: and for the skab swelling of the priuities. Wash thy hands in a lauer, wherin is put some Sage, let it dry in without wiping against their shaking. wine drink it to prouoke vrine, break the stone, to comfort the heart, and asswage headach. Let women with childe eate it to close vp ye matrix, to cause their fruit to liue, to strengthen ye same. Let women drink the iuice to become fruitful in procreation of children. Drink the iuice with hony against spitting of blood, vomiting of blood, for it stoppeth the fluxe blood incontinent, being taken Seeth it in water, and drinke it to cure the cough, the stopping of the liuer, pain in the side. Seeth Sage in wine, bathe or wash thee for the manginesse and skurfe, and itch of the priuie partes. Bake a loaf ful of Sage, and apply it to the eares to heare wel. Seethe Sage and drinke it to prouoke the flowres, apply it also to the Matrix. Sage is good for the palsie, it comforteth the sinews brain. leaues in the spring and sommer with bread and butter, but in winter vse as many leeke blades vnset, and drinke a good draught of ale after it to preserue health. Bruse Sage and put it into a litle bag, and put it into a quart of wine all night, and then strein it and vse it as Sage wine to consume flegme, and to comfort the brain and sinewes. Make Sage ale in like maner, or wash Sage leaues, put them into the bottome of a vessel at the clensing, and drinke thereof after it is three or foure dayes old: for euerie gallon two handfull of Sage is sufficient, and it is as good as Sage wine. Sage and Rue steeped in drinke, are good against the infection of the plague. If a woman drinke a little Sage with a little salte and sugar foure dayes before and after the vse with her husband, and the man doing the like before procreation, without doubt conception followeth. Mixe halfe an ounce of Sage with clarified honie, and eate it fasting to stop vomiting or spitting of blood comming from the breast, lunges or stomacke. Sage prouoketh vrine, cleanseth flegme, expelleth winde, dryeth vp the Dropsie, helpeth the Palsie, strengtheneth the sinewes, and purgeth the blood. Seethe Sage with running water, roch allom and woodbine leaues, to kill the kanker in the mouth, to quench the great heate, and burning, stinke, filth, and matter that commeth often through corruption of nature or Meretrix manner, in the secrete partes of men and women, which is holpen by putting thereto a little Aristolochia rotunda in powder. The broth wherein the leaues and branches are sodden, driueth forth vrin, the termes and birth. Drinke two cyaths of the iuice with an ounce of honie fasting, to stop the spitting of blood, and for the Ptisick exulceration of the lungs, which is a consumption. Take spikenard ii. drams, of the seed of sage parched, beaten, and searsed, fourteene drammes, of pepper twelue drammes, mixe altogether with the iuice of sage, and make pilles thereof, and take three fasting, and as much at night, at ech time a dramme, and drinke water after it for the griefes aforesaide. Women that haue bene long without children by drinking tenne ounces of the iuice with a grain of salt, a quarter of an houre before accompanying with their husbands, haue conceiued at that time: proued. Dropsie: distil Sage, centorie, and water cresses, of eche like much, and drinke the water first and last. (See Rye, Ruc. Flowres stopt: drinke Sage with Malmesey or honied wine. Frensie: drink the iuice of Sage, Sothernwood, and marigoldes fiue dayes. stampe Sage leaues with anniseeds, and seeth them in white wine and apply it. Madde: seethe Sage, marigolds, sothernwood, and branne, and drinke the broth: if a man be mad sodainly, let him drinke Sage, marigolds, and sothernwood with wine fiue dayes. Speeche lost: drinke Sage with water, or drie Sage in an ouen, and vse the powder with brothes, and drinks. For any gathering of impostumes or humours: drinke triacle with the decoction of Sage or yssope. Lame members: holde them ouer ye decoction of Sage. Sage in bathes causeth sweat, especially with peniroyall, mugwort and fennell well sodden: and then the water also applied with cloth, and so it healeth cold members. Tongue hote and bitter in the Iaundies: laye Sage in colde water three houres, and stroke thy tongue therewith. Eares dull: fill a loafe full of Sage, and bake it, and cut it through the middest, and apply it hote three or foure times. with as much salt in paste to coles, and rub them with the powder of it. Side paine belly dropsie, palsie, drinke Sage with wine a litle warmed. Iaundies, seeth a hen that hath yellow feete in white wine with Sage, Cummin, and saffron, and eate ye flesh drinke the broth. Dropsie, bake Sage great store with hysope chopped small in wheate paste, and breake it into ii. or iii. gallons of ale that is good, or else good wine, and after it hath stood Biting of a mad dog, stampe Sage with one peniworth of Treacle, and drinke it with milke or ale, and vse it, be letten blood. Ringwormes tetters, seethe Sage and alome in smithes water, wash therewith. seeth Sage Piretrum in vineger, hold it in thy mouth hote as may be suffred. Itch, seethe it with Egrimonie in raine water, and wash therewith. Flowres and seconds stopt, seethe it and drinke it, or apply it. Palsie, seeth the leaues in wine, and drinke it, and apply leaues dayly. For the strangury, the fluxe, and to clense the matrix, vse Sage in sauses, sit ouer ye decoction thereof sodden in water. Poyson venom, seeth Sage in wine or ale, drinke it Stomake griefes, to cleanse ye body, drinke ye iuice of Sage wt water hony, or vse to eate it. Itch, wash with the iuice of Sage. Ach of the stomack, sides belly, drinke Sage in wine wt a litle wormewood, it is good also for the palsie dropsie. Ache of the head stomacke, drinke the iuice of Sage with ale. Hoarsenes, stampe ye crops of Mints, Sage, Fiueleafe with Ginger Licoras, seeth them in stale ale, streine it drinke it. Palsie, stamp Sage, Rue, Pellitory, Mustardseede, Camamile and salt, boyle them in oile to ye one halfe, anoint therewith: it wil restore speeche. Head hands quaking, take the leaues and rootes of Sage Primrose, of eache like much, Mustardseede and Bay leaues, of each like much, stamp them mixe them with May butter, and fry it streine it, anoint the necke, sinowes, ioyntes, veines, and hands therewith. Palsie taking one side, drinke good store of Sage water, and rub thy temples veines therewith, and looke that thou haue great store of mustard Sage leaues stamped together, Fenell seede burned, a litle vineger, and make them lukewarme, and apply them to thy side, head, temples, armepits, and wash thrise a night, and on the morowe eate Sage and sharpe mustard together, till thy eyes water: if any thing helpe this will: but if the palsie be in one side of the head onely, apply it thereto all night, or to any other member, there is no better medicine. Dropsies of all sorts, take ix. red Mints, crops of blinde Nettles, and ix. crops of Sage, stampe them and drinke them with stale Ale morne and euen, ix. dayes. Palsie, seethe Sage, Rue, and Castory in wine, and drinke it. Yard chafed, wash it with wine that Sage was sodden it. plaster for the feuer, stampe ii. shiuers of sowre bread tosted with a pint of vineger, Sage and Aniseedes of eache a handfull, heate it and apply it to thy stomacke hote as may be suffered. Yard sores, wash with wine of the decoction of Sage. Frensie, stampe Sage, Marigolds, Sothernwood, drinke it with ale or wine morne and euen vi. dayes. For all euill about ye heart stomacke, seethe Sage Mints of each like much in white wine, drinke the wine and apply ye herbs, do so vi. dayes morne euen. Digestion to cause, seethe Sage, Rue, Pepper, Cummin with hony, eate euery day one spoonefull fasting. Stitch, seeth ii. or iii. handful of red Mints, one handful of Sage crops in running water to the one halfe, apply it hote in a bag as often as neede is. Feuer, seeth Sage Bay leaues of each halfe a handfull in a quart of clarified oe to the one halfe, then streine it put halfe a sponefull of pepper to it wt sugar, and drinke it before ye fit: proued, (see Rue. Breath stinking, rub Sage betweene thy hands, put it into thy nose, and let it rest there a good while a fortnights space, especially in the mornings. Gums impost. chop red Sage and Rosemary small, heate them with a litle hony, apply them to the sore tooth to ease the paine. Speech to restore, put ye iuice of Sage Primrose into his mouth. Falling euill, drinke the iuice of Sage herb Iohn gathered on midsommer morning before sunrising, anoint ye temples therewith, and fast bread water on midsomer euen. Felon, stamp Sage wt Castile sope, apply it as a plaster, when it is broken, stampe great reasins, the stones taken out, apply them. stamp ye leaues of Sage Rosemary wt a litle hony apply it warme: proued. Chollike, boile aqua co~posita vineger, ana vi. sponefull wt Sage Rosemary, ana one handful betweene ii. dishes, then dip a great dry tost therein, lay the herbs on it, a cloth on it, so apply them a little vnder ye griefe as warme as may be suffered, lie downe i. houre: proued. Flowres seconds to cause, seeth Sage drinke it apply it to ye matrix. Biles, felons, vncomes, stampe Sage with May butter, bores grease, wheate flowre, fry it, apply it to ripen, breake, draw it, (see Rue. S. Ant. fire, stamp Bur rootes wt Sage leaues apply it. Speech lost in sickenes, hold ye roote of Sage Primrose in thy mouth. Palsie, vse Sage, Primrose, Castory, Lauender Tansy wt a good piece of greene coprose a litle hony, streineit vse it, (see Primrose, Bursa Pastoris. Feuer in ye stomacke, seeth a good handful of Sage wt as much Otemeale in water yt runneth Eastward, i. sponeful of hony, scum it make it into pottage with a halfe peniworth of whole saffron, when it is thicke, eate a good messe wtout bread, drink not of ii. houres after, do so morne and euen. Pissing bed, (see Garlike. Teeth yellow, chop one handful of Sage wt as much salt, put them into past bake them dry, rub therof wtin a linen clout. Sweating sicknes, clarifie a quart of ale, put therto Sage Sorrel of each vi. crops, stamped and streined, put to it a qz. of a li. of sugar, seeth ii. or iii. walmes no more, drink thereof as hote as may be suffred, now then when thou feelest thy self faint, take as much Treacle as a beane: proued. Ache, wash ye place wt the decoction of Sage Auens often sodden, of eache like much in water. Burnings, stampe Sage royall with salt bacon, apply it, (see Betony, Rosemary. SAint Iames wort, it hath a speciall vertue to heale wounds, wherefore it is good for all old wounds, fistulaes, and naughty vlcers. The iuice gargled, helpeth all inflammations or swellings and impostumes of the throte. It healeth felons, fistulaes, moyst sores, venemous scabs, tetters, cankers, ringwormes, &c. Fellon Fistula Impostume Inflammation Kanker Mouth griefes Ring worme Skabs Sores Swellings Tetters Throte greefes Venom Vlcers Wounds Iohns wort. SAint Iohns wort with the flowres seedes boyled drunke, prouoketh vrine, and helpeth the stone in the bladder, expelleth the termes, and stoppeth the fluxe. Cast the powder of it into naughtie wounds, vlcers festred, old and rotten sores to cure them. Vse the water, iuice, syrupe or powder, for the sciatica. It is good for cut sinowes and casting of blood. Drinke the seedes with wine to driue foorth the stone, it is good against poyson. Great S. Iohns wort, or square S. Iohns wort, or S. Peters wort, drinke ii. drams of the seede with honied water a long space, it cureth ye sciatica. Wou~ds to heale vp, seethe the leaues in wine, and wash them therewith. Drinke S. Iohns wort with wine to cure ye plurisie. Shingles, bruise it and apply it till it looke white or red. Madnes and melancholy, burne it with greene Iuniper Frankincense in thy chamber. Bewitched, or inchanted, or forespoken, apply it with Treacle to the reines of the backe: it stoppeth fluxes. Drinke the herbe or decoction of it in wine or water, against all fluxe of the belly white or red. For carbuncles, and poyson, and venemous bitings, stampe it and apply it to draw out the poyson. balsam, take oyle oliue one pint, S. Iohns wort, Betony, Centory, Selfeheale, ana one handfull, stampe them and mixe them well together, and let them distill in a glasse all sommer long, then presse it out. It is most noble to cure wounds of all sortes, by onely anointing them morne and euen. It expelleth humors, and is wonderfull in fractures, bruises, and all such like. Drinke water of it ii. or iii. ounces at morne, noone, and euen, wt powder of the roote of Peony for ye falling sickenesse. It stoppeth al bloody fluxes, and kept in ye house, it suffereth no wicked spirit to come there. Bewitched from coeating with the wife, eate or drinke S. Iohns wort with Treacle vi. dayes, and also apply the hearbe with Treacle to the backe and genitors. Carbuncles Conception Demoniake Falling euill Fester Feuer Flowers stopt Fluxe SAllow, willow, or withy: the leaues barke do stay the spiting of blood, vomiting of blood, and all other fluxes of blood and the termes, being boyled in wine and drunke, and so they appease the paine of the synowes, and restore againe their strength, if they be nourished with ye fomentation or naturall heate thereof. Stamp the greene leaues very small, apply them to the priuie partes to take away the desires to venus. The ashes of ye barke mixt with vineger, causeth warts to fall off. It taketh away ye hard brawnes or skin of the hands or feete that commeth by labour, and ye cornes in the toes or fingers, being laide to. Stampe the leaues and streine them with wine, drinke it with a little pepper against the Iliake passion. The long buds or cats tailes that hang downe being sodden in wine drunke, are good against spitting of blood, and so is the barke. The iuice gathered when the tree flowreth, is good to clarifie the eies, and to take away the darknesse of them. The iuice of the leaues barke mixt with oyle of Roses warmed in the rinde of a Pomegranate, is good to be put into payned eares. It cleanseth away skurfe, mendeth ye defaults of ye skin. The seede broken is good against spitting of blood, so is the barke. The broth of ye leaues barke is good to bathe the gout withal, to driue away skurf scales. The iuice is to be gathered by cutting of ye barke whe~ it flowreth. The dryed iuice thereof is most excellent for the same purpose. The barke hath like power with the flowres and leaues, and is of a drier complexion. The ashes of the barke serue for all things that neede a mightie dryer. Eyes to comfort and clarifie, put in the milke of the rindes of Sallowe, when it beareth flowres. So doth the ashes of the tree made into a lee, and the eyes washed therewith. The dust of Sallowe coles cleareth them from all filthy blood. Fluxe to stop, dissolue Culuer doung in water of the decoction of Sallowe, and wash thy feete therewith. Milt to loosen and mollifie, seethe the rinde in water and hony, and drinke it. Lust to voide, eate the flowres of Willowe, or Sallowe, or Popler. Goute, mixe the iuice of the rootes of Willowe, or Sallowe, with oyle of Roses, and apply it. Seeth the leaues of white Willow in water, and wash thy feete therewith vp to the knees, and goe to bed and thou shalt sleepe. Mixe fine powder of the veluet coloured mosse that groweth at Willowe rootes, with the liquour of shoomakers shreads, and anoint any sores, cankers, or wounds of legs therewith to heale them. To kill wormes that eate the haires off, anoint with the mussilage of Willowe leaues. To cause deliuerance of a dead childe, drinke iiii. ounces of water of Willow leaues distilled in the midst of May. The iuice of the leaues helpeth the hurts of the eyes. Seeth Willow twigs in water, and drinke it to consume the spleene vtterly. The flowres of a Sallow or Willow, maketh colde all heate of carnall lust. The iuice of the rootes of Willowe or Sallowe, with oyle of Roses, is wonderfull good for the goute. Haire to growe, seethe Willowe leaues in oyle Oliue, and anoint therewith. Milt ache, stampe the leaues with a little Salt, and apply them to auoide the ache. Liuer chafte, chop Willowe leaues seeth them in water with some hony in an earthen pot, and when it is colde, drinke it fasting and lie on thy left side. Head balde, boyle Willowe leaues in oyle and apply them. Eyes bruised, apply ye water that commeth out of Willowes when they be cut or burned. Wounds to close vp and heale, stampe the leaues apply them. Lust to void, stampe Sallowe flowres yt hang ouer a riuer, or ye iuice of ye branches with vineger, and drinke it x. dayes, it stoppeth the termes, causeth barennesse. Agnailes Barrennesse Bloody flixe Chollike Dead childe Deliuerance Eares griefs Eyes griefs Iliak pas. Kanker Leg sores Liuer chaft Lust to voyd SAlsaperilla hath the vertues of Guiacum, and the roote China, (See Guiacum. SAmpere: The leaues, seeds, or roots, or altogether boyled in wine and drunke, prouoketh vrin termes, and is good against the Iaundies. They preserue the leaues branches in brine or pickle, as Capers, to be eaten as Capers, because they be good for the stomacke, and doe open the liuer, milt and kidneys. It is eaten raw, or sodden in sallads, or otherwise. It is best to seeth it in white wine, or in water, till it be tender, then put it into so much white vineger or vergis, (but vineger is best,) as will couer it, and then take it out as you neede: if it be too sharpe of the vineger, then steepe it a while in white wine or warme water, to take away the sharpenesse. The vse of it maketh a man to looke fresh. And the broth that it is sodden in, looseneth the belly, and draweth moysture from the kidneys. SAnders white, red, and yelowe: The yelowe is good for the trembling of the heart. The red hinder the flowing of humors to the parts of the body, and strengthen the gummes and stomacke. All the kindes are good for the trembling of the heart, ioyned with an agewe, especially being layd to the heart. Red Sanders are good with colde herbes, to be laid to the gout, and for the headach in a hote cause, and they stop humors that flow into the eyes, especially with Rose water, and likewise to the liuer. Sanders are good against itching, if the place be bathed with the liquor that they are sodden in. They are wholsome to stop fluxes, wounds: being applyed with Rose water and a piece of a Rose cake, they are good for the headach: mixe the iuice of Solarium and Purslen, with Sanders, and oyle of water Lillies, and anoynt the raging paine of the gout, to doe it away. Abhorring meate, mixe powder of red and white Sanders with oyle of Roses, and apply it to the stomacke. Frensie, apply the three kindes of Sanders, with oyle of Roses and vineger to the forehead. Liuer chafed, vse Sanders in thy brothes, with conuenient hearbes. Headach, mixe powder of red Sanders, with Sanguis Draconis, and the white of an Egge, and apply it to the forehead and temples: prooued. Wounds to heale apply Sanders and Coprose in powder, of ech like much, ouer the wound. Abhorring meate Backe ach and heate Eyes humors Feuers generall Flowers to stop Fluxes Frensie Gummes griefes Gout SAnicle: The iuice drunke, maketh whole and sound all inward and outward wounds hurts, so that he that hath Sanicle, needeth no Surgeon. Boile it in wine or water, drinke it to stop the spitting of blood, the bloody flixe, to cure the vlcerations and hurts of the kidneys. The same or the iuice thereof drunke, cureth burstings, the herb also being applied, either raw or sodden. The leaues root boyled in water and Hony, drunke, healeth the perished lungs, and all malignant vlcers, rotten sores of the mouth, gums and throte, being often washed therewith: it hath in maner the same vertues that Tormentill hath. Being sodden in wine or water drunke, it helpeth ruptures and inward wounds, spitting of blood, griefs of the kidneys, torments of the backe and belly, the bloody fluxe, both in men women, is good for all inward griefes, as Tormentil is. The herbe gleweth vp greene wounds, is to be vsed amongst wound medicines, especially the root therof, as also ye roots of Comfery, (See Tormentile, Comfery. Apply Sanicle hote to any swelling, to asswage it speedily. Drinke it with Pimpernell Bugle, to heale wounds: drinke it with any liquor, to heale all ruptures. The iuice of Sanicle bindeth al loosenesse of ye belly. Wounds to heale without salue, stampe it with Yarow Buglosse, of ech like much, streine it with wine, drinke it daily, at morne, noone and euen. Sanicle healeth, Yarowes cureth, Bugle keepeth the wound open, (See Planten, Ladies mantel. Horse stung with an Adder or Snake, stampe three hands full, streine it with new milk, giue it him wt a horne. Cattel, horses, or kine, bruised or wounded, let them drinke the iuice, apply ye herb to ye place. Lungs wasted Mouth griefes Reines running Sickenesse generall Spitting blood SArasins consound, or Solidago sarasenica: it healeth all wounds and vlcers both inward outward, in drinks, oyles, oyntments, and plasters. The same boyled in water drunke, stayeth the wastings of the liuer, and helpeth the stopping thereof, and of the gaul and the bladder, and is good against the Iaundies and feuers of long continuance, and such as are falling into the Dropsie. The decoction thereof is good against the vlcers and stinking of the mouth, and vlcerations of the gums and throte. Bladder griefes Dropsie Feuers generall Gaul griefes Gums griefes Iaundies Liuer stopt wasting Mouth griefs Throte griefes Vlcers Wounds Satyrion. Seeth it in potage, to restore nature that is lost. Drinke it with tart red wine, against the bowing backe of the necke: the herbe is of like nature as the roote. Satyrion royall, or Palma Christi bruised drunke in wine, prouoketh vomite, and purgeth the stomacke and belly, by meanes whereof it cureth the old feuer quarten, after conuenient purgation, if as much as ones thombe of the root be taken with wine before the fit come, (See Orchis. Consumption Feuer quarten Necke bowing backe Purgation Vomite to cause Sauery. SAuery eaten with Creame, purgeth a colde stomacke: drinke of the herbe, to defend thee from swooning. Take it in wine for the stopping and other griefes of the milt and liuer, and lungs, and to clense the matrixe: but women with childe must refraine the drinking and smelling of it. Seeth the herbe in wine, and apply it to the Palsie members, to auoyd their payne. Stampe it and apply it to the belly, to expel the dead yongling, and to prouoke vrine. Drinke it in wine against the Lethargy and drowsinesse, and also bathe the head often with vineger. Eate powder thereof with an egge, or drinke it with wine to stay vomiting. The vse of Saueric in meates, doth long preserue the body in health: it helpeth swellings and gripings in the body, it helpeth digestion, it expelleth the superfluities of the stomacke, prouoketh vrin and termes, and sharpeneth the weake sight that is dulled with euill moysture, moueth carnall lust, quickeneth the wits or braine: it helpeth the griefes of the lungs or breasts, and is much of like nature to Thime and Penyroyall, and with wheate meale, it is good for the sciatica. Seeth greene Sauery in white wine or water, and drinke it, to make the liuer soft, to cleanse dropsies, colde coughs, to cleanse womens diseases, and to driue out a dead childe It purgeth flegme. Stampe it and seeth it with vineger, and apply it to the hinder parts of the head against the Lethargie and forgetfulnesse. Winter Sauery is good in meats as Thyme, and Sauery hath the vertues of Thyme. Womans belly swollen as if she were with childe, stampe Sauery and streine it with ale, and drinke it with powder of Iet and white Amber, and frye Sauery, Isope and leekes in fresh butter, and apply them to the backe belly. Biting of a mad dog, stampe it with bread, and apply it. Lothing, take the powder of it fasting, with a rere egge. Congealed blood in the body, drinke it or Thime. Breast and stomacke ach, drinke it with wine and butter after supper. Deliuerance to cause, drinke it and Mugwurt with hote water. Seeth it in wine or water, and drinke it to purge the reines, bladder, bowels, and termes, and the lungs. Seeth it in wine or vineger, and drinke it, to haue a good stomacke. Gather it when it flowreth, and boyle the powder of it with clarified Hony, and drinke it, to loosen tough flegme in the breast. Belly fretting, drinke powder of it with wine warme, and be whole. To cleanse all the spirituall members, make grewell with water, wheate, and powder of Sauery, and eate thereof. iuice with a good quantitie of Hony on a gentle fire, and put thereto fine powder of Pepper, and stirre it well, and keepe it in a boxe, and vse it as an electuary for many colde and windy griefes. Lust to cause Mad dog Matrixe griefes Milke to cause Milt griefes Palsey Purgation Reines griefes Sciatica Sickenesse generall SAuin: The leaues boyled in wine and drunke, prouoketh vrine so strongly that the blood followeth, and driueth downe the termes, seconds, and dead births, and so doth the perfume of it. The leaues stampt with Hony, and applyed, cureth vlcers, and stayeth spreading and eating sores, and taketh away all spots, freckles, and deformities from the face and body, and causeth warts to fall off about the yard and secrete partes.
