And it may be mixt in stead of Cinamome, taking the double weight. all painefull sores, byles and pushes, being stampt and applyed. Mixe it with hote oyntments, for the coldnesse of the ioynts and senowes, and for Palsies. When it is vsed in medicine, it is good to put Cinamome to it. Kings euill, stampe it apply it, or vse it in plasters or oyntments. The powder of it with Hony anoynted, healeth all painefull sores which consume the flesh, and creepe from place to place, Impostumes, inflammations, and gatherings of humors. The same powder mixt with Creame, helpeth the skabs of childrens heads, and so doth the herbe sodden in Creame. The fresh leaues bruised and applied, healeth the creeping kanker or pocke, that runneth from place to place, and such like. Flowers stopt, seeth Sauin and the rootes of Smallach, Parsley and Fennell in wine, and drinke it. Flowers to stop, lay Ginger, Sauin, and Bay leaues on hote coles, and take vp the fume thereof through a funnell or close chaire. Morphue, drinke Sauin with water when the euil commeth on thee. Skabs, stampe Sauin, and seeth it well in water, wash there with often. Matrixe suffoc. steepe it in wine drinke it with treacle: but if the matrixe fall, vse the things beneath. Costiuenesse, seethe it in water with Hogs greace, make it an ointment, anoynt the Nauell. Warts, apply powder of Sauin with the iuice of Marygolds. Eares deafe, take vp the fume of Iuniper berries Sauin, in good wine. to stop French pocks Head sores Holy fire Inflammation Kanker Kings euill Matrix suff. falling Morphue Palsie Plague sore Pocks Pushes Pissing blood Seconds Senowes cold Skabs Skin to cleanse Sores SAusalone: It is vsed of some instead of Garlike: some ignorant Apothecaries, doe vse it in stead of Scordium: but not without great error. It is good for a colde stomacke, and to be mixt with colde herbes, to take away their coldnesse: but it is not good for them that are of a hote nature, or be disposed to the headach. SAxifrage: The seede or roote drunke in wine, or the decoction of it in wine, prouoketh vrine, breaketh the stone in the kidneis and bladder, and is singuler against the strangury, and stoppings of the kidneys and bladder. The root taken in the same maner, expelleth the termes, seconds, and dead birth. Powder of the roote taken with Suger, comforteth and warmeth the stomacke, helpeth digestion, cureth the gripings and gnawings of the belly, and the chollike, and expelleth windinesse. The same with the seedes, are very good for any convulsion or crampe, apoplexia, cold feuers, all venemous bitings, or any inward poyson. The same drunke with wine and vineger, cureth the plague: and holden in the mouth, it preserueth from the same, and purifieth the corrupt ayre. The same chewed, purgeth the braine, swageth the toothach, restoreth speech, and is good against the Apoplexia: and so it doth, being boiled in vineger alone: or with some water put thereto, and after holden in the mouth. The iuice of the leaues cleanseth all spots and freckles, beautifieth the face, and leaueth a good colour. It cleanseth rotten sores, being put into them: and so doe the leaues, bruised and applyed. The distilled water alone or with vineger, cleareth the sight, and taketh away all darkenesse, being put into the eyes. The same dried, may be vsed in stead of Pepper. The same vsed any way, in powders, potions, or electuaries is very good for the grosse and viscus humors in the stomacke, and the colde distemperance of the same, and for the passions of the chollike and matrixe, all poyson, and ache of the bowels, the stone of the kidneys, and to driue downe the vrine and termes. The seede also doth all the aforesaid, and so doth the distilled water being drunke three or foure spoones full at once. And the same drunke with Castorie, is good for the Palsie and many cold griefes. Wash the face with the water daily, to auoyd the deformities thereof, and to make it faire cleere. The rootes may be condyted in suger, being first sodden and vsed for the coldnesse of the stomacke, the chollike and stone. The rootes and seedes are better then the distilled water. Make a plaster of the grease of Hennes, Geese and Hedghogs, with the seedes of Gromell Saxifrage, and Gotes blood, and apply it for the strangury and stone. Drinke foure ounces of the water, with two drams of powder of burned Turpentine, twise a week early in the morning, to breake and expell the stone in the bladder. Stone, seeth it in strong wine, and drinke it continually. Stone in the reines and bladder, make a syrope with the water of the leaues and suger, and eate thereof: prooued. Chollike, stone, and strangury, seeth the roote in wine, and drinke it, or vse the powder of it with rere egges. Stone, stampe Filipendula, and Saxifrage, and drinke the iuice morne and euen. Pissing blood, stampe Saxifrage, Ambrose, and Parsly, of ech like much, and drinke if with Cowes milke. SCala celi, or Poligonatum: It is very good for wounds, and to skowre away spots and freckles from the face. Some make ashes of the roote, and thereof make Lee to the same vse. The roote stampt, closeth vp newe wounds. The iuice taketh away freckles, spots and bruised blood: but it is not to bee taken into the body: it is called white roote, or Salomons seale. Sleepe to cause, seethe the leaues well, and wash well thy feete therewith, vp to the knees. The iuice put into the eyes, helpeth many infirmities thereof. Eyes burning hote, anoynt them with the iuice, and the milke of a Bitch. SEa mosse is good to be layd to hote tumors or swellings at the beginning, and vpon all kindes of gouts that require cooling. The powder thereof taken, killeth wormes presently, and expelleth them mightily: it is Calcorolina. SEbestens by themselues or in decoction, are good for burning feuers and for wormes in children, for the drye cough, to supple the breast, and to drye vp the hote Reume, and also for heate of the Vrine, and the sharpenesse of choler in the bladder and kidneys, the strangurie, and burning of the vrine. Bladder griefes Feuer hote Kidneys griefes Reume hote Cough Strangury Vrine hote Wormes Sene. SEne: The cods and leaues taken one dram, doth purge flegme, choler and melancholy, with the broth of a chicken, pease broth, perry, or other like liquor. The leaues taken in this sort, are good for them that be sad, melancholy, pensiue, dull, or them that haue the falling sickenesse, the stopping of the liuer and milt, headach, maundge, skurfe, itch and leprie, and all diseases that come of melancholy or choler adust: it must be taken with Aniseedes, Ginger, and some salgem: or boyled with Aniseeds, Ginger and Raisins, and so it worketh quickely, and without griefes: or corrected with Masticke and Cloues, or with Cinamome. Sene purgeth gently from the heart, stomacke, lungs, liuer and milt, and is good against all agewes: it causeth mirth and good colour, and openeth the stoppings of all the inward parts. The broth of the leaues of Sene and Camomile, doth strengthen the braine and senowes, being washed therewith. The same vsed any way, strengtheneth the sight and hearing. It woulde be taken with a good deale of broth of a Cocke or a Henne, or wether mutton, or veale: or steeped in wheye with spike of India, and after sodden, and so streined and taken. There may bee put halfe an ounce or more to euery gallon of Beere before the tunning vp, for them that bee melancholly. It may bee mixed with syrope of Roses solutiue, and so drunke. But the best way is, to steepe it in colde wine or wheye, or distilled water with a piece of suger and some Aniseedes all night in a close pot, and in the morning to streine it and drinke it. But if it bee sodden with herbes agreeable for the sickenesse that it is taken for: then the herbes must bee sodden tender before it bee put in. Or vse it thus: Take Sene sixe drams, white Ginger one dram, the flowers of Buglosse two drams, put them into a cleane pot with a pinte of wheye of goates milke close stopt, and let it into a vessell of seething water two houres, then coole it and streine it, and drinke it in the morning against all griefes of the the head and braine, and so to the bottome of the bladder, and to helpe all the senses, hearing, seeing and smelling, and to strengthen all the body, and to take away all hurtfull humors, and to cleanse the blood. Wash one dram a halfe of the leaues, seeth them in a new earthen pot with wine or water, as the disease requireth, with twelue cloues, and one rase of Ginger sliced, Aniseedes and Fenell seedes, of ech two drammes: boyle more then the third part away, then streine it, and put suger to it, and drinke thereof morne and euen a reasonable draught foure houres before and after meate, it worketh without danger in all men, women and children, women with childe, of all ages. Some put thereto a little bruised Rubarbe, to make it worke more effectually. One dram of the powder taken with the broth of a Henne, worketh the same effect. Heart feeble of replection, take two drammes of powder of Sene with Pease broth blood warme morne and euen twise a weeke, it helpeth also the feuer quotidian. Stomacke and belly windie, take Sene three ounces, Ginger halfe an ounce, Aniseedes and Cumminseedes ana three peny weight, mixe their powder, and take thereof one spoonefull daily. Costinenesse, seeth it with Raisins the stones taken out, in white wine or wheye, and streine it and drinke it, sixe spoones full at once: or steepe one ounce and a halfe in a quart of white wine foure and twentie houres, and seeth away the third part, then streine it, and put thereto one dramme of powder of Ginger, and drinke thereof a prety draught in the morning. Itch, seeth a handfull in water of Roses and smallach, and a little vineger, and wash therewith. Steepe eight ounces in three pintes of white wine foure and twenty houres, then streine it and put thereto Currants two pound, fine suger one pound, boyle it till the wine bee consumed, and take one ounce or a little more of the Currants before meate when the body is stiptike. Chollike, Stone, Dropsie, Strangurie and Iaundies, take Sene halfe an ounce, Ginger, Aniseedes, Licoras, Nettle seede, Iet and Saffron, of eche one peny weight, seedes of Fennell, Carway and Spinnel, of ech one peny weight, Cinamome three peniweight: vse the powder of them when need is, in possit ale or potage: proued. Seeth two drams of good Sene, and one dram of bruised Aniseedes in halfe a pinte of the broth of a chicken or pullet, till the better halfe bee wasted, then streine it and drinke it in the morning warme, to purge the body: or take one dram of the powder, with halfe a dram of Aniseede with potage, and eate your dinner vpon it. Sene is good for the falling sickenesse, the snicopye, the griefs of the milt, the Emerods, and the feuer quarten, being boyled in water, and made into a syrope with suger, or with the iuice of Borage, made into a syrope or oximell made therewith, with vineger and Hony, for all the griefes aforesaid. SEtwall, garden Valerian, or Phue: The decoction of the roots prouoketh vrin and termes, and helpeth the ach of the side and stomacke, and so doth the powder drunke in wine. They are vsed in Antidotes and medicines against poyson and the plague, as The leaues and rootes of the great wilde valerian boyled in water, doe heale the vlceration of the mouth, and the inflammation and roughnesse of the throte, being washed gargarised therewith, it is good for the~ that be bursten inwardly. The Greeke or small Valerian is good for cuts and wounds. Setwall doth heate driue forth water, vsed in broth or powder: it is called of some Herba benedicta, and is not much inferior to Nard of India: but for the stone it is better. Seeth it in wine with Fennell seedes and Masticke, and drinke it for the chollike and stone. Phue drunke in wine, is good against venemous bitings and the plague, not onely drunke, but also smelled vnto. The decoction drunke, helpeth the strangury. And sodden with Aniseedes, Lycoras and Raisins, it is good against the straitnesse of the winde. The whole greene plant bruised and anoynted on the head, taketh away ache and pritching thereof. The wine wherein it is sodden, dropt into the eyes, is good against their griefes. The dried rootes laid among clothes, giueth them a sweete smell. Drinke powder of the roote of Phue or Valetian, to prouoke vrin and termes, and for the paine in the backe: or seeth it in wine, and so it helpeth also the strangury, and dropping of the vrine. Seeth the roote with Aniseedes, Fennelseedes, and Lycoras, and drinke it against shortnesse of breath and the cough. Stampe the hearbe and roote, and apply it to the headach, and to Byles or red apostumes, vlcers, sores, pyles, wounds and such like, to heale them. Eyes griefes and diseases of the head and braine, vse Valerian in broths and drinkes. Fistula, put in powder of Setwall and spurge rootes, to heale it speedily. Flowers to stop, stampe it and streine it with ale, and drinke it: seuen leaues the first day, fiue the next day, and three the third day, fasting. Palsie, to kill it, drinke powder of the roote of Valerian, and forbeare swines flesh. Seeth Setwall in wine and drinke it, to helpe the swelling in the flanke. Heart weake, vse Setwall in thy meates and brothes in powder. Feuer quotidian, hang the greene roote of Valerian about thy necke, till it bee drie. Chewe Setwall with Reisins and a little Lycoras, to preserue thee from the plague. Prickes to drawe out, whether it bee yron or wood, put in the iuice, and stampe the hearbe, and apply it as often as neede is. Prickes in woundes, put in the iuice with cents, and apply the substance. Setwall taketh away the smell of Garlike, Onyons, Leekes, &c. Valerian sodden in wine, and drunke fasting, helpeth the Iaundies, and the griefes of the Liuer and Milt. Eyes spots, boyle the flowers and roots of Valerian in wine, and drop it into the eyes: distill it in the midst of August in a Lymbecke, and apply it hote with linnen clothes to the plurisie, and also drinke thereof. Backe ach Belly ach Byles Bitings venemous Braine moyst Bursten Breath strait SHepherds needle, or wilde Cheruile, called Scandix: being eaten, it is good for the stomacke belly. The same boyled and drunke, openeth the stopping of the liuer, milt, kidneys and bladder, and is good for all the inner partes and bowels of man, and prouoketh vrine. Belly griefes Bladder griefes Kidneys stopt Liuer stopt Milt stopt Sickenesse generall stomacke griefes Vrine stopt Skirwits. SKirwits: The roots boiled, are good for the stomacke, prouoke appetite, and expell vrine. The iuice of the roote drunke with Goates milke, stoppeth the laske. The same drunke with wine, expelleth winde, and helpeth the gripings of the belly, and the Hicket. SKabious boyled by it selfe, or with the roote in wine or water and drunke, doth cleanse the breast and lungs, and is good for the olde cough and impostumes of the breast and other inward parts, in cleansing, ripening, and sodring them: and so do the conserue of the flowers made with suger, being vsed daily. It is good against all itch and skurfe, being stampt and applied, or mixed with oyles or oyntments fitte for it. The Lee wherein it hath bene boyled or steeped, doeth cleanse the haire from all branne and white skurfe, the head being washed with it. The decoction of Iacea nigra gargled, or the mouth often washed with it, doth waste consume the apostumes in the mouth throte, that are fresh and newe, and doth ripe and breake them that are olde. The broth or iuice of Scabious, vsed inward or outward, healeth skabs itch: it is good for all diseases of the breast lungs, to be applied to pestilent sores, to ripen them breake them with speed. Drinke the water in the plague time with Mithridate in the mornings to preserue thee. Eye prickt, or bleeding, drop in the iuice to heale it. Seeth it in wine, and drinke it to drie vp superfluous moysture. Seeth it in wine and drinke it to helpe the plurisie, the griefes of the breast, impostume, the cough, and all griefes of the chest. Take a handfull of dryed Scabious, Licoras scraped and bruised one ounce, Aniseedes and Fenell seedes ana one ounce, Figs xii. Irios halfe an ounce, steepe them twelue houres in a pottell of water, then seeth it till ye third part or somewhat more be wasted, then streine it and put thereto sugar or honie of Roses, and drinke thereof hote morne and euen to ripen and soften impostumes, to cause them to be easily spit out with coughing. The iuice is good for all maner of scabs, skurfe, mandge, and all such like, being washt therewith. The leaues stampt and applyed, represseth the Emerods, and the bruised wound, or mystie eyes, and dry vp the blood of wounds. Sit ouer the fume of the decoction thereof in wine to helpe the Emerods. Bruises to cure, drinke ii. spoonefull of the iuice of Comfrey and Scabious morne and euen. Heart griefes, stampe Scabious, and streine it with stale ale, and drinke it morne and euen ix. or x. dayes. Morphue, distill water of Scabious and Fumiterie, and vse it. Pockes and measels in children, if you feare blindnesse thereby, hang Scabious Rue about their necks. Squincie, mixe one pound of Scabious water with one ounce of aqua vitae, and apply thereof to the griefe as often as neede is. Impost. boyle the iuice with as much strong ale, drinke thereof warme: proued. Or drinke the iuice with as much aqua vitae, and some powder of Corall. Or wash one pound of the rootes and stampe them and streine them with ale, and drinke it with powder of Corall. Impost. generall, drinke one sponefull of the powder, with adraught of small ale. Squincy, mixe one pound of Scabious water withone ounce of aqua vitae, and apply it, and also gargle therewith to be whole in iii. houres. it and apply it, or boyle it with the roote of Mullin, and apply it. Scabs, boyle the iuice with vineger oyle, till it waxe thicke, and vse it. Stamp it and seethe it in wine, and drinke it to destroy humors in the stomacke. Drinke it dayly fasting with Eie bright, and the pestilence shall neuer breede in thee while thou doest vse it. Scabs generall dry and moyst, mixe the iuice with vineger and ashes of garlike, and seethe it together and anoint. Impost. to breake, drinke the iuice of it and Rue with powder of Coral a good draught. Water imperiall, precious aboue all others, take Scabious, Dittany, Pimpernell, and Tormentill, of eache like much, distill it, it helpeth all poyson and the plague being drunke. For the plague if one be infected, mixe water of Betony and Scabious of eache like much with good Treacle, and drinke thereof to expell the poyson from the principall partes, and to saue life, (see Matfelon. Breast paine, stampe good store of ripe Sloes, put them in an earthen pot, and fill it with newe ale, and so drinke it. To auoide dead flesh, boyle the barke in water till it be blacke and thicke, and put thereto Rie meale and hony, and apply it. Eyes teares, stampe ye greene barke with a litle vineger, put thereof into the eyes, and be whole in iii. dayes. Vrine to stop, seethe the barke in water and drinke it. Fleaes to voide, seethe it in water, and sprinckle the house with it. Canker, seeth ye barke in water tender till it be thicke blacke, and mixe it with Rie meale and hony, apply it, (see Rie. Seeth a quart of Sloes in a pottell of vineger, till it be wasted, then dry them put thereof into wine, and it wilbe vineger presently. Breast paine Dead flesh Eyes teares Fleaes to voide Kanker Pissing bed Prickes Smallache. SMallache, or Marsh Parsley, the seedes and rootes in working are like to the seedes and rootes of garden Parsley. The iuice doth clense corrupt festring sores especially in the mouth and throte, mixt with other things fit for ye same purpose. Frensie, seeth it in wine and wash thy head therewith. Eyes griefes, put in the iuice with the white of an egge at night. Eyes itche and hawe, mixe the iuice with soote, and the white of an egge, and let it stand Emerods, dip a cloth in pitch, and cast thereon powder of the roote and Masticke, and apply it. Flowres to stop, put in powder of Ceruse and Smallache. Iliake passion, boyle wheate branne with the iuice of Smallache, gylts grease, butter, and apply it to the paine of colde cause. Feuer cold, stampe one dram of the seedes, and steepe it all night in iii. sponefull of cold water, drinke it when the fit hath taken thee. Fester, (see Hempseede, Rie. Wounds ache, make litle cakes of ye iuice of Smallache, hony, and wheate flowre and oyle, fry it in a pan, and apply it, or mixe the iuice wt hony waxe, whites of egs, and wheate meale, vse it. Breast griefes, stampe one handfull of Smallache with as much sowre bread by it selfe, or with vineger, and apply it iii. or iiii. times to the breast to auoide heate of the breast, thirst, and stopping of the head. Feuer, bruise Smallache one handfull with as much Bay salt, and as much Olibanum as a Walnut, and deuide it into iiii. parts, and apply them one after another to ye bought of the arme iiii. times before the fit. Breast griefes, seethe the seedes with Licoras in small ale or water, and drinke it, (See Rie. Frie sheepes suet, or deares suet with sheepes doung, and the iuice of Smallache, for any burned place. Falling euill, drinke the iuice of Smallache, and thou shalt not fall that day, (See Sauine. Goute, mixe Smallache with oyle of Roses and milke, and anoint. Impost. eate Auens and Smallache till it breake, and the matter come foorth, See Mustardseede. Matrix suffoc. apply the iuice of Smallache, Hysope, Wormewood, hote to the nauel with a cloth to be whole: proued. Pappes swolne, mixe hony powder of Cummin with the iuice of Smallache, and of Onions, and crummes of Ote bread, and apply it. Strangury, drinke the iuice with red wine, (See Fenell, Or seeth ye rootes of Smallach, Parsley, Fenell, and Watercresses in white wine, and drinke the broth, and apply the rootes with Watercresse leaues. Vrine stopt, drinke the decoction of the seedes of Carway Smallache. Sleepe to cause, dip a spondge in the iuice of Smallache and womans milke, and apply it to the temples. Woundes to cleanse, apply ye iuice with hony apply the iuice with olde swines grease Rie meale. Liuer griefes, seeth Liuerwort with the iuice of Smallache in wine or water, and drinke. Vrine to cause, stampe Parsley, Smallache, and Fenell, of each like the reines and greines, or chop Smallache small, as much as two fistes, with as much Wheate branne, and seethe it in water till it waxe drye, and apply it to the bladder as often as neede is. Feuer flegmatike, make an Electuarie of the iuice of Clary, Smallache, and Fenell, and vse it. Stomacke hote swolne, stampe the rootes, and seethe it in wine or ale, and streine it and drinke a litle of it euery morning ix. dayes fasting, (see Fenell, Betonie. Spitting blood, drinke Smallache, Betony, Mints, and Rue with Goates milke hote as may be suffered. Ache, stampe it and streine it, boile it with aqua vitae, and bores grease, and styrre them well, and anoynt therewith by the fire morne and euen: proued. Eyes running, stampe it with the white of an Eg, and apply it, (see Feuerfue. Bladder paine, seethe it in wine, ale, or broth, and drinke it with powder of wilde Cummin. Bruises about the eares, stampe the seedes, and as much Ceruse with hony and apply it, or anoint. To dry vp milke in the breasts, vse Smallache, or ye seedes of it in thy meates, (see Agnus Castus. Ache in the shoulder blade, stampe the seedes and drinke them with wine. Frensie, wash thy head oft times of the day with the iuice of Smallache and vineger, but most of the vineger. Eyes bloody, apply the iuice with the white of an Egge. Eyes itche, mixe the iuice with good wine, and let it stand a day, and then wash the eyes therewith. Throte apostume or swolne, apply the iuice with crums of bread hony. Sores, (see Broome. houres in good wine, streine it drinke a litle oile of it Wounds and cuts to heale, mixe ye iuice of Smallache with ye white of an Egge, wheate flowre, powder of incense till it be thicke, apply it once a day dayly. Stomacke griefes generall, drinke the seedes of Smallache, Linseedes, Cummin wt hote water. For colde humors in the stomacke griefes of the liuer lungs, drinke powder of the seedes of Smallache, of Rue, pepper with wine. Smallache healeth wounds, ceaseth burning aking and ranckling of wounds, and is good for the feuer tertian. Wounds of al sorts, apply the iuice of Smallache and Planten with wheate flowre, Dropsy, seethe the rootes of Smallache, Fenell, Parsley, of eache like much, and make thereof a syrupe with sugar, hony, and wort, and drinke it morne and euen dayly. Mirth Nose bleeding Reines ache Shoulder ache Side griefes Sleepe to cause SMirnium: The leaues and roote doe appease the cough and difficultie of breathing: they stop ye belly, are very good against The seede is good against the diseases and stopping of the milt, kidneis, and bladder. The leaues applied doe dissolue wennes and hard swellings that be newe. It drieth vp sores and exulcerations, and gleweth wounds together. The seedes drunke in wine, are good against the sciatica stayeth windines of ye stomacke, prouoketh sweate, is very good for the dropsy feuers that come by fifts: it is called wild Alisander. Bladder griefes Breath short Cough Dropsie Feuers Flowers stopt Fluxe Hardnesse Kidneis griefes Milt griefes Sciatica Seconds Sores Stomake windy Swellings Venom Vrine stopt SOldanella purgeth downe all kind of watrish humors, and openeth the stoppings of the liuer, and is good for the dropsie, but it must be boyled with the broth of fat meate or flesh and drunke, or els dried and taken in powder with Aniseedes, Cinamom, Ginger, and great store of sugar. The leaues applied doe binde and close vp wounds, driue away brode inflammations swellings. Drinke Sorrell with Smallache or smale wine to helpe the Iaundies to quench burning Feuers. The leaues eaten fasting in ye mornings in ye plague time, is most wholesome. Liuer chafte, knead thy bread wt the iuice of Sorrell and Liuerwort, eate it apply the drosse of the same herbs to the place. Vomit to stop, drinke Sorrel, Liuer stomack hote, the hote feuer, to cause appetite, drinke the iuice or water of Sorrell. stampe it with oyle of Roses apply it, see Barley. Liuer milt stopt, and for the Iaundies, vse the iuice or syrupe of Sorrell and Wormewood. Brests sore running, apply Sorrell de Boyes rosted in a Wortleafe with vineger and hony. Feuer burning, drinke Sorrell possitale, hote as may be suffered. Ringworme or tetter, cut ye rootes very small, steepe them in strong white vineger houres, and rub therewith iii. or iiii. times a day, keepe them in the vineger. To heale the itche, boyle the rootes and wash therewith. Gomor passion, carry the seedes on thee gathered by a chaste boye. Flegme to void, (see Betony. Iaundies, seethe it and the roote thereof in white wine and drinke it. Drinke the water with one dram of ye roote of Tormentill, and halfe a dram of Treacle. Sweating sicknesse, (see Sage. Fluxe red or yellowe, eate the seedes with rosted Egs. Feuers hote, vse Sorrell. Wilde fire, and S. Ant. fire, rost it in a wet cloth halfe an houre, and grind it finely with clarified hony and apply it. Bitings venemous and rancklings, stampe it and apply it, and also drinke it. Sores hote with dead flesh in them, rost it in a paper, and apply it thrise to heale it. Iaundies, drinke ye iuice of Sorrell and Yarrowe with good ale and saffron iii. or iiii. times to cure it. Sneesing in children to stop, anoint their hand with the iuice of Sorrell. Eyes yellow by the Iaundies, put in the iuice of Acedula or small Sorrell. Mixe Sorrell with harts grease barley meale, and apply it to the temples for the For the stopping and wasting of the liuer, vse Sorrell with some Wormewood in brothes drinkes. Liuer wasting, seeth Sorrel, Water cresses, red Fenel wt a chickin in an earthe~ pot, vse it ix. dayes. swelling, apply Sorrell Smallach with vineger sheepes suet boyled together. Feuers, drinke Sorrell possitale made by putting the iuice to milke when it beginneth to seeth. Vomiting to stop, drinke the iuice or water, it helpeth ye inflammation of ye liuer, and quencheth great thirst. Botch to breake, rost it in a Wortleafe apply it. Stone to breake, and to helpe the Iaundies, and to expell vrine and the termes, vse the rootes. Botch Breasts sore running Dead flesh Eyes yellow Feuers hote Ranckling Ringworme Reines running S. Anth. fire Sores hote Sneesing Stomacke hote Stone Sweating sicknesse Tetter Thirst SOthernwood, the seed either greene, or drie, in powder, or boiled in wine or water, and drunke, helpeth shortnesse of breath, streitenesse of winde, and hardnesse, burstings, and shrinkings of the sinewes, the sciatica, stopping of the vrine and termes, and all cold moisture, tough flegme, and stopping of the milt, kidneis, bladder and matrix. And drunke in wine, it is good against all poyson and venome, and destroyeth wormes. The perfume or smel of it driueth away all venemous beasts, The ashes mixt with oyle of Palma Christi, or of rapes, or of raddish, or olde oyle oliue, restoreth haire, the head being anoynted with it twise a day against the sunne or fire, and causeth the bearde to come foorth speedily. Stampe Sothernwood with a rosted quince, and applie it to all inflammations of the eyes. Stampe it with barley meale, and seethe them together, and applie it to dissolue all colde humours and swellings. Lay it vnder thy bed, pillow or bolster, to prouoke carnall copulation. and resist all inchantments letting the same. Eyes burning, and swelling, Seethe with white bread in water, and applye it, The iuice mixed with oyle of Dill, causeth haire to growe in anie place of the bodie. Boyle the hearbe with Quince kernels to dissolue apostumes and flegmatike humours. Boyle it in oyle Oliue and anoynt the head to auoyde all intemperate coldnesse of it. Boile it with with Wine and Sugar, and drinke it to heate the stomacke. Boyle it with Parsley and sugar, and drinke it to breake and expell the stone of the bladder and kidneys. The oyle of it anoynted beneath the nauill, expelleth vrine. The hearbe drunke with Wine helpeth against poysons, and bytings of venemous beastes and wormes. The roote drunke often, killeth the wormes, and so doeth the iuice drunke with a little milke. Seethe the hearbe with ysope, licoras, or sugar in Wine, and drinke it for the griefes of the lungs and breast. Bruise the hearbe with oyle and salt, and apply it to the pulses of the handes, as a remedie against the feuer. Seethe the toppes of the flowers in Wine, or water, with honie or sugar, and drinke it three or foure times a day to helpe shortnesse and straitenesse of the breath, to cleanse out the griefes of the breast, to helpe the Cardiacke passion, and the Cough, to cleanse out the humours of the lunges, kidneys, matrix and bladder, to helpe the dropping of the vrine, and to cease all inwarde griefes. Stomacke weake, applie the hearbe in a linnen bagge somewhat dried, to comfort it. Sciatica and Goute in any place, bruise it with butter or oyle, or both, and seethe them in wine till the wine bee consumed, then streyne it, and anoynt therewith, or drinke the iuice of Sothernwood warme with wine. Forehead ache, and Vertigo, stampe it with honie and vineger, and drinke it. Mouth vlcers, stampe it with honie and anoynt both inwarde and outwarde. Flowers to stoppe, stampe it and drinke it with redde wine. salt, and applie it hote. Eares wormes, put in the iuice. Haire falling, seethe the barke in water, and washe therewith. Speech lost, (See Irios Womens secrete griefes, vse it with ale. Chollicke, applie a plaster of it and Wormewood with vineger, honie, and barley meale. Haire to growe, washe with Lee of the ashes of it. Haire to restore, mixe the ashes with oyle of raddish, and anoynt the balde place. Speaking in sleepe, and for the Vertigo, and swimming in the head, drinke it to bedward with wine a litle hony. Drinke powder of the seeds against al venemous bitings, and of the hearb to kil wormes. Powder of the hearbe with barley meale, breaketh hard apostumes. Headach, stampe it with vineger, and honie, and apply it. Frensie, stampe Marigold, Sothernwood, and sage, and strein it, and drinke it with Wine or ale sixe dayes morne and euen. Wormes, drinke it and tansie with Sothernwood is good for the Cough and gnawing in the bellie and breast, griefs of the bones, and stopping of the vrine, the seede beeing stamped with water and drunke. Bitings venemous, and for the colde Feuer, drinke it with wine. seethe it in vineger, and holde it in thy mouth. Bruise Bursten Chollicke Cold griefes Conception Cough Eares wormes Eies heate swolne Face salseflegme Feuers cold Flowers stopt to stop Frensie Gowte Hardnesse Heart griefes Headach Sinewes griefes Sicknesse generall Sides griefes Speech lost Speaking in sleepe SOwbread, drinke a dram or a dram and a half of the powder of the root with Hydromel to purge grosse and tough flegme, and other sharpe humors. Bitings venemous, and all poison, apply it, and also drinke it with wine. For the stopping of the liuer, the Iaundies, and to auoyde the yellow colour, drinke it with Hydromel, and couer thee well to sweate. To expell the flowres and dead childe, drinke it, or vse it as a pessary. Belly bounde, strake the nauel and the belly with the iuice, or put it into the fundament with wooll. Fundament falne, anoynt it with the iuice vineger to settle in the natural place it. Eyes spots, pearles, hawes, and al other impediments, and to cleare the sight, put in the iuice with hony. The root maketh the skin faire and clean, and voideth all naughty skurf and maunge, the falling of the haire, the marks and spots of the pocks and masels, and all other blemishes. The same or the iuice mixt with ointment or oiles for the same purpose, wasteth the hardnesse of the milt. Apply it with oile and vineger to heale wounds. Ioints out, heeles kibed, Gout in the feet, skurf of the head, wash with the broth or decoction of The oile wherein the roote hath bene boiled, closeth vp wounds, and with the same and a litle waxe, a good oyntment is made for kibes, chilblains, and griefs comming of cold. The root hanged vpon women in trauell, causeth speedie deliuerance. In what sort soeuer this root be taken, it is dangerous for women with child, or if it be but caried about them, or that they tread ouer it. If it bee put into wine, it maketh a man drunken, a iuice is pressed out of the roote, and sodden to the thicknesse of honie, and so kept. The roote is sliced and laid vp as Squilla is. Iaundies, stampe the roote of Sowbread and gladen, and drink the iuice, or sit in the decoction of them. Emerodes, mixe the iuice with powder of Agaricke, and hote oyle, and apply it. Dead childe Eyes griefes Emerodes Feete gowte Flowers stopt Fundament fallen Gowte Head griefes It also prouoketh vrine, breaketh the stone, is excellent good for the strangurie, and the Iaundies, it ingendreth good store of good milke, and causeth the childe that sucketh it to haue a good colour, and so doeth the broth wherein it is sodden, beeing drunke. The iuice doeth coole the heate of the fundament, and priuie partes, being applied with cotton, and of the eares beeing dropt in. Stamp the green leaues, and apply them to all hote swellings, and apost. especially of the stomack. Great hawkweed, wild cicorie, yellow deuils bit bee of the same operation, and are good also for the the iuice being dropt in, especially deuils bit. Apostume hote Bitings venemous Eyes dull Eares heate Fundament heate Iaundies Matrix heate Milke to cause Stomacke apostume Stone Strangurie Swellings Vrine stopt Sparewort. SParewort, stampe it and apply it in halfe a walnut shell seuen or eight houres to the sciatica, to reare a blister, then let it out, and apply a leafe of burre or colewort. To auoid dead flesh, apply it with hony and rye meale. Ach in the arme, shoulder or leg, blister it with Sparewort, and lay on an Iuie leafe, to draw out the humor. Anoint the pulses with the iuice to cure the feuer. Byle Botch Dead flesh Feuer Legge ache Shoulder ache Sores Sperage. SPerage helpeth the kings euill and the strangurie and palsie. The seeds and fruit are vsed in medicine, and wilbe kept in vertue foure yeres. Eate Sperach with meate for the stopping of the liuer hardnes of the milt. Seethe the root in wine, and drinke it for the shedding of the gall. Wash the mouth often wt the decoction of Sperage to cease al ye pain of the mouth teeth. Eat Sperage with cummin for swelling of the stomack, the chollicke, to mend the sight, to losen the belly gently, to purge the brest, bowels and reines, and to cause a good sauour in all the bodie. Seethe it in wine, and drinke it for the paine in the loynes and reines. Drink the root in white wine for paine of the stone, and for pain of ye matrix. Seethe the root in vineger to help the swelling, spots leapry of the skin. Parboile the yong springs and eat them with vineger and oile, to prouoke vrin, soften the belly, and for the strangurie. Seeth it with cypease, drinke the broth to open the liuer and kidneis, for the Iaundies, strangury, grauell, and stone, to ease the pain of the sciatica, and members out of ioynt. Bitings venemous, boile the root in wine, and drink it. Let barren women boile the berries, eate them with vineger, sweete oyle sugar to become fruitful. The water of the hearbe cleareth the eies. The syrop causeth naturall seede. No hearbe is sooner conuerted into good blood, then Asparagus. Rosted or sodden it asswageth the strangurie, the difficultie in making water, and the bloodie fluxe. The roote sodden with vineger or wine helpeth members out of ioynt. And sodden with figges and cyches, it healeth the iaundies, the sciatica, strangury. Feuer quarten, seethe the root in water and drinke thereof seuen dayes. ache Bitings venemous Blood to cause Bloody fluxe Breast griefes Chollicke Conception to cause Eyes dull SPinach, Loynes ache, vse pottage made with barley, and Spinach, and butter. Seethe it and eate it with meat to soften the bellie, and to auoyde the paine of the breast and lungs, to qualifie choller, to cleanse the bodie, and strengthen the stomacke. Drinke the decoction of it to expell euill humours, to cause easie breathing. But too much vse of it, and lettise breedeth melancholie: drinke the broath against grieuous paine of the backe, and for the paine of the throate, comming of Choller and blood. Spinach softeneth the bellie, helpeth the roughnesse and hoarsnesse of the throate, and the drie cough. Drinke the iuice or water to quench heate, and mitigate the gnawing of the stomacke. Apply the bruised hearbe to the stomacke and liuer, against their ach and inflammation. The same is good against stingings of venemous beasts, (See Beets. Hoarsenesse Liuer griefes Loynes ache Lungs paine Stinging Somack griefs SPlenwort, or Lonchitis, is very good against the hardnes, stopping, and swelling of the milt, being drunke, or applied with vineger. Apply it to wounds to keepe them from apostumation and inflammation. Sixe or eight seeds of it doe purge choller, flegme, and watrish humours mightily, and so doeth the iuice, but it is stronger in operation, it is of the very nature and facultie of Tithimal, and must be vsed as is saide of Tithimal. Seuen seedes taken with figges or dates purge the bellie, and so doeth the leaues sodden with a cocke. Fistula, and hollowe vlcers, Seethe it in wine, and put it in. Teethach, mixe the milk thereof with and fill the hollow tooth therewith, and seethe the root in wine and wash therewith morne and euen, euery moneth once, and you shall haue no pain. Take nine crops pulled vpward in powder with ale to purge vpwarde, and drinke some warme ale soone after it, and after vse some restoratiue. Drinke three graines with sugar cleane pilled, to loosen the bellie, three or foure leaues seedes with warme water cause vomite, and so doeth the iuice. Skin to cleanse Teethach Vlcers hollow Vomite to cause Squilla. SQuilla, being first couered round about with dowe, or lapped in paste, and baked in an ouen, or rosted in the embers till it be tender, and a spoonefull thereof taken with an eight part of salt, purgeth downewarde plentie of tough and clammie humours, and vse the same so prepared in medicines, to prouoke vrine, for the dropsie, Iaundies, belching, or woorking of the stomacke, and gryping of the bellie. Take it with honie and oyle to driue out wormes, both long and rounde. The same so prepared, is good for the old cough, shortnesse of breath, stuffing of the breast, and to cleanse the breast. Mixe it with honie to losen the bellie very gently, and so doeth the seedes taken with figges or honie. scale or twaine of the roote, being yet greene and rawe, is good to be laide vnder the tongue to quenche thirst in the dropsie. Seethe Squilla in vineger till it bee tender, and stampe it, and apply it to all venemous bytings beeing stamped. Boyle the inner part of Squilla in oyle or turpentine, and applie it to chappes or riftes of the feete, to kibed heeles, and hanging warts, especially being rosted vnder the embers, and so it healeth all running sores of the head, and the skurfe, scales, or branne of the head, beeing laide to. The leaues doe dissolue and waste the Kings euill, and kernels about the throate, beeing applied foure dayes. Squilla hanged ouer the doore, or chiefe entrie of the house, keepeth the same from all mishap, witchcraft and sorcerie. When the flowers of Squilla bee of a brownish colour, and doe not soone fall or vade away, that yeere shall bee verie fruitfull and plentifull of corne. Squilla may not bee taken inwarde rawe but rosted, baked, or sodden, halfe a dramme is sufficient to bee taken at once with honie, for the Iaundies, the olde Cough, shortnesse of winde, and gnawing in the bodie. It is good for the the falling sicknesse, disinesse of the head, griefes of the sinewes, breast, lunges and ioyntes, especially licked in with honie, it maketh a cleere voyce, and so doeth the vineger and Oximel thereof. It helpeth the hardnesse and and stopping, and swelling of the milte. It withstandeth putrifaction in the bodie, and therefore keepeth a man in health, and maketh his bodie continue still in young state, but they make a man leane. The Squilla helpeth loose gummes, and the vineger maketh the teeth fast, the mouth being washed therewith, voydeth stinke of the mouth, and causeth a sweete breath, it stancheth ache of the stomacke, it helpeth digestion, and causeth a good colour. It maketh a loose bodie fast, and compact howsoeuer it be taken. The sodden drink of it may be taken from tenne drammes to three ounces. The vse of Squilla quickeneth the sight, being taken with vineger honie, it killeth worms. Licke three halfe peny waight of it with honie for the griefes of the stomacke, when the meate swimmeth therein, the dropsie, Iaundies, old cough, shortnesse of breath and vomiting. The vineger, Oximel, and Loch. are good for the same purposes, and to kill all maner of worms, to expel melancholie, to helpe the apoplexia, to breake expel the stone, to clense the matrix, to help the sciatica. Where Squilla is placed, it keepeth trees and plants from noyance. For ruptures in the feete or handes through the French disease, diuide it, and boyle it in olde oyle till it bee tender, then grinde it, Emerodes, steepe rawe onions in Acetum Squilliticum, and applie them. Milt hard, mixe the fatte of a Crane with the vineger, and anoynt therewith after the comming out of a bath. Eies dull Emerodes Falling euill Feete ruptures Gummes loose Hands rupt. Head giddie skurfe sores Hickit Iaundies Kernels Kibes Kings euill Leane to be Lungs griefes Matrix to cleanse Melancholy Milt griefes Teeth loose Throate kernels Thirst Voyce ill Vomiting Venome Vrine stopt Warts Wormes SQuinant, which is like Date straw, the hearbe, flower, or roote drunke with pepper, doeth helpe the Dropsie, and is good for the lungs, milte, and reines beeing vsed. The roote is good against the winde Chollicke, flegme, and rawe matter in the bodie, or anie member of the same, the powder thereof Drinke one dramme of the root with as much pepper a few dayes against the loathing of the stomacke, the dropsie and crampe. The flowers are good against voyding of blood, and paine of the stomacke, lungs, liuer, and kidneys. STauesacre, fifteene seedes taken with honied water causeth to vomite grosse flegme, and slimie matter with great violence. The seede mixed with oyle, driueth away lice, and cureth all skuruie itche and maunginesse. The seede boyled in vineger, and holden in the mouth, swageth the toothache. The same chewed in the mouth, purgeth the head and braine. With vineger it killeth lice, being rubbed on the apparell. The seeds must bee steeped in vineger, and dryed, and the powder drunke with honied water, and the receiuer of it must walke continually, and drinke honied water often, when hee feeleth any kinde of choking, and so it will woorke without danger. Mixe the pap of sodden Stauesacre with wine lees, and wash the head therewith against the vlcers and skabbe, &c. The seeds mixt with oyle killeth nits, and with oyle and vineger it killeth lice. Stampe it with oile, anoint swellings therewith, especially about the nailes, and all skurfe, skabbe, and leaprie, and to kill Lice and nits both in man and beast. Seethe it it in vineger, wash the teeth therwith for their ach losenesse, and to stopp rhewme. Teethache, put in powder of Stauesacre, long pepper, and Piretum into a linnen bagge, and chewe it between thy teeth, or vse Stauesacre only. Eares dull, seethe it with raddish seedes, and wormwood, and dip tents therein, and put them in. Fistula in the eare, boyle powder of Stauesacre and Brionie in vineger, and put it in. Gummes rotten, seethe Stauesacre in vineger, and wash therewith. Lice to kill, mixe powder of it with black sope, anoynt therewith. Head to purge, holde the powder of it in a linnen bagge, and chewe it sometimes. Head sores, seethe it in water with wine lees, and wash therewith. Lice to kill, mixe it with oile and quicksiluer, and anoynt. Morphue, mixe the powder of it and Lytarge, make a bathe, and wash therewith. Dropsie; seethe it with yssop in wine, and drinke it. Teethache, put the powder in a cloute, and dippe it in aqua vitae, and apply it. Maunge Matrix to clense Morphue Mouth sores Nailes griefes Nits STinking Horehound: Dogbiting, stampe it with salte, and applie it. Roste the leaues in a Colewort leafe, and apply it to the swelling lumps in the fundament. With hony they purge filthy found wounds, and cure rotten vlcers. It driueth foorth water, and causeth to pisse well, it it bee drunke: it stoppeth the Bellie. If it bee layde to, it stoppeth the comming out of matter from the matrix. Taken with colde water, it helpeth the gnawing of the stomacke, it expelleth winde, helpeth the liuer, the Iaundies, and griefs of the kidneis, being sodden in water, and sitten ouer, it is good for the inflammation of the matrix, it is good to restore haire to the eye liddes, and to bee cast vpon bodies that sweate too much, and are moist. It is put into antibodies, and triacles, and it is commonly laide vp in a newe earthen vessell for eye medicines, beeing first made into powder, and then into rounde cakes, or trochiskes with wine. French Spikenard is good for the purposes aforesaide, it driueth foorth water more mightily, and is better for the stomacke, it helpeth inflammations of the Liuer, and the Iaundies. Drinke it with wine against the griefes of the milt, kidneis and bladder, and against all venemous bytings. It is somewhat weaker then Nardus Indie, or else of like vertues in all things. Vse Spikenard to drie vp the moysture of the dropsie. Heart weake, sicke, and swoning, seethe it in wine, and make a syrop, and vse it. Bellie loose Bitings venemous Bladder griefes Dropsie Heart griefes Haire to grow Iaundies STtchwort: If a woman drinke the seedes of it three dayes fasting, after shee hath had her naturall course, and that shee happen to conceiue within fourtie dayes after, it shalbe a manchild. Sodden in wine, it breaketh the stone, and is good against the hardnesse of the milte, and stopping of the liuer and gall, it cleanseth the reynes, bladder, and passage of the vrine. The seede doeth vehemently purge the vrine, and stoppeth vomiting. Conception Dropsie Eyes sore Liuer stopt Milt hard Stitch Stone Vomiting Vrine stopt Small Stoncrop, Stonhore or causeth vomite, taken with vineger, and so voideth grosse, slimy, and hote cholerick humors, and is good against feuers, and all poison in the body, but none must take it, but they that are strong and lustie. Mixt with Swines greace, it dissolueth and driueth away wennes, the kings euill, and swelling in the throate, and harde swellings. Being applyed alone on the bare skinne, it causeth wheales and blisters. Stoncrop for an Impostume, stampe it with Laureall and streine it, and drinke it with stale ale twise a day, it killeth wormes. Blister to make Feuers Impostume Kings euill Poyson Swellings hard Throate swolne Vomite to cause Wennes Wormes Stecados. STecados, or French Lauender sodden with the flowers, or the flowers alone, and drunke, openeth the liuer, lungs, milte, kidneys, mother, bladder, and all inner parts, cleansing and expelling all euill and corrupt humours, and is good against headache, and griefes of the breast and lunges, and expelleth the termes. Smell often to the leaues and flowers to comfort the brayne, memorie, and inwarde senses: It strengtheneth all the senses and the whole bodie, and deliuereth from all obstructions, and helpeth the griefs of the stomacke. Bladder stopt Breast griefes Braine weake Headache Liuer stopt Lungs griefes Matrix griefes Milt griefes Obstructions generall Poyson Sicknesse generall STtrawberrie, The iuice of the leaues with wine of Pomegranates, and a little Rose water applied, is good for hote Apostumes in their beginning and increase. The leaues vsed in a bathe, doe greatly helpe the Stone. Stampe three or foure handful of the leaues, and seethe them in water, and bate therwith the hips vpward, and then anoynt with this oyntment: take Dealthea one ounce, hony halfe an ounce, waxe one dram, and melt them together and vse it both for the Sciatica to soften hardnes, and to prouoke vrin. The berries take away vnnaturall heate, and do coole and moisten drie Chollericke men. The hearbe eaten in meate is good for the milt and the griefes thereof, and so is the iuice drunke. The iuice with white pepper helpeth them that are short winded. The berries slake thirst, and are good for the stomacke. The decoction of the rootes drunke morne and euen, doeth qualifie the Liuer. And the decoction of the hearbe and roote together, doeth qualifie the heate of the Liuer, and doeth cleanse the reynes and bladder. The best distilling of the berries, is when they bee ripe, but not ouer soft, and they which growe in hillie Woods are best. The water drunke, or mixed with somewhat, and drunke, qualifieth Drinke iiii. ounces morne and euen to helpe the leapry. To purge the blood, drinke it with wine, or otherwayes eate it with bread to cleanse the foule skab of the body. Drinke it in the same maner to helpe the liuer, the Kings euill, to loosen the breast, to comfort the heart, to purge the blood, and for the stone of the kidneis and bladder. Gargle therewith to helpe the vlcers and grieuous swellings and stinke of the mouth and throte. Let women drinke it to clense them and send downe their termes. Wash the filthy corruptions and skabs of the legs therewith morne and euen, and also apply it with linnen clothes. Drinke thereof and also wash filthy wounds therewith to heale them. Mixe it with salt, and distill it ouer againe, to coole and cleare the eyes. Strawberies or the water of them, is good for all inward heate of the liuer and lungs, the inflammation of the whole body, to quench thirst, and to helpe the rednes of the face being dayly drunke, and ye face washt therewith. And likewise it comforteth the heart, helpeth the griefes of the breast, cleanseth the blood, and helpeth the Iaundies. The water helpeth the vlcers of the mouth and the squincy being gargarised. The same taketh away the spots and rednes of the face and legs. The beries put in a brasen vessell with salt in a low seller viii. dayes till it turne to a greene water, is very good for the paine in the eyes. The decoction of the plant drunke, stoppeth the taske the termes. The same holden in the mouth comforteth the gummes, and cureth the vlcers and sores of the mouth and stinke of the same. The iuice of the leaues cureth the rednes of the face. The continuall vse of the beries is good for a hote stomacke. The leaues eaten in meates, or the iuice drunke with hony, helpeth ye griefes of the milt, and with pepper it helpeth shortnes of winde. There is a iuice pressed out of Strawberies, which in time increaseth strength, and is a present remedy against the sores and wheales of the face, and bloodshotten eyes. Vse the leaues with Borage and Buglosse in meates to ingender good blood. Mixe the iuice of the leaues of Planten, of eache iii. drams, with one dram of Ash leaues, and seethe them together to a plaster, and apply it to a broken legge or any other member to knit the bones speedely. thereof is good to be drunke against the ache and heate of the head, and for sweating and inward heate. The iuice taken with Cummin, is good against a stinking breath. And taken with Borage, it is good against the ache of the head heart. And with the iuice of Planten, it stoppeth ye termes. The water dropt into the eyes, helpeth their rednes, itche, and inflammation. Heape Strawberies on one ounce of Salgem iiii. or v. dayes, then streine it and put it in a boxe, and vse it to the web of the eyes. Eyes payne, distill the berries with white wine, and vse it for the pinne and the webbe. Stone to breake, distill Strawberies with their leaues, and drinke the water as other drinke. Conserue of Strawberies, set a quart of them on the fire till they be foft, streine them and put thereto twise their waight of sugar, and seethe it till it be incorporated. It is good against a hote liuer, and burning of the stomacke, especially in hote feuers. Face leprous, wash with the water being first putrified in a glasse before they be distilled. Iaundies, vse the leaues and rootes in pottage certayne dayes. Mixe the iuice with hony and a little white Pepper, and vse it for the paine of the milt and the ptisike. Face pimples, put ripe Strawberies into a leape of greene rushes, and hang it against a wall where the sunne hath most power ouer a glasse, and anoint with the water. TAmarinds scowre away choller, and holde downe the rage of it of the heate of blood. They are very good for the burning of the liuer and stomacke, thirst, all kindes of burnings, and the Iaundies. They stop vomitings, and helpe hote and hastie agues that had neede of purgation. The dose is one ounce of the flesh streyned, and some are suffised with halfe an ounce. It is good to put to it almost as much Cassia, and so may the Cassia be the better taken. And some Spikenard or Mastike, or Maces, are good to be put to it to mitigate the coldnesse of it. It will worke more strongly with the iuice of hops, or of Parsley, or of Fenell, or of Endiue. The best are blacke, shining, fresh, and not drie. They are good to be vsed for the griefes of the head. Hote griefes &c. Iaundies Liuer hote Stomacke hote Thirst Tamariske. TAmariske: it is a medicine of excellent power and vertue against the stopping hardnes of the milt, if it be but drunke out of, being made into a vessell to drinke it. the leaues and yong springs boyled in wine with a little vineger and drunke, doth heale the stopping and hardnes of the milt, and so doth the iuice drunke with wine. seethe the branches and leaues in wine, and hold it hote in thy mouth. Flowers to stop, seeth the leaues in water, and sit in it hote. Lice nits, seethe it and wash therewith to kill them. The fruite of the great Tamariske, is good against spitting of blood, to stop the flowers and the laske, and against venemous bitings. The same fruite is vsed in stead of galles in medicines for the griefes of the mouth and eyes. The barke is of the same vertue that the fruite is of. The leaues, wood, roote, and iuice sodden in wine and drunke, helpeth the griefes of the lungs, milt, kidneis, bladder: it driueth foorth melancholie, it helpeth spitting of blood, and the excessiue flowing of termes and all other fluxes, the Iaundies, and all other griefes that come of obstructions. The roote sodden with Reasins and drunke, helpeth the Leapry, because it cleanseth and healeth the milt, whereof the Leapry commeth. pyggin made of the branches thereof, is good for them to drinke in that be splenetike. The decoction of the leaues is good for women that be pale to sit in, when they are troubled with the whites. The ashes cast vpon spreading sores doeth drye them vp, and helpeth burnings with fire. Vse powder of it in bread for the quarten Feuer and the Dropsie. The fruite is like Galles, and may be vsed for them. The ashes of the wood applyed to the conuenient place, stoppeth the outragious flowing of the matrix. The broth of the leaues is good to sitte in for women that haue a loose mother in perill of falling downe. The barke of the rootes of heath may be vsed in steade of the barke of the roote of Tamariske, rather then the barke of quickebeame. The broth of it sodden with Reasins drunke, is good for the Leapry. Tamariske dressed after the maner of Guiacum for the French pockes, is thought to haue the like vertues. Milt griefes, stampe the leaues with vineger and apply them. Bladder griefes Burnings Dropsie Eyes griefes Feuer quarten Flowres to stop TAnsie: the seede is singular good to kill wormes and expell them howsoeuer it be taken. Sinowes ache and swolne, stampe it with oyle and apply it. Feuers, anoint with the iuice of oyle of Roses to put away the fits. Bladder paine and pissing by drops, drinke it with wine. The roote condited or preserued with sugar, is good to be taken for the paine of the goute in ye feete. Seethe the seedes in wine with hony, and drinke it to kil wormes. The same hath also the nature of Camamile, it ceaseth ache, and prouoketh sweate. Tansie is good for the palsie, for it voydeth flegme, and dryeth the sinowes. It killeth wormes, and voydeth the matter whereof they breede, and is good for the stone and stopping of the vrine. Stampe Sage, Rue, and Tansie, of eache like much with wine and drinke it for the feuer quarten. Teeth wormes, stampe it, and put it in. and swelling, stampe Tansie, Sothernwood and Rue with salt, and apply them hote. Eyes bleared, put in the iuice. Iaundies of colde cause, and for pissing of blood, drinke the iuice. Cough, fill drye Figs with Tansie seedes, and seethe them in white wine with one ounce of Licoras, with a soft fire to the one halfe, and drinke thereof euery night. To purge the matrixe, stampe halfe an ounce, and streine it with wine and drinke it. Boyle Tansy and wilde Tansy with salt, and drinke it for inward bruises. Matrix to cleanse, drinke halfe an ounce of the powder of it with good white wine. Fluxes generall, mixe the iuice with yolkes of egges, and the fatnesse of wheate, and bake small cakes of it, and eate them two or three dayes. Flowers to stop, drinke the iuice, and apply the substance. Wormes, stampe it and seethe it in water and drinke. Ache in the backe, kidneis, and lymmes, stampe Tansy with sheepes tallow, and frye it apply it. Feuer quarten, stampe Sage, Rue, and Tansy, of eache like much, and drinke it with wine. swol. Bladder paine Bursten bruised Cough Eyes bleared Face deformed Feuer quarten Feete goute Flegme Flowers to stop Fluxes generall Goute Iaundies Palsie Pissing blood Pockes Sinowes swolne Swellings Sweate to cause Stone Teeth wormes Vrine stopt TArragon is good in Sallads with Lettuse as Rocket is, and is sharpe and salt enough of it selfe, without the helpe of vineger and salt. TArre, or liquid pitch, taken with Hony, doeth cleanse the breast, and helpeth shortnesse of winde. It doeth mollifie and ripen all heart swellings, and is good to anoint the squincie or swelling in the throte, and is an anodine to take away ach or paine. Applyed with Barley meale, it softeneth the hardnesse of the matrixe and fundament. Mixt with quicke Brimstone, it represseth fretting vlcers, skabs, and skurfe. With salt, it is good for venemous bitings and stingings. It cureth the riftes and chaps of the fundament, hands, and feete. And with fine powder of Frankincense, it healeth hollowe vlcers or fistulaes, and filleth them vp with flesh. It is good to bee put into fistulaes, with a tent of Bacon. Matrixe rent, stitch it vp and anoynt it with Pix liquida. To cause a siege in Tenasmus, or streyning to voyde the excrements, take vp the fume of Tarre, or Turpentine. With Rose oyle, it helpeth the mattering of the eares. With as much Waxe, it helpeth the rough nayles and the impetigo, ringworme, tetter, skabbe, and itch. Sodden with Barley meale in the vrine of a chaste boy, it breaketh strumes, wennes and swellings. And with Raisins and Hony, it healeth carbuncles and rotten vlcers, and breaketh them. Fundament fallen, anoynt it with Tarre, and put it in. Head skalde, mixe it with salt, foote, and sallet oyle of eche like waight, and anoynt it dayly and be whole, it bringeth also plentie of haire. Matrixe fallen, cast on powder of wherein Chickens haue bene hatcht, and then lay on Tarre. To bring a Canker out of a sore old or new, mixe one spoonefull of Tarre with as much newe creame, and apply it with a cloth thrise if neede be. Put it into a hollowe tooth to breake it, and cease the ach. It taketh away blewenesse vnder the eyes. Pyles, apply the reddest Tarre vpon newe lockrome, and thereon lay bolsters, and doe so once a day, and binde them to. Belly bound Bitings venemous Breast to cleanse Breath short Bruise Chaps Conception Carbuncle Eares matter Emerods Face deformed Fundament hard fallen Fistula Matrixe fallen hard rent Nailes rough Piles Poyson Ringworme Scabs TAsell: the roote boyled in wine, and stamped to the thicknesse of an oyntment, healeth chaps, and rifts, and fistulaes of the fundament: but to preserue this oyntment, it must be kept in a copper vessell. The small wormes that are found in the heads worne about the necke or arme in a thin leafe, doe cure the quarten feuer. The water that standeth betwene the leaues and stalkes doeth the same. Vse the distilled water of the leaues for rottennesse of the mouth and gums, and chaps of the fundament, especially the roote sodden in wine to pappe, and then mixt with waxe and put into a copper vessell, and so it helpeth chaps, fistulaes, and creeping sores, shingles, pimples, and hanging warts. The water that standeth in the leaues, is good for red eyes, spots of the Dropsie, stampe the rootes of Tasell and Danewurt, and seeth them in wine, and drinke it. Gout, seeth Tasell in red wine, and drinke it morne and euen nine dayes. Spitting blood, seethe Tasell and Planten in raine water, and drinke thereof with suger at morne, noone, and euen. Flowers to stop, drinke two drams of the powder of it with a Poringer full of pease broth, or stampe it and boyle it in vineger, and apply it vnder the Nauell. Wounds moist and hard to heale, stampe it and apply it. Fluxe and excoriations of the belly, drinke powder of it with good wine. Gums rotten Gout Kanker Mouth griefes Sores Spitting blood Warts THapsia, Mesnes, Turbith: The barke of the roote one dram or somewhat lesse, purgeth flegme and choler from the stomacke and all parts, and is good against shortnesse of breath, stopping of the breast, the cholike, paine in the sides, shrinking drawing of the senowes, the gouts and ach of the ioynts. Layd too with oyle, it is good against foule skurfe of the head, and causeth haire to grow againe. The iuice of the roote with Hony, taketh away Lentiles, spots, and skurfe of the face or elsewhere. The root with oyle and waxe, is good for the olde paine of the head, and ach in the side and outward parts. It must be corrected with Ginger or long Pepper, and a little Suger, when it is taken inward. Ranker to heale, apply powder of the roote of Turbith with Hony. Breast stopt Breath short Bruise Dropsie Face deformed Head ach olde skurfe Haire to growe Ioynts ach Kanker Purgation Poyson Senowes griefes Side ach Skin deformed Swellings Wounds Thlaspi. THlaspi seedes eaten, purge choler both vpward and downeward, prouoketh termes, and breaketh apostumes both inward and outward. and taken with a Glister, it helpeth the sciatica, and is good also to bee applyed outwardly, as Mustard seede. It seemeth to bee that which wee call peny weede among grasse on layes and balkes. THistle: the wilde Thistle, that, especially with the blacke long roote boyled in wine and drunke, prouoketh by vrine, and expelleth all superfluities of the blood, and causeth the vrine to stinke, and so maketh the body and free from such strong smell. The same applied with vineger, healeth the wilde skurfe and naughtie skab. Some vse to eate the buds and rootes, but it giueth no good nourishment, but watrish and naught. Lady Thistles, the rootes drunke in wine, is good against spitting of blood and feeblenesse of the stomacke, and loosenesse of the belly: it prouoketh vrine, and expelleth it out. Teeth ach, seeth it in wine and vse it to the teeth. Stampe it to colde and soft swellings, to consume them. The seede is good for the crampe in children, or the drawing awry of any member, and the bitings of any venemous beast. Dropsie, drinke the iuice of sowe Thistle morne and euen, or seethe the leaues of Lady Thistle in wine or water to the one halfe, and drinke thereof morne and euen nine dayes. Dropsie in the belly and Iaundies, seethe sowe Thistle and the roote thereof in ale, from a gallon to a quart, and drinke thereof. Face sauseflegme, stampe the sharpe Thistle, and drinke it till thou be whole. To auoyd all ill humors out of the stomacke and other parts of the body, make broth of Saint mary Thistle, water Cresse, Eldren buds, Auens, Parsley and Isope, and vse it. Vrine stopt, stampe the roote of Thistle, and boyle it in wine and drinke it. Prickes, apply the leaues or rootes of the Thistle with Pitch, Rosin, and the white of an egge. Stone, gather Thistle rootes in saying the Lords prayer, and wash them eight times, and put thereto eightie one graines of Pepper, and so streine it and drinke it. For biting of a mad dog, and madnesse that commeth thereby, Drie the flowers of wilde Thistles in the shadow, and drinke a Wall nut shell full of the powder of them with white wine, and be whole at thrise taking of it. White cotton Thistle, the leaues or rootes drunke, are good for the Crycke and shrinking of the senowes, by meanes of the crampe, (See Caltrope. Eyes blemish Face sauseflegme Iaundies Mad Mad dog Prickes Purgation Skab Skurfe Spitting blood Stinking sweat Stomacke weake Stone Swellings Teeth ach Vrine stopt THroughwaxe boyled in water or wine and drunke, healeth wounds, and so doe the greene leaues bruised and applied, mixt with waxe, oyle or oyntments fit to heale wounds: it healeth burstings of yong children. Stampe it with meale and wine, and lay it to the nauels of yong children, to keepe vp their bowels, and drawe them to the Naturall place and settle them, and to slake them when they are too much windy and swollen. The like doth the powder of the seedes applyed in like maner. Stampe it with waxe or glewe, and apply it to the swelling of the Cods, burstings, inflammations and wennes. The herbe or the water thereof, is good for the holy fire and the shingles, and it cooleth a hote stomake. The whole herbe is very meete to heale both inward wounds, sores and burstings, especially of children, and the going out of the nauell great gut, and so doth both the seedes and leaues. The powder of the leaues drunke with wine, helpeth the herneyes. The herbe applyed to the nauell, healeth the vlceration thereof. Children bursten, stampe it, and lay it to the nauell: or take the powder of the seedes with wine or milke. Holy fire Inflammation Nauell out sore Shingles Sores Stomacke hote Wennes Wounds THyme: Running Thyme prouoketh the termes and vrine, and stoppeth the distillings of the head proceeding of a colde stomacke being drunke in wine. And helpeth the headach and frensie being sodden in Rose water and applyed. Vomiting blood, drinke two drams of the iuice with vineger. Drinke the herby part daily with wine, to breake and expell the stone, both of the kidneys bladder. Apply the herbe to the stinging of a Bee, to heale it. with the iuice of sweete Lycoras, and drinke it, to helpe the cough and purge the breast. Seeth it wt Aniseeds, drinke it to heate the stomacke, to voyd winde in the Guts, and for the strangurie. Seethe it in vineger and Hony, and drinke a at once, to helpe the spitting of blood: or drink foure drams of the iuice with vineger, for the same purpose. Seeth it in wine Hony, apply it to the squincy, to helpe it. Seeth it in wine and drinke it, to open the stoppings of the liuer and milt, and to prouoke vrine. Drinke three ounces of the distilled water morne euen, to strengthen amend the head and braine, and stomacke, and to prouoke appetite, to auoyd rumbling in the belly, to soften the hardnesse of the stomacke, to prouoke vrine, to comfort the sight, and to consume the distillation of the head. Drinke ye said water with water of wormewood, to heale the feuer quotidian. Drinke three ounces of the water at once, to amend the cold liuer and milt, and for the exulceration of the guts, to open the stoppings of the nostrels and eares, to restore hearing, to helpe the giddinesse of the head, to stay vomiting, to auoyd the gripings in the belly, to breake the stone, and to prouoke vrine. Apply the water with linnen clothes, to bruises, to heale them. Stampe the herbe with Hony, apply it to senowes shrunke, or ioynts out. Seeth it in wine and drinke it, for the ach griefs of the stomake, grauell in the reines, and to increase milke. Stampe it and apply it to the head, to stop reume. Seeth it in wine or water and drinke it, to driue downe the termes, grauell stone, and to prouoke vomit, to stop the laske, to oure gripings cramps, and the drawings or shrinkings of the senowes. Vse it in meates broths against all poyson venemous bitings and stingings of serpents. Apply it with oyle of Roses vineger, to the forehead temples, to auoyd headach, rauing and frensie. It is called wilde Thyme, running Thyme, Puliol mountaine, and groweth also on banks in fields. Seeth it in wine with Hony, Aniseeds Lycoras, for the drie clammy cough, to comfort the stomacke, and to helpe the strangury. Garden Thyme drunke with wine, prouoketh vrine termes, and purgeth the bowels. Sodden with Hony, it helpeth shortnesse of breath, and most griefes of the Drinke foure drams of the fine powder with oximell, to purge choler, and to cleanse the bladder. Drinke i. dram of the powder with Mellicrate, one spoonefull fasting, to ease the paine of the bowels and loynes. Drinke three drams of the powder, with one spoonefull of oximell, to auoyd the winde of the breast, sides flanks: and so it purgeth melancholy humors, and helpeth the dulnesse of the senses comming of melancholy, cleareth the sight, and helpeth the paine of the eyes, being taken fasting. Drinke the powder with wine, for the paine of the gout. Vse not Thime to much, because it is hote, and breedeth choler: the whitest is best, and the blackest the worst. Seeth Thyme in wine, drinke it against wheasing, straitnesse and shortnesse of breath, small wormes in the belly, bruised blood, to driue downe the flowers, seconds, and dead yonglings, and to resist poyson: vse it in meates sawses, for all things that running Thyme serueth for. Apply it with vineger, to bruises, congealed blood warts: it may be vsed for wilde Thyme or Sauery. Seeth it with Hony or Mede, to cleanse the lungs, breast, reines, matrixe bladder, to kill wormes: vse the powder in potage, to comfort the The Bees profit most by it, of all herbes, so that plenty of Thyme flowers, bringeth plenty of Hony. Drinke i. ounce of dried Thyme, with iiii. drams of oximell, with an emptie stomacke before dinner or supper, to helpe the stomacke, guts, matrixe and bladder red eyes, and for the gout. Mixe the powder with Hony, and licke it in, to clense the breast. Take it with vineger, to dissolue lumpes of bruised blood. Apply it with wine and parched barley meale, to the sciatica. Chollike and winde in the stomacke, seeth it with Licoras in wine, drinke it. Liuer, milt, kidneys and bladder, seeth wilde Thyme in wine or ale, and drinke it. Belly ach, seeth it in wine and oyle, and apply it. Chollike, stampe it with saffron and streine it with oyle, and drinke it. Eyes watrings and teares, seethe wilde Thyme in water, and wash Breath short, seeth it in water, and when it is colde, streine it, put to it, and skum it, and drinke thereof to bedward. Gout sciatica, stampe it with the white of an egge, and apply it: or apply the ashes thereof, with the white of an egge. Fistula and hollow sores, stampe Thyme with salt, and apply it. Knees swollen of colde cause, seeth one handfull in a quart of Malmesie to the one halfe, then put a piece of sweete butter to it, and boile it, and bath therewith to bedward, and also apply it with a cloth. Bruises, distill wilde Thime in a Limbecke, and apply it with linnen clothes. Spitting blood, seeth wilde Thyme in vineger and Hony, and take foure ounces euery day, or take halfe an ounce of the iuice and vineger. Chollike, stampe a good handfull of vnset Thyme, with three cloues of Garlike, and then streine them with ale, and make a possit, and drinke the ale of it. Tythimall: The iuice openeth the belly, and sometimes causeth vomite, and bringeth foorth tough flegme and cholerike humors: and so doe the seedes and rootes, especially the barke thereof: and are good for them that fall into the dropsie, being well corrected and prepared: the same mixt with Hony and anointed in ye sunne causeth haire to fall off: the same put into hollow and rotten teeth, swageth the toothach: but put none of the iuice vpon any sound teeth, but couer them with waxe to preserue them from it. The roote boyled in vineger and holden in the mouth, is good for the same intent. The same doth cure all roughnesse of the skinne, maundge, leprie, wilde skurfe, and spreading skabs, the white skurfe of the head, and causeth all kindes of warts to fall off: it taketh away the knobs hardnesse of Fistulaes, corrupt and fretting vlcers, and is good for hote swellings and carbuncles: it killeth fish being mixt with any bayt, and giuen them to eate. The barke of the rootes of the Tythimalles soked foure and twentie houres in vineger, and then dried and made into powder with Aniseedes or Fenell seeds, or Dragagant, or masticke, and taken with some cooling liquor, as of Endiue, Cycorie, or of Oringes, it will worke without trouble or paine. The powder of spurge or Tythimall supped vp with a little Cinamome, in the broth of a Chicken or a rere egge in the morning, will purge grosse flegme very gently, and so it will being taken with Hony of Roses. Seuen seedes taken in a Fig, will purge melancholy and water. Twentie seedes drunke with pure sweete water, helpeth the dropsie. dram of the roote drunke with Hydromell, purgeth flegme downewards. The outward barke of the rootes of Tythimall or Esula steeped foure and twenty houres in vineger or milke, and then dried and powdred, and halfe a dram of it drunke with wine, or Hydromell, or mellicrat, expelleth all kinde of watrish humors and choler, and is good for the dropsie. The seedes of all Tythimalles, are of like vertue, but more hote and sharpe troubling the belly and prouoking strong vomites. The milkie iuice may be mixed with the flower of Beanes or Peason, and made into little cakes, and dried in the sunne and kept for all purposes that it is good for. Mixe the iuice of it with wheate flower, and fill hollow teeth therewith, to helpe the toothach, or seeth the roote thereof in wine, and wash therewith euery moneth once, and you shall haue no toothach, (See Spurge. For swelling and aking of the cheekes and teeth, seeth it in water, and wash therewith, and apply the substance. Tooth to drawe out, apply the milkie iuice with wheate flower. To kill a Fistula or kanker quite, mixe the milkie iuice with fresh swines grease, and melt them and put thereto a little myrrhe, and dip tentes therein, and put them in deepe ynough: prooued. Teeth to fall out, mixe the milke with wheate flower, and drie it in the sunne till it be hard, and so keepe it and lay thereof vpon the tooth and vpon none other: for swelling and aking of the cheeke, and for tooth ach, seeth it in water, and wash with the water, and apply the substance, (See Spurge, Esula. Fish to kill Flegme Hardnesse Head griefes Haire to fall Kanker Knobs Leprie Maundge Melancholy Plague sore Purgation TOrmentill: the leaues and rootes sodden in wine, or the iuice drunke, prouoketh sweate, and thereby expelleth all venome from the heart. And eaten or drunke, they are good against all poyson and pestilence: the same vertue hath the powder of the dried rootes drunke in wine. The root drunke with wine when there is no feuer, or with water wherein Iron hath bene often quenched, in a feuer, cureth the bloody fluxe, and all other fluxes of the belly, and stoppeth the termes, and all issues of blood. The decoction of the leaues and roote, or the iuice vsed both inward and outward, is good for all wounds, it openeth and healeth the stoppings and hurts of the liuer and lungs, and the Iaundies. Eate the powder of the roote with the white of an egge, to stay the desire to vomite, and against choler and melancholie. Boyle it in water, and wash the mouth therewith, to cure all euill vlcers, and the sores thereof. Stampe the herbe with oyle, to heale the sorenesse of the feete and skabs in three dayes. Drinke powder of the roote with the iuice of Planten, against the stopping or skalding of the vrine. It is good against poyson, the plague, and the bloody fluxe. One dram of the roote, or one handfull of the herbe or roote sodden in wine and drunke warme, expelleth poyson and the plague. The herbe, roote, iuice or powder, openeth the passages of the liuer and lungs, and helpeth the Iaundies, especially the iuice thereof. If any man be taken with sudden sickenesse, and cannot tell what it is, let him take one dram of treacle with wine of the decoction thereof, and couer him well, to sweat out all the venom, feuer and pestilence. The roote vsed any maner of way, is good for all fluxes, both white and red. red wine, cureth the bloody fluxe, if the party haue no feuer, but in a feuer one dram of it, with the distilled water twise a day drunk, doth helpe it. Mixe the powder with the white of an egge, halfe a nutmeg, and as much Ote flower, and bake it in a frying pan, and turne it nowe and then, and eate it, to heale all fluxes: or bake the powder with the white of an egge, on a hote bricke or tile, and take one dram thereof with water of red Mints, for the same purpose. The herbe and roote stamped applied, taketh away all hardnesse, swellings, and gatherings of humors, wennes, knots, kernels, taketh away the paine of the hips. And with vineger, it helpeth the running skab, emerods, piles, and such like.
