One part of the root drunke in raine water, and another part bruised with vineger, and applied to the reines, will hold the birth, that it can not fall before the naturall time. It is good to bee taken with Planten water, of them that cannot holde their water. Let women sit in the broth of it vp to the nauell, to stop their flowers: or kneade the powder with Hony and spikenard, and lay it to the nethermost part of the belly. Sight to restore, seeth it in wine and drinke it daily no other drinke, and apply the sodden herb euery night ouer the eyes three or foure moneths. Bruise the roote and seethe it, and drinke the broth for the chollike and pinching griefe of the belly. Chollike, drinke two parts of Tormentill, and a third part of Ginger with hote wine. Tooth to drawe out, apply a piece of the greene root. Fistula to heale, put in the iuice with a tent. Eyes dull, and yet cleere, seeth it in wine, drinke it first and last sixteene dayes, shut thine eyes together, and apply the herbe euery night warme, (See water imperiall in Pimpernell, or Scabious. Tormentill comforteth the sight, cleanseth the body from diuers maladies. Seeth the herbe root in white wine, till the third part be wasted, drink thereof nine mornings cold, nine nights a little warmed, to recouer ye sight: but if the eye be hurt, stampe it seeth it in white wine a little water, and binde it to the eyes. Stampe it and the roote of it, and put it into a little vessell of wine three moneths, and then drinke the wine to recouer the sight. Belly ache, stampe the roots and drinke it with a little white wine or ale. Eyes red and dropping, wash them with water of Tormentill, wt a little Tutia prepared put into it. Sciatica, take powder of the roote in winter, with Iuie water, but in summer with conserue of Roses, (See Sorell. Bloody fluxe, take i. dram of the roote often, with good red wine. Itch and swelling of the Emerods, stampe the leaues roots, and boile them in vineger and wash therewith. Consumption, boyle powder of Elecampana and Tormentill with Hony, vse it. Stomacke griefes Swellings Sweat to cause Teeth ach to drawe Venom Vomiting Vrin hote and stopt Wennes Whites Wounds TRagium or stinking motherwurt, growing by sandy wayes: Smell vnto it, or binde it to the nauell, for strangling of the mother. TVrpentine: The cleere Rosin of the firre tree, which is liquid, or Venice Turpentine, taken about the weight of halfe an ounce, looseth the belly, and driueth foorth hote cholerike humors: it cleanseth the kidneis, prouoketh vrin, and driueth forth the stone and grauell, and is good for them that haue the gout. The same taken with Nutmeg and suger, as much as a Nut, cureth the strangury, and is very good against the going off of the skinne, or fluxe of the secret parts. It is also excellent for all greene wounds, especially of the head: for it healeth and cleanseth much. The Rosin of the Larch tree, is as good as any of the other Rosins, to be put in Plasters and oyntments, to glew together, and to cleanse and heale wounds. Licked in with Hony, it cleanseth the breast, looseth the belly, prouoketh vrine, and driueth out the stone and grauell taken inwardly: and to be short, it is of facultie very like to the right Turpentine, and may be vsed for the same. The Rosin of the Turpentine tree, which is the right Turpentine looseth the belly, openeth the stoppings of the Liuer and milt, cleanseth the kidneys, prouoketh vrine, and driueth out grauell, being taken in quantitie of a wall nut. In an electuary with Hony, it cleanseth the breast and lungs, ripeneth flegme, and causeth it to be easily spit out. It is good for the wilde skurfe and maundge, chaps and clifts of the feete, and is vsed in emplasters to make smooth and soft. Mixed with oyle and Hony, it is good to be put into the eares against the matter and running of them, and against the itch of the priuities. Among all Rosins, the Rosin called Turpentine is the best, then the Masticke, then Rosin of the Pine tree, then that of the red Firre tree. Turpentine with Verdigreace, Coprose, and naturall is good against Leapries. Cleere venice Turpentine washed and tempered with Hony, will cleanse the lungs. Taken with Suger in Pilles, it will cleanse the reines, open the bladder, purge grauell, cleanse much vrine, and helpe the yard, and mollifie the belly. Take Turpentine two ounces, often washt in water of Fenell or Thyme, then put to it powder of new saffron and Hyera simplex, of ech halfe a dramme, keepe it in a boxe for any griefe of the guts or reines. The turpentine of the larch tree taken foure spoonefull, or thereabout with meate and drinke, expelleth inwarde poyson, it purgeth gently, and healeth the griefes of the breast, lungs, and liuer. The same is good against a consumption, or leannesse, the olde cough, shortnesse of breath, spitting of blood, and the Ptisicke. To expell the seconds, smell to the smoake of Turpentine. To make naturall turpentine, Take oyle of Linseede one pounde, the elder the better, Rosin of the cleerest foure ounces, Colophonie one ounce, dissolue them in a potte, set into a potte of seething water, and clarifie it into a cleane vessell, all the corruption will fall into the bottome, then put to it one pinte of clarified honie, and boyle them all together till the thirde parte bee wasted, then powre out the cleerest of it, add that is naturall Turpentine. Flowers to cause, and to cleanse the Matrix, dippe Cotton therein, and put it in as a Suppositor. Take vp the fume layde on a hote yron into the fundament three or foure dayes, to auoyde great payne and gnawing in the bellie and guttes. Stone to auoyde, burne foure ounces on a redde hote plate, and drinke two drammes of the powder with foure ounces of Saxifrage water twise a weeke at the breake of daye two moneths together, or washe Turpentine tenne times in water, and make little balles, or boli thereof, with Saxifrage iuice, and a little Sugar, and vse it as aforesayde. Wormes, spread Venice turpentine on alomed leather, and laye it from the pitte of the stomacke to the toppe of the nauill in the wane of the Moone. wound, take one ounce of Turpentine washed in Woodbine water, and the yolks of two newe layd egges, and beate them well together: then put in two blades of Saffron, and mixe them all together, and keepe it in a boxe, it will bee good one yeere. Whites, and running of the reynes, Vse pilles of Turpentine rowled in ginger and Cinamome, and vse them morne and euen. Matrix loose after trauaile, swallowe Venice Turpentine with Sugar, and vse Comferie with Alebrewes. Cornes, pare them, and laye to Turpentine and redde waxe boyled together. Woundes to heale, vse Venice Turpentine with halfe as much yolkes of egges. Turpentine is abstersiue, attractiue, mundificatiue, and resolutiue, good for the breast, prouoketh vrine, laxeth the bellie, and healeth skabbes. With brimstone it cureth the Leaprie, skabbes, tetters, and ringwoormes. Woundes, vse it with the yolke of an egge and oyle of roses. For hardnesse, and stopping of the bellie, to purge the lunges, liuer, milte, and kidneys, and to comfort all the spirituall members, vse it with honie resolued in a sawser. For the falling of the fundament, take vp the fume of Turpentine and pitche, and sitte long on a boarde of Iuniper or Cedar. Head skabbed, anoynt with the gall of a Bull, Turpentine and honie. Bruise, or wounde, applie the yolke of an egge with Turpentine and Saffron. Turpentine is good for the woundes of the sinewes and muskles. Sinewes pricked or cutte, boyle salte in oyle, and put Turpentine to it, and applie it, or applie Turpentine with the leaues of Centorie. For the fluxe and great paine of the fundament, lay one ounce of Turpentine on a hote iron in a close stoole, receiue vp the smoke of it. Stone in the bladder, burne foure ounces on a redde hote yron, and drinke two drams of powder, with foure ounces of saxifrage water twise a week, eight weeks together. Wash an ounce with borage water, or other cordiall water nine or ten times, and put thereto three ounces of fine sugar, and when neede is, make pilles thereof, and rowle them in Cinamome and Sugar, and take thereof at any time for many inward infirmities and passions, especially comming of choller and flegme, and to cause appetite. Breath short Bruise Chafing Chaps Choler Consumption Cornes Cough Deliuerance Eares matter Nayles rent Poyson Priuit. chafte itch Purgation Ptisike Ringwormes Seconds Senowes griefes Gout, anoint the place with cleere Hony, then apply a plaster of Rosin with a linnen cloth, till it fall off of it selfe. Bruise, boyle Pitch, waxe, Rosin swines grease, of ech like much, apply To consume an impostume in the stomacke without breaking of it vpward, take powder of Rosen with one spoonefull of Ale or Beere, or mixe it with Treacle, and take as much as a great Nut, and drinke after it to wash it downe. It is good to driue any infection from the heart, and will cleanse any stuffing or tough flegme about the heart and stomacke, and is good with Treacle for any bruise. If one take it sometimes when he is well, it will keepe the body in good state and from corruption and impostumation. Breast griefes Bruise Flegme Goute Heart griefes Health to keepe Impostume Leapry Stomacke impostume Tutsan. TVtsan: Gomor passion, boyle Castory in the iuice of it, and drinke it. Drinke two drams of powder of ye seedes to purge choller, and to helpe the sciatica, but water must be taken after it. The heat be healeth burnings, and stoppeth blood being applied, and so doeth the wine wherein it is sodden, (See S. Iohns wort. Flux to stop, drinke possitale of Vergis, and keepe thee warme and close. Vergis is good for all faint cattell, as kine, buls, and oxen, so that they drinke it and goe presently to pasture. Or giue euery one a pinte with a small handfull of Bay salt, first rubbing their tongues therewith. Burning and skalding, wash quicklime with Vergis ix. or x. times, then mixe it with oyle and vse it. hony. Eares noise and take vp the fume of Vergis from a tinne vessell. Seeth Vergis with as much raine water to the one halfe, and while it seetheth, fill it with the iuice of Limons, and when it is colde, put to it the whites of iiii. egges beaten together, and vse it against all sunne burning, and other filthinesse of the skinne. Burnings Cattell sicke Eares noise Face deformed Fluxe Heart griefe Mouth blistred Skalding Skin deformed Swooning Vineger. VIneger: mouth stinke, swallowe Vineger when thou goest to bed. Hickit, holde thy hands in hote water, and then apply Vineger to thy stomacke with a spondge. For all feuers, seethe a quart of white Vineger, with Sanders and Licoras, of eache one peniworth to the one halfe, then streine it and drinke a spoonefull or two at once, and be whole. Burnings, apply the dregs of Vineger with an Eg. Swelling, boyle Beane meale in Vineger till it be thicke, and apply it. Breath stinking, steepe tostes of bread in strong Vineger and eate it. Face pimpled and red, wash it nine dayes with good Vineger. Face salseflegme, seethe Elecampana in a pot with Vineger till it be drye, then grinde it with Brimstone, Swines grease, and Quicksiluer, and anoint therewith, (see Eg, Alom. Head megrem, toste the nether crust of a browne loafe, and soke it in Vineger, and heate it againe and apply it to the temples as hote as may be suffered, or drinke Sage royall, Betony, and Wormewood thirtie houres with Vineger. Ringwormes and tetters, dissolue gumme of a Plumtree or Cherritree in Vineger, and anoint therewith. Stomacke griefe, stampe Wormewood with crums of bread and Vineger, and apply it warme to the stomacke. sugar with iii. pound of water ouer a soft fire, and skum it and put thereto three pints of the best white Vineger, and boyle it till it rope. It is good for all hote diseases comming of choller, and all colde diseases comming of flegme. It comforteth the liuer, heart, and stomacke, and slaketh thirst: it may be taken before and after meates. Face salsflegme, mixe one peniworth of white Coprose, with one pint of white Vineger, and wash therewith to bedward euery night. Itche, seethe Rosemary and Celondine of eache halfe a handfull in halfe a pint of white Vineger, and streine it, and put in a quantitie of white Coprose while it is hote, and wash often therewith. Ache, beate the yolkes of two newe laid egs, with iii. spoonefull of white Vineger, and one spoonefull of Roses, and put thereto Beane flowre, and heate it and apply it on a linnen cloth, but for a swelling put thereto vi. spoonefull of Barme, and apply it colde. stampe Sothernewood with Vineger and salt, and apply it hote. Bleeding, apply smoothe troden earth with Vineger, or red Nettles stampt with Vineger. Headskalde, shaue off the haire and wash the head with Vineger and Woodashes, and be whole. Haire to fall, touche the place with Vineger and ashes of Horseleches, (see Wormes. Morphue, put powder of Brimstone into a cloute, and dip it in Vineger and anoint. Mouth heate in sicknesse, boyle white Vineger with as much Hony, and a litle Alome, and anoint with a fether, and also wash the mouth often therewith, and also take vp the vapour thereof. Lice to kill, drinke wheye that is preast out of cheese with Vineger certaine dayes first and last, and they will drye. Ptisike and weakenesse of the stomacke, seethe white Vineger long, and put in good store of sugar, and stirre it well till it waxe thicke, and vse it first and last dayly. Fluxes generall, seethe the yolke of an Egge hard in Vineger and eate it. seeth Betony, Sage, and roche Alome in Vineger, and hold it in thy mouth. Steepe an Egge iii. or iiii. dayes in Vineger, and it may be drawne thorowe a ring: and steepe a whetstone therein An ointment for all sores, seeth i. pound of hony with halfe as much Vineger, and halfe a peniworth of Verdigrease, and vse it. To make Vineger by and by, powre pure Wine halfe sodden into a newe earthen Vessell, and stop it close, and set it in hote skalding water. Skin to be white, heate litarge of siluer in distilled Vineger, and wash therewith. Morphue, skurfe, and leapry, take powder of quicke Brimstone and blacke Sope, of eache two ounces, and hang it in a pint of strong wine Vineger in a linnen cloute ix. dayes, and wash with the vineger, and let it drie in by it selfe. Flints laide in Vineger seuen dayes, may be rubbed into powder. Lethargy, rub the plants of the hands and feete with Mustard and Vineger. Fluxes generall, apply Doues doung with Vineger to the nauell. Face salsflegme, seethe a pint of Vineger with as much milke, and one handfull of Barley flowre and anoint therewith, and after wash it with womans vrine sodden with the iuice of Houseleeke. Flowers to stop, seethe newe horse doung in Vineger, and apply it hote to the nauell. Fundament fallen, seeth egs in Vineger, and mixe their yolkes with oyle de Bay, and sit thereon till thou beest well. Goute, apply Vineger with Wheate branne colde, and it will flee downe from the plaster, then breake it with Sparewort, and after lay on a plaster of hony and barley flowre, or anoint it often with hony, and seethe Ambrose in wine, and drinke it. Canker in the mouth or lips, stampe Sage with Vineger and Salt, and apply it. Memorie to preserue, mixe the iuice of Smallache with a litle Vineger and Castory, and apply it to the hinder part of the head. Nayles to fall off, apply Brimstone or Arsenicke with Vineger. Face rancke or red, put iii. newe layd egs into a pint of Vineger, and stirre them well together, and let it stand iiii. dayes and nights, and then drinke thereof first and last, and also wash therewith for the saltflegme, and heate of the liuer and lungs, though the scabs be as great as a Walnut. Teeth to be white, rub them often with powder of Bricke and Vineger. Cornes, apply ashes of the rinde of Willowe, or Sallowe with Vineger. seethe Vineger with running Thyme and oyle of Roses, and apply it. apply Vineger with a cloth to thy cods or paps. Plague, a defensiue, drinke v. spoonefull of Vineger, iii. spoonefull of running water, halfe a spoonefull of Treacle, and as much Bole Armoniake as a small nut first and last at morne and euen. Ringwormes, anoint with glewe dissolued in Vineger, or grinde one ounce of Verdigrece with v. ounces of Vineger, and put thereto iii. ounces of hony, and boyle them to the thickenesse of hony, and vse it. Heate outwarde, mixe Vineger and milke with Coprose, and apply it with cloutes, or hurds. Burning, mixe fiue parts of the iuice of Lilly leaues with one part of Vineger and a litle hony, and vse it. Lice to kill, anoint with Mustard, Vineger, and a little Saltpeter, or with Stauesacre, Brimstone and Vineger. seethe a litle Camphere in Vineger, and holde it in thy mouth, or seethe Henbane rootes in Rosewater and Vineger, and hold it in thy mouth. Teeth to be white and fast, rub them with Vineger of squilles. Mouth stinke, wash it with Vineger, chewe Mastike a good while. Heart swooning, cast cold water with and Vineger into his face. Vineger to make, put wine into a vessell that Vineger hath beene in, and set it in the sunne or by the fire, and put thereinto newe brickes or tiles hote. Nose bleeding, put Vineger into the eare on the same side that bleedeth. Eares sounding, put in Vineger wt oleum Irinum, that is of Flowerdeluce, or Ellebore sodden with Vineger. Leaue to be, drinke iiii. ounces of Vineger with powder of Pepper fasting as often as neede is. Eies sore, put Plumtree flowres into Vineger in a cleane bason couered iii. dayes, then put it in a boxe, and anoint therewith. Nose bleeding, drinke the iuice of Fiueleafe, and wash thy face with Vineger. Morphue, anoint with blacke sope and Vineger and Brimstone, of eache like much. Head pushes, wash it often with Vineger, or seethe Tartar in Vineger and wash therewith. Drowsinesse, forgetfulnesse, or Lethargy, burne thine owne haire and apply it to thy nose with Vineger and Pitch, or apply Rue and red Mints with oyle and strong Vineger to thy nostrels, or stampe Sauery and seethe it in Vineger, and apply it to the hinder part of thy head. Frensie, anoint thy temples with ye iuice of Planten or of Morrall and Vineger. Ringwormes, stampe the rootes of Burres, and seethe them in Vineger, and anoint therewith, or stampe Planten rootes with Vineger and salt, and anoint therewith warme. Morphue and foulenesse, anoint with Doues dongue and Vineger ground together. seethe Coloquintida in Vineger and holde it in thy mouth, or boile Hysope in Vineger and wash therewith. Nosebleeding, apply a plaster of clay, Vineger, and whites of egges to thy cods, or put in Hares haire with Vineger and water, or seethe Beanes in Vineger and eate them, or vse them plasterwayes, or seeth Peares with Vineger and drinke it with Mastike. Bloody fluxe, seeth the liuers of any beastes in Vineger, and eate them, or apply Doues doung stampt with Vineger. Chollike, seethe olde oyle with butter and strong Vineger of eache like much, till it be thicke, and apply it often to the belly. Milt swolne, stampe Docke leaues, and seethe them in Vineger and apply them. Mother rising, squirt raine water and strong Vineger into her nostrels. Feuer quarten, drinke the rindes and leaues of a Nut tree with Vineger. Drunken, rub the plants of the hands and feete with Vineger and salt. Eares ache, take vp the fume of Vineger, or seethe one dram of the roote of blacke Ellebore in one pound of Vineger, and take vp the fume of it, and also put thereof into the eare. Eyes ache, seethe Roses in Vineger, and apply it. Eyes web, mixe Doues doung with Vineger and oyle of Roses, and streine it, and anoint therewith with a feather. great and heauie, mixe powder of Aloes, Masticke, Frankincense with Vineger and whites of Egs, and apply it with stuphes to the temples, or stampe greene Mints with Vineger and anoint, or anoint wt ashes of garlike Vineger, or apply Goates doung with Vineger vii. dayes to cure it for euer, or rub the place with a Spiders web, and oyle, and Vineger, or seethe Wormewood in Vineger and apply it, or anoint with the iuice of ground Iuie, oyle, and Vineger. with hony and Vineger, and drinke it, or anoint with Rue and Vineger, or with the iuice of Cicory, oyle of Roses and Vineger. Canker, wash it iiii. or v. times a day with warme Vineger, and sprinckle on some powder that is good for it. Wash thy gums with Vineger, then mixe alome with it, keepe it in a boxe, and anoint therewith iiii. or v. times a day. Leapry, anoint with the gum of a Plumtree dissolued in Vineger, or with Aspaltum Vineger. Lethargy, shaue thy head or nape, and anoint it with the iuice of Smallache, oyle of Roses, and Vineger, or apply the iuice of Smallache with Vineger, powder of Mustardseede. Mad, drinke Rue seedes with Vineger, or Gentian with hony and Vineger. Mother rising, put Vineger into her nose with a feather. Face pimples, stampe Planten rootes with Vineger and salt, and wash therewith. olde, seethe salt in strong Vineger, and chafe it well therewith iii. dayes against the fire, but if the matter be broken, wine will serue in steade of Vineger. Sores and swelling of the legs, mixe Goates doung with Barley meale Vineger, and apply it, or apply grosse meale of Oces with the white of an Eg Vineger. Teeth to be white, kneade a cake of Barley meale Vineger, and burne it on the coles, and rub thy teethe with it, or the powder thereof. Sleepe to voide, seethe Rue with Vineger in a close vessell, and smell to it, and put thereof into thy nose with a feather. Hoarsenesse, drinke hote water at morne, noone, and euen, and dip a linnen cloth therein with as much Vineger, and bind it warme about thy necke often, and forbeare cold and cold things. Vomiting, steepe a piece of bread in salt and Vineger, and bruise it and apply it to the pit of the stomacke, and strike some of it on thy mouth. Stomacke wambling, drinke an Egge shell full of springing water with as much Vineger. Feuer generall, take halfe a spoonefull of Vineger, with as much iuice of the greene barke of Eldren. Head frensie, and lethargy, anoint with Vineger and oyle of Roses. Lethargy, seethe Castory in strong Vineger, and put thereto powder of Anacardium, and anoint the hinder part of the head therewith. seeth Henbane roote in Vineger, holde it in thy mouth, and chewe the roote. Speech lost, drinke Peniroyall with Vineger, and also apply them to the stomacke hote. Appetite to cause, vse Vineger in meates sauses, especially with Sage, Mints, Parsley, and Pepper. Vineger on a full stomacke softneth the belly, but on an emptie stomacke it bindeth it. For weakenesse in sicknesse or after it, weete tostes of bread in Vineger, and rub thy mouth and nostrels therewith, and binde it to thy pulses. Swellings of wounds in the hands, seethe wheate branne with Vineger, and the iuice of Wormewood, and apply it. Breasts swolne with too much milke, boyle hony with Vineger, and spread it on a cloth, and cast thereon powder of Cummin, and apply it. Liuer and milt chafed, mixe yellowe Rubarbe, and Barley meale and Vineger, and apply it to the right side, and bleede in the milt veine, and in sommer drinke Scabious, but in Winter sugar Roset, (See Bread. Cornes, quench vnslecked lime in strong Vineger, and when you will occupie it, pare the corne, and mixe it with and apply it. Feuer, stampe iiii. handfull of Groundswell with Bay salt and Vineger, of eache iii. spoonefull, and boyle it till it be almost drie, and binde it to the wristes an houre before the fitte. skinning water for a Fistula, steepe one pound of fine powder of Litarge of gold, in a quart of strong white Vineger iiii. dayes, and streine it well twise a day, then let it settle and vse the clearest of it, and so haue you the mother. Morphue white and blacke, stampe Mustardseede with Vineger salt, anoint. Plague, take water and Vineger of eache one sponefull, Treacle as much as a Walnut, and drinke it luke warme within Bones broken, stampe Dasy, Comfery, and Egrimonie with Vineger, and apply it. Hoarsenesse, seethe a pint of white Vineger with as much hony, vse it. Ioints out, stampe Mugwort with Vineger and swines grease, and apply it. To knowe which goute is hote and which is colde, apply a plaster of Rie meale with Vineger: if it comfort, it is the hote goute, if it grieue, it is the colde goute. Speeche lost suddenly, drinke Puliol with Vineger, and also apply it to the nostrels. houres, and it will turne white, and is good for the skurfe and falsflegme. To make olde waxe faire and newe, and good, boyle faire Vineger in an earthen pot, and put in the waxe till it melt and boyle, then let it coole, after take the waxe and clarifie it, and put therein a litle oyle Oliue, and then worke it. Wash any grieuous sore with possite Ale made with white Vineger, and apply the curd. Stomacke hote, drinke possite ale made with good red Vineger with sugar. Vineger of Roses, gather the Roses before they be full blowne in drye weather, lay them on a boarde halfe a day, and then put them into the Vineger close stopt houres, then stampe them and set them in glasses in the sunne all sommer, then streine it and vse it, if it be renewed with Roses, it is the better: it may be made with wine eyther white, or red, or claret. And so make Vineger of Eldren flowres or Violets, &c. stampe Egrimonie, and Mouseare, and frie them with Vineger and Bores grease and apply it. seethe Willow tops with a litle Rosemary in Vineger till the third part be wasted and wash therewith. Thornes in the fingers, stampe Sothernwood with Vineger and apply it. scrape a Henbane roote and slice it and seethe it in a good quantitie of wine Vineger, till it be almost wasted, with three spoonefull of and holde of the roote betweene the teeth, and holde the liquour in thy mouth iii. or iiii. times. Drunken Dropsie Drowsie Eares ache noise Eyes ache sore web Egge Face deformed pushes megrem giddy skald Haire to fall Heate outward Hoarsenesse Rose vineger Sciatica Sicknesse generall Syrupe Skin cleansing Skurfe Sleepinesse Sores Warts Waxe to renue Weakenes Wilde fire Wounds swolne Veruine. VEruine, the roote or leaues, or both together sodden in water, are good for sores and vlcers of the mouth and iawes being often washt therewith. It helpeth the toothache, and fastneth and strengtheneth them and the gums. And being drunke v. dayes continually, it cureth the gripings of the belly. Veruine mixt with oyle of Roses and vineger, or boyled in oyle and layde to the forehead, cureth the and so doth a garland of it worne round about the head. The leaues stampt with swines grease or oyle of Roses applied to the matrix, doeth mitigate the paine thereof. The same stampt with vineger, helpeth Saint Antonies fire, and olde rotten sores, and stampt with hony it cureth greene wounds, and closeth vp olde wounds. Drinke i. dram of the hearbe with three halfepenie waight of Olibanum in ix. ounces of olde wine dayes together fasting to helpe the Kings euill, and paine in the throte. The leaues laid to with Rose oyle fresh swines grease, taketh away the paine of the mother. Appetite to cause, eate it or apply it to the stomacke, it also healeth gatherings and apostumes. Deliuerance to cause, drinke it with wine, or the iuice thereof with water. Kernels, seethe it with hony in water and drinke it, and apply the rest. Lust to voide, beare it about thee, or vse it in thy drinke, and it is best that thou cary Veruine about thee next thy body, and so thou shalt be effeminate, and whosoeuer thou touthest often therewith, shalbe vnapt to ye acte of venery. Head megrem, seethe Betony, Veruine, Horehound, and Hysope in white wine, and wash therewith, and apply the rest as hote as may be suffered. Mischiefe in childe bearing, stampe good store of Nep with a litle Veruine, an streine it with stale Ale or white wine, and drinke it hote first last till you be whole. Squincie, stamp Veruine and apply it hote. weare a garland of Veruine about thy head night and day, or seethe two handful chopped smal in a quart of Wine with a little Sacke, and apply it warme. Mad, seethe Camamile flowres and Veruine of eache one handfull in a quart of water or lee, and wash thy head therewith. Eyes spottes, tye the whole hearbe, and roote about thy necke. Feuer colde, seethe three rootes and three leaues of Veruine, and drinke it before the colde fit. Stampe it with wine and drinke it, and also apply it against all stinging venome and poyson. Stampe three rootes and drinke it for the feuer tertian, and foure for the feuer quarten. Stone, drinke it with Saxifrage and Betony, of eache like much with wine. Beare it about thee to haue loue of great men, and to haue thy request if it be good and right. Gather it in the first day of the newe moone before sunne rising, and beare it about thee, and thou shalt haue no lust to women, or drinke the iuice to auoide lust for vii. yeeres. Veine broken, drinke ye iuice of Veruine, Betony, and Fiueleafe, boyled with as much Goates milke warme vii. dayes in the increase, and seuen dayes in the wane of the moone. Falling euill, gather it while {Sun} is in drinke it with white wine and powder of Peony seedes. Bitings venemous, beare it about thee, and no serpent will hurt thee. Or seethe ii. or iii. handfull and wash therewith, and apply the hearbe with hony to heale it. Hoarsenesse, seethe it with Licoras in water and streine it, and vse no other drinke till you be well. Eyes watring, stampe it with the white of an Eg, and apply it at night on the eyes. Eyes bleared, stampe it with wine and salt, and apply it night and day. Nose bleeding, be not straite girded, and holde thy handes full of Veruine, and looke vp to the Sunne. Squincie, stampe it and apply it hote. Appetite to cause, eate Veruine. Deliuerance to cause, stampe it and drinke it with water. Feuer tertian, stampe iii. leaues and iii. rootes, and dissolue them in water, and drinke it before the fit. Feuer quarten, stampe iiii. leaues iiii. rootes, and seeth them in wine, and drinke it before the fit. Deliuerance to cause, stampe it and streine it with wine, water or vineger, and drinke it. Seethe it with Draconitum in water, and let it stand till it be cleare, and anoint any edge toole therewith to make it hard and sharpe. Fundament falling, seethe it in wine, and mixe it with a litle lee and wash it therewith warme. Eies blooddyshot, stampe the leaues with a litle salt, apply it in the nights, and be whole. Matrix sores, wash with the water distilled in the end of Iune. It helpeth also the griefes and dulnesse of the eyes being often dropt in. Deliuerance to cause with speede, drinke it with colde water. Eyes swolne, dimme, and bloody, stampe it with the white of an egge and apply it, or the iuice of it. Hold it priuily in thy right hand, and aske the sicke howe he doth, but let him not see it, take him by the right hand, and as his answere is, so shall he doe, whether it be to liue or die. Milke to cause, drinke it with water, or rather with wine. Mouth stinke, holde the iuice close long in thy mouth. Stone, stampe Veruine, Betony, and Saxifrage, of eache like much, and drinke it with wine. Biting of a mad dog, stampe it with as much Planten, and streine it with red wine or stale ale, and drinke it with Treacle, and apply one of the same herbes, stampt with salt to drawe out the venome. VIolets: gather them in March, and drie them in a shadowy place in the ayre. Stomacke windy, drinke the flowres. Flowers stopt, drinke two drams of the seedes with wine. Milt swolne and the hote goute, seethe the roote in wine and apply it. Dead childe to expell, and to cleanse the matrix, and voide the swelling of it, boyle white Violets and apply them. Matrix to clense and to prouoke the termes, foment with the decoction of it. hote and to cause sleepe, apply Violets to ye forehead. Syrupe of Violets helpeth the causeth sleepe, softneth the breast and throte, and helpeth the falling of the Pallat and the Squincie. Milt swolne and for the goute, seethe the roote in Vineger, and drinke it and apply the roote. Cough in children, boyle the hearbe and roote and apply it. anoint with the oyle. Belly wormes, mixe the oyle with Wormeseede, and anoint. The Syrupe helpeth the burning Feuer, looseth the belly, and qualifieth the hote liuer. The purple Violet drunke in water looseth the belly, quencheth choller and thirst, helpeth inflammations, and putteth away the Iaundies, and so doeth the Conserue of Violets. Cut off the greene part of the flowers, and pun them small, and put thereto twise so much Sugar, but to all other flowres thrise so much Sugar, and keepe it in a gally pot, it will last one yeere, and is very good for a hote stomacke and liuer, it cooleth the head, procureth sleepe, and tempereth the heart, and all other partes of the body: the leaues in brothes are good for the same purposes. The decoction of Violets is good against all hote Feuers, and all inward inflammations, and driueth out by siege hote chollerike humors, and so doeth the syrupe, and conserue, and iuice. The syrupe is good against the inflammation of the lungs and breast, the plurisie and cough, and also against Feuers, especially in children: it cureth all inflammations and roughnesse of the throte being holden in the mouth, and so doeth the sugar of Violets, or the conserue, or iuice. Head vlcers and sores, stampe the leaues with hony and anoint therewith. Frensie and watching, make a suppository of oyle of Violets and Opium, and vse it. Stampe Violets alone or with oyle, and apply it to the extreame ache of the head and to abate the heate, to prouoke sleepe: for melancholly, to moysten the braine. Stame Violets with Barley meale, and apply it to hote apostumes and carbuncles, inflammations of the eyes, hote vlcers and inflammations that come with the falling downe of the fundament. Drinke the seedes with wine or water against the stingings of Serpents or Scorpions. The yellowe which is in the middest of the flowers boyled in water and gargled, is good for the Squincie and swelling in the throte, and is good to bee drunke of children for the falling sicknesse. The hearbe or plant is very good against all hote Feuers, the inflammation of the liuer, and to loosen the belly. Take two or three sponefull of the Syrupe to take away sharpe Feuers, to soften impostumes, and to strengthen the heart for the plurisie all hote griefes. The syrupe taken with spring water, is good to quench thirst. The oyle, water, and vineger of Violets applied, is good for the head ache and inflammation of the liuer. Violet water and Sallet oyle of eache one ounce drunke, cleanseth rotten matter in the lungs and stomacke, and helpeth cough and paine of the lungs. The broth of Violets is giuen from iiii. ounces to viii. ounces. The syrupe from ii. ounces to iiii. ounces, the conserue from one ounce and a halfe to iii. ounces to purge the body. Drinke one dram of the powder of Violets with the broth of a Capon, or of peason before meate to purge the belly. Seethe Garden Violets, and stampe them and apply them to the bottome of the belly, against the stopping of the vrine in a feuer. For hote aches of the head or else where, apply Violets. Eies blasted, stampe the rootes with Myrrhe and Saffron, and apply it at night. Head wounded, stampe the leaues with vineger and hony, and apply it. Sleepe to cause in sicknesse, seethe it well in water, and soke well thy feete therein to the ancles when thou goest to bed, and binde the herbe to thy temples. Eyes sore, ache, and swelling, stampe Violets with Myrrhe and Saffron, and apply it. Sleepe to cause when choller is the cause, seethe the leaues in water, and wash thy head therewith. Cough of hote cause and for thirst, and roughnes of the throte, drinke the syrupe with a litle water blood warme. Head pushes, stampe the leaues with hony and apply them. Eares running, put in the iuice with clarified hony. seethe Violets in wine, and hold them in thy mouth. Throte griefs rough swollen Tongue blisters Venom Vrine stopt Vuula fallen Windinesse Wounds Virga aurea. VIrga aurea: It healeth wounds, and hath the vertues of Sarasins consound: boyle it in wine, and drinke it against the stone in the reines, and to prouoke vrine, and so doth the water of it: drinke one spoonefull of the powder with a rere egge foure houres before meate, to prouoke vrin within halfe an houre, and so taken, it expelleth the stone in ten or twelue dayes without paine, (See Solidago. WAl barley, Waybent, or red Darnell, drinke it with red wine, to stoppe the flowers and fluxes. Binde the herbe to the body in Crimson lether, to stop bleeding. WAlnuts new green, are better to be eaten then dry nuts, yet they be hard of digestion, nourish very little. The drie nuts nourish lesse, and yet are of harder digestion, they cause headach, hurt the stomacke, cause cough shortnesse of breath. dried nut or two taken fasting with a fig a little Rue, withstandeth poison. And mixt with figs Rue, they cure old vlcers of the Paps other cold apostumes. Apply dry nuts with salt, hony onyons, to the biting of a mad dog. Stampe olde oyly nuts, or the oyle of them, and apply it to blew marks bruises, and skurfs skales. The decoction of the greene husks with hony, is good to gargle against al tumors vlcers of the mouth throte. The leaues be almost of the same vertue, Poyson, See Figs. Mad dogs biting, chew a kernell fasting, apply it. Some gather the greene husks about midsummer, dry them into powder, vse them in their meats in stead of Pepper: it is much better to put dried sage thereto. The tender leaues that are reddish, dried, are good for the same purpose. The yong nuts are gathered about midsummer, condyted with suger or hony into a sucket, for many purposes. Walnuts mixt with a little hony Rue, are good for the inflammation of the Paps, Apostumes and loose ioynts: and with hony, an onyon salt, it is good for the biting of a dog, of a man, or of an oxe, and for blackenesse comming of a bruise. The water distilled out of Walnuts about midsummer, is good for the inflammation of the Paps loose ioynts. Walnuts burned with their shels, and mixt with oyle or wine, and applyed to the nauell, is good for the torments of the belly. The shels burnt mixt with oyle wine, nourisheth restoreth haire that is fallen. The kernels burnt mixt with wine, healeth carbuncles, and so doth the oyle pressed out of the nuts. The oyle with hony, or the greene nut rindes, wil kill the kanker, the place being anoynted, also bring haire, withstand baldnesse. They are fit to be taken fasting, of them that would vomite. If they be eaten in great plenty, they kil brode wormes. With Rue and oyle, they are good to be said to the squincie. taken off, they are good for the stomacke, do somewhat loosen the belly. The water of greene nuts distilled about midsummer two or three ounces drunk, cooleth resisteth poyson the plague. And ye water of ye vtter husks, distilled in September drunk, is a sure experiment against the plague. Walnut put into a Chicken, maketh it to roste the sooner. Walnut leaues with bores sewet, restoreth haire, and so doe the ashes thereof. Steepe the leaues in cold water, at night spring off the water and apply them one after another as they dry, to running eyes. Make powder of they flowers when they bloome, take two drams of it with an egge rosted till it be hard, with oyle three mornings fasting, (See Filbeard, Hasell. Stampe greene huskes, and anoynt dogs therewith, no fleaes shall anoy them, his eares especially being anoynted. Haire falling, chewe the meate of them well in your mouth, and apply it presently to the place. Poysoned, pare away the vttermost of the barke, and steepe powder of the rest all night in water, streine it and drinke it fasting, to cast vp the venom. Haires to be yelow and shining, seeth well the huskes of the nuts, and the barke of the tree in water, and make Lee therewith, or stampe them with ashes, and make Lee therewith, and wash the haires. Stampe as much barke of a Wall nut tree as thy finger, with womans milke, and anoynt the headach therewith, and put thereof into thy eare. Feuer colde and shaking, take the rinde of the roote, scrape off the vpper part, and make powder of the middle part, and grinde it with vineger, and streine it two or three times, till it be somewhat thinne and cleere, and drinke thereof a good quantitie, to auoyd the sickenesse, and to purge thee cleane. Bruises Carbuncle Eyes running Feuer colde Fleaes Headach Haire falling Skales Skurfe Spots Squincy Sucket Throte sores Vomit to cause VVAter cresses are good in sallads, either by themselues or with other herbes, it prouoketh vrine, and expelleth grauell and stone, and is good for the strangury, and all stoppings of the kidneys and bladder. The lesser Water cresse taketh away the spots and freckles of the face, and all such blemishes, being applyed morne euen. The wilde Passerage or Cuckow flowre boyled in Lee, driueth away Lice of the head, being washt with it. Kine that feede where plenty of Cuckow flowers are, giue very good milke. Cough, seeth the iuice of Water cresse, with as much water, and good store of Hony and suger candy, and vse it: prooued. The iuice is very good for the dropsie, and so is the water distilled with Sage and Centorie, of ech like much, and drunke first and last. Eate euery day three crops of Water cresse, to take away all the swelling of the dropsie, but drinke not after it. Impostumes, stampe Water cresses, and apply them hote. Strangury, drinke the iuice with wine, or seeth the rootes of Parsly, Fenell, and Smallach, with Water cresses in white wine, and drinke the broth, and apply the rest. Vrine stopt, drinke wine of the decoction of Water cresse. Headach of a murre or reume, drawe in the powder of Water cresses dried in an ouen into the Nose. Seeth a quart or a pottell of Water cresses chopped small, with as much branne in a bag, in a kettle of water, and anoynt the Nauell and loynes with butter, and apply the bag round about thee hote as may bee suffered, at morne, noone and euen, and lye on thy backe for the most part, to mollifie the body, to auoyde paine, and to cause vrine. Vrine to cause, seethe Water cresses in a newe pot with wine, and sit ouer it. apply them to thy wombe: but let a woman vse the suffumigation thereof. Wormes of all sorts, boyle the iuice with swines grease, or May butter, and anoynt, or frye them, and apply them, (See Otes. Plurisie, spread hony on a cloth, and cast thereon powder of the seedes of Water cresse, and so apply it. Legs and feete swollen, chop small, and seethe them in an earthen pot with dregges of white wine, wheate branne, and weathers tallowe, of ech like much, and apply it hote foure and twentie houres, and then renewe it. Swellings, seethe Water cresses in white wine, and bathe well the place therewith, and keepe it to foure and twentie houres, and hote, and doe so two or three dayes, then cut large Figs the broadest way, and steepe them in womans milke one day, and binde them to with a cloth three or foure dayes without remoouing. Dropsie, make potage with Water cresse, Borage and red Mints, with a red Cocke or Capon, or with Porke vse them, (See Nettles, Polypody. Boyle Water cresse in water, till they be tender, make them in balles, and drie them, apply one of them to the Emerods, as hote as may be suffered nine dayes, if neede be. Vrine stopt, seeth it and apply it, and sit in the decoction of it. Emerods, streine the iuice into hote water, and of the herbe and iuice, make a plaster, and apply it. Skall to heale, seethe the iuice with Bores grease and brimstone, and anoynt therewith. Seeth Water cresses with water, or with flesh, and sup the broth, to cleanse the inward members, and for the fluxe, and the strangury. Dropsie, eate Water cresses, Mints and Parsly dayly, Bruise, (See Dockes. Face deformed Feete swollen Fluxe Grauell Head ach skall Hoarsenesse Impostume Kidneys stopt Legs swolne Lice Milke to cause Plurisie Reume Senowes drawen Skall Skin to cleanse Strangury VVAter Betony, or Browne wurt: The leaues, stalke, seed, roote or iuice, doth waste and dissolue all swellings and hardnesse, being stampt with vineger, and applyed at morne, noone and euen. Stampe the leaues and apply them to olde rotten corrupt spreading and fretting sores and pockes, to heale them: and with salt to kankers. Emerods, eate the roote to drie them vp, or stampe it and apply it outwardly. Stampe the whole herbe, and drinke the iuice of it against spitting of blood, the fluxe and excesse of flowers and bleeding at the nose. Bruise the leaues or seede cases, and apply them on fresh wounds to heale and skin them, and to rotten sores, figs of the fundament, swellings and leprie: the iuice doth the like. Drinke the seedes with myrre and Pepper with wine, to helpe the sciatica excellently well. Take the iuice of the whole herbe and roote in May: keepe it in a close glasse: when neede is, take thereof with waxe and oyle, of ech like much, boyle it till it bee an oyntment, and vse it for all skabs and leprie. The distilled water, taketh away all pimples and rednesse of the face. The water or iuice with brimstone and taketh away the ach of the eyes. The seede mixt with hony and applyed to the forehead, stoppeth the running of the eyes. The herbe alone sodden in well water, quencheth all vnkinde heates without danger, and exceedeth all others for the marmall, leprie, skab, itch, &c. wheales, pushes, &c. Eyes dull, put in the iuice of it and Botch in the throte or else where, drinke the iuice, to driue it out. Apostume Bitings venemous Bleeding Botch Eyes ach dull running Emerods Fig in ano Flowers to stop Fluxe Fundament fig Hardnesse Itch Kanker Leprie VVAter Pepper or Culerage: The leaues and seede doe waste swellings and hardnesse, and dissolueth congealed blood of bruises. The powder of the dried leaues may bee vsed for Pepper in meates, like as our Dittany and Passerage. VVAter Planten: Dropsie, apply good store of the leaues to the shankes, to drawe out the water from the belly: it hath the nature of Planten. VVHeate rawe chewed, is good to be laid to the byting of a mad dog: whole Wheat is good for the paine of the gout, The meale with the iuice of Henbane, applyed to the senowes, is good against the falling of reumes and subtill humors into them. The same with oximel cleanseth away all lentilles spots from the face. The meale of March or summer Wheate applyed with vineger, helpeth venemous bitings. The same boyled like to paste or pap licked, is good against spitting of blood. And boiled with Hony, butter and Mints, it is good against the cough roughnesse of the throte. And boyled with Hony water, or with oyle water, it dissolueth all tumors swellings. The branne boyled in vineger, is good against the skuruy, itch, and spreading skab, dissolueth the beginnings of all hote swellings. The branne boyled in the decoction of Rue, doth slake swage the hard swellings of womens breasts. The leauen of Wheate meale, draweth out shiuers, splents thornes, especially in the soles of the feete, and doth ripen, open breake al swellings impostumes, being applied with salt. Wheat bread boyled in Honied water, doth swage appease all hote swellings, especially if good iuices of herbs be put thereto fit for the same purpose. Wheat bread newe baked, soked in brine or pickle, doth cure all old white skurfe, and the foule creeping spreading skab. The amyll starch of Wheat, is good against the falling of Reumes humors into the eyes being applyed: and it cureth filleth with flesh, wounds hollow vlcers. And mixt with milke, it swageth ye roughnesse or sorenesse of the throte and breast, and causeth easie spitting. Mixe Wheat meale, incense and doues dung, with the white of an egge, and apply it to the forehead, to auoyd all headach. Take as much Wheate flower as will lie on three french crownes, mixe it with as much well or spring water, as will make it of the thickenesse of milke, and giue it to a childe to kill wormes. Mixe Wheat branne with Pigeons dung, and the white of an egge, and apply it to the contrary side of the griefe to take away all giddinesse and dassing of the head. Wheat meale with the iuice of Henbane taketh away the inflammation of the guts. Wheat bread that is leauened, is better then the meale in Plasters for the stomacke. The iuices of Rue, Mints, Sage and wormewood mixt with Wheat meale or Wheat and vineger, is good in plasters plaster of the branne with vineger, and the iuice of sower Pomegranates applied warme to the belly, doth stop the flixe swelling of the guts. Bread that hath much Wheat branne in it, maketh the eater thereof leane. The oyle pressed out of Wheat betwixt hote irons, healeth vlcers wounds, and all chaps of the hands, lips and feete. Plasters of Wheat meale leauen, and salt, vineger, butter and oyle of Roses, are good against all bruises, to heale them, if they be curable, the same being applyed the patient drinking Vnguentum Potabile, and rolled in a long towell. Wheate, or meale thereof vsed in brothes, is both comfortable and restoratiue. Wheat flower well sodden in water or milke with butter, is good against the cough, hoarsenesse, and spitting of blood, and all griefes of the breast. The same sodden with Honied water, driueth away all inflammations. The branne sodden in water or Hony, healeth the exulcerations of the throte, and being gargarised, it helpeth the swelling and inflammation of the iawes. Seeth the branne in vineger, and foment the members and senowes that are loose. The same sodden in vineger with Rue, is good for creeping sores, pockes, wheales, inflammations swellings, especially of the Paps and priuities: it helpeth also the stingings of vipers. The leauen of Wheat meale, is good to draw, to ripen heate the knobs and Agnailes of the feete: and with salt, it helpeth fellons, vncomes and such like. Apostumes, frye Wheat branne with dregs of wine and sheepes sewet, and apply it. Bloody fluxe, kneade a cake of VVheat meale with the iuice of Motherwurt, and bake it in the fire, and eate it hote. Botches, seeth VVheat meale, with oyle in water, and apply it. Cods swollen, seeth the branne with Parietarie in sweete wine, and apply it. Kanker, mixe Hony with VVheat meale and Ribwurt, and apply it. Wounds to heale, apply white bread crums stamped with water and the white of an egge, and apply it. Swelling of wounds, apply the pith of bread of VVheate with the iuice of Smallach. Bruises, gouts, wounds and such like, apply a plaster of VVheat branne, sheepes tallowe and white wine. Pushes to auoyd, stampe VVheat with wine, and apply it. Tenasmus, seeth a bag of VVheat branne in water, if the disease be hote, or else in wine, if the disease be colde, and sit vpon it. Swelling of blood letting, stampe white bread crums with wine, and apply it. Stones apostumed of colde cause, seeth the branne, and apply it. Squincy, apply a plaster of white bread, wine and Hony, to ripen and breake it, and vse butter. For the ach and Apoplexia of the liuer and milt, boyle Wheat meale, and the branne thereof, with the iuice of woormewood, till it be thicke, and apply it. For inflation of the stomacke and belly, stampe Planten with Wheat bread, and apply it. Head skalfering, cast seething hote water into Wheate branne, and let it stand foure and twentie houres, then streine it, and put a little vineger to it, and strake the head therewith, as often as neede is. Spitting blood, seeth Wheat in butter and water, and eate it three dayes as potage, it helpeth also the cough of the lungs. Nailes to growe soone, apply Wheat flower with Hony. Breasts hard, (See Rue. Prickes to drawe out, seethe Wheate flower and apply it, it helpeth the ach, voydeth the venome, and healeth it againe, and is good to heale a byle, vncome or fellon, or whiteflaw. Freckles, wash with the decoction of Wheate branne, or crummes of bread and water. Fluxe, bake cakes of Wheat flower and the iuice of Yarow, and eate them hote. Bloody fluxe, seeth Wheat till it be broken, then streine out the iuice, and seeth it in a posnet and eate it, or knead cakes of Wheat flower and the iuice of white Tansie and yolkes of egges, and bake them and eate them, and drinke a little after it. Belly grinding, bake Wheate cakes sowred, and vse them as Ote cakes, (See Otes. Gouts generall, make powder of dried salt, put thereto as much Hony, and as much Wheat meale, as it commeth from the mill, boyle it till it bee thicke, and apply it. Fellon, boyle good ale dregs with Wheat meale, and apply it. Apostume flegmatike, boyle oyle Oliue, Hony, Butter and Wheate meale, and anoynt therewith, (See Figs, Apostume to drawe, apply Wheate flower with common oyle. Ranker, (See Radish, Elecampana. Skabs, boyle Wheat leauen in good ale dregs, and apply it. Ach by breaking of any thing, apply Wheate meale with wine. Fluxe, boyle clarified Hony and white bread crummes with red wine, and drinke thereof two or three times. Flowers to stoppe, seeth Wheate flower in milke and Hony, and apply it to the nauell hote. Senowes drawen, (See Camomile. Sores, boyle Wheat flower with Hony, and vse Plasters thereof. Stomacke heate, stampe smallach with the finest Wheat bread, and apply it to the chest stomacke three dayes together, fresh euery day. To make fine Wheat cakes, Take faire Wheat flowre a pottle, Rose water halfe a pinte, Cinamome halfe a sticke, powder of Aniseeds two spoones full, suger i. pound, whites of egs iiii. salt a quantitie, butter ii. or iii. peniworth, but no barme: make cakes thereof, &c. Eyes humors and teares, streine Wheat flower with water, and put it into the eyes, (See Rue. Gout, seeth salt sifted Wheat branne, Hony and red wine, till it be thicke, and apply it. Ach or bruise, seeth Wheate bread crummes in water till it be thicke, and stirre it well and apply it, to restore the colour againe, (See Fenigreke, Lilly, Planten, Chickeweede, Leekes. Falling euill, kneade cakes of Wheate meale, with the deawe on midsummer morning, and bake it and eate it. For womens breasts that be hard, and for all venemous bitings, seeth the branne with the iuice of Rue, and apply it. For itch and wormes in any place, steepe VVheate in wine, with powder of Olibanum, and apply it. Arme swollen by blood letting, apply the meale with hony and milke. Headach continuall, make a cake of the flower and vineger, and apply it, (See Spurge, Tythimall. Pricke in the senowes with needle or such like, seeth the flower in white wine, till it be thicke, and apply it hote, (See Branne, See Housleeke. Pyles, seeth VVheat branne in Lees of white or claret wine, and apply it as often as neede is, hote. Sores, (See Dasie. Blood to stop, apply VVheat flower with Raddle and whites of egges. Breasts curded milke, make pellets with VVheat flower, water and swines blood, and apply it to bring out all filth. Laske to stop, bake cakes of VVheate flower and yolkes of egs on a tylestone, and eate them morne and euen. Byle to breake, apply wheate flower with Hony, the yolke of an egge, and a little salt. Amyl, amidum, or starch: Tongue blisters or bladders, mixe starch with Rose water, and apply it. It is good in eye medicines, for wounds, roughnesse, and reumes of the eyes, and is an excellent helpe for spitting of blood being drunke: and with milke it stoppeth fluxes, it is good for apostumes of the spirituall members and the cough, sodden in Barley water, and Almond milke, with some Penides. Taken with milke, it helpeth the roughnesse of the throte. It helpeth all fluxes, pushes and vlcers of the eares, (See Leauen, Branne, &c. Aches Agneiles Apostume. Kernels Leane to be Liuer ache stopt Lungs (See breast.) Mad dogge Masels Milt ache stopt Nailes to growe Piles Pockes VVHite Saxifrage, with the graines and berries of the same boyled in Wine, and drunke, prouoketh vrine, cleanseth the kidneys and bladder, breaketh and expelleth the stone, and is excellent against the Strangurie, and all the griefes of the reynes. The powder of the rootes in an Electuarie with honie, hath the same vertues, and so hath the water distilled in May. VVIntercresse or Herba S. Barbarae, is good in sallads, and is vsed in Winter for sallads, and doeth aswell as Cresses or Rocket. It cleanseth corrupt wounds or vlcers, and consumeth dead flesh that groweth too fast, being applied, and the iuice dropt in. The seed prouoketh vrin, and driueth forth grauell, cureth the Strangury. Plucke vp haires, and anoynt with the iuice, and it will grow no more. VVOad: the garden or sowen woad, is good to be layd vpon the woundes of mighty strong people that vse dayly labour, and to stanch bleeding, and to fretting sores and rotten vlcers, and to all colde apostumes, to dissolue them. The leaues applied as a plaister, stoppeth all swellings, ioyne greene woundes, stoppe bloud, healeth S. Anthonies fire and all hote apostumes, consuming, rotten, and spreading sores. The Wilde woad both drunke and applied, helpeth the milt. VVOodlillie, or Lillie conuaile, the flowers drunke in new wine, doe strengthen the heart, braine, liuer, and all the spirituall parts, panting of the heart, giddines of the head, the falling sicknesse, the Apoplexia, and frensie, paine and trembling of the heart, and stoppeth the passages of the leaprie, that it spread no further. And beeing anoynted, it auoydeth the skabbe and ringworme, and that the sooner, if they bee washed first, sundrie times with the water. The water also asswageth the swellings of the stingings of Bees and waspes. And being distilled in wine, the water helpeth the inflammation, and mist of the eyes, and it is thus made: take the flowers and steepe them in newe wine thirtie daies, then take them quite out of the Wine, and distill the wine fiue times ouer in a Limbecke, or bodie of glasse. This wine is more precious then golde, for if anie drinke thereof with sixe graynes of Pepper, and a little Lauender water, they shall not neede to feare the Apoplexia that moneth. The Wine may also bee made thus: Fill a gallon glasse with good olde Wine, and one pounde of the flowers, and set it to sun fourtie dayes, then distill it in a Limbecke of glasse twise ouer, and put thereto a little Lauender water and Pepper, or else the flowers of Lauender and of Rosemarie, and other good spices, and distill it ouer againe, and keepe it close stopped in a narrowe mouthed glasse, a spoonefull of it taken at the poynt of death, doeth reuiue and prolong life: it comforteth the brayne, ceasseth the Chollicke, and helpeth the Impostume in the hinder patte of the brayne, and helpeth the Apoplexia, it giueth good memorie and readie witte, by anoynting the head before and behinde with it. The water of the flowers sixe ounces drunke, helpeth them that are poysoned, and helpeth the byting of a madde dogge, the birth of children, it comforteth the brayne, heart, and senses. And beeing drunke fourtie dayes, it putteth away the falling sickenesse. The same water drunke, helpeth the Strangurie, the pricking about the heart, and inflammation of the liuer, and staieth the excessiue menstrues. Drinke one spoonefull of the water of the flowers distilled in good strong Wine, to restore speeche in the Apoplexia, and for the Palsie, and the goute, and to comfort the heart, to strengthen the memory and restore it. Drop it into the eyes against their inflammation and watering. Leapry Liuer hote weake Madde dogge Memorie Palsie Poyson Restoratiue VVOodbine, the fruite drunke wine fourtie daies together, doeth heale the stopping and hardnesse of the milt, and maketh it lesse, and purgeth by vrine the corrupt humours so strongly, that after the dayly vse thereof eight or tenne daies together, it will cause the vrine to bee red and bloudy, and is good for shortnesse of breath, or any dangerous cough, it helpeth women in trauell, and drieth vp the naturall seede of man. And beeing sodden in oyle, and stamped, and the ridge bone anoynted therewith before the fitte, preuenteth the shaking of Agues. The same healeth wounds and corrupt vlcers, and taketh away hurtes and spottes of the bodie and face. The iuice of the leaues and fruite are euill for women with childe. For the breaking out of the head, with ringwormes, &c. washe it with strong vineger, and cast thereon ashes of the rinde of Woodbine. For Impostumes, and webbes of the eyes, mixe the iuice of Honisuckle, with pure honie, and put it into the eye. Take Woodbine leaues one handfull, white Wine a pinte, powder of Ginger foure ounces, seethe them till it bee somewhat thicke, and anoynt thy face therewith fiue or sixe times to auoyde the pimples, and to make it faire. Stampe the leaues, and apply them to wartes sixe times, to destroy them. Gather the seede when it is ripe, and drie it in the shadowe, and drinke one dramme in wine fourtie dayes to melt away the milt, to voyde wearinesse, for shortnesse of winde, for the hickit, and to expell vrine: the leaues haue the same vertues. leaues drunke seuen and thirtie dayes together, so dryeth vp the naturall seede of man, that hee shall gette no moe children. The oyle thereof is very good for all colde griefes and numbednesse. The syrop is good for the lunges and the sores of the mouth and throate. The berries are good against pissing of blood, and to hasten deliuerance, but the water is better and more pleasant, which also helpeth the hote griefes of the eyes, and of the liuer. Applie a Woodbine leafe to chappes, till they bee whole. Eyes webbe, seethe ribwoort, Woodbine, and Planten, with Maye butter, and streine it and vse it. Stomacke sore, stampe fifteene leaues, and streine them with stale ale, and drinke it nine dayes first and last. Tongue palsie, stampe the leaues and holde them vnder thy tongue. Woodbine healeth cankred sores, wounds, bladders, and toothach, sores in the toes, and is good against swelling in the bodie, comming of venome or poyson. Skin to growe where it is rawe, stampe the leaues, and seethe them in a quart of good ale, and streine it, and put thereto honie and allome, and seethe it to one halfe, then dippe graye paper therein, and applie it. Mouth kanker, mixe the iuice of Woodbine and Fiueleafe with honie and allome, and applie it. Sores, (See Sage. Ringworme, washe it with strong vineger, and cast on ashes of the rinde, it healeth all skabs of the head, or els where. Face redde, take white Wine one pinte, Woodbine water, two or three ounces, a handfull of the leaues, foure ounces of ginger in powder, seeth them till it be somewhat thicke, and annoint the rednesse pimples fiue or sixe times. Face spots, red pimples and wheales, distill the flowers and wash often with the water, and also drinke foure ounces morning and euening. Fluxe to stop, seeth it in water till it be soft, and wash thy body and feete therewith. Kanker, mixe burnt alom with the iuice of Woodbine, vineger hony, and annoint. salue for a green wound, wash one ounce of turpentine in Woodbine water, and mixe it with the yolke of two new layd egges, and put thereto two blades of saffron, and mixe them well and keepe it in a boxe, it wil last good one yeere. Being put into wine, it reioyceth the heart, and comforteth the diseased liuer, and so it doeth being sodden in wine. Seeth it in olde ale and drinke it against pissing of blood. Stampe it and drinke it with wine to heale sores of the mouth. Stampe the seede and drinke it with strong vineger to helpe the bloodie fluxe. Bloody flux Heart griefe Liuer griefe Mirth Mouth sores Pissing blood Wounds VVolfthistle. VVOlfthistle, the iuice drunke with wine is good for the liuer. VVArdens: to inlarge breath and open the pipes, shread iiii. pound of wardens, the rootes of Elecampane and radish of eche ii. pound, put them into a pot with as much hony as will couer them, couer it with paste and bake it with a batche of bread, and take thereof one spoonefull morne and euen. VVOrmewood, drinke the iuyce ten dayes, drinke halfe an ounce at once with sugar to helpe the Iaundies, the water betweene the skinne and the flesh, to driue out many noysome humours of the liuer and milt. It comforteth the stomacke and liuer, and mooueth appetite to meate, helpeth the diseases comming of obstructions, as the dropsie and such like diseases. And it killeth wormes in the belly, and expelleth them mightily, in this sort: take Wormewood foure ounces, Euphorbium halfe an ounce, harts horne burnt one ounce, a hares gall one ounce, and some hony, worke them together and apply it to the belly. Bruise it and boyle it in water, and dip a linnen clothe therein, and washe the head therewith gently for the Boile it in wine drink foure ounces at once, to preserue the blood from putrifying in the bodie. Boyle Wormwood in vineger, and wash the mouth therewith to amend the euill sauour thereof. Drinke the decoction of it to put away the swelling of the milte. Boyle it in oyle oliue, and anoynt therewith about the breast, to helpe the weaknesse of the stomacke, and malice of the liuer. Seeth it in lee with sothernwood, to helpe the shedding of the haire. Stampe it with as much rue, and a litle pepper, and boile them in wine, and drinke it to comfort and purge the stomack. Seethe the leaues or flowres in meate or drink: they are good for the stomacke, helpe digestion, and cease ache, expell poyson, choller, and the termes, being sodden in wine drunk. Seeth it in wine, and drinke it with Cummin, to warme the stomacke, and to helpe the torment and ache thereof, to expell wormes, to helpe the Iaundies, to expell the termes, and all manner of poyson or venome. And sodden with vineger, it helpeth the strangling of mushromes. The flowers dried and stamped with salt and giuen to cattell to eate, helpeth their inward griefes, and driueth away all noisome things within them. The iuice or water applied to the temples, taketh away the headach that commeth of cold cause, and dropt into the eares or eyes, it taketh away their paine, and cleanseth them. The herbe stampt with and honie, is good for the squincie. The vapour thereof is good for the ache of the eares, beeing receiued through a tunnill. Seethe it in wine, and apply it to the stomacke to take away the loathing belch and ach thereof. Steepe a branch or two in halfe a pint of good white wine in a close vessell all night, and drink it in the morning warme with sugar to haue a good colour, and to be free from wormes. Make Wormwood wine thus: take aqua vitae and malmesey, of eche like much, put it in a glasse or bottell with a fewe leaues of dried Wormwood, and let it stand certaine dayes, and streine out a litle spoonful, and drinke it with a draught of ale or wine: it may bee long preserued. Wormewood vsed of them that bee leane and euill coloured, restoreth their liking and colour. The water thereof healeth watring sores in the corners of the eyes. With hony it is good for the brusings and darknesse of the eyes, and for the mattering of the eares. The broth with Malmesey is good to anoint the aking eyes withall. The iuice killeth itche, and put to inke, mice will not eate the paper that is written with it. Take the broth or infusion of it from v. ounces to viii. ounces. The iuice from iii. drams to iiii. drams, the powder from ii. drams to iii. drams with wheye or with reasins the stones taken out, or with Roses, or with Fumiterie to purge the body. In steade of Wormewood wine, mixe one good spoonefull of it made with Malmesey and aqua vitae, as afore is said, with a good draught of wine and drinke it. Eies red and bloodshot, stampe it with the white of an Egge and apply it. Steepe it in the wine vineger or water that inke is made withall against eating with myce. Eares wormes, put in the iuice with the iuice of Rue, and of Southistle, and be whole. Clarifie one pound of May butter in the sunne, and stampe two pound of greene Wormewood, and set them in the sunne ix. dayes, then seeth it one houre and a halfe, and streine it and keepe it in a Gally pot, and therewith anoint the nauell at the full of the moone to kill wormes. Wormewood purgeth by siege and vrine chollerike humors from the veines of the liuer, wherefore the decoction or infusion thereof taken dayly, cureth the Iaundies. If it be taken fasting, it preserueth from drunkennesse that day. With Anniseedes it is good against windinesse and paine of the belly and stomacke, wambling and desire to vomite. Drunke with vineger, it is good against the sickenesse that comes by eating of Todestooles. With wine it resisteth all venome and poyson, chiefely of humblocke, and all venemous bitings and stingings of spiders, and other venemous beastes. Apply it with hony to the dimnesse of the eyes that are bloodshotten, or haue blacke spots in them. Boyle it in Bastard or other sweete wine, and strake therewith painefull bleared eyes. meale, and apply it to the belly, sides and flankes to helpe the dropsie, and griefes of the milt. The oyle thereof rubbed vpon any place, keepeth away fleas, flies and gnats. Seethe it in vineger and apply it to sores that breed in the eares. It helpeth a colde stomacke drunke two spoonefull tenne mornings, and is good for the dropsie. The wine thereof is good against dropsies, coldnesse of the stomacke, winde, and swelling. Seethe a handfull in a gallon of cleane water, or wine, in a vessell of siluer, glasse, or stone, with some calamus Aramaticus, squinant, cinamome, and the flowers of Cassia, and some spikenard, and dates of ech foure ounces, beaten all together, or els put them into a vessell of newe wine, with a linnen bagge, and keepe it close two moneths, and then drinke thereof for the yellow Iaundies, paine in the reines, loathsomnesse of the stomacke, stopping of the termes, swelling after meat, continuance of vomiting, cold passions of the heart, &c. Stampe one pound of the leaues finely, and put thereto foure pound of the best white sugar, till it bee well incorporated, and keepe it in a close glasse, or gallie pot, and vse it to helpe the dropsie, by taking euery day one ounce three houres before meate. The oyle thereof is good against ache, noyse, and deafenesse of the eares. Wormewood Romaine is singular against all inflammations, and heate of the stomacke, and liuer, and for that purpose is better then all other kindes of Woormewood. While it is young, it is eaten with other sallade hearbes to strengthen the stomacke, to open the liuer and milt, and so to preserue health. The Wormwood wine at the Stilliard is good for the same purposes. Eares paine, and wormes, put in the iuice of Wormewood. Hands wounded, swolne, boyle the iuice with vineger and wheate bran, apply it. Mother griefs, or suffocat. drink a dram of mithridate with an ounce and a halfe of Wormwood water Backach, stamp rue, Wormwood, sage, of ech a handfull, with barrowes greace, and fry it, and streine it, and keepe it in boxes, and vse it. Bones ach, stamp it with sage and sothernwood, of ech a handful, of rue handfull, mixe them with oile oliue and malmesey, of ech a pint, and let them stand fiue dayes in an earthen pot close stopped, then seethe it till the wine be consumed, then strein it, and keep it in boxes, and vse it. For al sudden swellings, boile Wormwood in wine, or in vineger, and apply it. Eares ach and dull, boile the seeds of stauesacre, raddish, and Wormwood, and strein it, and dip tents therein, and put them into the eare. Eyes griefes, seethe olibanum Wormwood in wine, and drink it with sugar, and a litle ale first and last. Eyes spot or web, bruise Wormwood with womans milke, and strein it, and put in one drop of the iuice. For rednes and blood in the eyes, bruise new gathered Wormwood with the white of an egg, apply it. Gout, boile VVormewood in a litle oyle, and apply it. Headach, seethe it wt veruiue betonie in water, and wash therwith, also grind the herbs wt wheat bran, apply it with a cloth to ye mould of the head thrise, as hot as may be suffred: proued. Mixe VVormwood wt ground iuie, whites of egs, hony, apply it to ye head for ye ach therof. Eies ach, swelling by a bruise, heat dried wormwood on a tile, apply it. Headach, seeth VVormwood in vineger apply it to the forehead. Iaundies, drinke the iuice of planten VVormwood, of ech like much with sugar. Impost. seethe it with cummin in wine, and apply it. Liuer ach, boile the meale bran of wheat with ye iuice of wormwood til it be thick, apply it to the liuer or splene. Matrix suffoc. apply the iuice of VVormwood, smallach and ysop, hote to the nauil with a cloth and be whole. Mouth vlcers, stampe VVormwood with hony, holde it in thy mouth, it is a singular remedy. Speech lost, stampe it with water, and put in a spoonful into his mouth. Milt griefs, seeth the rootes of yong ashe plants, with as much wormwood in a gallon of wine, to the one halfe, and drinke thereof at euen hote, and at morne colde. Stitch, stampe mallowes and VVormwood with new butter, apply it. Wormes in children, stampe Wormewood, and apply it to the nauell. Vomiting, stampe Wormewood and Rose cake of eache one handfull, and seethe them in red wine, and apply it to the stomacke, or quilt Wormewood, Mugwort, and Hyrsse, or Millit, of eache iiii. drams in a bag, and seethe them in wine and water, and presse it a litle, and apply it warme to the breast to comfort the colde stomacke, and to stay vomiting. It helpeth also women with childe, and them that haue the stone ingendred of colde cause, and for gripings. Stomacke euill after meate, seethe vineger with Wormewood, and rub thy feete therewith when thou goest to bed, and so thou mayest perhaps sweate to doe thee good. Liuer colde, vse Wormewood in thy meate to comfort and warme the stomacke and liuer, to vnstop the liuer, the yellowe Iaundies and the dropsie, or take as much as a Chestnut dayly at morne, noone, and euen. Belly griefes, if the body be mistempered and hard, and the vrine stopt, chop two handfull of Wormewood small, and put it in a bag, and seeth it in wine with as much water, and apply it to the body as hote as may be suffered halfe an houre, and heate it againe as often as neede is in the same liquour. Belly wormes, mixe two ounces of the iuice of Wormewood, with one ounce of an Oxe gall, and strake it vpon the belly. If you put thereto halfe an ounce of Aloes Epatica, and Euphorbium, it will be much the better, the gall of a Hare is better then the gall of an oxe. Feuer quarten, seeth a handfull of Fenell, with iii. or iiii. leaues of Wormewood in halfe a pint of wine, till the third part be wasted, and drinke it warme before the fit with halfe an ounce of hony of Roses, halfe a glassefull at once, and when the colde fit is past, lie downe to sweate, and sleepe if you can, if you be thirstie, drinke more of it and vse it in the mornings fasting v. dayes, or seeth one handfull of Fennell with halfe as much Wormewood in strong ale or wine to the one halfe, then streine it and put to it some hony of Roses, and drinke thereof a glassefull before the fit, and walke after it as long as you can, and then lie downe and couer you well to sweate, and eate nothing of iiii. or v. houres before the fit. Cornes in the feete, anoint them with the iuice of Houseleeke, and then apply Wormewood warmed on a tile, and sprinckled with vineger, and doe so three or foure times. Eares clensing, seethe Wormewood in vineger, the vrine of a boy vnder yeres old, and put it in with tents of linnen, and lie vp therwith. apply the iuice wt hony. Stomack windy, apply the iuice or herbe. Stomacke cold, and want of digestion, mixe the iuice with as much hony, and twise so much good wine, and boile them together, and take euery day a good spoonful morn euen. Stomack swolne, seethe iii. handful of Wormewood, and a handfull of rue in good wine, drinke it. Illiack passion, boile powder of hote seedes with Wormwood in wine, apply it. Kanker, (see Flaxe, Fundament falling, of termes in man or woman, take vp the fume of Wormewood sodden in white wine, and anoint it with black inke. Ache and swelling in the feet, legs or thighes, take the roots of Wormewood, doe off the vppermost, boile it in water well, and stamp it with horse grease, apply it in a cloute. Leapry, boile the iuice with swines grease, till the iuice be consumed, then streine it, and put thereto mortified, and vse it also for all salseflegme. Scab, (see Celondine, Dock. Worms in the hands, (see Docks. Belly swolne, seethe a handfull of Wormewood in a pint of malmesey to the one halfe, then streine it, and drinke it, and boyle fine powder of coliander, with butter, till it be an oyntment, and vse it. Heart burning, seethe it in faire water, and streine it, and drinke it daily: prooued. Head skurfe, seethe it, and washe therewith, and apply the herbe to helpe it by by, and to make the haire faire, cleane and euen. Haire falling, make lee with the ashes of Wormewood, and powder of Doues doung, and washe the head therewith. Take the rootes of yong Ashe plants, and a good quantity of Wormewood, seethe them in a pottell of Wine to the one halfe, and drinke thereof at euen hote, and at morne colde, and vse the oyntment of Ashen ashes, and doe these things nine dayes and bee whole. Stitch, (See Rue, Sage. Stomacke griefes, (See Cummin, Mints, Rosemary. Whites to stop, seeth wormwood and mallowes in sacke, and apply it plaisterwise to the belly, as hote as may be suffred. Eies bloodshot, running and rhewmatike, stampe it with the white of an egge, rosewater, and apply it when you goe to bed, be whole. Headach, stampe it and apply it to the temples, or the iuice thereof, (See Cucumber. Eies red and bloody, stampe it with the white of an egge, and apply it. To defend from the stinking vermin called pulices, anoynt with the iuice and oyle oliue. Vomiting on the sea, to preuent it, drinke the iuice of Wormewood. For old paine of the liuer, and sides, seeth it in wine, and put thereto oile of nuts, or of spikenard, and apply it or anoynt. To voyd headach, and cause sleepe, stampe it and boyle it in water, and applie it. Steepe the leaues in water ten houres, then take them out, and seethe the water to the one halfe, and take foure ounces of it, and couer thee well to sweate, to auoyde old feuers that come by fits. To heale the disposition that commeth before the dropsie, and the obstructio~ of the meseraicall veins, take the iuice of Wormwood sugar ana half a pound, spikenard a dram, cinamom drams in pouder, them wel, and take two ounces with wine or broth morn euen. Breasts sore, seethe sage, margerom and Wormewood, of ech a handful in white wine, and wash therwith, or applie powder of black beanes with honie. Head giddie, and swimming, seethe it in vineger, and stampe it and apply it. Wounds to heale, stampe it with groundswell and olde Swines grease, and applie it to woundes and rotten sores. Eyes dull, put in the iuice of Rue and Wormewood, (See Mallowes. Stomacke cold, and not digesting, take the iuice of Wormewood and honie, of eche one cuppefull, wine as much as them both, boyle them, and take one spoonefull morne and euen, (See Horehound, Elme. Nostrels stinke, Ach in the hands, wristes, feete or sinewes, seethe it in oyle oliue, or in oyle of linseede, and streine it, and anoynt therewith. Iaundies, seethe it in water, and wash therewith thrise, and drinke Iuorie with wine, (See Auens. Belly ach, Wormewood anoint with the oyle, (See Peach, or seethe it in water with galles, and bathe therein. Drinke it with spikenard against the windinesse of the stomacke and bellie, With honie it helpeth the swelling in the mouth. With the gall of a bull it cleareth the sight, and helpeth all the impediments of the eies. Clarifie a pound of May butter in the sunne, and mixe it with two pound of green Wormewood well stamped, sun it nine dayes in May, then boile it an houre and a halfe, and streine it, and keepe it in a gallie potte, and anoynt the bellie therewith to kill wormes.
